column2: The politician everyone was talking about in the German capital the morning after national elections was not Chancellor Angela Merkel.
Do dogs get mosquito bites?
A team of scientists said new mutations made it practically impossible for evolution to reverse direction.
Scientists, using images taken by a camera on a Martian orbiter, discovered signs of water ice in craters far from the planet’s poles.
The top cause in the United States for injuries requiring medical attention cuts across age groups, federal health statistics showed.
A fast-growing segment of the lending industry serves the many Indians who lack paperwork to prove their income or collateral other than gold jewelry.
Charley Casserly, who was fired in 1999 as general manager of the Redskins, is not a fan of in-season dismissals.
The head of the failed Internet division also agreed to pay $8.7 million in restitution for falsely promoting the unit and pumping up the share price.
An investigation is expected to conclude that Georgia set off the conflict, but to place blame on Russia for creating and exploiting the conditions that led to war.
Francis Lewis High is one of a number of New York City public schools teeming with students despite the system’s overall drop in enrollment.
Bombings across the country left nearly 20 people dead and wounded dozens more after a lull during the holy month of Ramadan.
Cellphones can be used on more than 15,000 flights a month, but not on American carriers.
Pope Benedict XVI said on his last day in the Czech Republic that communism failed because it rejected God.
The Internet portal’s proposed deal to buy a stake in Focus Media, a digital media company, has waited months for government approval.
Quarterback Brett Favre’s game-winning pass on Sunday might have justified the Vikings’ prolonged courtship of him in the off-season.
The de facto government blocked a protest march and shut down two broadcasters, but later reversed its emergency decree.
There is a movement in more than a dozen states to outlaw a crucial element of health care reform: the requirement that everyone be insured or pay a penalty.
In the early 1980s, the Supreme Court decided more than 150 cases a year. Now, it decides about half that many.
The president will land in Denmark on Friday to try to help Chicago in its bid to host the 2016 Olympic Games.
Stocks bounded higher on signs that companies once again had enough cash, credit and confidence to undertake big-ticket deals.
The court said Jestina Mukoko could not be tried for terrorism because she had been tortured by the state.
Business realities are changing for big technology suppliers as corporate customers depend less on products and more on services.
The changes, which include the removal of the term “Communism” from the constitution’s text, are perceived as an attempt to improve the country’s image abroad.
The sudden move to arrest Roman Polanski for possible extradition to the U.S. after 31 years as a fugitive has offended supporters of the filmmaker.
It was not the first such test conducted by Iran, but it came at a time of high tension over Tehran’s nuclear program.
Facing criticism over its response to the disaster, the government appealed for international aid.
A study that looked at the posting of unprofessional content by medical students found the practice was more common than anticipated.

SHIELDS--Bobby, standup comic, award-winning dancer, great singer, died in Atlanta September 25th after 20+ year battle with Parkinson's. Survived by son, Michael, daughter-in-law Nancy, three loving grandchildren. Predeceased by his devoted wife, Sonny and his grandchildrens' beloved Nana. See his story at www.cnn.com/ac360.

Ahmad Bradshaw gained 104 yards Sunday, and most of them were not boring. They were full of head fakes, shoulder feints and dance steps away from the grasp of tacklers. ''He got hit, spun, got himself north again, and was able to do that on a number of occasions,'' Coach Tom Coughlin said.
GROSFELD--Marilyn Joy. May 11, 1934-Sept. 29, 1998 Thank God for you, the wind beneath my wings. Luv forever, Sonny
Q.How often do you fly? A. Two to three times a month.

de LARROCHA--Alicia. The Treetops Chamber Music Society mourns the passing of its friend and Artistic Advisor, Alicia de Larrocha. We will remember her for years to come not only as the iconic artist she was, but also as a sensitive mentor, who lent her hand to our organization at its very start. Oskar Espina Ruiz Artistic and Executive Director

MALONEY--Clifton H.W. The Board of Directors and staff of Lighthouse International mourn the loss of Clifton H.W. Maloney, husband of The Honorable Carolyn B. Maloney, who has been a strong supporter of people with vision loss. To Congresswoman Maloney and her entire family, we extend our heartfelt sympathy. Lighthouse International Roger O. Goldman, Chairman of the Board Mark G. Ackermann, President and CEO

Republicans are using a clip from President Obama's recent Sunday morning news media blitz to make a political point about the vocabulary of health care reform. In a Web video posted Monday, the Republican National Committee included part of a Sept. 20 interview in which George Stephanopoulos of ABC News cited a dictionary in asking Mr. Obama how requiring individuals to buy health insurance -- and fining them if they do not -- would not by definition be a tax.

BLUTMAN--Edna Nadell, passed away on Saturday at age 90. She was adored by her loving husband of 63 years, Max, her sister, Gloria, her three children, and her five grandchildren. Her family never tired of her colorful stories of life on Georgia Avenue, her work on the Manhattan Project, and her 20 years as a teacher in Harlem, or the way she told them with humor, exuberance, and bite. We all were lucky to have known her.

BERENS--Frances Cookman, of Oyster Bay, New York on September 24, 2009. Beloved wife of the late Conrad Berens, M.D. Loving mother of Lawrence Penington Berens and Rodney Bristol Berens. Cherished grandmother of Hope, Nicholas, Amy, Brooke, Emily, Robert, Michael and Eleanor and great-grandmother of Emma, Jack, Conner and Zander. Dear sister of Mary Ellen Day. A memorial service will be held on October 5, 2009 at 11am at Christ Church, 61 East Main Street, Oyster Bay, NY 11771. Interment Private. Contributions may be made to the Church.

MURPHY--Suzanne Crosby, 79, beloved wife, mother and grandmother, of Rye, NY and North Palm Beach, Florida, died September 25, 2009 after several months of being ill. Born in Great Neck, NY, Suzanne Crosby Murphy was the youngest child of John Francis and Emilie Morris Crosby. Raised primarily in Washington, DC and summering in Spring Lake, NJ. She graduated from Georgetown Visitation, a Catholic girl's high school in Washington, DC and earned an associates degree from Georgetown Visitation Junior College. Trained and practiced as a medical secretary, she went on to become a secretary to the well-known first televangelist, Bishop Fulton Sheen in Washington, DC. On November 5, 1955, she married Thomas S. Murphy of Brooklyn and Quaker Hill, NY and moved to Albany, NY. Eventually moving to Rye, NY where they have lived for over 37 years. Her husband was Chairman and CEO of Capital Cities/ABC, Inc. for 26 years. An active local community member, she enjoyed participating in Rye based organizations such as the Rye Youth Council, and was President of the St. Elizabeth's Guild for eight years. She took great joy in tutoring underprivileged children, particularly in the Catholic inner city schools. She was also engaged in wide ranging and numerous philanthropic interests in local, regional and national not for profit organizations. She was passionate about providing opportunities for children and adults to reach their potential, and relieving suffering in the lives of others, particularly in the areas of education and mental health. She served on the Executive Committee of the Catholic Big Sisters of New York City from 1992 to 2000 and was the honoree in 2003 at their Gala. She funded the Suzanne Crosby Murphy Professor in Pediatric Neuropsychiatry Chair at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, held by Dr. Bradley S. Peterson, MD, who is Director of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry, Director of MRI Research. She was a member of the Dames of Malta. In addition to her husband, Thomas S. Murphy, she is survived by four children, Emilie Murphy of Rye, NY, Thomas S. Murphy, Jr. of Greenwich, CT, Kathleen Murphy of Sante Fe, NM and Mary Conlin of Los Angeles, CA; two siblings, Elaine Crosby Murphy of Trenton, NJ and William Crosby of Tampa, FL; and eight grandchildren; Edward Byron, Suzanne Nealy and Larke Ann Nimocks of Rye, NY; Caitlin Brown, Grace Sawyer and Virginia Louise Murphy of Greenwich, CT; Thomas Sawyer and John Crosby Conlin of Los Angeles, CA. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Rye Youth Council or the Madison Square Boys and Girls Club of New York. The Funeral Mass at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY will be held at 4pm on September 29th. She will be remembered as Loving, Laughing, Listening and Learning. www.grahamfuneralhomerye.com

FISHER--Don. The directors and staff of Teach For America mourn the loss of our board member, champion and friend, Don Fisher. Along with his beloved wife Doris, Don launched Teach For America's growth effort. With their generosity and support, and Don's sage advice and vision, Teach For America grew eight-fold, allowing us to channel the energy of thousands of our nation's future leaders towards ensuring educational opportunity for all children. Don brought an entrepreneurial spirit and wisdom to our work, born of his success in business and his belief in public education. He always believed in the potential of young people to make our country better the potential of young teachers and leaders and, most importantly, the potential of children growing up in high poverty communities. While his legacy will endure in the millions of children reached through his philanthropy, we remember him equally for his commitment to his family and for the qualities he brought to our work: unbounded drive, optimism, and humility. We will miss him deeply, and our sympathies go out to Doris and their magnificent family.

10 P.M. (ABC) THE FORGOTTEN Alex Donovan (Christian Slater, above) and his investigative network take on the case of a Jane Doe in her 20s who was found strangled and dumped in an alley six weeks earlier. She is wearing an engagement ring, but her fiancé doesn't seem to be looking for her. 4 P.M. (NBC); 8 P.M. (55) THE ELLEN DeGENERES SHOW Drew Barrymore talks about her film ''Whip It,'' which she directed.

We've just got too many cattle on hand and too many heifers on hand, and the supply just keeps on coming and coming. TONY DE GROOT, a dairy farmer in Hanford, Calif., on an oversupply caused by high-tech breeding. [A1]

GURWIN--Joseph. A kind and gentle man who demonstrated that giving is the highest level of living. We will miss his leadership, vision and passion for life. But most of all, we will miss his friendship. Our heartfelt condolences to Phyliss, his children, his grandchildren and the entire Gurwin and Pressman families. Sandy and Larry Simon

FISHER--Don. The KIPP Foundation Board of Directors, School Leaders, staff and over 20,000 KIPPsters pay deep and heartfelt respects to KIPP co-founder and Chair of the Board, Don Fisher. We extend our sympathy to Don's wife and partner, Doris, his three sons and their families. Along with his family, KIPP was one of the greatest loves of his extraordinary life, and all of us across the KIPP Team and Family have been blessed to have Don Fisher as our most passionate champion and leader. Don believed that schools can and should provide all children with an opportunity to pursue the American dream. His legacy will live on as generations of children graduate from college and pursue successful, happy lives. Through his commitment, Don demonstrated to us, every day, the absolute transformative power of faith and love. His faith in us, and his love for us, knew no bounds. We will deeply miss his zest for life, grit in the face of obstacles, and love for all children. Our deepest sympathies go out to Doris and the Fisher family.

DUFFY--Alice Katherine "Kate", on September 27, 2009. Beloved daughter of Alice Duffy and the late Benedict Duffy. Devoted sister of Clare and Benedict and his wife Amanda. Loving aunt of Rosalind, Alexander and Elliot. Editorial Director at Kensington Publishing. The family will receive friends on Wednesday, September 30, 3-6 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue and 81st Street. Memorial service to be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The International Myeloma Foundation, 12650 Riverside Drive, Suite 206, Los Angeles, CA 91607.

McCABE--Frank J.,85, died peacefully at his home on September 7, 2009. Husband to Lucille, father to Carole, Peter, and David. Full obituary available at annarbor.com. Memorial service in Westchester on October 3rd. For details, call (315)351-6343.

When the Senate Finance Committee resumes debate Tuesday on its health care bill, a proposal for a government-run insurance plan -- the so-called public option -- will take center stage. Supporters say a public option would drive down the cost of private insurance. But the insurance industry opposes it, saying lower-priced government competition would put private insurance companies out of business.

CHURCH--Forrest. The Council on the Environment of New York City mourns the passing our of dear friend Forrest Church. Reverend Church served as Chairman and on the Board of Directors providing leadership, guidance and encouragement. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Carolyn Buck Luce, his children and family and to all who will miss his warmth, humor and good counsel. Marcel Van Ooyen Executive Director Robert J. Kafin Chairman

FERSKO--Penny (Sands), passed peacefully on Sunday, September 27. Survived by her beloved husband, Anthony (Saso) Ippolito, mother of Edith Sands, son Charlie (Tara) Fersko, brother John (Diana Lieb) Sands, grandchildren Abigail and Joshua Fersko, and Saso's loving family in Staten Island. She had a big and loving heart, and her generosity knew no bounds. She will be sorely missed. Funeral Services Thursday, October 1, 12 Noon at Menorah Chapels, 2145 Richmond Ave., Staten Island, NY. 718-494-7700.

SAFIRE--William. The Rockefeller University mourns the passing of renowned journalist, commentator and linguist William Safire. As chairman of the Dana Foundation, he wisely and creatively guided the Foundation's philanthropic support for medical research, arts education and the communication of science. His leadership helped significantly advance research in neuroscience and immunology at The Rockefeller University and at countless institutions nationwide. He did all this in the most unassuming, friendly and witty manner. We extend our heartfelt condolences to all his family and friends. Russell L. Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Paul Nurse, President Ralph M. Steinman, Professor The Rockefeller University

KOPPELMAN--Shirley. Born October 16, 1919 in New York City, NY, died September 26, 2009 in Scottsdale, AZ. Beloved wife of Irving. Devoted mother of Jane Ash of Scottsdale, AZ and Lewis Koppelman of New York City. Loving grandmother of David and Richard Blank and Amy Kahn. Devoted great-grandmother of Samantha and Jacob Blank and Rachel Kahn. Shirley will be remembered as a special friend, a marvelous hostess and an outstanding bridge player. Services to be held September 30 at 11:30am, The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., New York City. Memorial donations may be made to Hospice of the Valley, 1510 East Flower St., Phoenix, AZ 85014.
KAPLAN--Herb (Whitey). Whoever called parting "sweet sorrow" never knew what I'm going through. Hug Laurie for me too. Your Iris

MURPHY--Suzanne C. The TeenScreen National Center for Mental Health Checkups at Columbia University is deeply saddened by the loss of Suzanne Murphy. Suzanne served on TeenScreen's National Advisory Council for seven years and was both an active and engaged member and a generous donor. Suzanne's warmth, enthusiasm and passion for children's mental health issues were inspiring and she will be greatly missed by all at TeenScreen. Our sincere condolences go out to Suzanne's husband Tom and to her children and grandchildren. Laurie Flynn and Leslie McGuire, TeenScreen National Center for Mental Health Checkups at Columbia University

MASON--Francis. It is with admiration and gratitude that we remember Francis Mason for the many decades he gave of himself to the art of the dance. His many achievements always demonstrated, in a multitude of ways, his great generosity of spirit. Ballet Society Inc. Nancy Lassalle, President

DANNENBRING--David, 69, on September 27, 2009. He was a professor of business management and an administrator in a number of positions at Baruch College, CUNY, most recently as Provost and Vice-president of Academic Affairs and Special Assistant to the President. Survived by his wife Barbara, sons Robert and Michael, daughter Sarah (Kurt) Myers, two grandchildren A.J. and Sophia and sister Bonnie Groos. Memorial service 11am Friday, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., Dobbs Ferry, NY. Visiting from 10 - 11am.

FISHER--Don. The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America wish to express their profound sorrow over the passing of Mr. Don Fisher, a long-time member of our National Board of Governors, friend, advocate and true champion for America's young people. Don Fisher's involvement with the Boys & Girls Club Movement spans more than four decades, beginning with his generous support of the Columbia Park Club in his hometown of San Francisco. In 1996, he joined Boys & Girls Clubs of America's National Board of Governors, bringing visionary leadership and expanding the organization's services to young people in need of hope and opportunity. In recognition for his years of extraordinary service to young people and Boys & Girls Clubs, Don Fisher was presented with the organization's highest honor, the Herbert Hoover Humanitarian Award in 2000. Our hearts go out to his wife Doris who was always by his side and shared her husband's passion for philanthropy. Don Fisher was a truly exceptional human being who will be greatly missed by everyone in the Boys & Girls Club Family. Boys & Girls Clubs of America Robbie Bach, Chairman Roxanne Spillett, President/CEO

POLLAN--Richard, on September 26, 2009. Loving husband of Diane Lesser, father of Julia and Rachel. Brother of Stan and Jim. Services Tuesday, September 29, 11:45am at Riverside Chapel, 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave.

Looking out across his green rice fields, Nguyen Van Truong can take pride in hedging his bets when he joined the global marketplace more than a decade ago and began to make money. When Vietnam began a tentative engagement with the world economy in the mid-1990s, Mr. Truong was one of the first people to see profit in his local craft, embroidery, and he joined with other villagers in marketing it for export and domestic sales.

MASON--Francis. The Trustees and staff of the Morgan Library & Museum note with sadness the death of Francis Mason, former assistant director. A valued colleague and friend, Francis was also an advocate for wide-ranging cultural programs. We extend sincere sympathy to his family. S. Parker Gilbert, President William M. Griswold, Director

MALONEY--Clifton. New York Road Runners mourns the death of Clifton Maloney, who died September 25 after he reached the 27,000-foot summit of Cho-Oyu on the border of Tibet and China. Maloney completed the New York City Marathon 20 times, including a 3:58 finish in 2008 at age 71. We express condolences to Maloney's wife, U.S. Congresswoman Carolyn Maloney.

GURWIN--Joseph. With profound sadness the Board of Directors, Administration, Staff and Residents of the Gurwin Jewish Nursing & Rehabilitation Center mourn the loss of our esteemed founding President and benefactor, Joseph Gurwin. Joe was an inspiring, kind and generous gentleman, whose dedication to philanthropy brought lasting joy and an enhanced quality of life to countless people throughout the United States and around the globe. Because of his inability to bring his parents to the United States before they perished in the Holocaust, Joe and his late wife Rosalind took the opportunity to help create a Center that would care for the parents of others in a dignified and compassionate manner. His vision, dedication and leadership through the years have made the Gurwin name synonymous with excellence in caring for the elderly and those in need. He touched countless lives and will forever be remembered for helping to make his dream of "caring for those who cared for us" possible. Our Center will long stand as a legacy to our very special friend. We express heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Phyllis, his children Laura Flug, Eric and Karen Gurwin and his grandchildren Danielle, Jeffrey, Jason and Jaclyn, as well as the Pressman family. Lawrence Simon, Chairman Bert E. Brodsky, President Herbert H. Friedman, Exec VP

FRIER--Marilyn Esq.,on September 26th 2009. Devoted daughter of the late Miriam and Samuel Aaronson. Beloved wife of the late Joseph H. Frier, Jr. Loving mother of Susan and Ron; and cherished by Melissa, William, James and Daniel as their "Skippy Grandma." We all will miss you always. Sherry Frier and Greg Danilow

MALONEY--Clifton. The CIVITAS board of directors on which Clifton Maloney sat for many years is devastated by his untimely death. Clif cared greatly about our community and contributed enormously to CIVITAS' work. Our sincere condolences go out to his family.

SAFIRE--William. The Trustees of Syracuse University and Chancellor Nancy Cantor, on behalf of the entire Syracuse University community, mourn the passing of alumnus and Honorary Trustee, William Safire. Bill maintained a close relationship with the University for nearly 60 years. He generously donated his early papers and book collection to the Syracuse University Library mandating that the Safire Room, where they are housed, be open to students at all times. In 1986 the William Safire Chair in Modern Letters was established by lifelong friend Robert B. Menschel and the Dr. Scholl Foundation in the College of Arts and Sciences of the University. He was actively involved in the intellectual life of the University and in 2003 established the Speaking of Science series with Syracuse University and the Dana Foundation. Our deepest condolences go out to Helene, Mark, Annabel and their entire family. John H. Chapple, Chairman of the Board of Trustees and Nancy Cantor, Chancellor and President, Syracuse University
Dot Earth From Andrew C. Revkin's blog, nytimes.com/dotearth.

HOVNANIAN--Kevork S. We mourn the loss of Kevork S. Hovnanian, a wonderfully warm, gentle friend and benefactor of the Vivian and Seymour Milstein Family Heart Center, which will open at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center in 2010. A successful businessman and a wise humanist who believed that success brings responsibilities, he was a compassionate and generous philanthropist who will be sorely missed. He clearly loved his family. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Sirwart; his four daughters, Sossie Najarian, Esto Barry, Lucy Kalian, and Nadia Rodriguez; his son, Ara; and his 13 grandchildren. Herbert Pardes M.D. President and CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital

MURPHY--Suzanne C. The Board of Directors of Catholic Big Sisters and Big Brothers and staff notes with sorrow the death of Suzanne Murphy, former board member from 1992-2000. We will cherish the memory of Suzanne's kind and generous spirit and her dedication to children in need. Our thoughts and prayers are with the entire Murphy family.
ZAKIN--Albert. "Big D" Happy Birthday. Still quoted, remembered and missed. Bernice and your loving family

SAFIRE--William L.,on Sunday, September 27, 2009, William L. Safire of Chevy Chase, MD. Beloved husband of Helene Safire. Devoted father of Mark (Karen) and Annabel Safire. Loving grandfather of one. Funeral services and interment private. A memorial service will be held at a later date. The family will receive relatives and friends on Wednesday and Thursday evenings at 7pm at the late residence. Memorial contributions may be made to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network, 2141 Rosecrans Ave., Suite 7000, El Segundo, CA 90245. Services entrusted to Torchinsky Hebrew Funeral Home, 800-500-5401.
International NO DETAIL OVERLOOKED

SAFIRE--William. The Directors and staff of the Dana Foundation express our profound sense of loss with the death of our colleague, Chairman and CEO, William Safire. He served on our Board since 1993 and as our chair since 2000. We mourn Bill not only because we have lost our chairman but also because we have lost a dear friend, a man of unparalleled intellect and wit who was devoted to the Foundation and its work. During his tenure, Bill was our greatest champion-always working to enhance and build Dana's mission and outreach. We extend our most heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Helene and his children, Mark and Annabel.
HOLIDAY FASTING AMID A FEAST

HURWITZ--Melvin, who died September 28 at age 92, saw the world as embodying great hope and possibilities. He was a blessing to his family and friends, and a lesson to everyone around him. A courageous man who defied convention, Mel ran for state political office in Brooklyn in the 1960s, taking on the establishment. He graduated from Pace University at age 68, received his law degree at age 72 and was admitted to the Bar five years later. A charming and loving man, Mel will be missed by his son, Ken, and his wife Susan, his daughter Fran and her husband Elliot and his grandchildren, Emily, Daniel, Samantha, Russell and Marla. Burial at Montefiore Cemetery (Queens) on September 30 at 1pm.

DAVIES--Frederick, organist at Radio City Music Hall and former associate Vice President with Citibank died on Thursday, September 26 of a heart attack. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, October 11 at the United Presbyterian Church in Paterson where he was the Director of Music. The church is located at 375 Van Houten St. in Paterson. For further details, call the church at 973-742-9755.

PHOTOGRAPHS The images of Iranian protests after this year's disputed election seemed eerily familiar to the photojournalist David Burnett. He had witnessed and documented similar scenes in 1979 during the Iranian revolution. nytimes.com/lens

SMALLENS--Alexander, Jr.,74, died peacefully on Monday at his home in White Plains. He is survived by his wife, Timmi Smallens; two children, Meredith and Sandy; and five grandchildren. Funeral service Tuesday (today) at 1:00pm at Bet Am Shalom, 295 Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY 10606.

Commentators often note the size of Jets quarterback Mark Sanchez's extra-large hands, and how they are supposed to help him as a quarterback. But Sanchez has yet to play in snow, and he needs to improve his ball security before the weather grows worse. On Sunday, Sanchez had two potential interceptions dropped. He also fumbled twice.
General Motors plans to close its Saturn brand after Penske Automotive abruptly called off an agreement to buy the division, Nick Bunkley of The New York Times reports from Detroit.

Last year the European Heart Journal published a study that continues to prompt discussion among researchers who work with marathoner runners and those, many of them the same researchers, who run marathons. In the study, German scientists scanned the hearts of 108 experienced, male distance runners in their fifties, sixties and seventies.

Edo de Waart, the music director of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra, will conduct the Metropolitan Opera‘s performances of “Der Rosenkavalier” on Oct. 13, 16, and 19, in place of James Levine, the Met said on Wednesday. Mr. Levine, the Met’s music director, is having surgery to repair a herniated disc, but is expected to return in time for its new production of “Les Contes d’Hoffmann,” which opens on Dec. 3, as well performances of “Der Rosenkavalier” in January. Mr. de Waart made his Met debut in 1998 with “Die Zauberflöte” and returned the following season to conduct “Le Nozze di Figaro.”

Be prepared for what could be the shortest, punchiest acceptance speech in PEN history: on Wednesday, the literary organization PEN USA said that it would give its Lifetime Achievement Award to Elmore Leonard, the prolific crime fiction novelist. The award will be presented to Mr. Leonard at a ceremony in Beverly Hills on Dec. 2. At that time, the organization will also hand out honors in other categories, including prizes for fiction, given to Kim Barnes, for “A Country Called Home”; creative nonfiction, given to Steve Lopez for “The Soloist”; research nonfiction, awarded to Leslie T. Chang for “Factory Girls”; and screenplay, given to Dustin Lance Black for “Milk.”
The Broadway revival of “West Side Story” playing at the Palace Theater has recouped its original investment of $14 million after 30 weeks and 247 performances, its producers said on Wednesday.

In a book-bending experiment combining film and prose, Simon & Schuster and Vook, a multimedia company that produces video content for books, are releasing four digital titles in which links to short video segments are seamlessly interspersed throughout the text.

As it turns out, predicting the arrival date of a baby (and planning one’s career around it) is not an exact science. Lincoln Center Theater anticipated (back in February) that Kelli O’Hara would return from her maternity leave to its production of “South Pacific” on Oct. 6. But on Wednesday, the theater company said that Ms. O’Hara will resume the role of Nellie Forbush on Oct. 13. Ms. O’Hara and her husband, Greg Naughton, welcomed their son, Owen James, into the world on June 27. During her leave, Laura Osnes has been playing Nellie.

Despite limited distribution, Pearl Jam’s “Backspacer” (Monkeywrench), was the best-selling album in the United States last week. Available only at Target stores, iTunes, small record shops and through the band’s Web site, pearljam.com, “Backspacer” sold 189,000 copies its first week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan, opening at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. Jay-Z’s “The Blueprint 3” (Roc Nation/Atlantic) fell to No. 2 after two weeks on top, with 134,000 sales. The Canadian rock band Three Days Grace is in third place with its new “Life Starts Now” (Jive), which sold 79,000. Other high-charting new releases include “Daisy” (Interscope) by the Long Island group Brand New, at No. 6 with 46,000; Five Finger Death Punch’s “War Is the Answer” (Prospect Park), at No. 7 with 44,000, and Harry Connick Jr.’s “Your Songs” (Sony), at No. 8 with 37,000. Whitney Houston’s “I Look to You” (Arista) is No. 4 with 66,000 sales, and Miley Cyrus’s mini-album “Time of Our Lives” (Hollywood), sold through Wal-Mart, is No. 5 with 61,000.

LOS ANGELES — In a bizarre twist to Roman Polanski’s renewed legal fight over a 32-year-old sex case, a retired deputy district attorney who triggered claims of official corruption by telling a documentary filmmaker he had coached a judge in the case now says he made it all up.
This post contains spoilers.

When Harvey Weinstein goes head-to-head with filmmakers he often gets what he wants, but his Weinstein Company will likely not be distributing the highly sought-after independent film “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire.” On Friday, Variety reported, a federal district judge in Manhattan dismissed a lawsuit brought by the Weinstein Company, which said it had struck a deal to handle the movie’s release. In February, the rival studio Lionsgate announced that it had paid about $5.5 million to distribute the film, about a teenager in 1980s Harlem, which won the the Grand Jury Prize at this year’s Sundance Film Festival. Soon after, the Weinstein Company filed suit against Lionsgate, the film’s producers and the film sales company Cinetic Media, saying that Cinetic had reneged on a deal with the Weinstein Company. In dismissing the breach of contract suit against the film’s producers, Judge Naomi Reice Buchwald noted that a transfer of film rights requires a signed agreement, which negotiations between Cinetic and the Weinstein Company never yielded. Lionsgate is planning to release “Precious” on Nov. 6.
What we’re reading on Wednesday morning.

A typical talk-back session after a play involves performers and creative-team members answering questions from curious audience members. But the Broadway transfer of the David Mamet play “Oleanna” is taking a different approach: among the guests who will be fielding inquires after the drama, about a possible act of sexual harassment made by a university professor against his female student, will be Anucha Browne Sanders, a former senior marketing executive for the New York Knicks who sued the team and Madison Square Garden for sexual harassment. Ms. Browne Sanders, who in 2007 won a $11.5 million settlement from the Garden and its chairman, James L. Dolan, is scheduled to appear at a talk-back on Tuesday, following that evening’s preview performance of “Oleanna” at the Golden Theater. Other guests also slated for coming talk-back sessions include former Mayor David N. Dinkins (on Oct. 9), the talk show host Montel Williams (Oct. 10, evening performance) and the outgoing “Law & Order: Criminal Intent” star Kathryn Erbe (Oct. 17, evening performance). “Oleanna,” which stars Bill Pullman and Julia Stiles, began previews on Tuesday and is to have its official opening on Oct. 11.

When you have starred in one of the most successful television comedies of recent years as well as its less-than-beloved spinoff, what do you do for an encore? Get meta. Matt LeBlanc, who followed 10 seasons on the NBC series “Friends” with 46 episodes of the solo project “Joey,” will return to television in a new show in which he will play a satirical version of himself. The new show, called “Episodes,” will be jointly produced by Showtime and the BBC, the television channels said on Wednesday in a news release, and is created by David Crane (a co-creator of “Friends”) and Jeffrey Klarik. It will focus on a British couple whose hit comedy is reworked for American television in a watered-down version starring Mr. LeBlanc. In a statement, Mr. LeBlanc said he was glad he got the role because “seeing someone else play Matt LeBlanc would have been devastating.” “Episodes” will be produced in London and Los Angeles, and will have its debut on Showtime and BBC Two next year.

If you missed Paul McCartney‘s three-night stand at Citi Field in July, possibly in fear for your eardrums, a coming recording of those concerts will allow you to experience those shows at more moderate decibel levels. Songs from those shows, which Mr. McCartney performed on July 17, 18 and 21, will be appear on the live album “Good Evening New York City,” which is planned for release by Hear Music/Concord Music Group on Nov. 17. In a news release, publicists for Mr. McCartney said the album will be released in two versions: a three-disc set (containing two CDs and one DVD), and a deluxe four-disc set containing a bonus DVD of Mr. McCartney’s July 15 performance on “Late Show With David Letterman,” when he played on the marquee of the Ed Sullivan Theater. “Good Evening New York City” will feature Mr. McCartney’s performances of various Beatles, Wings and solo songs, including a version of “Something” performed on a ukulele given to Mr. McCartney by George Harrison.

After two French cabinet ministers were roundly criticized this week for leaping too quickly to the defense of the director Roman Polanski, a French government spokesman on Wednesday offered a more diplomatic view of Mr. Polanski’s arrest.

Carnegie Hall and the Boston Symphony Orchestra have found a new conductor for Thursday night’s season-opening gala. It is Daniele Gatti, who is in New York for performances of Verdi’s “Aida” at the Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Gatti will replace James Levine, the Boston Symphony’s music director, who had to withdraw because of surgery for a herniated disk. Mr. Gatti is music director of the Orchestra National de France and chief conductor of the Zurich Opera. The program will remain the same, said Carnegie’s spokeswoman, Synneve Carlino, except for Berlioz’s “Roman Carnaval,” which will be replaced by Beethoven’s “Coriolan” Overture.

I've always really liked guns. Growing up, I fantasized about them endlessly, though my parents discouraged it every way they could. I came to agree with them in principle - that violence doesn't solve much of anything, that the world would be better without weapons - though it didn't keep me from stockpiling toy armaments. In the years since, I've become a partisan in pacifist causes, around which congregates a community that has no patience for packing heat. But I continue to feel that old attraction. I can still get swept away in fantasies of firepower. So nearly a decade into legal age with nary a shot fired, I decided it was time to test my reveries against the real thing: would a gun really satisfy them or cause me to recoil in horror?

PHILADELPHIA - One of the heartwarming story lines to the Phillies' World Series title run last season was Jamie Moyer, who at age 46 won a ring in front of his hometown fans. If the Phillies are to repeat as champions, Moyer will not be able to help. He tore three tendons - two in his left groin, one in his lower abdomen - while throwing a pitch Tuesday night and needs season-ending surgery. Dr. Michael Ciccotti, the Phillies' team physician, said Moyer was expected to be ready for spring training.

With the Inverness-cape look now reaching its post-Victorian fashion apex, style editors will likely queue up at theaters when the new Sherlock Holmes film arrives in December. In the meantime, there's "Inspector Lewis," a mystery series currently airing on PBS. Its detective duo isn't as epically dandyish (though Lewis's partner, Detective Sergeant Hathaway, has been known to be fond of skinny ties). There is, however, elegance in the writing and the cinematography, and lots of pull for the armchair traveler. Each episode features a knotty murder plot and the two agreeable sleuths, but it's the city - Oxford - that stars: sunlit spires, misty punting and the occasional homicidal don. (Contemporary Oxford is apparently only slightly safer than Darfur.) For Anglophiles needing a brief fix, it kills.

Having spent the last two years consumed by feeding, changing diapers, racing to day care and doctor appointments and answering the question "Why, mommy, why?" I found myself stumbling for something to write about. I have worked for the same company for almost four years, recently married my partner and devote any free time to our two daughters and my stepson. My life has become rather predictable - well, as much as life with three children can be. Trips to the emergency room, explosive diapers, laughter, and meltdowns aren't so predictable! I often reflect on the year I spent in Iraq, sitting in city council meetings, attending dinners at the governor's house, never sure of what was going to happen next. In hindsight, that time of my life was filled with excitement, fear, laughter, tears, and a lot of uncertainty. Suddenly, all of those emotions have resurfaced.

New York City has taken ownership of the Bowne House, a 17th-century Anglo-Dutch structure in Flushing, Queens, that is a major symbol of the growth of religious freedom in America. For years, a longstanding federal law has stood in the way of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to convert the city's taxi fleet from gas-guzzling Crown Victorias to more environmentally-friendly hybrids. Two attempts to do so were tossed out by a judge after challenges from taxi owners.

Hasted Hunt Kraeutler will unveil its new gallery space with the opening of Edward Burtynsky's show "Oil" on Oct. 1. The Canadian photographer's latest body of work deals with the controversial subject of petroleum - from its rather brutal extraction from the earth to the rampant consumption in our modern culture to its possible depletion. Burtynsky, who is known for his epic photos of landscapes altered by manufacturing from mining to drilling (he was the subject of "Manufactured Landscapes," a documentary that was shown at Sundance in 2007), will also show the works at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, starting Oct. 3. If your carbon-footprint guilt is kicking in, you can forgo the trip to D.C. and buy a copy of the "Oil" monograph (Steidl), out later this month.

Everything about Imelda Marcos flies on rumor. From her "affair" with the assiduously tanned actor George Hamilton to the construction workers supposedly encased in concrete at the Manila Film Center on her orders, the Steel Butterfly has battled her fair share of gossip. Tonight, "Imelda, A New Musical" opens at the Julia Miles Theatre, complete with its own Marcos mini-drama. As the Pan Asian Repertory Theater's singing and dancing story of the beloved, beloathed and BeDazzled fallen Philippine first lady's life makes its East Coast debut, word is that the Muse of Manila (an honorific bestowed on Imelda after she successfully protested her third-place finish at the Miss Manila contest) is most concerned about what the lead looks like. Apparently the 5-foot-2 star of the Los Angeles production was deemed too short by the proud 5-foot-7 beauty queen, who sent one of her Blue Ladies to scope out the musical. ("She was wonderful, very put-together, very elegant and very over-the-top," says costume designer Ivy Chou of the mole. "You could spot her a mile away.") Well, that's the dish anyway.

It's a complete cinematic cliché: the man in the gray flannel suit. The symbol of corporate drone. Yet the image also conjures up nostalgia for a time when men dressed appropriately for the office, in clothing that fit and, just as important, was properly fitted. Having survived yet another round of prophesies of its demise, the flannel suit seems a bit more open for personal interpretation and adaptation, and I'm feeling the call to wear one. The familiarity and comfortable constraint of a well-cut jacket and trousers make you feel safe and even a bit powerful.

David: Gail, Recently I was reading a book called "Moral Minds" by Marc Hauser of Harvard. The book is about the underlying grammar of our moral judgments, but in the middle of it, he has a section on honor killings. He describes a killing that took place in Jerusalem in 2001. A guy named Mr. Asasah stood in front of his 32-year-old daughter. She was single and pregnant. Asasah had a noose and an ax and a group of about 30 men and women behind him. He asked his daughter to choose the means of her death. She chose the noose.

London, Milan and Paris may be in the midst of fashion madness, but in Berlin, predictably, it's art that has taken center stage recently, as the city played host to two major fairs last week. The bigger one was Artforum, featuring blue-chip galleries like Spruthe Magers and Max Wigram exhibiting in the grand Deco setting of the Messe Berlin fairgrounds. Standout artists on display include Ronnie Bass, represented by the New York-based gallery I-20; Bass scored, directed and starred in his own music video, which offered a satirical take on the retro aesthetic of 1980s New Wave and New Romantic bands. Another name to watch is the conceptual photographer Veronika Kellndorfer, represented by Christopher Grimes Gallery in Santa Monica, Calif. Her work bridges gaps between photography, architecture, painting and installation.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Big health care news. This just happened. The public option backed by President Obama was just voted down by the Senate Finance Committee, or as supporters of universal health care call them, the Death Panel.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: The former governor of Alaska, Sarah Palin, has completed her memoir, and it'll be in stores in November. So that's something to look forward to. A lot of people aren't taking her seriously. I've seen it. It's a big, huge book. But when you go into the store, you can use that big book to step up so you can reach a better book.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on NBC: I was reading today about President Obama's new plans for education. I guess President Obama wants kids to spend more time in school. He wants them staying later in the day. That's not new. We had that when I was in school. It's called detention. I was there until 5:30, 6 every night.

While some wildlife seems to do better around civilization than in the wild, in earth's most crowded places, like the corridor along the Yangtze River, there is a different outcome. First, scientists recorded the vanishing and apparent extinction of the baiji, a dolphin species unique to that river. Now another denizen, the Chinese paddlefish, Psephurus gladius -- which measures up to 20 feet long and decades ago was commonly seen leaping above the waters -- appears to be on the verge of extinction, if not already gone forever. A three-year survey of the fish's normal haunts in the upper stretches of the river by Chinese biologists has turned up nothing. "It is strongly suggested that P. gladius is on the verge of extinction," the researchers wrote, "and further rigid measures are proposed to save the very few remaining specimens."

Museum silence is like no other: the squeak of a sneaker, the stifled sneeze. At MUDE, Lisbon's recently reopened Museum of Design and Fashion, early Rolling Stones tunes play as an odd but pleasant soundtrack to the debut exhibition, "From Corbusier to Alaia." The space, an old bank headquarters from the 1950s, is as raw as a shucked oyster, with exposed pipes and dangling wires. The unpolished setting makes for a nice contrast to the 170 pieces of designer fashion and artful construction on display in this bubbly curtsy to the aesthetics of the 20th century.

An obituary on Monday about Edward Gelsthorpe, an innovative marketer of consumer products, misspelled part of the name of the company at which he introduced Ban roll-on deodorant. It is Bristol-Myers, not Meyers.

A column on Friday about the New York Film Festival, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, misstated the year the society plans to open its new film center on West 65th Street. It is 2011, not next year.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Tuesday about a confrontation between a star of the Broadway play “A Steady Rain” and an audience member whose cellphone rang during a performance misstated the star’s surname at two points. As noted elsewhere in the report, he is Hugh Jackman, not Jackson.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Saturday about personnel changes in the Metropolitan Opera’s performance of “Tosca” on Thursday night misstated the given name of the conductor who replaced James Levine, who has a back ailment that requires surgery. He is Joseph Colaneri, not James.

As noted elsewhere in the article, the Libyan leader is Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, not Qadaffi, and about 40 percent of the project — not “most” of it — is being built over a railyard.

The DealBook column on Tuesday, about a recent uptick in mergers and acquisitions, described incorrectly a benefit of strategic deals, in which one company buys another with the aim of making it an integral part of its business. An article on Monday about the trucking industry’s concerns over proposals to ban texting while driving referred incorrectly to statistics regarding large trucks and fatal crashes. The statistics, from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, cover trucks that were involved in fatal crashes; they do not specify the number of crashes “caused” by the trucks. The article also misstated the change in numbers of fatal crashes involving large trucks from 1997 to 2007. According to N.H.T.S.A., that number declined to 4,808 in 2007, from 5,416 in 1997; it did not increase to 4,808 in 2007, from 4,777 in 1997. (In 1997, N.H.T.S.A. data differentiated between medium-weight and heavy trucks; in the 2007 data, they were counted together as large trucks.).

Gov. Tim Kaine said Tuesday he could not think of any reason he would stop the execution of John Allen Muhammad, left, who was sentenced to death in the sniper killing of a man at a Manassas gas station. The victim, Dean Meyers, was one of 10 people killed over three weeks in October 2002 by Mr. Muhammad and a teenage accomplice, Lee Boyd Malvo, who is serving a life sentence. Mr. Muhammad is scheduled to be executed Nov. 10 for the killing spree in Washington, Virginia and Maryland. “I know of nothing in this case now that would suggest that there is any credible claim of innocence or that there was anything procedurally wrong with the prosecution,” Mr. Kaine said during his monthly call-in radio show. Mr. Kaine, a Roman Catholic, is opposed to the death penalty but has allowed nine executions and commuted one sentence since he took office in 2006. The Iranian foreign minister, Manouchehr Mottaki, said Tuesday that talks between Iran and six major powers, which are to take place on Thursday, must be a ''two-way street'' and not just a long list of demands focused on his country's nuclear program. ''On paper they claim to recognize Iran's right for a peaceful nuclear program,'' said Mr. Mottaki in an interview at the Iranian mission to the United Nations. ''That is not enough to say that on paper.''

PAPSCO--William G. (Bill), 84, died at home in Windsor, CA on September 27, 2009. A pioneer in the development of "open plan" interiors for offices and schools, his concept for portable wall systems helped introduce the office cubicle. Another success, the "Star Divider" became the standard for portable study havens at American colleges in the 1960s. He was an engineering graduate of Cornell University (1946) where he was coxswain of the "Big Red" crew, attended Harvard Business School (1953) and was a supporter of St. Benedict's Preparatory School in Newark, NJ, his hometown. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Carol, his two children, Mary Papsco Young of Eureka, CA, and Thomas of Poulsbo, WA, two grandchildren Katie Guzzi of Cairo, Egypt and Camille Guzzi of Seattle, WA, and his brother Robert E. Papsco and his wife Carol of Lloyds Neck, Long Island, NY. Bill Papsco was also the founder and owner of Pele Nevada, LLC, a precious metals processing company in Reno, NV. A lifelong wine enthusiast and gourmet chef, he will be most remembered as a person who treasured his family and friends. Among them are his buddies from Harvard who often traveled with him to places around the globe, his loving cousins in Austria, and his loyal beachcombers at Makena Surf.

That could ease the strain across the American armed forces and free up extra combat units for duty in the Afghanistan war, which has become a priority for the Obama administration.

GOODMAN--Joan. We mourn the loss of Joan, loving wife of Peter and mother of Drew, his wife Sommer and their daughter Sklyer. Born in White Plains, she resided in New York City and the Springs. A graduate of Vassar College and a member of Delta Sigma Theta sorority, she taught kindergarten, first graders and music at PS 49 in the South Bronx for over thirty years. As the District Representative for the United Federation of Teachers (UFT) she fought for the rights of teachers and children. She served on the Executive Board of her union, chaired Committees on Gifted and Talented Education and created the mandated Child Abuse and Neglect course required of all child care providers. She trained teacher union leaders in South Africa during the depths of apartheid. She mentored untold numbers of children and teachers, she urged, cajoled and demanded excellence from all around her. She left her mark on all she touched. Funeral services will be held on Friday, October 2nd at 11am at First AME Bethel Church, 60 West 132nd Street, New York, NY. Interment at Cedar Lawn Cemetery, East Hampton, NY.

BERSON--Iolabee "Sis". Our grandmother was one of the most incredible women we have ever known. She was born here in New York, the oldest of four children in the Dworman family. As the only girl, she was raised as "one of the boys." She went to college in Macon, Georgia (where they had never seen "a Jew" before) and then worked in the family's real estate business. When she married our grandfather (to whom she was married for over 60 years -- as different as two people can be but a real love affair) he was a young physician in private practice. However, our grandmother always encouraged him "to dream big" -- as she always did. And so the two of them started to build private hospitals and never looked back. They worked tirelessly -- and side by side. They had two loving daughters together -- Rhetta and Bonnie -- and with that gave birth to a beautiful family tree of grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Our grandmother was a New York icon, known throughout New York as a hard-driven businesswoman but always a lady. All of Manhattan knew "Mrs. Berson" and she wore the title well. In our grandmother's world, you could never be overdressed. She was a spectacle of perfection, bedecked and bejeweled, from head to toe. Our friends called her Queen Elizabeth and they were not far off. She was known at Old Oaks for appearing at the gym in the early morning wearing white gloves and a Chanel suit in full make-up to "run" on the treadmill. Our grandfather worshipped her. He told us that she inspired him to be better and he adored her for that. They had a love affair like no other and their marriage was an amazing example for all of us. We all feel fortunate that our children got to spend such meaningful time with their great-grandmother whom they adored -- and that she got to share with them her stories about how she learned to fly an airplane and rode horses and owned a pet monkey who used to steal her red lipstick. She loved being the focus of their attention and they adored being in her regal presence. We all did. She was truly one of a kind and we will miss her dearly. Nikki and Paul, Sydney, Alex and Ben Aimee and Jonathan, William Lauren and Jon, Molly and Jackson Marla and Gregg, Nathalie and Andrew Dara and Evan, Sasha and Tatum Heather and David, Sam and Lola Rhetta and Max Bonnie and Steven

Since moving to New York from San Francisco a year and a half ago, Joe Mangrum has been doing sand paintings around the city, in this case on the sidewalk at the southwest corner of Central Park. He names the installations by date and location -- this is ''September 18, 2009: Columbus Circle'' -- and usually spends six to eight hours creating them. In the end, he sweeps up the sand to be recycled and possibly reused in future works. Previous installments of Sight/Site, which examines public art, are available at nytimes.com/lens.

A September call-up to the major leagues had Donna Sachet understandably nervous. On Tuesday night, Sachet made history at AT&T Park before the San Francisco Giants played host to the Arizona Diamondbacks, becoming the first drag queen to sing the national anthem at a major league game. In a telephone conversation a few hours before leaving for the stadium, Sachet acknowledged having butterflies. ''I'm nervous about what kind of reaction I'll get,'' Sachet said.

NOONAN--Daniel Edward, aged 85 of Tucson, Arizona, died on September 26 due to complications related to Parkinson's disease. Dan Noonan was born on November 17, 1923 and was resident of Staten Island, New York for most of his life before retiring to Tucson in 1977. He proudly served his country 1942-43 as a sergeant in the U.S. Marine Corp seeing extensive action in the South Pacific. He founded Daniel E. Noonan Inc. in 1955, which was to become the largest and most successful international money broker on Wall Street before he retired in 1977. Besides being a successful Chief Executive Officer of his company, he was most proud of being the first in his profession to hire people from minority groups. Dan was a devout Catholic and was active in the Urban League when he lived and worked in New York. Dan was a loving and devoted husband of Patricia (nee Smith) for 60 years. He was the proud and loving father of John, Daniel, Lindsay and Paul. Daniel Noonan will be remembered for his unquestionable integrity and was a huge hearted man who was the first to help those who needed it most. Services entrusted to Adair Funeral Homes Avalon Chapel Tucson, Arizona, 520-742-7901

His six years as the manager of the Chiba Lotte Marines over, Bobby Valentine will spend the league championship series and the World Series as an ESPN studio analyst. If the television stint ends there and Valentine is hired to manage a major league team, that will be O.K. with ESPN. ''We know teams would be crazy not to ask Bobby to manage,'' said Norby Williamson, ESPN's executive vice president for production. Valentine worked for ESPN in 2003 after the Mets fired him. Asked about the 2009 Mets, he said during a conference call from Japan, ''I think it's been a tragedy.'' RICHARD SANDOMIR

SINNOTT--Jeanne Nolan, 79, beloved mother and grandmother, of Rye, NY died of cancer September 28, 2009. A resident of Rye for more than 55 years she was a member and past president of the Rye City Board of Education; member and past president of the Resurrection Parish Council and St. Monica's Mother's Club; Trustee and volunteer St. Agnes Hospital. She is survived by her dearly loved daughters, Colleen Powers of Rye, NY and Louise Stocker of New York City; her beloved sons-in-law, James Powers and Michael Stocker; and her very special loves, grandchildren Brian, Patrick and Molly Powers of Rye, NY and Luke Stocker of New York City. MALONEY--Clifton H. W. Maloney, 71, passed away on September 25th on Cho Oyu Mountain located between the boarder of Nepal and China. He had reached the 27,000 ft summit on the morning of September 24th, making him the oldest American to ever summit an 8,000 meter peak. He spent that night at Base Camp 3 and arrived the following day at Base Camp 2 at 23,000 feet where he died in his sleep. His last words were, "I'm the happiest man in the world. I've just summited a beautiful mountain." Born in Philadelphia on October 15, 1937, Mr. Maloney graduated from Princeton University in 1960, Harvard Business School in 1965, and served in the U.S. Navy from 1960-1963. An investment banker and real estate investor, Mr. Maloney worked at several financial services companies, including The City Management Corp, Electronic Bond and Share Company, and New York Securities Co., Inc. In 1974, he became a Vice President of Goldman, Sachs & Co. In 1981, he founded his own company, C.H.W. Maloney & Co., Incorporated, to acquire established businesses for long term investment. Mr. Maloney served as a director of several companies, including The Wall Street Fund, Inc. and Interpool Limited. Mr. Maloney was a dedicated marathon runner who had finished the New York Marathon 20 times and in 2008 finished as the fastest American in his age group. He enjoyed sailing and was a member of the New York Yacht Club. Deeply committed to the quality of life in his local community, Mr. Maloney was on the Board of Civitas and the New York Foundation for Senior Citizens and was active in Carnegie Hill Neighbors. He was the Annual Giving Class Agent for the Princeton Class of 1960 and was proud to report more than 70% class participation. He was an avid mountain climber having climbed five of the Seven Summits (including Mount Elbrus, Aconcagua, Mount Vinson, Denali, and Mount Kilimanjaro). In addition, he climbed Orizaba, Mexico's highest volcano. He was a member of the Explorer's Club and the American Alpine Club. His passion for mountain climbing and an equally great passion for boats of all sorts stemmed from his experiences as a lifelong summer resident of Blue Mt. Lake in the Adirondacks. Mr. Maloney is survived by his wife, Congresswoman Carolyn Jane Bosher Maloney to whom he was married in 1976, his daughters, Christina Paul Maloney and Virginia Marshall Maloney, his mother, Virginia Wells Maloney, his sister, Virginia Maloney Lawrence, and eight nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Clifton H.W. Maloney Scholarship Fund at Princeton University, the Explorer's Club or the American Alpine Club. YANGON, Myanmar -- U Win Tin, Myanmar's longest-serving political prisoner, was tormented, tortured and beaten by his captors in the notorious Insein Prison for nearly two decades. Now, at 80, he faces a new kind of torment: watching colleagues from his political party decide whether to play ball with the junta that put him behind bars. Released in September 2008 after more than 19 years in prison, Mr. Win Tin remains remarkably spry, upbeat, and politically engaged. A co-founder of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy, he is a vocal opponent of taking part in national elections set for next year. The vote, along with the implementation of a new constitution, would nominally return Myanmar to civilian government after four and a half decades of military rule.

Jets receiver David Clowney has not made the expected impact after another stellar preseason. He was inactive against the Titans because Coach Rex Ryan was not happy with his complaints, via Twitter, about playing time. The message in question, regarding the Jets' game Sept. 20 against the Patriots, said: ''1 play in the 1st Half, 4 plays in the 2nd half. A bit disappointed about my playing time but very happy and satisfied about the win.'' Ryan said of Clowney's practices last week: ''He responded the way I wanted him to respond. He gave us a phenomenal effort.'' GREG BISHOP

A land mine possibly planted by Islamist insurgents blew up a vehicle carrying two American soldiers and a Filipino marine in the southern Philippines on Tuesday, killing them and wounding two other Filipino marines, the Philippine Army said. It was the first time in seven years that members of the American military had been killed in the Philippines. Lt. Col. Romeo Brawner, an army spokesman, said the blast occurred near the town of Idanan on the southern island of Jolo, an area of recent fighting between government forces and Islamist militants. Colonel Brawner said the Americans were noncombatants helping to supervise a school-building project. Their names were not immediately released.

SAFIRE--William. The "Wednesday Ten" mourns the passing of our founder and inspiring leader, Bill Safire. It was over 50 years ago that Bill got the idea of bringing together a group of young men who had come to New York to build their careers. The "rules" were simple: we would meet once a month (often with accomplished guests); there would be no more than two from each profession or calling; we would tell one another about our work and our lives; we would teach one another about the world as we saw it and the opportunities it presented. From that humble beginning sprang a group who continued to meet together, though less frequently, right up to today. It bred lifelong friendships, much learning of the ways of the world and produced a host of successful people. Now, over 50 years later, we have lost the man who conceived the idea, brought us together and continued to lead us in the ways of friendship, knowledge and success. We will miss Bill Safire profoundly. We will miss his erudition, his wit and his teaching. The best thing we can do in his memory is to seek to keep our group going until, over time, we all join Bill in his new venue where we are sure the table will be laid and he will be waiting for us with his wry smile. Howard Amron Stanley Bartels Fred Berman Thomas Bishop Edward Bleier Paul Chan Joseph Forman Roy Goodman Arthur Gray Larry Grossman Mort Janklow Morton Lacher George Lang Robert Lifton Marshall Loeb Robert Menschel Edward Meyer Thomas Morgan Marvin Newman Leon Root James Rosenfield Charles Sigety Leonard Zweig

To prepare for the National Day holiday, retailers here have been stocking up on merchandise like designer bags, gold jewelry -- and banned books. Big downtown bookstores and airport kiosks alike carry paperbacks detailing the latest gossip about Communist Party cadres. More serious fare can be found at the city's tiny ''upstairs'' political bookstores tucked above ground-floor storefronts. Inside are stacks of books on the Cultural Revolution, the Great Leap Forward, the Tiananmen Square crackdown of 1989 and almost everything else Beijing does not want people reading.

When President Obama looks at the screen in the Situation Room on Wednesday, he will find a face he has not seen lately except in newspapers. There, via secure video from Kabul, will be Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, his commander in Afghanistan, explaining directly to the president for the first time why more troops are needed. General McChrystal has not spoken with Mr. Obama since submitting his grim assessment of the war a month ago and has spoken with him only once in the 100 days since he took command of all American and NATO forces in Afghanistan. The lack of direct communication has generated criticism and fueled suspicions of strains between the White House and Kabul.

To many Americans, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's February 2003 speech to the United Nations on Iraq's unconventional weapons was powerfully persuasive. It was a dazzling performance, featuring satellite images and intercepts of Iraqi communications, delivered by one of the most trusted figures in public life. Then a long and costly war began, and the country discovered that the assertions that Iraq possessed illicit weapons had been completely unfounded.

CLASSIC potato salads range from the American picnic favorite made with mayo and little else, to the more elegant French version with warm waxy potatoes, a good vinaigrette and herbs. Both of these have their place, but for those wanting something less traditional, look to the Southwest. Start with sweet potatoes, which are in season, beautiful and cheap, and roast them with red onion and olive oil. Roasting instead of boiling makes a huge difference: not only do you get a rich, smoky flavor, but the peeled exterior is toughened a bit so that the potatoes stay intact when tossed with the other ingredients.

When the first new authorized tale of Winnie-the-Pooh in more than 80 years is released on Monday, the book will introduce a new, female character to that bothersome bear’s mostly male entourage. The new character, called Lottie the Otter, will make her debut in “Return to the Hundred Acre Wood,” written by David Benedictus and illustrated by Mark Burgess, and approved by the Pooh Trustees. In a news release, the Dutton Children’s Books imprint of Penguin Young Readers Group, which is releasing the book on Oct. 5, described Lottie as “a smart and elegant character” who is “always dressed in pearls,” and who “has her own ideas about how things should be done and believes that everyone should follow the correct etiquette.” In the course of “Return to the Hundred Acre Wood,” the publisher said, Lottie takes a swim in Christopher Robin’s bath, helps to set up a school for the denizens of the Hundred Acre Wood, and turns out to be great at cricket.

This post contains spoilers.Poor Lea Michele. It’s one thing to play the ingénue to Kristin Chenoweth’s dipsomaniac belter, which is what she had to do Wednesday night on the fifth episode of “Glee.” It’s quite another to have the show cut back and forth between you and her as you both sing “Maybe This Time” from “Cabaret.” Ms. Michele is a fine singer, but really. We’re talking about Kristin Chenoweth. It felt like there should have been a mercy rule, so they could call it off before anyone had to sing “Everybody … loves a winner …”

The number of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender characters has grown in recent years on prime-time network television, but decreased on cable, the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation said. For its recently published “Where We Are On TV” study, the alliance reviewed 79 scripted comedies and dramas announced to air on the broadcast networks during the 2009-2010 season, and found that of 600 series regulars on these shows, 18 are lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender. The study said that ABC has the most such characters, with 8 out of 168 total series regulars; Fox has four (including cartoon characters from “The Simpsons” and “American Dad”), NBC has three, CW has two and CBS has none. In its review of mainstream cable channels, including HBO, Showtime, Comedy Central, AMC and others, the alliance found that the number of series regulars who are lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender decreased this year to 25 from 32 last year. When the gay-oriented cable channels here! and Logo were accounted for, the study said, an additional 27 such characters were added to the tally.

Updated | 4:35 p.m. TLC said Thursday that it had suspended filming of the Gosselin children on its hit reality series “Jon & Kate Plus 8,” after a lawyer for Jon Gosselin told the cable channel in a letter that that production crews were forbidden from entering the Gosselin family home.

The Richard Prince exhibition “Spiritual America,” which was planned to open Thursday at the Tate Modern museum in London, was withdrawn Wednesday, following a warning from Scotland Yard that its inclusion of a nude photograph of Brooke Shields taken when she was 10 years could violate obscenity laws, The Guardian reported. The exhibition was to be shown as part of the gallery’s program Pop Life: Art in a Material World, but was closed off from display after newspaper reviews of the exhibition drew the attention of the Metropolitan police. The photograph, which was included in “Spiritual America” when it was shown at the Guggenheim Museum in 2007, was taken by Mr. Prince from another that photograph was made by Gary Gross in 1976 and authorized by Ms. Shields’s mother. Scotland Yard told The Guardian that the actions of its officers were “common sense.” A spokeswoman for the Tate Modern said that the display had been “temporarily closed down” and that the catalog for the exhibition had been withdrawn from sale.

Updated | 3:12 p.m. The Broadway cast of “Billy Elliot the Musical” is about to lose another cast member who plays the title character — only this time it’s someone who has reached the age of majority. Stephen Hanna, the former New York City Ballet dancer who portrays the role of Billy’s older self in that musical, will rejoin the company of City Ballet as a guest artist for its coming 2009-2010 winter season. In a news release, City Ballet said on Thursday that Mr. Hanna, who departed for the Broadway show last year, will assume his former rank as principal dancer when he returns to the company. Mr. Hanna joined the corps of City Ballet in 1997; he was promoted to soloist in 2004 and made a principal dancer in 2005. A press representative for City Ballet said that Mr. Hanna would depart “Billy Elliot” at the end of October. A representative for the Broadway musical confirmed Mr. Hanna’s departure and said that a replacement for him had not yet been determined.

Marina Zenovich, the director of the HBO documentary “Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired,” said Thursday that she was “perplexed by the timing” of remarks by David Wells, a former deputy district attorney who said in her film that he had coached the judge presiding over Mr. Polanski’s 1978 trial, but who now says he made it all up.

It’s not often that fans of “Theater Talk” and “Monday Night Football” converge, but that just might happen at “Fantasy Football: The Musical?,” a show making its world premiere at the New York Musical Theater Festival.

The multimedia revue of the life and work of Stephen Sondheim that fizzled earlier this year at the Alliance Theater of Atlanta will be plugged back in on Broadway by Roundabout Theater Company. On Thursday, Roundabout said that it would produce “Sondheim on Sondheim,” a project with music and lyrics by Mr. Sondheim, conceived and directed by his frequent collaborator James Lapine. This new work will star Barbara Cook, a Tony Award winner for “The Music Man” (and nominee for her 2002 concert event “Mostly Sondheim”) in her first Broadway musical in more than 37 years, as well as Vanessa Williams (a Tony nominee for “Into the Woods”), Leslie Kritzer (“Rooms: A Rock Romance”) and Michael Arden, with additional cast members to be announced shortly. “Sondheim on Sondheim” is to begin previews on Studio 54 on March 19 with an official opening of April 22. Its limited run concludes on June 13. A roster of songs was not immediately announced. The project at the Alliance Theater, called “iSondheim,” was to have featured music from shows including “Gypsy,” “West Side Story” and “Sweeney Todd,” but was canceled due to fund-raising difficulties.

For Western pop acts booked in China, it’s never completely certain whether the gig will actually take place; last-minute, unexplained cancellations by government authorities are common, and the crackdown has been severe since last year, when Bjork chanted “Tibet, Tibet!” at a concert in Shanghai.

How do you cram the entire career of Stephen Sondheim into a single show? James Lapine might have the answer, having collaborated with Mr. Sondheim on musicals like “Sunday in the Park With George,” “Into the Woods” and “Passion.” Mr. Lapine is also responsible for conceiving and directing “Sondheim on Sondheim,” a Broadway revue of Mr. Sondheim’s work that was announced on Thursday but has been long in the making.

LOS ANGELES – Michael Jackson’s official autopsy report indicated that the surgical anesthetic propofol in combination with three other sedatives probably stopped the pop star’s breathing and killed him, said an anesthesiologist who reviewed the document.

Updated | 1:41 p.m. If you were planning to see Kanye West and Lady Gaga together, better hope you saved that recording of the MTV Video Music Awards on your TiVo. A national concert tour featuring Mr. West and Lady Gaga has been canceled, The Associated Press reported. The concert promoter Live Nation was to produce the tour, which was to be called “Fame Kills” and run from November through January, but on Thursday announced that all dates had been canceled. Lady Gaga told Billboard magazine that the cancellation of the tour had been a “mutual decision” made by her and Mr. West, adding: “Kanye’s going to take some time off. But the good news is that I’m going on tour in a few weeks.” Live Nation said that ticket holders would receive refunds.

First there was fiction, then there was a scene, now there’s another book: “The Taqwacores: Muslim Punk in the U.S.A.,” by the New York-based photographer and journalist Kim Badawi. The book, published by Brooklyn-based powerHouse Books, is a collection of images that he took while traveling with four Taqwacore bands on tour in August 2007. Prints from the book are on display at powerHouse’s gallery space in DUMBO where Mr. Badawi will participate in a talk about the movement on Saturday.

China celebrates 60 years of Communist Party rule this week. But devotion to a socialist ideology seems to have been replaced by pride in rising standards of living and the ability to go shopping, at least in the glittering precincts of Shanghai and Beijing. The Chinese government is expanding subsidies for consumer spending on home appliances. Retail sales during the eight-day national holiday are expected to soar, and 560 million people are expected to travel in China during this holiday week.

China dominates the show today - and that was the point of its vast parade in Beijing to celebrate the country's 60th anniversary (Slides 1, 2 and 3). As The Times reported earlier this week, no detail was overlooked in the meticulous preparation for China's National Day. Soldiers practiced endless hours to hold their rifles at precisely the same level, some with needles in their shirt collars, pointed at their necks, to correct poor posture. The result was a dazzling and precise spectacle. And the chaos continued (Slides 4 and 5) as the death toll rose to 1,100 from the quake that hit a village in Sumatra on Wednesday evening. Many hundreds more were injured.

Abortion -- the politically volatile issue that the Senate Finance Committee grappled with Wednesday in the context of federally subsidized medical insurance -- remains a divisive topic. In T's current fall travel issue, the Times style reporter Guy Trebay reports on Instituto Cultural Inhotim, a 3,000-plus-acre park in southeastern Brazil where a pig-iron magnate has assembled one of the world's most extraordinary collections of contemporary art. Inhotim lies outside the small town of Brumadinho in the state of Minas Gerais, not far from the metropolis Belo Horizonte, far off the radar of most international travelers. So we asked Trebay to tell us more about his trip - and some of what lies beyond the wonders of Inhotim itself.

Seeing Things is a biweekly design column by Brooke Hodge, a design writer and curator based in Los Angeles.The Los Angeles-based potter Adam Silverman's ceramic vessels are known for their distinctive shapes, unusual colors, pitted surfaces and lava-like glazes. Last year, after becoming studio director for the venerable Northern California company Heath Ceramics, Silverman traded in his cozy Atwater Village studio for an open, airy space connected to Heath's Los Angeles shop, which opened in January. Silverman still makes pieces under his own Atwater Pottery label, but he has also begun working with Heath's signature forms and glaze colors to expand the company's repertory to contemporary pieces.

In one of those periodic mood swings, Nicolas Ghesquiere today took Balenciaga back to the streets. The clothes had a hard urban edge, beginning with hooded vests that combined leather and leather woven with other materials for an industrial texture. Ankle boots repeated the illusion. Last season, in the same gold-and-cream salon at the Crillon hotel, Mr. Ghesquiere offered a kind of "Belle de Jour" elegance, all drapery and fancy black stockings. Yesterday, after the Rochas show, Agnès Boulard - French television's feisty Mademoiselle Agnès - and her collaborator Loïc Prigent were needling me for predictions. Would the French spring ready-to-wear collections be more frigid lady or cool street?

PARIS | In a corner of Le Bon Marché, a bright and glittering Parisian department store, is an unlikely display with enough emotional power to pull shoppers right out of their consumer reverie: a provocative exhibition of films by the visionary fashion photographer Guy Bourdin."Guy Bourdin Ses Films," showing through Oct. 29, is a mesmerizing exploration into the visual and intellectual world of the artist, made possible by Samuel Bourdin, who is working to maintain his father's estate and legacy -- despite the photographer's famous last wish that all his work be destroyed after his death, in 1991.
