All I can say is "thank goodness we're back at Suzuka" after a two year absence. The Mount Fuji circuit just didn't cut it in very many ways at all. The one thing that was nice about Fuji has now been accomplished by Suzuka: The paddock itself in Mount Fuji was an easier place to work in, for the teams, the media, the paddock club, the whole thing. But upon returning today to Suzuka the teams and media and others have found a transformed circuit. Thank goodness there's no much they can do to change the track, since Suzuka remains a sensational track. But they have given a complete makeover of the pitlane garages and the paddock behind the pitlane.

FRONT PAGE.

An obituary on Sept. 18 about Willy Ronis, a noted photographer of Paris scenes, misidentified the site from which he took a picture of a pair of lovers. It was the July Column, the tower commemorating the July Revolution of 1830 that overlooks the Place de la Bastille; it was not the tower of the Bastille, the prison destroyed in the French Revolution. The obituary also misidentified his first book. It was “Photo-Reportage: The Hunt for Images,” a description of his work published in 1951 — not “Belleville-Ménilmontant,” published in 1954, which was his first collection of photos.
Mr. Bellmon was a former Oklahoma governor and U.S. senator and a leading figure in Richard M. Nixon’s 1968 presidential campaign.
A music review on Monday about a concert featuring works by Mario Diaz de León, at Roulette in SoHo, rendered his surname incorrectly. It is Diaz de León, not de León.

A music review on Wednesday about the violinist Jennifer Koh’s performance of Bach’s Partita No. 2 in D minor, at Columbia University’s Philosophy Hall, misstated the number of partitas Bach wrote for solo violin. It is three, not six. (His six works for solo violin include three sonatas along with the partitas.).

An article on Sept. 22 about the shows that won the most Emmy Awards this year, including the PBS presentation of the mini-series “Little Dorrit,” misstated that show’s viewership. PBS estimated that 9.6 million people viewed some portion of the five-part series, not that the five episodes were viewed by a total of 9.6 million. It also estimated that an average of 3.5 million people watched each episode, not 1.9 million. The article thus also misstated the ratio of the number of viewers of the Emmy Awards ceremony to the average audience for “Little Dorrit.” The Emmy audience, nearly 13.5 million, was almost four times as large, not seven.
A managed funds group told lawmakers that, unlike big banks, hedge funds do not pose a systemic risk to the economy.
The man charged with killing an abortion protester last month in Owosso, Mich., and another man the same day, has been deemed incompetent to stand trial, prosecutors said.

A picture caption with an article in some editions on Monday about questions over whether New York City’s political runoff system is superfluous referred imprecisely to the candidate who defeated Mario A. Procaccino, a Democrat, in the 1969 mayoral election, the last one before the runoff system was adopted. Although the winning candidate, Mayor John V. Lindsay, was a Republican at the time, he ran on the Liberal-Fusion line that year, not the Republican one.

An article in some editions on Tuesday about the latest census figures on family income and poverty in the New York region misstated the 2007 and 2008 poverty rates for Connecticut and one of its largely suburban counties, Fairfield. The statewide rate was 9.3 percent in 2008, up from 7.9 percent in 2007 — not 24.2 percent and 21.3 percent. The Fairfield County rate was 8.5 percent in 2008, up from 6.6 percent in 2007 — not 20 percent and 15 percent.

An article on Wednesday about the firings of 1,800 immigrant workers by a Los Angeles garment maker, American Apparel, because of irregularities in their identity documents misstated the number of garments the company produces each week in Los Angeles. It is 800,000, not 250,000.

An article and an accompanying picture caption last Thursday about the spread of organic gardening at Harvard referred incompletely to the Rev. Peter J. Gomes, whose residence, Treadwell-Sparks House, is part of the project. He is more widely known as the longtime minister at the university’s Memorial Church, not just as a professor and a minister. The caption also referred imprecisely to the location of his residence. It is considered part of the campus; Mr. Gomes does not live “near Harvard.”.

Carnegie Hall and the Boston Symphony Orchestra have found a new conductor for Thursday night’s season-opening gala. He is Daniele Gatti, right, who is in New York for performances of Verdi’s “Aida” at the Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Gatti will replace James Levine, the Boston Symphony’s music director, who had to withdraw because of surgery for a herniated disk. Mr. Gatti is music director of the Orchestra National de France and chief conductor of the Zurich Opera. The program will remain the same, said Carnegie’s spokeswoman, Synneve Carlino, except for Berlioz’s “Roman Carnaval,” which will be replaced by Beethoven’s “Coriolan” Overture. ...Edo de Waart, the music director of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra, will conduct the Metropolitan Opera’s performances of “Der Rosenkavalier” on Oct. 13, 16, and 19, in place of Mr. Levine, the Met said on Wednesday. Mr. Levine is expected to return in time for the Met’s new production of “Les Contes d’Hoffmann,” which opens on Dec. 3.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Wednesday announced five programs to support the 1,400 nonprofit groups, 40,000 employees and “countless artists” making up New York City’s cultural sector. The city plans to provide indoor and outdoor space for art exhibitions, specialized job training, financial counseling to cultural institutions and artists, and $25,000 grants to two art “clusters” in city neighborhoods. The sector generates more than $5.8 billion in economic impact through direct spending, according to the city. The programs, which will be administered by the New York City Economic Development Corporation and the Department of Cultural Affairs, build on a set of plans announced in April to help all of the city’s nonprofit organizations survive the economic downturn.

While the merry bells will keep ringing for the musical “Irving Berlin’s White Christmas,” the show will ring in a new cast when it returns to Broadway in November. Press representatives for the musical, which is adapted from the 1954 “White Christmas” film with even more Berlin tunes, said that its principal cast would feature James Clow (of “Assassins” and “Wonderful Town”) in the Bing Crosby role; Melissa Errico, above (“Amour”), in the Rosemary Clooney role and Tony Yazbeck (“Gypsy”) in the Danny Kaye role. This latest Broadway run of “White Christmas,” which is directed by Walter Bobbie, will begin previews at the Marquis Theater on Nov. 13. Its limited run ends Jan. 3.

A typical talk-back session after a play involves performers and creative-team members answering questions from audience members. But the Broadway transfer of the David Mamet play “Oleanna” is taking a different approach: among the guests who will field inquiries after the drama, about a possible act of sexual harassment by a university professor against his female student, will be Anucha Browne Sanders, above, a former senior marketing executive for the New York Knicks who sued the team and Madison Square Garden, alleging sexual harassment. Ms. Browne Sanders, who won an $11.5 million settlement in 2007, is scheduled to appear at a talk-back on Tuesday, after that evening’s preview performance of “Oleanna” at the Golden Theater. Guests scheduled for coming sessions include former Mayor David N. Dinkins (on Oct. 9), the talk show host Montel Williams (Oct. 10, evening performance) and the outgoing “Law & Order: Criminal Intent” star Kathryn Erbe (Oct. 17, evening performance). “Oleanna,” which stars Bill Pullman and Julia Stiles, began previews on Tuesday and is to have its official opening on Oct. 11.

When you have starred in one of the most successful television comedies of recent years as well as its less-than-beloved spinoff, what do you do for an encore? Get meta. Matt LeBlanc, who followed 10 seasons on the NBC series “Friends” with 46 episodes of the solo project “Joey,” will return to television in a new show in which he will play a satirical version of himself. The show, “Episodes,” will be jointly produced by Showtime and the BBC, they said on Wednesday in a news release, and is created by David Crane (a co-creator of “Friends”) and Jeffrey Klarik. It will focus on a British couple whose hit comedy is reworked for American television in a watered-down version starring Mr. LeBlanc. In a statement, Mr. LeBlanc said he was glad he got the role because “seeing someone else play Matt LeBlanc would have been devastating.” “Episodes” will be produced in London and Los Angeles and will have its debut on Showtime and BBC Two next year.

Be prepared for what could be the shortest, punchiest acceptance speech in PEN history: The literary organization PEN USA said on Wednesday that it would give its Lifetime Achievement Award to Elmore Leonard, the prolific crime fiction novelist. The award will be presented to Mr. Leonard at a ceremony in Beverly Hills on Dec. 2. At that time, the organization will also hand out honors in other categories, including a prize for fiction, given to Kim Barnes for “A Country Called Home”; creative nonfiction, given to Steve Lopez for “The Soloist”; research nonfiction, awarded to Leslie T. Chang for “Factory Girls”; and screenplay, given to Dustin Lance Black for “Milk.”.

Despite limited distribution, Pearl Jam’s “Backspacer” (Monkeywrench) was the best-selling album in the United States last week. Available only at Target stores, iTunes, small record shops and the band’s Web site (pearljam.com), “Backspacer” sold 189,000 copies its first week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan, opening at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. Jay-Z’s “Blueprint 3” (Roc Nation/Atlantic) fell to No. 2 after two weeks on top, with 134,000 sales. The Canadian rock band Three Days Grace was in third place with its new “Life Starts Now” (Jive), which sold 79,000. Other high-charting new releases included “Daisy” (Interscope) by the Long Island group Brand New, at No. 6 with 46,000; Five Finger Death Punch’s “War Is the Answer” (Prospect Park), at No. 7 with 44,000; and Harry Connick Jr.’s “Your Songs” (Sony), at No. 8 with 37,000. Whitney Houston’s “I Look to You” (Arista) was No. 4 with 66,000 sales, and Miley Cyrus’s mini-album “Time of Our Lives” (Hollywood), sold through Wal-Mart, was No. 5 with 61,000.

The one-two punch of “NCIS” and “NCIS: Los Angeles” once again lifted CBS far ahead of its competitors in the ratings on Tuesday night. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “NCIS” drew 20.6 million viewers a week after its debut, when it was the most watched show on television. “NCIS: Los Angeles” attracted 17.4 million viewers. ABC was runner-up on the night with a lineup that included “Dancing With the Stars” (12.5 million). At 10 p.m., the new CBS series “The Good Wife” (13.4 million) easily dominated “The Forgotten” on ABC (7.5 million) and “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC (6.6 million). NBC finished third, followed by Fox with “Hell’s Kitchen” (6.5 million) and “So You Think You Can Dance” (5.3 million).

BENDHEIM--Maxine Asch, of Scarsdale, NY on September 28, 2009. Beloved wife for 58 years of John and loving and devoted mother of her four children John Jr., Andrew, Tom and Joanna Schulman and their spouses. Survived by her brother, Gordon Asch, and nine grandchildren whom she loved dearly. An active member of the community, giving herself to organizations such as the JCC of Mid-Westchester and Quaker Ridge Golf Club. Her lifelong devotion to family and friends serves as an inspiration to all. Funeral services will be held Friday, October 2, 12:30pm at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Marmaroneck Rd, Scarsdale, NY. Contributions may be made to White Plains Hospital or Westchester Jewish Community Services.

FLEISCHER--Steven J.,65, of Rosegarden Street, Warwick, RI, and formerly of New York City, NY, died on Wednesday, September 30, 2009 at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence, RI. Born in New York City, the son of the late Samuel and Betty (Sheldon) Fleischer, he lived in New York for most of his life. Mr. Fleischer was a teacher at the Co-Op City School in the Bronx section of New York City for 25 years, retiring in 2001. He was a devoted and much-loved teacher. He was a history buff. He is survived by a sister, Joyce L. Simon of Warwick, RI; and a niece, Robin M. Simon of Rehoboth, MA. His funeral services will be private. Services by Barrett & Cotter Funeral Home, Warwick, RI.

ROSENBERG--Florence. The members of the NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases Department of Orthopaedic Surgery mourn the untimely passing of Florence Rosenberg, devoted mother of our valued colleague and friend, Dr. Andrew Rosenberg. Dr. Rosenberg, Chairman of the Department of Anesthesiology is a longstanding physician leader in our institution and has served with distinction for many years. Florence Rosenberg leaves a grieving family and friends who will remember her for her kindness and devotion to her family. We mourn her passing as we celebrate her life and extend our heartfelt condolences, at this difficult time, to her sons Andrew, Leon and Mitchell and to the entire family. Joseph D. Zuckerman, MD, Chairman William Jaffe, MD, Vice Chair Joseph Bosco, MD, Vice Chair Clinical Affairs Kenneth Egol, MD, Vice Chair Education
VOLPE--Robert P.,died September 26, 2009. Beloved husband, grandfather, father, and brother-in-law.

Nike announced Wednesday that it would resign from the board of the United States Chamber of Commerce, becoming the latest company to break with the group over climate policy. Nike said, however, that it would remain a member of the chamber, unlike three large utilities -- Pacific Gas and Electric, PNM Resources and Exelon -- which recently announced plans to pull out.

A United States service member was killed when a suicide car bomber struck a military convoy on Wednesday morning in eastern Afghanistan, according to allied officials and provincial authorities. Lt. Tommy Groves of the Navy, a spokesman in Kabul for the United States military, confirmed the service member's death in a telephone interview. The attack took place about 8 a.m. on a highway just a few miles south of Khost, said Col. Yaqoob Khan, the security chief for Khost Province. ''All we know is one of their armored vehicles was destroyed in the attack,'' Colonel Khan said. No civilians or members of Afghan security forces were wounded, he added. The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack, Reuters reported.

IVANHOE--Morris (Scotty), on September 29, 2009 at age 92. Beloved husband of Sylvia for 67 years. Adored father of Nora Freedman, Linda Jacob, Robert Ivanhoe and brother of Leonard Ivanhoe. Eddy Curry's streak of misfortune and misery continued when doctors discovered a torn calf muscle that will sideline him for three to five days. He will miss the Knicks' preseason opener Sunday. The torn plantaris muscle is present in about 40 percent of the population and is not needed. Once he recovers from the injury, the calf should be fine, the team said. Curry missed most of last season because of injuries and poor conditioning. He lost more than 40 pounds over the summer, providing some hope that he might become an effective player again.

Liberal opposition to Senators Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Finance Committee, and Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, has intensified since the two voted against a government-run insurance plan, or public option, on Tuesday. Two groups, Progressive Change Campaign Committee and Democracy for America, vowed to raise money and run advertisements against the two senators in hopes of pressuring them to vote for a public option when the legislation reaches the Senate floor, which could be as early as the week after next.

8:30 P.M. (TV5Monde) FALAFEL (2006) In his feature-film debut, Michel Kammoun tells the story of a young Lebanese man (Elie Mitri) who discovers, as he wanders the streets of Beirut on the way to a party, that a ''normal'' life is a luxury beyond reach. In ''A Lost Man'' (2007), above, at 9 on the Sundance Channel, the director Danielle Arbid contemplates the Western presence in the Middle East in this tale about the encounter between Thomas (Melvil Poupaud), a French photojournalist on a road trip in Syria and Jordan, and Fouad (Alexander Siddiq), an itinerant Lebanese with a mysterious past. Thomas wants Fouad to act as his translator and to help him with a project: to photograph himself having sex with scores of random women. 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOWNicholas D. Kristof, a columnist for The New York Times, and his wife, Sheryl WuDunn, a former reporter and editor for The Times, discuss changing the world by empowering girls living in poverty.

WAITERS hoisted bottles of Champagne with sparklers plunged into the corks; demiclad young visitors danced on banquettes, their improvised antics captured by cameras; others tossed back tequila and rang up four-figure tabs. That cheerfully dissolute scene, reminiscent of party nights in Miami Beach or St-Tropez, was in fact played out on a recent Saturday at Bagatelle in the meatpacking district in Manhattan, home to a weekly bacchanal masquerading as a brunch. By midafternoon, the restaurant, with its Old World woodwork and chandeliers, teemed with young Europeans and New Yorkers shedding their proprieties along with their coats. Some of the men were turned out in T-shirts, while their female companions flaunted sequins, stilettos and lots of flesh -- the better to catch the eye, perhaps, of a promising mogul or banker.

WILDERNESS campers are well aware that backcountry travel necessitates some discomfort, even when it comes to drinking water. For years, they bungled with slow, cumbersome filters and endured the flavor of iodine. But in recent years, new water-treatment products have made it simpler to treat water in the wild, while making the water itself tastier. ''Filters have gotten much, much, much easier to operate, and you get greater flow rates,'' said Frank Kosco, the water-treatment product buyer at Campmor, an outdoor-equipment retailer. ''The resistance on the pump isn't as tough as it used to be, and you get longer life from the filters.''

The recession is driving up enrollment in Medicaid at higher-than-expected rates, threatening gargantuan state budget gaps even as Congress and the White House seek to expand the program, according to a survey released Wednesday. The annual survey of state Medicaid directors, conducted for the Kaiser Family Foundation's Commission on Medicaid and the Uninsured, found that the program, which insures the poor and the disabled, had been spared the worst effects of huge state budget shortfalls because of federal aid in the stimulus package. But it also revealed grave concerns about what will happen when that relief dries up at the close of 2010.

All the versions of health care bills now in Congress would require all but the smallest employers to provide health care coverage or pay into a government pool to help provide coverage for the otherwise uninsured. Critics predict that many businesses would simply drop health benefits because it would be cheaper to pay the new tax. The steepest of the proposed penalties, one under consideration in the House, would assess most businesses a tax of 8 percent of payroll. The cost of providing employee health insurance is typically 12 percent of payroll, according to the Congressional Budget Office.

SAFIRE--William. The staff of the Dictionary of American Regional English and its Board of Visitors honor the memory of our colleague and friend William Safire. Bill introduced the readers of "On Language" to DARE, which he called "the most exciting linguistic project going on in the United States." His frequent references to the Dictionary contributed significantly to its success. We value his service on DARE's Board of Visitors and celebrate his ability to play with language and embrace the wonders of American English.

In a bizarre twist to Roman Polanski's renewed legal fight over a 32-year-old sex case, a retired deputy district attorney who triggered claims of official corruption by telling a documentary filmmaker he had coached a judge in the case now says he made it all up. ''I've got to tell you, I lied,'' the former prosecutor, David Wells, said Wednesday. ''I tried to butter up this story to make me look better.'' Mr. Wells's recantation was first posted by Marcia Clark, a former Los Angeles district attorney who prosecuted the O. J. Simpson murder case, on The Daily Beast Web site. Chad Hummel, a lawyer for Mr. Polanski, declined to comment on the recantation. Sandi Gibbons, a spokeswoman for the Los Angeles county district attorney's office, said: ''Anything we have to say will be in legal pleadings or in court.'' Mr. Wells said he had informed the district attorney's office of his lie several months ago, and offered to make a formal statement, though none was taken. Mr. Wells said he was publicly recanting now, in order to clear his actions away from other issues in the Polanski case.

Media attention to a recent spate of suicides at France Télécom has revealed a paradox at the heart of French society: even with robust labor protection, workers feel profoundly insecure, with many complaining that the pace of economic change is pushing them beyond their limits. A popular image outside France is of a cosseted work force protected from layoffs by near-hermetic job security and pampered by a 35-hour workweek. But the reality is often different, according to experts, union representatives and the workers themselves.

With time running out, Congress passed a stopgap measure to keep the federal government operating for another month while it struggled to finish nearly a dozen overdue spending bills. The interim spending bill was needed since the current fiscal year ended at midnight. In the absence of the annual spending measures, the federal government technically would have no authority to spend any money on anything, including the military. The bill, approved in the Senate by 62 to 38, continues spending for most federal agencies at current levels. The House passed the bill Friday.

The Philadelphia Phillies had already clinched their third consecutive National League East title Wednesday night before Brad Lidge threw his first pitch in the ninth inning, but there was no one else Manager Charlie Manuel wanted on the mound. Lidge needed only that one pitch to wrap up a 10-3 victory against the visiting Houston Astros, a spot of good karma for a team facing some problems as it defends its World Series title. Lidge, who lost his closer's role last week, recorded the final out of the Phillies' division-clinching win last season, and Manuel called on him with two outs in the ninth inning Wednesday. He was the final member of a bullpen that pitched five scoreless innings in relief of Pedro Martinez, who threw an inefficient 84 pitches over four innings.

At 60 acres, Prospect Park Lake would seem to be big enough for two pairs of swans. And for a while, it was. One pair kept to the south end, and the other stuck around the northern half, their white feathers contrasting with the greens and browns of the park, to the delight of picnickers and wedding parties. But this year, both pairs had families, and that neighborly dynamic came to a fast -- and surprisingly violent -- halt.

MALONEY--Clifton H. W. Maloney, 71, passed away on September 25th on Cho Oyu Mountain located between the boarder of Nepal and China. He had reached the 27,000 ft summit on the morning of September 24th, making him the oldest American to ever summit an 8,000 meter peak. He spent that night at Base Camp 3 and arrived the following day at Base Camp 2 at 23,000 feet where he died in his sleep. His last words were, "I'm the happiest man in the world. I've just summited a beautiful mountain." Born in Philadelphia on October 15, 1937, Mr. Maloney graduated from Princeton University in 1960, Harvard Business School in 1965, and served in the U.S. Navy from 1960-1963. An investment banker and real estate investor, Mr. Maloney worked at several financial services companies, including The City Management Corp, Electronic Bond and Share Company, and New York Securities Co., Inc. In 1974, he became a Vice President of Goldman, Sachs & Co. In 1981, he founded his own company, C.H.W. Maloney & Co., Incorporated, to acquire established businesses for long term investment. Mr. Maloney served as a director of several companies, including The Wall Street Fund, Inc. and Interpool Limited. Mr. Maloney was a dedicated marathon runner who had finished the New York Marathon 20 times and in 2008 finished as the fastest American in his age group. He enjoyed sailing and was a member of the New York Yacht Club. Deeply committed to the quality of life in his local community, Mr. Maloney was on the Board of Civitas and the New York Foundation for Senior Citizens and was active in Carnegie Hill Neighbors. He was the Annual Giving Class Agent for the Princeton Class of 1960 and was proud to report more than 70% class participation. He was an avid mountain climber having climbed five of the Seven Summits (including Mount Elbrus, Aconcagua, Mount Vinson, Denali, and Mount Kilimanjaro). In addition, he climbed Orizaba, Mexico's highest volcano. He was a member of the Explorer's Club and the American Alpine Club. His passion for mountain climbing and an equally great passion for boats of all sorts stemmed from his experiences as a lifelong summer resident of Blue Mt. Lake in the Adirondacks. Mr. Maloney is survived by his wife, Congresswoman Carolyn Jane Bosher Maloney to whom he was married in 1976, his daughters, Christina Paul Maloney and Virginia Marshall Maloney, his mother, Virginia Wells Maloney, his sister, Virginia Maloney Lawrence, and eight nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Clifton H.W. Maloney Scholarship Fund at Princeton University, the Explorer's Club or the American Alpine Club. The funeral will be held next Friday, at 11am on October 9th, 2009, at the Brick Church on Park Avenue between East 91st and East 92nd Streets in Manhattan.

It is not easy to get swept by the worst team in baseball, but leave it to the Mets to find a way. Needing three outs to complete a 4-2 victory Wednesday against the Nationals in Washington, the Mets turned the game over to closer Francisco Rodriguez, who gave up a two-out, full-count, bases-loaded home run to the rookie Justin Maxwell. Final score: Nationals 7, Mets 4. In addition to losing a third straight game to the Nationals, the Mets announced that shortstop Jose Reyes had further damaged his injured hamstring and will almost certainly need surgery. The Mets' season long ago turned into a blur of injuries and mind-boggling defeats, and Wednesday was just the latest example.

Nothing like spending your birthday immersed in the Great Health Care Debate of 2009. Can you any longer read Henry James or George Eliot? Do you have the patience? MARYANNE WOLF, a professor of child development at Tufts University. [A4]

SIMSON--Jerome, died of complications from Alzheimer's Disease on September 29th. He is survived by his devoted companion, Ellen Monness, his children, Pamela, Betsy, Peter and Emily and his granddaughters, Alexandra, Sydney, Laura and Georgina. A graduate of Swarthmore College and NYU Medical School, Jerry practiced Rheumatology and Internal Medicine until his retirement ten years ago. He was an outstanding diagnostician, a great listener beloved by his patients, and he was invited to speak at medical conferences around the world. Jerry had an appointment to NYU Medical School and he created and developed the Arthritis Group for Jamaica Hospital in the 1950s. A natural athlete, Jerry excelled at four sports at different times throughout his life. At Swarthmore, as pitcher for the baseball team, his performance once inspired the headline "Simson Beats Penn!" As goalie for the soccer team he was named to Little All-American. During his service in the army he was recruited as a starting player for the basketball team with teammates who went on to become professional athletes. Later in life Jerry took up tennis and became singles champion of his tennis club. He took particular delight in coaching family and friends. He was an extraordinary teacher and his understanding and love of the game made all of us better players. Jerry was an avid reader who could quote the classics with ease. It is believed that he coined the phrase "for free." A wonderful friend to so many--loving, caring, connected and always on call, Jerry had a reputation as a gentleman of the first order. We will miss him beyond words. Service will be private. Visitors will be received on Sunday, 2:00-5:00 at 254 East 68th Street, Apt 14B. Donations may be made to Visiting Nurse Service of NY Hospice Care, 1250 Broadway, New York, NY 10001.

In a push to lock down votes, Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Finance Committee, is pulling together changes to his health care bill intended to address the chief concern among Democrats: that health insurance be made as affordable as possible for moderate-income Americans. Among the proposals under consideration is an amendment by Senator Maria Cantwell, Democrat of Washington, that would create a ''basic health plan'' for Americans earning less than 200 percent of the federal poverty level, or $44,100 for a family of four. The proposal would let states develop or expand various existing insurance programs that now typically cover people who qualify for Medicaid. Small states could develop joint plans.

A typhoon headed west toward Laos on Wednesday after battering central Vietnam with powerful winds and heavy rain, leaving behind blue and sunny skies but dangerously rising floodwaters. The official death toll in Vietnam was placed at 41, but officials said that number was expected to rise. The storm was already weakening as it headed toward Laos, weather stations reported. The damage in Vietnam was far less than in the Philippines, where the typhoon was reported to have caused 246 deaths.

YANGON, Myanmar -- U Win Tin, Myanmar's longest-serving political prisoner, was tormented, tortured and beaten by his captors in the notorious Insein Prison for nearly two decades. Now, at 80, he faces a new kind of torment: watching colleagues from his political party decide whether to play by the rules of the junta that put him behind bars. Released in September 2008 after more than 19 years in prison, Mr. Win Tin remains remarkably spry, upbeat, and politically engaged. A co-founder of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy, he is a vocal opponent of taking part in national elections set for next year. The vote, along with the implementation of a new constitution, would introduce a shared civilian and military government after four and a half decades of military rule.

SAFIRE--William. The "Wednesday Ten" mourns the passing of our founder and inspiring leader, Bill Safire. It was over 50 years ago that Bill got the idea of bringing together a group of young men who had come to New York to build their careers. The "rules" were simple: we would meet once a month (often with accomplished guests); there would be no more than two from each profession or calling; we would tell one another about our work and our lives; we would teach one another about the world as we saw it and the opportunities it presented. From that humble beginning sprang a group who continued to meet together, though less frequently, right up to today. It bred lifelong friendships, much learning of the ways of the world and produced a host of successful people. Now, over 50 years later, we have lost the man who conceived the idea, brought us together and continued to lead us in the ways of friendship, knowledge and success. We will miss Bill Safire profoundly. We will miss his erudition, his wit and his teaching. The best thing we can do in his memory is to seek to keep our group going until, over time, we all join Bill in his new venue where we are sure the table will be laid and he will be waiting for us with his wry smile. Howard Amron Stanley Bartels Fred Berman Thomas Bishop Edward Bleier Paul Chan Joseph Forman Roy Goodman Arthur Gray Larry Grossman Mort Janklow Mortimer Lacher George Lang Robert Lifton Marshall Loeb Robert Menschel Edward Meyer Thomas Morgan Marvin Newman Leon Root James Rosenfield Charles Sigety Leonard Zweig

WILDERNESS campers are well aware that backcountry travel necessitates some discomfort, even when it comes to drinking water. For years, they bungled with slow, cumbersome filters and endured the flavor of iodine. But in recent years, new water-treatment products have made it simpler to treat water in the wild, while making the water itself tastier. ''Filters have gotten much, much, much easier to operate, and you get greater flow rates,'' said Frank Kosco, the water-treatment product buyer at Campmor, an outdoor-equipment retailer. ''The resistance on the pump isn't as tough as it used to be, and you get longer life from the filters.''

What we’re reading on Friday morning.Landesman Says N.E.A. Is Non-Partisan: Rocco Landesman, the recently appointed chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, said in a letter to Senator Mike Enzi, Republican of Wyoming, that his agency was not using its funding to help advance President Obama’s legislative agenda, The Los Angeles Times reports. In his letter, Mr. Landesman said that Yosi Sergant, the endowment’s former director of communications who resigned after leading a conference call that was perceived to be pro-Obama, was a “isolated incident” that “should in no way tarnish” the agency’s work.

Bill Carter and Brian Stelter have a full report in The New York Times about David Letterman‘s revelation on Thursday that he had been the victim of an extortion attempt over charges of sexual affairs with staff members, claims that he conceded were true.

Updated | 11:07 a.m. Steve Martin may have arguably been the biggest name at the 20th annual International Bluegrass Music Awards but he was not the biggest winner when those prizes were awarded on Thursday in Nashville, The Associated Press reported. Dan Tyminski, a guitarist and singer who is a member of Alison Krauss‘s band Union Station, won top album for his 2008 release “Wheels,” as well as male vocalist of the year, the fourth time he’s won that award since 2001. The duo Dailey & Vincent won best entertainer for the second consecutive year, as well as vocal group of the year and best gospel recorded performance for “On the Other Side.” Mr. Martin, the actor, author and comedian, won two awards for his bluegrass album “The Crow: New Songs for the Five-String Banjo,” including best liner notes and best graphic design. In a tongue-in-cheek commentary on Mr. Martin’s stature in the bluegrass world, the musician Pete Wernick announced a performance by Mr. Martin and his band, the Steep Canyon Rangers, by saying: “Here’s a man who needs an introduction.”
Life isn’t fair, but sometimes karma evens things out.

Put the filmmakers Steven Spielberg and George Lucas together and you are certain to get something that is very costly and deeply nostalgic. Their latest collaboration, however, isn’t a science-fiction adventure or another “Indiana Jones” sequel, or even intended for the big screen: they will pool their private collections of Norman Rockwell artwork for an exhibition at the Smithsonian American Art Museum in Washington, BBC News reported. The exhibition, which will open July 2 and will run through Jan. 2, 2011, will explore the connections between movie-making and Rockwell’s illustrations, and will include video interviews with Mr. Spielberg and Mr. Lucas about their collections. “Both of them say Rockwell was a master of storytelling, and a master of telling the story in one figure, and that is just like one frame for a movie,” said Virginia M. Mecklenburg, a senior curator at the museum, according to the BBC. Between the two directors, Mr. Lucas owns the earlier piece of Rockwell art: a Life magazine cover from 1917.
This post contains spoilers.

Friday night’s all right for sci-fi fighting: On the Cartoon Network, the animated series “Star Wars: The Clone Wars” returns for a second season (8 p.m.), while on Syfy the latest series in the “Stargate” family, “Stargate Universe,” has a two-hour premiere (9 p.m.).

One of this fall’s best new food books, Wendell Berry’s “Bringing It to the Table: On Farming and Food” (Counterpoint, $14.95), isn’t so new at all. It’s a volume that collects Mr. Berry’s provocative and plainspoken agricultural essays dating back to the 1970s. It’s a bracing bedside companion.

Though the Grateful Dead are most closely associated with the Haight-Ashbury district of San Francisco, the Upper West Side of Manhattan can briefly lay claim to that industrious and ever-evolving band in the weeks and months ahead. In March, the New-York Historical Society will open an exhibition on the Grateful Dead that will trace its history and cultural influence. In a release, the society said that the exhibition, to be called “The Grateful Dead: Now Playing at the New-York Historical Society,” would feature artwork, posters, marionettes and other stage props as well as banners and decorated fan mail from throughout the band’s 30-year career. Prior to its opening, the society will hold a fundraising event that will be attended by the Grateful Dead members Phil Lesh and Bob Weir, where items from the Grateful Dead Archive at the University of California, Santa Cruz, will be previewed. More information on that event, which is scheduled for Oct. 21, will be available online at nyhistory.org.

Public radio’s popular Washington, D.C.-based “Diane Rehm Show” will get a more prominent New York home next week when WNYC Radio shifts its evening lineup of classical music programming to WQXR, and opens up some airtime on WNYC’s AM and FM stations for news and talk programming. The two-hour show, hosted by Ms. Rehm for 30 years, is now heard in New York midday on city-owned WNYE-FM, but starting Oct. 9 it will also air on WNYC-AM weeknights at 8 p.m.

Doyle New York auction house is preparing for an onslaught of opera fans this weekend. On Friday, a five-day preview opened for a sale of 467 lots from the soprano Beverly Sills’s estate. Doyle has largely cleared out her apartment on Central Park West and reassembled some room settings at the salerooms for Wednesday’s auction. Sills, who died in 2007, hung folk paintings of crowd scenes from floor to ceiling, as well as costume designers’ original illustrations of her full-skirted stage outfits. “It was like an audience of happy people surrounding her when she came home,” said Louis Webre, Doyle’s senior vice president for marketing and media. Sills, who was always attending or hosting benefits, stocked her apartment with huge sets of bone china and glassware and dozens of jeweled evening bags. Doyle is selling her mink and sable coats and some elementary school report cards.

The thief or thieves who stole millions of dollars’ worth of artwork from private collectors in Pebble Beach, Calif., left behind a ransom note demanding money, The Californian reported. Thirteen works, including pieces by Matisse, Miró, Rembrandt, Renoir, van Gogh and Jackson Pollock were reported stolen Friday from the home of A. Benjamin Amadio and Dr. Ralph Kennaugh. In a news release, they said the ransom note was found Tuesday by police officers, but did not say in the release the amount of the ransom being asked. The Monterey County Sheriff’s Office confirmed to The Californian the existence of the ransom note. The Pollock work was estimated to be worth between $20 million and $60 million, while the other pieces are collectively estimated at $7 million in value. The collectors have offered a $1 million reward for the return of the paintings and $5 million for the arrest and conviction of the perpetrator or perpetrators of the theft. A lawyer for the collectors did not immediately return a request for comment.

There’s a strong regional identity at work behind the Austin City Limits Music Festival. But at this point, in its eighth year, it also has the unmistakable clout and ambition of a national event. With artists programmed on eight stages over three days, Friday through Sunday, the festival — known to most locals by its initials, ACL — has evolved into a legitimate heavyweight. Three-day passes sold out six months in advance. Attendance each day is estimated to exceed 65,000.

Funny Jews, tortured Jews, anxious Jews, avenging Jews. All are current or recent subjects of popular films. As A.O. Scott writes in his Arts & Leisure column this week, puzzles of Jewish identity continue to inform our popular culture decades after the Holocaust. In “A Serious Man” Joel and Ethan Coen torment their protagonist as though he were Job. In “Inglourious Basterds” Quentin Tarantino adds a revenge sequel to World War II. As “fresh expositions of ancient dilemmas and anxieties quarrel and contend,” Mr. Scott writes, “Nothing is settled.”

The director Kevin Smith is no stranger to the world of comics: He owns a comic book store in Red Bank, N.J.; his films like “Mallrats” and “Chasing Amy” have focused on characters who create (or are just obsessed with) comic books; and he even named his daughter, Harley Quinn, after a Batman villain. Mr. Smith is also the writer of “Batman: Cacophony,” which appears at No. 1 on our hardcover list this week. The story, illustrated by Walt Flanagan, is about a superhero killer named Onomatopoeia that crosses paths with Batman and the Joker. During a violent struggle, the Joker suffers an injury that forces Batman to choose between capturing his new opponent and saving the life of his long-time foe.

LOS ANGELES - As if the struggling Dodgers did not have enough to worry about in trying to hold off the Rockies for the N.L. West title, getting Manny Ramirez and Andre Ethier untracked and crossing their fingers about their bullpen, they received more disconcerting news Friday.

The Pittsburgh Penguins raised their Stanley Cup banner at the Mellon Arena and began their final season in the league's oldest building with a victory. (The Igloo is 48 years old.) Commissioner Gary Bettman was on hand, and he noted with some relish that just a few years ago the Pens were in financial trouble and almost moved -- a history he likened, rather improbably, to the current situation in Phoenix.
After returning to Somalia in 2008 to aid victims of a drought, the locals asked Mohamed Aden to become their leader. In less than a year, he has transformed Adado, Somalia, into an enclave of peace.

A few years back, in a not-unusual state of panic in my personal life and hubris in my professional one, I spent several winter months in Wyoming. More specifically, my job as a journalist required me to sit at a battered kitchen table in the middle of the Wind River Indian Reservation, swapping stories with a quadriplegic Northern Arapaho horse gentler and traditional healer named Stanford Addison. I went home with nothing particularly resolved, but happier than I'd been in years. Stanford had lost more than anyone I'd ever known. He was paralyzed at age 20, when the truck in which he was traveling to a party hit some horses wandering on a dark reservation road. But by the time I arrived 23 years later, he was holding sweat lodges to help his neighbors twice a week. He was assisted in the lodge and the corral by young men and kids, some adopted as his own children, others just passing through or released to him by tribal courts and social programs. When the beds filled up, kids and other visitors slept sprawled on couches or on the floor.

I'm delighted to announce the winners of the Half the Sky contest. There were more than 700 entries, and sifting through them was a dazzling process -- so many wonderful people doing awesome work. And one of the things that struck me was how often the intercultural engagement involved Westerners who were as much beneficiaries of the process as the local people.

Fresh off Air Force One and his failed attempt in trying to secure the 2016 summer Olympics for Chicago, President Obama talked about the day's bad economic news. Earlier Friday, the Labor Department released the job-loss figures for September, with the highest rate so far for unemployment since 1983 -- 9.8 percent. Republicans quickly pounced on the figures as a sign that the $787 billion stimulus package wasn't doing much to create new jobs.
Survivors and rescue teams worked frantically on Friday to search for survivors of the powerful earthquake that struck western Sumatra.

Democrats in Congress and at the White House were abuzz on Friday afternoon after Time magazine's Web site published an interview with the former Senate majority leader, Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee, saying he would vote in favor of the Democrats' big health care legislation if he were still in Congress.

After consideration of more than 500 amendments, the Senate Finance Committee has just posted the latest version of its proposed health care legislation, America's Healthy Future Act. Those of you looking for a little weekend diversion can find it here (pdf). Next up: the Congressional Budget Office and the Joint Committee on Taxation weigh in with cost estimates, after which the committee will vote.

The offices of Curbed, a blog network start-up, are located in the Village Voice building in New York. That is perhaps telling, as readers increasingly turn to blogs like Curbed's -- which cover real estate, dining and shopping in big cities -- instead of print newspapers.
Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City. Subjects include public housing in Greenwich, Conn., a runoff election and the unveiling of a former governor's portrait.

There's a new name you need to know: Peter Copping. The English designer, who used to work with Marc Jacobs at Louis Vuitton and has just taken the helm at Nina Ricci, made a strong case for flirty femininity by rejuvenating the house's signature vocabulary of lace, bows and frills to create a sexy Lolita-like collection. Underwear as outerwear was already a trend in Milan. Now, thanks to Copping's Parisian coquettes, it's one that's sure to gain traction.Another newcomer to the main stage is Rodolfo Paglialunga, who recently decamped from Prada to head up Vionnet. Many of Madeleine Vionnet's masterful pieces from the 1930s are currently being exhibited at the Musée des Arts Decoratifs, so it was easy to understand how Paglialunga sought to make her groundbreaking experiments with draping and construction newly relevant. Among his standouts were brightly printed, jeweled dresses made from a single piece of skillfully manipulated fabric.
What took them so long?

On Saturday, the most significant trial in Pakistan is scheduled to resume: that of seven suspects accused of planning the rampaging terrorist attacks in Mumbai last year in which at least 163 people were killed.
The Dessert Truck folks may be setting up shop at a storefront at 6 Clinton Street, as Eater reported, but that doesn't seem to mean that Michael Huynh's plans for a restaurant there are dislocated.

A German shepherd named Taz, who was almost 2 years old when he was assigned from the city police's K-9 unit to do search and rescue at the World Trade Center after the 9/11 attack, has died.

A nine-day trek along the 93-mile, aptly named Wonderland Trail in Mount Rainier National Park becomes a journey of discovery and - for a few chilling moments - of sheer survival for Eric Wilson, a fashion reporter for The New York Times. He also lives to tell about wearing khakis.

Every game at Fenway Park since May 15, 2003, has sold out, but the Boston Red Sox make a certain number of tickets available on the day of each game for fans who do not mind arriving early and standing in line.

The Starwood Capital Group, the real estate investment firm run by Barry Sternlicht, is close to a deal with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to purchase the assets of Corus Bank, which failed under a mound of soured condominium and commercial mortgage loans, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

Of all the senses that are being stimulated during Paris fashion week, taste has been the least indulged. That's why "Through the Looking Glass. Drink Me! Eat Me!," the culinary design exposition organized by Marc Brétillot, Yannick Alléno and Vendôme Luxury at the Hotel Meurice - right by the Carrousel du Louvre! - is such a standout. Most of the works function as art instead of treats, so they will only be savored visually. But the 15 participants seek to cook up a dialogue about the meaning and symbolism of food, while offering imaginative delights on par with those on display on the catwalks.

The established icons of Arctic climate change are the polar bear and, to a lesser extent, those indigenous communities that are trying to maintain traditional ways in the face of slushy floes and the relentless erosion of coasts exposed to waves as sea ice retreats.

Did Obama err in backing Chicago's bid? And does the decision mean that the world still dislikes America?.

One oft-heard argument in favor of Barack Obama's presidential candidacy was that he would help restore the image of America abroad, tarnished as it was by the Bush administration's unilateralism. Indeed, the pollsters have even found quantitative proof that the president has achieved that goal. So, one is tempted to ask, why is that back in the height of the Bush presidency in 2005, New York at least made it to the second round of voting in its bid to host the 2012 Olympic Games, yet on Friday, despite the personal efforts of not just the First Family but Oprah as well, Chicago didn't even clear the first hurdle?

Technicians at a West Virginia coal-fired power facility began injecting carbon dioxide captured from the plant into rock deep underground on Thursday evening, in an experiment to determine the costs and technical feasibility of carbon capture and storage.

Tarte Tatin is the second-best apple pie in the world, after Jackie's Polish-style szarlotka (which my Aunts Jennie -- I had two, one on each side of the family, both fine bakers -- also used to make but called simply "apple cake"). The amazing thing about tarte Tatin is how the caramelized apples are somehow transformed into something entirely new but at the same time remain intensely apple-y. It is also one of the easiest to make. And one of the hardest.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Perhaps because nobody knows quite what to call it - the '00s? the aughts? - this decade does not seem to have the resonance of the '60s, the '70s, and so on. But it's still fun to look at these 10 years that start with a zero and find baseball's decade leaders.

Look, one loss is not catastrophic in college football. But two losses can be. In the B.C.S. era only the 2007 L.S.U. Tigers managed to win a national title with two losses. Remember, both those losses came in the third overtime and they beat seven ranked teams on their way to a national title. This weekend, California, Southern California, Oklahoma and Miami are all trying to avoid that second loss. It's even bigger for Cal and U.S.C. A loss in that one and you have two conference setbacks staring at you. (Sidenote: Tough that those two games are on TV at the same time on the same channel. Packers (2-1)at Vikings (3-0)Monday, 8:30 p.m.Line: Vikings by 3Brett Favre is as polarizing as any political figure. Ninety percent of the opinions about him are formed long before he takes the field, and he inspires a din in the sports media that makes buzzing fluorescent lights sound soothing. The need for consensus between Favre's boosters and his bashers is urgent as "Monday Night" hype reaches jackhammer decibels. To move past the rancor, Favre's fiercest critics must acknowledge that he has done all he was asked to do this season, plus a little more; Favre's cheerleaders, meanwhile, must concede that he hasn't been asked to do very much. Aaron Rodgers inherited Favre's job and some of his traits, but none of his charismatic invulnerability.

Google's recent update of its free Picasa photo-editing program now includes the same "name tags" technology first introduced in its Picasa Web Albums. With the name-tags feature turned on, Picasa 3.5 analyzes the faces of the people in your pictures and groups similar ones together -- making it easier to identify people by name for sorting and searching. A tutorial on using Picasa name tags is here; Picasa 3.5 itself, which works recent Windows and Mac OS X systems, can be downloaded at picasa.google.com.

An exhibition review on Sept. 11 about “New Amsterdam: The Island at the Center of the World” at the South Street Seaport Museum, using information from the exhibition and its catalog, included erroneous information about a memorial to Jan Rodrigues, perhaps the first immigrant resident of what became New York City. According to a spokesman for the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, there is no plaque about Rodrigues in Riverside Park.
The defensive coordinator Gregg Williams is using the principles Buddy Ryan preached when he and Williams worked together in Houston in 1993.

An article on Tuesday about a new video game for the iPhone combining the music and artwork of the singer and songwriter Daniel Johnston, using information from the designers, misstated the length of time one designer worked on the game. Peter Franco worked on it from the start of this year — not for a year and a half, which was the amount of time the other designer, Steve Broumley, spent on it.
This new show, written by Nora and Delia Ephron, is about matters of the heart and matters of the closet.
Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday previewing the Rangers’ 2009-10 N.H.L. season misidentified the site of the team’s first game. It will be in Pittsburgh on Friday, not at home.

An article on Thursday about the pending departure of Kenneth D. Lewis as chief executive of Bank of America misidentified the state where Mr. Lewis began his tenure with the bank. It was a small bank in North Carolina, not South Carolina.

An article on Thursday about the Treasury Department’s buying distressed assets from banks misstated the name of one of two private investment firms joining in the deal. It is the TCW Group, not the TWC Group.

An article on Thursday about efforts by a group of hedge funds to head off regulation in Washington misstated the position of Darcy Bradbury, who is expected to lead the efforts of the group, called the Managed Funds Association. Ms. Bradbury is a senior vice president and public affairs director of the D. E. Shaw Group; she is not its chief lobbyist. The article also misstated the association’s future relationship to Eric Vincent, whom Ms. Bradbury would succeed. He is expected to remain on its board, not to become its executive chairman.

The Patient Money column on Aug. 22, about the costs of medical service animals misstated a federal tax rule on deducting medical expenses. Medical expenses in excess of 7.5 percent of adjusted gross income can be deducted; expenses equal to the first 7.5 percent of adjusted gross income are not deductible. A reader’s message pointing out the error was misdirected at The Times.

An article on Wednesday about the handful of voters who went to Public School 108 in the Bronx to cast ballots in New York City’s runoff elections misstated, in some editions, the number of poll workers per election district represented at P.S. 108 and the total cost of their wages. There were four workers per election district, not eight, and their wages totaled $6,400, not $12,800. The article also misstated, in some editions, the ages of two voters interviewed; Hannibal Coscia is 83, not 80, and Joe Parone is 81, not 73.

An article on Wednesday about the expected pace of the American military withdrawal from Iraq misstated the origin of a commitment to withdraw all but about 50,000 troops by August 2010. It was ordered by President Obama; it was not specified in the agreement on forces reached by the United States and Iraq last year.

The Richard Prince exhibition “Spiritual America,” which was to open on Thursday at the Tate Modern museum in London, was withdrawn Wednesday after a warning from Scotland Yard that its inclusion of a nude photograph of Brooke Shields taken when she was 10 years old could violate obscenity laws, The Guardian reported. The exhibition was to be shown as part of the gallery’s program “Pop Life: Art in a Material World” but was closed off from display after newspaper reviews drew the attention of the police. The photograph, which was included in “Spiritual America” when it was shown at the Guggenheim Museum in 2007, was taken by Mr. Prince from a photograph made by Gary Gross in 1976 and authorized by Ms. Shields’s mother. A spokeswoman for the Tate Modern said that the display had been “temporarily closed down” and that the catalog for the exhibition had been withdrawn from sale.

The exhibition was to be shown as part of the gallery’s program “Pop Life: Art in a Material World” but was closed off from display after newspaper reviews drew the attention of the police. TLC said on Thursday that it had suspended filming of the Gosselin children, left, on its reality series “Jon & Kate Plus 8” after a lawyer for Jon Gosselin told the cable channel in a letter that production crews were forbidden to enter the Gosselin family home. The letter was reported on Thursday on CBS’s “Early Show,” which said it was dated Tuesday, the same day that TLC announced it would sideline Mr. Gosselin and rename the reality show “Kate Plus 8.” Mark Heller, a lawyer for Mr. Gosselin, said in a statement that he was confident his client “will be completely successful in his quest to take back control of his family and preserve, protect and ensure their future well-being by putting the brakes on his divorce and pulling the plug on TLC, the media giant that he perceives as a monster.” The “Jon & Kate” show drew a wide audience in the spring and summer, when the couple’s marriage effectively collapsed. In a statement on Thursday, TLC said, “We are aware of Jon Gosselin’s recent statements and remain deeply disappointed at his continued erratic behavior.” TLC said that Mr. Gosselin and his family were shooting for the show as recently as last Friday.

The multimedia revue of the life and work of Stephen Sondheim that fizzled this year at the Alliance Theater of Atlanta will be plugged in on Broadway by Roundabout Theater Company. Roundabout said on Thursday that it would produce “Sondheim on Sondheim,” a project with music and lyrics by Mr. Sondheim and conceived and directed by his frequent collaborator James Lapine. This new work will star Barbara Cook, above, a Tony Award winner for “The Music Man” (and Drama Desk nominee for her 2002 concert event, “Mostly Sondheim”), in her first Broadway musical in more than 35 years. Other stars include Vanessa Williams (a Tony nominee for “Into the Woods”), Leslie Kritzer (“Rooms: A Rock Romance”) and Michael Arden. “Sondheim on Sondheim” is to begin previews at Studio 54 on March 19, with an official opening of April 22; its limited run will end on June 13. The roster of songs was not immediately announced. The Alliance Theater’s project, called “iSondheim,” was to have featured music from “Gypsy,” “West Side Story” and “Sweeney Todd,” among other shows, but the revue was canceled because of fund-raising problems.

Despite a bevy of new competition, the CBS mainstays “Criminal Minds” and “CSI: NY” earned Wednesday night’s largest television audiences. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “Criminal Minds” drew 13.6 million viewers and “CSI: NY,” above with Melina Kanakaredes and Gary Sinise, attracted 12.9 million as CBS won the night. ABC ranked second; its new comedies “Hank” (8.5 million) and “The Middle” (8.6 million) had strong debuts, followed by new episodes of “Modern Family” (9.9 million) and “Cougar Town” (9 million). In a virtual tie for third, Fox’s combination of “So You Think You Can Dance” (6.7 million) and “Glee” (7.3 million) averaged roughly the same number of viewers as NBC’s lineup of “Mercy” (7.3 million), “Law & Order: SVU” (7.9 million) and “The Jay Leno Show” (6 million).

The first new authorized tale of Winnie-the-Pooh in more than 80 years, set for release on Monday, will introduce a female character to that bothersome bear’s mostly male entourage. Lottie the Otter will make her debut in “Return to the Hundred Acre Wood,” written by David Benedictus, illustrated by Mark Burgess and approved by the Pooh trustees. In a news release, the Dutton Children’s Books imprint of Penguin Young Readers Group, which is publishing the book, described Lottie as “a smart and elegant character” who is “always dressed in pearls” and who “has her own ideas about how things should be done and believes that everyone should follow the correct etiquette.”.

The number of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender characters has grown in recent years on prime-time network television but decreased on cable, the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation said. For its “Where We Are on TV” study, the alliance reviewed 79 scripted comedies and dramas announced for the broadcast networks during the 2009-10 season. It found that of 600 regulars on these shows, 18 are lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender. The study said that ABC has the most such characters, with 8 out of 168 total series regulars; Fox has 4 (including cartoon characters on “The Simpsons” and “American Dad”), NBC has 3, CW has 2 and CBS, none. In its review of mainstream cable channels, including HBO, Showtime, Comedy Central, AMC and others, the alliance found that the number of series regulars who are lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender decreased this year, to 25 from 32 last year. When the gay-oriented cable channels here! and Logo were included, the study said, 27 gay characters were added to the tally.

The International Monetary Fund on Thursday forecast that the world economy would expand 3.1 percent next year, after a year in which much of the world struggled through a recession. In its World Economic Outlook, the fund's prognosis was marginally better than its prediction in July that growth in 2010 would reach 2.5 percent. But it emphasized that the upswing was mainly a result of aggressive crisis management in the United States, Europe and Asia, not a self-sustaining recovery.

Playa del Carmen, Mexico -- Forty miles down the Riviera Maya coast via Mexico 307, I was a world away from the relentless hubbub of Cancún, rolling along a narrow, winding flagstone road to the ocean through mangrove so thick that it blocked the sun in spots. Over the last 15 years, as Cancún's growth has begun to max out, vacationers and retirees have looked to the Riviera Maya, the 100-mile stretch of blue-green Caribbean and bleached white sand that stretches south to Tulum. There are now a total of 35,000 hotel rooms, condominiums and timeshares on a coast that not long ago was largely fishing villages backed by scrubland and verdant jungle.

How Japanese see the coming role reversal with China depends largely on what generation they are from. Young Japanese, in particular, feel apathy and bewilderment. They came of age in Japan's lost decade of economic stagnation. When the Internet research company Macromill asked 500 20-year-olds whether they would describe Japan's future as ''bright'' or ''dark,'' 82 percent chose dark. Japanese executives are the most pessimistic in the world, according to a recent cross-cultural survey that scored responses from 7,200 respondents on the outlook for their businesses in the short term.

The White House has often held out the Mayo Clinic as a model for health care. But Dr. Denis A. In 1962 the Italian poet, novelist and cinema immortal Pier Paolo Pasolini talked for the first time about a movie he was about to begin, a work he called an ''essay in film journalism,'' titled ''La Rabbia'' (''Rage''). It was a curious, unlikely project for Pasolini. It had been commissioned by a producer, Gastone Ferranti, who, according to the Italian scholar Roberto Chiesi, was in the market for an exploitation flick along the lucrative lines of ''Mondo Cane,'' a 1962 Italian feature compilation of found footage and cheap shocks that resulted in untold imitations. What Ferranti got instead was a passionate tour of the frenzied spectacles of the 20th century -- with stops in Italy and France, as well as in Hungary and Korea -- that Pasolini characterized as ''an act of indignation against the unreality of the bourgeois world and the historical irresponsibility to which it gives rise.'' Using existing documentary and newsreel images shot by anonymous others, Pasolini rewrote history through montage.

8 P.M. (TCM) NIGHT AT THE MOVIES: THE SUSPENSEFUL WORLD OF THRILLERS Turner Classic Movies has subtitled its newest series ''Film Studies 101,'' analyses of major cinematic genres starting with movies that make us want to cover our eyes and scream. The Friday-nights-in-October fright fest begins with an hourlong documentary, hosted by TCM's resident godfather, Robert Osborne, that examines the various types of thrillers (political, crime, gothic, psychological or just plain good) and the tools filmmakers use to keep viewers on the edges of their seats. Those interviewed include Ken Follett, Diablo Cody, Kenneth Branagh, Mel Brooks, Norman Lloyd and Martin Landau. Two thrillers by Hitchcock, who gets his own category -- ''The Master of Suspense'' -- follow. ''Rear Window'' (1954), with James Stewart (above), will be shown at 9 and ''Shadow of a Doubt'' (1943) at midnight. 8 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER When a crime investigator is found murdered, evidence seems to point to her philandering fiancé. But the case is muddled when a young journalist (Camille Chen) is attacked by a cabdriver, and DNA implicates the same man in both assaults. Then Detective Lupo (Jeremy Sisto) gets a little too close to the victim.

I ARRIVE at Walden Pond State Reservation here just after sunrise, recalling that a certain local resident named Thoreau once wrote that ''morning brings back the heroic ages.'' Only a few cars are scattered across the lot -- funky foreign rustbuckets adorned with yoga stickers or a little plastic hula girl perched on the dashboard. A thermometer attached to one of the outbuildings records the temperature at 55 degrees. Beside a dented brown Toyota a lean man with a wetsuit rolled down to his waist is performing a handstand, his body straight and still, feet pointed at the lightening sky. On this brisk late-summer morning, it seems I've entered the world of alt exercise, where the iron will of the endurance athlete merges with flights of Thoreau-like contemplation.

SIEGAL--Susan, on September 30, after a three-year illness. Adored wife of David Siegal, beloved mother of Jeffrey and Sandy, cherished grandmother of Rita Tolkach, devoted sister of Joan Locker, revered aunt. Esteemed sisterhood board member of Barnert Temple, Franklin Lakes, NJ. Services Friday (October 2), 11am, Barnert Temple. Memorial contributions may be made to the general fund of Barnert Temple.

Dunes National Park, Colo. -- The pile of gear laid out in our garage was incongruous: sand shovels and pails, skis, sun hats, a snow sled. We were packing for a trip to Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve in southern Colorado. Tucked in the curve where the Sangre de Cristo range meets the San Luis Valley, 30 square miles of sand pile up in dunes as high as 750 feet. On the drive toward the park along the flat expanse of the valley, the dunes materialize unexpectedly, as if someone had superimposed the Sahara onto Colorado's lush, blue-green mountains. Last month my husband, Jeff, and I, along with our three small children, hiked through the sand sheet, the vegetated stretch of sand surrounding the dunes. In the distance a fuzzy-antlered elk nibbled on Indian rice grass. Yucca and prickly pear cactus lined the trail, which led us to the base of the dunes. The children cooked sand cakes and lay down to make sand angels. They dug until they hit water, then jumped into the mucky pit, barefoot and giggling.

In a signal that Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Michael Vick still has a long way to go before attracting major endorsements, Nike on Thursday clarified reports that it had signed a contract with him, even as it acknowledged that it had agreed to give him free products. ''Nike does not have a contractual relationship with Michael Vick,'' KeJuan Wilkins, a Nike spokesman, said in a statement. ''We have agreed to supply product to Michael Vick as we do a number of athletes who are not under contract with Nike.''

The top Iranian opposition leader warned ahead of the talks between Iran and major powers in Geneva that tougher sanctions on Iran over its nuclear program could hurt the opposition movement more than the government of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad. The opposition leader, Mir Hussein Moussavi, who lost to Mr. Ahmadinejad in the disputed June election, wrote in a statement that the sanctions would most hurt ordinary citizens.

A new military investigation into the 2008 battle at Wanat, Afghanistan, one of the deadliest engagements of the war, will examine whether decisions by senior commanders contributed to the deaths of nine American soldiers in the firefight, officials said Thursday. Previous inquiries focused on decisions and actions by the small unit assigned to a remote outpost in Wanat in northeastern Afghanistan, which was almost overrun in a surprise attack by insurgents. The vicious, four-hour battle, on July 13, 2008, also left more than 30 American and Afghan troops wounded.

Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, the only Republican on the Senate Finance Committee who has expressed any willingness to support the health care legislation, may be the most closely watched figure in the committee's debating sessions. As Thursday afternoon's proceedings wore on, Ms. Snowe got up to leave the dais -- senators frequently walk in and out -- and apparently tripped and fell. Aides helped gather her papers, and she quickly left the hearing room. A spokesman for Ms. Snowe said she was just fine.

Lucy, meet Ardi. Ardi, short for Ardipithecus ramidus, is the newest fossil skeleton out of Africa to take its place in the gallery of human origins. At an age of 4.4 million years, it lived well before and was much more primitive than the famous 3.2-million-year-old Lucy, of the species Australopithecus afarensis.

At the request of Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, Attorney General Jerry Brown's office has opened an investigation into Acorn's activities in California. Mr. Schwarzenegger wrote to Mr. Brown after viewing a video made by conservative activists purporting to show a San Diego Acorn employee giving tips on how to smuggle under-age girls into the country. ''I applaud Attorney General Jerry Brown for taking action and launching an investigation of Acorn,'' Mr. Schwarzenegger said.

Romania's coalition government collapsed Thursday after nine ministers from the Social Democratic Party resigned in solidarity with a colleague who was fired. On Monday, Prime Minister Emil Boc fired Dan Nica, the interior minister, left, who had made comments suggesting that Mr. Boc's Liberal Democrats were prepared to engage in fraud in presidential elections scheduled for Nov. 22 -- allegations Mr. Boc has strenuously denied.

Spoiler alert: The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, and the House minority leader, John A. Boehner, disagree on the popularity of the public option. The two leaders debated the issue Thursday via their weekly news conferences. Mr. Boehner, an Ohio Republican, said he had yet to talk to anyone -- besides some in Washington -- who backed a government-run insurance option.

HAZARD--Sarah Halsey, of Bedford, New York died September 28th at the age of 80. Born September 19, 1929 in Wilkes-Barre, PA to Joseph Gaius Halsey and Ellen Elisabeth Wolf Halsey. Sarah, known as Sally, grew up with her sisters Jacqueline Harvey and Frances Melanie Wickser in Conyngham, PA and Nantucket, MA. Sally will be remembered for her grace, humor, and strength. She truly loved her home in Bedford and was involved in many community organizations, including: Friends of the Bedford Free Library, the Bedford Historical Society, the Bedford Garden Club, Saint Matthew's Church, and Northern Westchester Hospital. Sally was a beloved wife of Oliver C. Hazard (born 1932; died 2009) and is survived by her children, Eliza Hazard (Herndon, VA), Peter R. Hazard (Telluride, CO), and Caroline H. Hazard (Silver Spring, MD). A service will be held at St. Matthew's Church on Saturday, October 3rd at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Sally's name may be sent to the Bedford Free Library, Village Green, Bedford, NY 10506.

One in five Somali children is wasting away from malnutrition. Tens of thousands need urgent medical care to survive. The whole middle belt of the country is teetering on the brink of famine. United Nations officials say Somalia has not been in such perilous shape since the central government collapsed in 1991 and is in desperate need of help. But right now that help is being delayed, they say, at least partly because the American government is worried that its aid is going to feed terrorists.

The Yankees made a big deal out of their decision to hold ticket prices steady for the first round of the playoffs. That's right, even those $5 seats in the center-field bleachers with obstructed views of the field would remain $5 when the Yankees play either the Detroit Tigers or the Minnesota Twins next week. But unless you are a season ticket-holder, forget about that $5 price. Fans selling those bleacher seats on line are charging no less than $98 each for a chance to see about two-thirds of the field, according to FanSnap, a Web site that scans dozens of ticket resellers. The bulk of the tickets advertised in those bleacher sections do not note that there are obstructed views.

DANNENBRING--David. It is with much sadness that we note the passing of David Dannenbring, one of the guiding spirits of Baruch College. Among many other roles, David was a veteran faculty member and chair of the Department of Management; his area of special expertise was operations management. He was well known and beloved by a great many of us because, in the later part of his career, he was called on to assume a variety of administrative positions. Beginning in the mid 1990s, he served as Associate Dean, then in 1999 as Acting Dean of the Zicklin School of Business; Provost and Senior Vice President for Academic Affairs; Acting Dean of the Weissman School and Special Adviser to the President. His expertise in managing complex systems, along with his unwavering loyalty to Baruch College, made him a man for all seasons. Known for his patience and his gentleness, David was called upon to fill many roles and he took on each of them with great skill, intelligence, kindness, and good humor. He had great affection for Baruch College, as Baruch had for him. His passing is a great loss to his colleagues, to his many friends and, indeed, to the entire Baruch College community. Stan Altman President, Baruch College

The pile of gear laid out in our garage was incongruous: sand shovels and pails, skis, sun hats, a snow sled. We were packing for a trip to Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve in southern Colorado. Tucked in the curve where the Sangre de Cristo range meets the San Luis Valley, 30 square miles of sand pile up in dunes as high as 750 feet. On the drive toward the park along the flat expanse of the valley, the dunes materialize unexpectedly, as if someone had superimposed the Sahara onto Colorado's lush, blue-green mountains. Last month my husband, Jeff, and I, along with our three small children, hiked through the sand sheet, the vegetated stretch of sand surrounding the dunes. In the distance a fuzzy-antlered elk nibbled on Indian rice grass. Yucca and prickly pear cactus lined the trail, which led us to the base of the dunes. The children cooked sand cakes and lay down to make sand angels. They dug until they hit water, then jumped into the mucky pit, barefoot and giggling.

The critical regional World Cup qualifying match between the United States and Honduras in San Pedro Sula on Oct. 10 will be available only on closed-circuit television at sports bars and pubs around the United States. The match (kickoff at 10 p.m. Eastern) will not be shown by ESPN, Fox Soccer Channel or GolTV, and will not be available to residential pay-per-view customers. Currently, the home federation (in this case, Honduras) owns the TV rights to its qualifiers. The Hondurans reached a deal with a Spanish company, Mediapro, for the game against the United States. After unsuccessfully trying to sell the rights to ESPN and Fox Soccer Channel, Mediapro made a deal with Integrated Sports Media to present the game on closed circuit.
