KING--Elford A.,died September 28. He was predeceased by his life partner of 49 years R. Alan Cordingley. Mr. King was the son of More C. and Irma L. King, brother of Elizabeth A. Bidwell. Survived by nephews John K., Scott T., and Peter R. Bidwell and their wives. A memorial service will be held at the Yale Club in New York City at a date yet to be determined.

B Y and large, my generation of military professionals trained for and thought about what we might call ''Type A'' war -- modern war, featuring the clash of mechanized forces fielded by industrial states. Happily, we never had to fight the Soviets on the northern German plain, though Operation Desert Storm showed we might have been pretty good at it, had the balloon gone up. In Afghanistan we're fighting a ''Type B'' war that is in some of its essentials ''postmodern.'' Like postmodernism itself, the concept has a variety of meanings and may not represent a coherent set of ideas. But one thing is clear: the Type B enemy likely has little to lose -- no territory to protect, few important targets at risk, perhaps even no life worth living. Thus the Type A objective of fatally weakening an opponent by destroying assets important to his success -- in theory, a measurable process -- is replaced in Type B war by the much more complicated, essentially unquantifiable task of defeating him.
Dance Jack Anderson

RIDLESS--Randy. Principal of the interior design firm, Randall A. Ridless, and loved for his humor, warmth and spirit, died at age 49 on October 2 at his home in Manhattan. His design portfolio of residential and commercial interiors includes flagship projects for Burberry, Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman, Van Cleef & Arpels, Frette and St. Johns. Randy is survived by his partner, Tim Riordan, mother Marilyn Cohen, step-mother Adele Ridless and siblings Hank, Glenn, Joshua, Jennifer and Christine Ridless. A memorial service will be held at Friends Seminary Meeting House, 15 Rutherford Place in Manhattan, Tuesday, October 6 at 6:30pm. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to the Randy Ridless Memorial Fund, Rhode Island School of Design, Attention Louise Olson, 2 College Street, Providence, Rhode Island 02903.

S KEPTICS of state-building proposals question whether the Kabul government -- now almost fully dependent on foreign aid -- will ever be able to support the military and police forces being trained. Yet there has been comparatively little investment by the international community in helping Kabul collect taxes, even though insurgents and corrupt officials have proved it can be done. In addition to collecting taxes from the illegal opium trade, Taliban forces extort money from trucks carrying legal cargo through their territories and demand ''protection fees'' from local businesses, even hitting up construction projects financed by NATO.

Here's a new way to find a vacation rental: Hit up your Facebook friends. Second Porch, a new company based in Portland, Ore., started a Facebook application that lets people ''friendsource'' vacation homes through their social network. The app lets homeowners list their rental properties through Facebook, and build ''followers'' or potential guests. Renters , in turn, can find vacation homes through their Facebook friends, as well as rate and recommend properties to others.

COZY/ (k z) /adj. / Giving a feeling of comfort, warmth and relaxation; intimate, as in, 'I can't bear to go to the Monkey Bar again. Let's order in -- it's so much more cozy.' Also refers to a New Economy approach to decorating that embraces texture, layering and clutter. Baby, it's warm inside. COMMUNITECTURE/ (k my n tek chr) /n. / An idea of building and design that places the common good over egocentricity; an antidote to starchitecture, as in, 'Don't get me wrong -- I love my new Jean Nouvel condo. But what this city really needs is more communitecture like the High Line.

CARY--Eve (Greenberg), 65, died September 29, 2009, after a long and difficult illness. Loving and beloved wife of Richard, mother of Peter and Anne, and relative, friend and mentor to countless others, Eve was an accomplished and respected law professor, author and civil liberties lawyer. Most important, she was a person of extraordinary goodness and self-awareness. She was unique.

TOYOTA said its ''consumer safety advisory'' issued on Tuesday about floor mats possibly jamming the accelerator pedal would not result in the world's largest redesign of mats. Instead, the automaker was looking for a way to make sure the driver could overcome a stuck accelerator. ''This is not a floor-mat recall,'' said Brian Lyons, a Toyota spokesman. ''We want to put in an on-vehicle countermeasure.''

TEN years ago the digital music revolution got jump-started with the invention of Napster and the rise of file sharing. In 1999 the artist and blogger Andrew Kuo was a 21-year-old music obsessive who kept a record of every album he bought and every show he saw. (He still does.) Below he charts the way his experience of acquiring and enjoying music has changed along with the advent of iPods, MP3 blogs, iTunes, MySpace, streaming, RapidShare and Twitter. ''I enjoy music more than ever, and I spend more time on it than ever, but I'm not participating in it in the same way in that I'm spending a lot less money,'' he said. ''When I hear that an album leaks, I want to hear it right away. Instead of finding information one step at a time, one record at a time, now it seems like the information finds you, from multiple and seemingly endless sources.''

The Red Sox have had numerous Champagne celebrations over the last 10 years, but last week's was different. On Wednesday night, Boston needed a home victory over Toronto or a loss by the Rangers, who played the Angels on the West Coast, to clinch the American League wild-card berth. When the reeling Red Sox dropped their fifth game in a row, the mood in the clubhouse was dreary. Still, most of the players remained because the Rangers' game was just starting in Anaheim.
STORCH--Murray M.,died on September 28, 2009. Survived by wife Maxine Storch and daughter Kym Storch.

The Evening Hours column on Sept. 20 misstated the surname of the New York Philharmonic's incoming chairman, who was a guest at the orchestra's opening-night gala on Sept. 16. He is Gary W. Parr, not Carr.

TO win in Afghanistan, the United States and its allies must prevent the rise of a new generation of anti-American terrorists, particularly suicide terrorists. The metric for measuring this threat is not the amount of territory controlled by the Taliban or Al Qaeda, but the number of people willing to be recruited as suicide terrorists. These individuals are motivated not by the existence of a terrorist sanctuary, but by deep anger at the presence of foreign forces on land they prize.

AS the artist Tom Sachs sees it, nothing beats the Hermès Kelly bag. ''It's the holy grail of handbags,'' he said. ''There's no bag beyond it.'' Except, of course, his version, fashioned from hardware-store supplies for added durability. Priced at a cool $12,000 (higher than the classic Hermès style, but, as Mr. Sachs reasoned, ''it's far more exclusive''), the bag is among the myriad art objects for sale at Larry Gagosian's new Madison Avenue shop, up the street from his uptown gallery. There are Jeff Koons porcelain puppy vases; Marc Newson marble tables and chairs; prints by Ed Ruscha and Damien Hirst; and an assortment of artist books, including Richard Prince's ''Bettie Kline,'' a leather-bound publication that juxtaposes photos of Bettie Page with paintings by Franz Kline. Its release will be celebrated on Oct. 6, along with the store's official opening.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Dementia Risk Seen in Players in N.F.L. Study,'' Sept. 30: Dr. Ira Casson, the league's primary voice in denying any association between an N.F.L. career and dementia, is the sole examining physician in a long-term study of 120 former players. How does this differ from a drug company's sponsoring a research study of its own products? As a co-chairman of the N.F.L. committee on this issue, Casson should be objective in his roles as protector of patients (players) under his care, adviser to the N.F.L and researcher.

Pinstripe fanatics who hustle from their cars to their seats for playoff games this month may not realize it, but there are plenty of things to do near Yankee Stadium that don't involve beer, booing or going broke. Concourse Village -- taking its name from the Grand Concourse -- has museums and theaters that put the lie to the outdated image of a South Bronx aflame. Better yet, they don't require a week's salary (or millions in tax-free bonds) to finance a family outing. Parts of the South Bronx were still smoldering more than 25 years ago when arts administrators and civic boosters began building the South Bronx Cultural Corridor, showcasing local and international artists, all near the 161st Street stop on the No. 4 or the D train.

SIDI--Hildegard Kosterlitz, 86, passed away peacefully at home on October 1. She was predeceased by her loving husband of 53 years, Dr. Henri Sidi. Their lives together were blessed with two daughters and son-in-laws and five grandsons. She escaped Nazi Germany and started a new life with Henri. She worked for more than 20 years at BMW as an executive assistant, while he worked at Tenneco as a research scientist with more than 100 patents attributed directly to his work. They will be missed by all. Contributions may be made to Autism Speaks.

ONE recent afternoon, I slid into a spot on Queens Boulevard controlled by parking meter No. 417-1003 with a minute left on it. Needing change, I rushed across the street to a tiny bakery to buy three pieces of sugar-free rugelach. With two quarters in my hand to legalize my relationship with the meter, I loped out of the bakery to find an officer writing a ticket for $35.

Parents usually try to steer their children away from ingredients like sugar and artificial cherry flavoring. But this fall, those pedestrian food additives might help treat some children stricken with the flu. With the liquid children's version of the anti-influenza drug Tamiflu in short supply, pharmacists are making their own children's version by mixing cherry syrup with the contents of the Tamiflu capsules.

THE government of Pakistan, through its intelligence agency, has long been a patron of the Afghan Taliban, and Gen. Stanley McChrystal recently warned that the collaboration continues. Pakistan sees the relationship as a way of hedging its bets in Afghanistan, an asset in its confrontation with India. It is difficult to define a clear benchmark for ending that aid because the Pakistanis refuse to acknowledge that any relationship exists. But let us consider it to have ended or gone into remission if, a year from now, six consecutive months have gone by with no credible reporting of the sort that underlay the general's observation.

ROSS--Ira Franklin, DDS, 89, of St. Petersburg, FL, formerly of South Orange, NJ, died October 1, 2009. Noted periodontist, author, professor NYU Dental School, and Chair, Periodontics Department, NJ College of Medicine and Dentistry. Member, NJ State Board of Dental Examiners and Diplomate, American Board of Periodontology. Served in WWII as a Major in the U.S. Army Air Corps (Dental Corps). In retirement, he wrote, narrated and produced "Opera for Everyone", a CD series distributed free to music educators world-wide. Member of the Academy of Senior Professionals at Eckerd College (ASPEC) and dedicated philanthropist. His family was his greatest joy. He is survived by his wife of nearly 64 years, Helene Strousse Ross, his daughters Dr. Margaret Ross Link, Laura Roth, and Elizabeth Ross, and eight loving grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in St. Petersburg, FL in November.

It is not often that a player adds his name to a list that had included just the Hall of Famers Tris Speaker, Paul Waner and Stan Musial. But that is what Brian Roberts did on Sept. 9 when he hit his 50th double of the season, becoming the fourth player to record three 50-double seasons in a career. At 56 doubles, he has a slight chance of becoming the first player since 1936 to reach 60 doubles. Even if Roberts does not reach 60 doubles, he made baseball history on Sept. 29 by hitting his 56th double of the season, which broke Lance Berkman's record for doubles by a switch-hitter, set in 2001.

Alabama running back Mark Ingram, left, had a career-high 140 yards and 2 touchdowns in the Crimson Tide's 38-20 victory over Kentucky. He scored on runs of 11 and 32 yards. Toledo quarterback Aaron Opelt completed 30 of 38 passes for 422 yards and threw a 51-yard touchdown pass with 27 seconds to lift the Rockets to a 37-30 victory over Ball State.

FEW in the auto industry were satisfied with the calculations that awarded the Chevrolet Volt a mileage rating of 230 miles a gallon (which has since been topped by the Nissan Leaf battery car at 367). Those numbers are based on a draft Environmental Protection Agency standard for plug-in hybrids and battery cars. But the agency says its work isn't complete and it is searching for meaningful ways to present mileage information to car buyers on the window sticker.

RICHMOND--Renee, of Purchase, NY, and formerly of Scarsdale, NY, died on September 25 at 1:30am. Beloved wife of Henry Richmond for 62 years. Mother of Pamela Carnot, David Richmond and Eileen Richmond-Becker. Grandmother of Brett, Kimberly and Justin. Great-grandmother of Zoe, Eden and Emma. Renee graduated from NYU with a degree in Occupational Therapy. Over the years she used her artistic talents to design a bathroom that became National. She acquired and surrounded herself with beautiful art. Living room curators lend works from collections to the Neuberger. Renee Richmond led off with the Rembrandts, moving on to the Goya, Piranesi, Hograth and Canaletto. She and her husband Henry began their art collection with works by the old masters, she said, so it was fitting to start a tour of the collection in the couple's front hall, where the oldest picture hung. Renee was a beautiful woman who surrounded herself with beauty and the love of family and friends. We shall all miss her dearly.

TOOHEY--Edward Joseph, of New York City and Southampton, NY passed away on September 30th at home in Southampton just four months shy of his 80th birthday. Born in Jersey City, NJ on January 15, 1930, he was a graduate of the Peddie School and Yale University, Class of 1954. He served on active duty in the US Marine Corps for three years followed by 18 years in the Marine Corps Reserve attaining the rank of Major. His long and distinguished career at Merrill Lynch spanned 45 years. He was a Board member of many organizations including the New York City Ballet, the Peddie School, the Windham Foundation, and Bunbury Company. He will be deeply missed by Phyllis Toohey, his wife of over 60 years, his daughter and son-in-law Karen and Jeff Hughes and his adored grandchildren Andrew and Alexandra Hughes, as well as his extended family and many friends. The family will receive friends at Frank Campbell Funeral Home in New York City on Tuesday, October 6 from 6-9pm. A funeral service will be held Wednesday, October 7th at 10:30am at The Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest at Fifth Avenue and 90th Street. Burial will be Thursday at 11am at Southampton Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Yale University, Office of Development, P.O. Box 2038, New Haven CT 06521 or the Marine Corps Heritage Foundation in support of the National Museum of the Marine Corps, 3800 Fettler Drive, Dumfries, VA 22025.
Following the Rules For Subletting

A MERICA cannot achieve even the minimal objective of preventing Al Qaeda from re-establishing safe havens in Afghanistan without a substantial increase in forces over the coming year. The Taliban insurgency in Afghanistan's south is growing. The Afghan and international forces there now cannot reverse that growth. They may not even be able to stem it. That is the assessment of the top American commander there, Gen. Stanley McChrystal. President Obama said in August, ''If left unchecked, the Taliban insurgency will mean an even larger safe haven from which Al Qaeda would plot to kill more Americans.'' Some of his advisers now say the opposite: Taliban control will not lead to terrorist havens. Why not? Osama bin Laden first built camps in the territory of a Taliban leader, Jalaluddin Haqqani, in the mid-1980s. Relations between Al Qaeda and the Taliban remain close. Even if they do not invite Al Qaeda in, could they, unlike Pakistan, keep Al Qaeda out? The president was right: the triumph of the Taliban will benefit Al Qaeda.

SEIDMAN--Harold W.,died September 27, 2009. Adored husband of Miriam (Mimi), and devoted father of Lynn Tepe and Sam Seidman (deceased). Lived at Peconic Landing, Greenport, NY, after many years in Glen Cove, NY. A CPA who practiced accounting in Astoria, Queens, and later in Glen Cove. After active military service in WWII (purple heart, bronze star), he retired as a Lt. Colonel in 1970. In 2001 he was recognized for his lifetime achievements by the American Institute of CPAs, and was voted accountant of the year in 1990 by the NYS Society of CPAs. As chairman of the Glen Cove Housing Authority he helped plan and fund construction of the elderly housing complex which bears his name. He was an Adjunct Associate Professor of Accounting and Taxation at CW Post College.

After being interrupted by a 2-hour-and-20-minute rain delay, the Mets held on to beat the Houston Astros, 5-1, at a mostly empty Citi Field on Saturday. Pitching in a downpour, Pat Misch gave the Mets five solid innings, allowing five hits and one run, before the umpires halted the game. Asked if he had any idea why the umpires resumed the meaningless contest, Jerry Manuel said, ''No, I don't.'' ... Carlos Beltran was scratched from the lineup because, Manuel said, ''he was a little under the weather.'' Like David Wright, who was rested Saturday, he is expected to play in the final game of the season Sunday.

SAFIRE--William. The "Wednesday Ten" mourns the passing of our founder and inspiring leader, Bill Safire. It was over 50 years ago that Bill got the idea of bringing together a group of young men who had come to New York to build their careers. The "rules" were simple: we would meet once a month (often with accomplished guests); there would be no more than two from each profession or calling; we would tell one another about our work and our lives; we would teach one another about the world as we saw it and the opportunities it presented. From that humble beginning sprang a group who continued to meet together, though less frequently, right up to today. It bred lifelong friendships, much learning of the ways of the world and produced a host of successful people. Now, over 50 years later, we have lost the man who conceived the idea, brought us together and continued to lead us in the ways of friendship, knowledge and success. We will miss Bill Safire profoundly. We will miss his erudition, his wit and his teaching. The best thing we can do in his memory is to seek to keep our group going until, over time, we all join Bill in his new venue where we are sure the table will be laid and he will be waiting for us with his wry smile. Howard Amron Stanley Bartels Fred Berman Thomas Bishop Edward Bleier Paul Chan Joseph Forman Roy Goodman Arthur Gray Larry Grossman Mort Janklow Mortimer Lacher George Lang Robert Lifton Marshall Loeb Robert Menschel Edward Meyer Thomas Morgan Marvin Newman Leon Root James Rosenfield Charles Sigety Leonard Zweig

GOODMAN--John B.,unexpectedly on September 16, 2009 in Colorado, formerly of New York. Son of Richard and the late Dorothy. Brother of Annie. Survived by his wife Rebecah, three children Sarah, Joshua and David and two grandchildren. Donations can be made to the Denver Humane Society.

TO defeat the insurgency, the Afghan government and its main partner, the United States, need to win the confidence of the public. Accountability must replace the widespread immunity enjoyed by officials who abuse their power. Despite all the problems with our recent election, the incoming government will have a chance to start fresh, and a proper vetting of all new officials is the place to begin. This means establishing strict accountability mechanisms for high officials in the districts and provinces as well as in the ministries and directorates in Kabul. Simply shuffling abusive and incompetent officials among offices -- as has been the norm over the past eight years -- keeps the public from getting the governmental services it needs.

THE WILD SIDE Predators create a landscape of fear. I imagine this as a place of shadows, where your heart beats fast, you are listening and alert, and forever glancing over your shoulder. In places where predators roam, the landscape of fear is as real as the physical landscape. But rather than being made of mountains and valleys, forests and grasslands, it's smells, sounds and adrenaline. Some time ago, I saw a clear example of how predators can change things. A friend of mine had a fish tank containing one big fish (about a foot long) and seven or eight much smaller fish (each about an inch). The small fish always went around together, in a tight school. Then, one day, after a long and pampered existence, the big fish died. As soon as his body was taken out of the tank, the little fish stopped schooling. You could almost hear them gurgling with relief.

WOLDMAN--Murray M.,87, husband of the late Harriet Woldman of Norwalk, Connecticut passed away Thursday, October 1, 2009 in Boca Raton, Florida. SAFIRE--William. The Directors and staff of the Dana Foundation express our profound sense of loss with the death of our colleague, Chairman and CEO, William Safire. He served on our Board since 1993 and as our chair since 2000. We mourn Bill not only because we have lost our chairman but also because we have lost a dear friend, a man of unparalleled intellect and wit who was devoted to the Foundation and its work. During his tenure, Bill was our greatest champion-always working to enhance and build Dana's mission and outreach. We extend our most heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Helene and his children, Mark and Annabel.

Lucy, you sweet young thing. No longer can you lay claim to being the oldest creature on the human branch of the primate family tree. The honor goes to Ardi, who at 4.4 million years old has you beat by a little over a million. Her assembled bones were unveiled Thursday by scientists who had been analyzing the Ardipithecus specimen since fragments were found in Ethiopia in 1992. The particulars: Taller and heavier than Lucy, she weighed about 120 pounds and stood four feet tall (yes, she probably walked upright, though she was still an agile tree-climber). Forget the high heels; her feet had no arches (Lucy's did). Tim D. White of Berkeley, a leader of the study team, said, ''We are getting so close to that common ancestor of hominids and chimps, and we'd love to find an earlier skeleton.''

KELLY--Richard J. (Dick). May 4, 1934 September 26, 2009. Born in Yonkers, NY. Dick attended Jamaica High School in Queens, NY. He was a graduate of CUNY Queens College earning a B.S. degree in Accounting and Economics. Dick earned his Certified Public Accountant (CPA) license and was the youngest professional to be named Partner at KPMG (Hurdman and Cran-ston at the time). Dick rose to become managing partner of the KPMG Stamford, CT office. After retirement at age 55 he was recruited by KPMG to be managing partner again, but this time for a start-up office in St. Maarten. After just 18 months the office had established itself on the island and Dick was told "you did such a good job building this practice we don't need you anymore." He then joined the Rotary Club and started his own practice for 4++ years along with a senior partner. Dick was also a prolific writer. He authored "The Advertising Budget," a standard reference work of The Association of National Advertisers which was translated into four languages and was an international business book best seller. Dick served as a consulting editor for the national accounting magazines "CPA" and "The Journal of Accountancy." He was a member of several professional and social organizations including a founding member of The Wild Geese, an organization that promotes Irish American heritage. While living in Croton-on-Hudson, NY, he was very active in community affairs. He became a Village Trustee, member of the Croton Council Knights of Columbus, parishioner of Holy Name of Mary Church, was an umpire, coach and six-year member of the Croton Little League Board of Directors. But it was his position as Little League sports columnist of the two local newspapers he was most proud. For three years he wrote a weekly newspaper column on Little League happenings in Croton. "There's one thing I'm quite proud of in writing those columns," he said. "Every year by using a little imagination, I was able to work in the name of every player in the league. It really meant something for those kids to see their names in print." His main interests were his extended family, friends, The Brooklyn Dodgers (and subsequently NY Mets), golf, reading, particularly history and politics, crossword puzzles, traveling and organic gardening. He is predeceased by a brother and a sister. He is survived by Elaine, his wife of 53 years, his oldest son Richard and wife Nancy, his second son Christopher, three grandchildren Megan, Laura, Brendan, a brother Ed and sisters Jeanne and Peggy. There will be a small private service and the family will receive friends at a later date.

DESSAU--Ruth S.,85, passed away, September 30th in New York City. Beloved mother of Stephen and Richard, widow of the late Stephen M. Loving grandmother of Julie, David, Dustin and James. Loyal and caring sister of Anthony Spinner. She was a highly intelligent, creative person, active patron of the arts and enthusiastic international traveler. She will be greatly missed by her family and her friends. Services to be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison, Monday, October 5th, 9:30am. In lieu of flowers please make donations to the Susan B. Komen Fund for Breast Cancer Research.

SOAKING UP THE SUN IN FRANCISCO COLOANE MARINE PARK, STRAIT OF MAGELLAN, CHILE, MARCH 10, 2009 Nicole Rickenbach, a 32-year-old hotel clerk from Ftan, Switzerland, relaxes after a rain-soaked whale-watching trip. ''The whales were so powerful and big. I felt lucky to see them. There's a wideness to Tierra del Fuego; it's just wide open. To get around, I hitchhiked -- I don't do it in Switzerland, but in Patagonia, I wasn't afraid -- and I took the bus. During one bus trip to Puerto Natales, I met an old man, about 75 to 80 years old. He was impressed that I'd come from so far away. He invited me to come to his home. His wife is dead. His son and daughter live with him, and they have sheep, and many children. His daughter cooked for me. I stayed there for two days. They were worried for me because they weren't used to a woman traveling alone. They wanted to accompany me all the time. Near their house, they showed me a condor's home in a rock, and we watched small condors learning to fly. The people in Patagonia have a lot of heart, and a great sense of humor.'' As told to Hilary Howard

Of all the weeks for injuries to ravage members of the Jets' secondary, this may be the worst. Some -- like safeties Kerry Rhodes and Jim Leonhard, and cornerback Darrelle Revis, below -- missed practice but are expected to play. Others, like cornerbacks Lito Sheppard and Donald Strickland, could miss their second game this season. The Jets have held opposing quarterbacks to the lowest completion percentage in the N.F.L. (47.9) and rank second in opposing quarterbacks' passer rating (50.2). On Sunday, they face Drew Brees, who holds a 118.1 passer rating and has completed 69.1 percent of his passes.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Saturday, September 19th 2009, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount and department stores; and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics; and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

For parents who think they are doing the right thing, financially, to prepare for their children’s college years, there is a troubling article in today’s Times by Sean D. Hamill.
About one in eight women take an antidepressant at some time during pregnancy, reports Roni Rabin in today’s Science Times. But is it safe?

The good news for the late-night comedians this weekend: a new celebrity sex scandal had just broken full of juicy details for them to spin into jokes. The bad news: the celebrity in question was their fellow late-night host David Letterman.

What we’re reading on Monday morning.Writing on Deadline: In The New Yorker, Tad Friend contributes this profile of Nikki Finke, the Deadline Hollywood Daily reporter and blogger, providing an intricate portrait of the relationships between entertainment industry executives and journalists. (David Carr previously wrote about Ms. Finke for The New York Times in July.) In Hollywood, Mr. Friend writes, “relationships are paramount but provisional … you’re friends with benefits, without being friends.” On her own blog, Ms. Finke writes that she is “relieved that The New Yorker didn’t lay a glove on me.”

Want frites with your Mona Lisa? Visitors to the Louvre in Paris soon won’t have to travel far to enjoy the works of Leonardo, Delacroix and Géricault after dining on Le Big Mac: a McDonald’s restaurant and McCafé are planned to open near the Louvre in November, The Telegraph of London reported. Though the fast-food establishments will be in the underground shopping area below the museum, called the Carrousel du Louvre, and not the Louvre itself, the impending opening is already causing indigestion among some art aficionados. “I’m not against eating in a museum but McDonald’s is hardly the height of gastronomy,” Didier Rykner, the editor of the Web site, The Art Tribune, told The Telegraph, adding: “Today McDonald’s, tomorrow low-cost clothes shops.” In a statement, the Louvre said that it welcomed the fact that its visitors, “French or foreign,” will be able to enjoy “a rich and varied” selection of restaurants. Last year, Louvre employees and art admirers sent the museum a petition to protest a Starbucks planned near the museum, but were unable to stop the coffee shop from opening.

AUSTIN, Tex.–“We’ve been here three days in Austin,” said Eddie Vedder of Pearl Jam on Sunday night, “and we’ve received many, many gifts. So we hope to repay some of it tonight.” He looked out across the teeming, mud-spattered crowd at Zilker Park, and struck a note of solidarity: “I’m not leaving here ‘til I’m covered in dirt!”

Show business, take note: there just might be increased demand for horror offerings in the weeks leading up to Halloween. Paramount has become the latest movie studio to stumble onto this truism with the limited release of its micro-budget film “Paranormal Activity,” whose midnight screenings have proved so successful that the company said it was expanding the film’s showings at theaters this weekend. In the spirit of inexpensive thrillers like “The Blair Witch Project,” “Paranormal Activity,” purports to be the found footage recorded by a man and a woman who hear inexplicable noises in their San Diego home. The film, written and directed by Oren Peli and made for a cost of about $10,000, was released on Sept. 25 with midnight-only screenings in 13 college towns. It later expanded to 20 metropolitan areas (including New York) after audiences voted to request the film on the Web site eventful.com. Over the weekend, Paramount said that “Paranormal Activity” sold out all of its midnight screenings in 33 cities, earning $535,000 in ticket sales or about $16,000 per screen. Starting Friday, the studio said, it will expand the film to 40 markets where it will be shown at all hours.

A documentary series hosted by DJ AM, who died from a drug overdose in August, will be shown on MTV, the cable channel said Monday in a news release. For the eight-episode series, called “Gone Too Far,” young addicts were recorded in meetings with DJ AM and their families and friends as they discuss their substance abuse problems and seek treatment. DJ AM, whose given name was Adam Goldstein, was found dead in his Manhattan apartment on Aug. 28. Last month, the New York medical examiner’s office ruled that he died from an accidental overdose of prescription drugs and cocaine. In a statement, Mr. Goldstein’s family, which gave its approval for the series to be shown, said it hoped it would “inspire others to seek help.” MTV said that the first episode of “Gone Too Far” would be shown on Oct. 12.

Four years into the much-delayed renovation of the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow, that city’s mayor has warned the principal contractor behind the project that it would be replaced if it did not speed up the job, Agence France-Presse reported. “We have warned the main contractor that we are on the verge of dispensing with their services,” said the mayor, Yuri Luzhkov, in comments to reporters that were broadcast on state television, Agence France-Presse reported. He added that he had expressed concerns about “the sluggishness of the work” after visiting the construction site. The 185-year-old theater, home to both the Bolshoi Ballet and Bolshoi Opera, closed in July 2005 to undergo renovations that were supposed to be completed by 2008, but are now not likely to be finished until at least 2011. Last month, Russian prosecutors said that they had opened an investigation into the possible embezzlement of funds for the restoration project.

The ubiquitous Sherri Shepherd — a host of “The View,” a recurring cast member of “30 Rock,” a serious actress in “Precious” — becomes even more inescapable with the premiere of her own sitcom, “Sherri” (Lifetime, 7 p.m.). She plays a recently divorced woman who’s working as a paralegal but wants to be an actress. Any resemblance to her own very public break-up with the comedian Jeff Tarpley will be purely coincidental.

The show is going on. The Manhattan Theater Club is going ahead with plans to open its Broadway production of “The Royal Family” on Thursday night despite the illness of one of its stars, Tony Roberts.

An etching put up for auction on Thursday that purports to depict Hitler and Lenin playing chess failed to attract any bidders, according to Richard Westwood-Brookes, the curator of the auction. The auction was held by Mullock’s Specialist Auctioneers & Valuers in Shropshire, England. The pre-sale estimate was about $63,000 to $95,000.

Update | 5:25 p.m. The debate over the United States’ behavior toward the victims of Nazi genocide is shot through with passion, so when an article in The New York Times was published last month about new evidence interpreted as critical of President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s policies, scholars who had other views spoke up.
So far in our coverage of the New York Musical Theater Festival we’ve explored fantasy football and a fat camp. Now we turn to a show with a more serious subject.
Update | 5:07 p.m. The Metropolitan Opera and its stagehands are in a dispute over who gets to build the huge set for the Met’s new “Ring” cycle scheduled to open next season.
In May, word leaked that Archie Andrews, the famous comic-book redhead from Riverdale, would propose to one of his longtime love interests: Betty Cooper or Veronica Lodge.

As Hollywood chews over what obligatory congratulations gift to send Rich Ross, the Disney Channel president who was just named as the new chairman of Walt Disney Studios, a real life movie star has weighed in on the promotion.

Matt Ginsberg is back with another creative and unusual puzzle. If you haven't tried this Tuesday crossword, I have a special quiz just for you. Name a common English word that has the sequence MPG somewhere in the middle. No, I'm not even going to tell you how many letters. Got it? How about ADQ? KSG? The toughest might be ZKR. If you're struggling, you'd be right to suspect compound words are useful to consider. The ZKR answer derives from another language, but it also appears in English dictionaries. Two more: SPB and NKC.
Levi Johnston, the former fiancé of Bristol Palin and the father of Sarah Palin's grandson, is making light on his past in video advertisements for a pistachio company.

Peter Baker reports in Tuesday's Times that the White House has begun promoting the missile strikes and raids that have taken out militants working with Al Qaeda in Pakistan, Somalia and elsewhere, noting that President Obama will visit the National Counter Terrorism Center on Tuesday to call attention to the operations.

A friend of mine is running for a seat on the town council, and the other day she and I sat on the porch of the local coffee shop talking about the village she lives in all year round and I call home in the summer and early fall. The town is Andes, N.Y. It is on Route 28, roughly halfway between Woodstock and Cooperstown, about three hours and change from the city. And it flourishes against all odds. I'm trying to figure out why.

For just one glimpse at why senators are anxiously awaiting the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office's cost estimate of the Finance Committee's health care bill, consider an amendment offered by Senator John D. Rockefeller IV.
Fall's later sunrises bring longer shadows to the morning rush hour. On any particularly sunny morning, the shadows of people in the city seem to constitute a fleeting parallel universe at our feet.
In the hierarchy of Manhattan media, Condé Nast Publications long had the status of a gated community, a place where reality was always turned away by security.
Matthew Yglesias of the Center for American Progress and Alyssa Rosenberg of Government Executive discuss the politics of police procedural shows.

After 16 years with Green Bay and one unsatisfying one with the Jets, Vikings quarterback Brett Favre played the Packers for the first time tonight. The Fifth Down was watching, and we'd love to hear from you.
Howard Marks is chairman of Oaktree Capital Management.
A look at discussions inside the Arab world, as played out in Arabic newspapers.

ATLANTA - Rogers Redding, the Southeastern Conference coordinator of football officials, said Monday that Georgia receiver A.J. Green was penalized incorrectly late in Saturday's game against Louisiana State for excessive celebration.

David Letterman apologized on the air Monday to his wife, Regina, for his revelation last week of his sexual relationships with staff members, saying she had been "horribly hurt" and adding, "I've got my work cut out for me" to mend the relationship.
Expanding health insurance to cover everyone over the age of 51 might help save costs to Medicare in the long run, according to a new study reported in the Annals of Internal Medicine.

The roll-out of the swine flu vaccination program, one of the largest such drives in U.S. history, started Monday. The federal government has ordered 250 million doses of vaccine, which will be distributed by state health officials this fall.

A 45-year-old man fell to his death last Tuesday while cutting tree limbs at a Taylor Road home in Millburn. Elides Urena of Bound Brook fell from about 50 feet, according to the Millburn Police Department. Officers responded to a 911 call at 10:50 a.m., and C.P.R. was performed. Mr. Urena was taken to Saint Barnabas Medical Center and pronounced dead at 11:35 a.m. The cause of the fall has not been determined. -- Jean-Pierre Mestanza

Fraudulently claiming to be a decorated war hero so infuriates veterans that they have given the deception a name: stolen valor. And since 2005, it has been against federal law, punishable by a fine and up to a year in prison.Now, in perhaps the highest-profile case of its type this year, the government has charged a Colorado man, Richard G. Strandlof, with fraudulently claiming to have won a Purple Heart in Iraq.

Can a television executive run a movie studio? Robert A. Iger sure thinks so, naming Rich Ross, president of Disney Channels Worldwide, to run Walt Disney Studios. Add some substantial filmmaking firepower to Mr. Ross's corner: Steven Spielberg and Stacey Snider.

JPMorgan Chase plans to expand its work force of private bankers in the coming months as the wealthy move out of banks hit hard by the financial crisis and into stronger ones, the chief executive of its American private bank said Monday.
After writing about the search for a lost painting by Leonardo Da Vinci in my Findings column, I have several questions for you:

Leaf-peeping season is upon us, and thousands of travelers are undoubtedly making plans to head north for their annual sightseeing journey along the roads and trails of New England. But the travel Web site Gadling has alternative suggestion: Head south to Kentucky.
Morgan Stanley has hired Kevin Dunleavy from Bank of America Merrill Lynch to be a managing director in the firm's sales and trading division.
In today's Science Times, reporter Carla Baranauckas writes about a major new effort to study the role that pets play in human health.
The meeting in Geneva last Thursday between the United States plus allies and Iran was the best of foreign policy, it was the worst of foreign policy. Take your pick.

They tend to stay out of the spotlight and that's how they like it. Many of them boast impressive political resumes and illustrious lineage, and are seasoned veterans of past campaigns -- some successful, others not.
Thanks for your questions on therapy pets and autism. See Dr. Nishawala's responses, below.
AY Donald writes:

Some might think that people like us are silly, or even obsessive. When we say "people like us," we mean cooks who do not buy pre-ground meat but do it themselves, starting with meat purchased from farmers or butchers they trust.
Chinese officials zealously guard the image of Chairman Mao, but that has not stopped young artists from reinterpreting his image amidst a thriving underground art scene.

Bank of New York Mellon, which has been busy integrating its merger and conserving capital for the past two years, is now ready to seek wealth management acquisitions across the United States as well as expand in several overseas markets.

Of the few things in life more mind-numbingly tedious than watching Baz Luhrmann's antipodean epic, "Australia," flying between New York and Down Under ranks high on the list. In fact, given a choice, I'd take Luhrmann's schlockbuster any day.

Taylor and Cassidy Saporito won the Constitution State Challenge Dancesport Championship on Sunday. The two sisters were declared the winners in each of the 10 dances they performed. Taylor attends Millburn Middle School, and Cassidy goes to South Mountain School. The girls trained with Mr. Spencer Nyemchek and Mrs. Elena Nyemchek of Bergen County.
Today's Really? column by Anahad O'Connor tackles a colorful question: Does green nasal discharge signal a bacterial infection?

Last month, Bryant Park hosted the white tents and devotees of Fashion Week. This month, it's been replaced by another temporary structure with very different guests: a large sukkah, or ceremonial hut, where Jews pray and dine in celebration of the eight-day harvest holiday of Sukkot.
On a sunny morning, the filmmaker Jeff Scher finds a fleeting parallel universe in pedestrians' shadows.
Many found the appointment of Fabio Trabocchi as the new executive chef at the Four Seasons restaurant surprising.

As the editor of publications like Rugged PC Review and the founder of Pen Computing Magazine, Conrad Blickenstorfer has been reporting on tablet computers for over two decades. He still remembers, for instance, when a Microsoft executive predicted in 1991 that "the impact of pens on computing will be far greater than the mouse," creating low-cost portable PCs "that will appeal to a broader spectrum of users than ever before."
The Walt Disney Company has hired one of its star TV executives to overhaul its struggling motion picture studio.

When Comme des Garçons approached Artek - the 75-year-old Finnish company known for producing Alvar Aalto's furniture designs - to create a fragrance, one of Artek's first ideas was to have it smell like one of the company's showrooms. ''That would have been naïve, to have a scent of birch,'' says Ville Kokkonen, Artek's head of design, who explained that ''bottling the scent of chairs'' just wouldn't make sense. (Tell that to Herzog & de Meuron, whose 2005 perfume Rotterdam smells like hashish and Rhine water.) Instead, Artek's result, Standard eau de toilette, evokes the brand through a more subtle blend of linnea borealis flowers, Finnish labrador tea and metal - nature meets machine, as in the classic bentwood chairs for which the company is known. Standard is a major departure for Artek, which is looking to branch out to other cultural platforms; hence the splashy appearance at this summer's Venice Biennale. But in general, perfumes by designers and architects aren't quite the rarity they once were: In addition to Herzog & de Meuron, the Japanese architecture firm Sanaa recently released the limited-edition scent Translucence for the New Museum in New York, channeling the lightness of its buildings in notes of musk, freesia and apple.

Typhoon Parma continued on its path of devastation, hammering northeast Taiwan and forcing evacuations (Slides 1, 3 and 5). In Indonesia, crews were still searching for victims of last week's earthquake (Slides 2 and 4). Ultra-Orthodox Jews prayed at the Western Wall in Jerusalem during Sukkot (Slide 9). And protesting milk producers took aim on lower prices in Europe (Slide 12).
Bikers found a worthy cause to rally for on Sunday when the Turpin Foundation held its first annual Graham Turpin Memorial Motorcycle Rally to support pancreatic cancer research.

The judge overseeing the trial of Anthony D. Marshall, the son of Brooke Astor, the legendary New York society matriarch, exhorted the jury to "hang in there" on Monday afternoon, after the jury sent the judge two notes suggesting that it was struggling to reach a verdict.

When Defense Secretary Robert Gates said on Monday that it was "imperative'' that military advice to the president on Afghanistan remain "private,'' he left little doubt that he was talking about Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal. (See related article.)
Mark Bittman makes a light and delicious dessert.
MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. -- The connection between hip-hop artists and the Miami Hurricanes dates to the team's glory days of the late 1980s and early 1990s.

Every city has a few places where you're likely to find people from the wine trade. Here in New York, I run into wine people at Terroir, at Bar Boulud, and at my friend Mateo's place, Pata Negra. But I don't think I've run into quite as many - importers, winemakers, writers, sommeliers, sales people - anyplace as consistently as I have at the Ten Bells.

The Dutch Finance Ministry and Deutsche Bank are still in talks to meet an EU competition remedy that would allow a merger between state-owned ABN Amro and Fortis Bank Nederland, the ministry said Monday. The European Commission gave the Dutch government, which nationalised Dutch ABN AMRO and Fortis operations last year, an extension late Friday night to close an asset sale deal because of an ''imminent'' transaction with a ''large international bank." The ABN AMRO assets to be sold are the same ones Deutsche Bank was in talks to buy until Sept. 17, when talks between the ministry and bank broke off. When asked if the Dutch Finance Ministry was also in talks with French bank BNP Paribas about a possible deal to meet the EU remedy, a ministry spokeswoman said: ''We have made a proposal (to the European Commission) with possibilities. That's all I can say for now.''

Whenever a new version of the Microsoft Windows operating system becomes available, users of previous versions wonder and worry if their existing systems - hardware and software - will be compatible with it.

As if scoring goals on the road in World Cup qualifying isn't hard enough, the United States will be without one of its most effective attacking players Saturday in Honduras. Midfielder Clint Dempsey will miss the World Cup qualifier in San Pedro Sula with a shoulder injury.

For sheer fashion audacity, the prize goes to Viktor & Rolf: with the singer Roisin Murphy performing live in a lampshade tulle ensemble, the Dutch duo put on one of their most extravagant shows in seasons, reminiscent of their whimsical early couture experiments. They said that they had been inspired by the "credit crunch," which led them to cut through heavy layers of tulle to create mind-boggling sculptural effects. (One can't imagine, however, that they saved any money in the process.)

In the first part of thecrane.tv's special, "Fellini of Fashion," designers like John Galliano and Viktor & Rolf gushed over the runway producer Alexandre de Betak's creative vision. Now, in Part Deux, the Frenchman talks about how he reached his privileged perch.

Though the ratings for the 2010 Zagat guide to New York will not be officially released until Wednesday, it seems that a computer glitch resulted in some newer restaurants that either were not listed in last year's guide or were listed but unrated, being shown prematurely online today with their 2010 ratings.
Some people might think of retirement as moving to Florida, seeing their grandchildren, maybe a little fishing or golf. But on K Street, retirement can be a term of art.
Someone posted login details for thousands of Hotmail e-mail accounts online over the weekend, in what appears to be only part of an enormous haul of stolen passwords netted in a phishing scheme.
Since the American League has decided to play some more baseball before determining its postseason teams, I'm going to focus first on the National League and then the American later this week.

You spend all that time, years maybe, writing a book, and what does someone do? Gives it to a book reviewer. Or worse, a critic. Writers, take heart. Samuel Johnson understands, and speaks for you. Celebrating Johnson's tercentenary, Harvard University Press has just published a fine edition of his "Selected Writings," edited by Peter Martin. In an essay for the "Idler," Dr. Johnson expounded on what it takes to be a book critic:
Last week on Internet Protocol, we took a look at overzealous friend requests and being trapped in instant-messaging limbo.
Tired of iceberg? Weary of romaine? Try some of the more unusual greens now available at many farmers’ markets.

At a towering 6 feet 6 inches, Jay H. Walder, the new chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, barely fit beneath the ceiling of the Main Street Station in Flushing, Queens, the last stop on the No. 7 line, where he arrived on Monday morning to greet commuters as part of his first day in one of the state's most high-pressure jobs.

As Brazil celebrates its selection as host for the 2016 Summer Olympics, prepares to host the 2014 World Cup and enjoys its qualification for the 2010 tournament, its most keen rival in South America, Argentina, has been gripped by the grimly unthinkable.

A wave of defections from the United States Chamber of Commerce continued last week when Exelon, one of the country's largest utilities, announced its departure. John W. Rowe, the utility's chief executive, said Exelon was leaving because of the chamber's "stridency against carbon legislation." The chamber has recently opposed an Environmental Protection Agency proposal to use the Clear Air Act to set limits on greenhouse gases. In addition, chamber officials have been quoted calling for a "Scopes monkey trial" about the science of climate change. The chamber, which recently clarified its position on climate policy, says it is concerned that measures intended to address global warming will raise costs for business.

The Anne Frank Museum in Amsterdam, which preserves the memory of the young diarist who died of typhus in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp in 1945, posted the only known film footage of Anne Frank on a new YouTube channel launched last week. According to the museum, the film was shot on July 22, 1941, to record the wedding of a woman who lived next door to the Franks. About nine seconds in to the silent film embedded above, the camera tilts up from the bride and groom to show young Anne leaning out of the window of her house to see them.

JEMINA PEARL ''Break It Up'' (Ecstatic Peace/Universal Motown) Growing up might have seemed a liability to Jemina Pearl, who until last year was the lead singer for the Nashville punk outfit Be Your Own Pet. That band was chipper in its brattiness, and Ms. Pearl steered it as if inebriated. But what a wonderful mess she made -- the band's two albums were thrillingly cheap reminders of punk's simpler pleasures.

(Lifetime) SHERRI Sherri Shepherd of ''The View'' moves to prime time in this new series about another Sherri who shares a few things -- single mother, part-time actress -- with the woman who plays her. After that, fiction takes over. This Sherri supports herself as a paralegal while trying to re-enter the dating scene after divorcing the husband who cheated on her. James Avery plays Sherri's father; Kali Rocha is her difficult boss; and Michael Boatman a potential beau. In this premiere episode Sherri learns that the 20-year-old girlfriend of her ex (Malcolm-Jamal Warner, above, with Ms. Shepherd) is pregnant. FRED HAMMOND ''Love Unstoppable'' (Verity) The gospel singer Fred Hammond started as a bass player and consequently he sounds as if he's working from the engine room rather than from the front office. His music can be complex, and he sings from deep within its details. With ''Pages of Life'' (Verity), Mr. Hammond's best-selling record from the late 1990s, made with his band Radical for Christ, it seemed he'd set up a self-perpetuating system, concentric circles of chants and funk vamps, free roaming in his arrangements and the cycles of his amazing band and chorus.

HAUER--Rose Muscatine died Saturday, October 3. Beloved mother, grandmother and wife was born July 5, 1916. She was the pillar of the family, so loving and unwaverlingly loyal to all. We will always keep the wonderful feelings and experiences of her in our hearts. She graduated from the Beth Israel School of Nursing in 1939 and was Dean of the School of Nursing and Vice President for Nursing at Beth Israel until her retirement in 1988. She remained active in nursing nationally and internationally until her death. Her devotion to the profession of nursing and to Beth Israel was unparalled. Funeral services will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76st Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Tuesday, October 6, 10am. Private graveside service. Donations can be made to the Beth Israel School of Nursing Rose Hauer Fund.

Sub-Saharan Africa does not bring to mind an image of a woman with perfectly manicured nails flipping through glossy magazines in search of the latest handbag or celebrity haircut. Yet such women are there, and in far greater numbers than the news media's portrayal of Africa might suggest. In the wealthy neighborhoods of Lagos, Nigeria; Nairobi, Kenya; Luanda, Angola; Dakar, Senegal; and the like, ladies of leisure, successful businesswomen and middle-income housewives make up an attractive demographic that, in the past, relied on international fashion magazines for style and beauty information.

GOSSIP ''Music for Men'' (Columbia) A short list of tweaks turns Gossip into a pop band on its album ''Music for Men.'' Concentrate a little more on melody. Round off some guitar distortion. Follow through on the dance beats of the 2006 studio album ''Standing in the Way of Control.'' And add instruments and backup vocals here and there to the band's bare-bones sound: Hannah Blilie on drums, Brace Paine on guitar or bass and Beth Ditto on vocals. And voilà -- indie-rock barnstormers are pop contenders.

TALISMAN--Wilbur S.,Athlete, Attorney, Provocateur, formerly of Brooklyn, NY died October 3. We were a group of adolescent boys growing up in Borough Park during the 40's and 50's. We bonded together for life and called ourselves the "Secans" and defied the world to define us. Wilbur was our mainstay. He was an essential part of the New Utrecht High School basketball team and the annual basketball championships, we won at the Boro Park YMHA. Later as an attorney specializing in negligence cases, he was the scourge of the defense attorneys who came up against him. He was a legend on the tennis court as denoted by his competitive spirit. We hereby note our great loss, the absence of his insouciant wit and the love and generosity of his friendship. We join with his dear wife, daughters, sons-in-law and grandchildren in mourning our loss. The Boys From Boro Park

Did winning an Emmy Award on Sept. 20 translate into a boost in a series' ratings the following week? Of the top five category winners ranked in the chart, two have not been back since the awards broadcast. ''30 Rock,'' with Tina Fey and Alec Baldwin, above, won the comedy series award, and will have its season premiere on Oct. 15. ''Wizards of Waverly Place,'' which won the children's show award, will open a new season on Friday. Among the shows returning after the Emmys, ''The Amazing Race'' ended Season 14 and began Season 15 with a bump in ratings. Several other winners had an increase as well: ''The Daily Show,'' ''Mad Men,'' which rose to 1.2 from 0.7, and ''South Park,'' which went to 1.0 from 0.8. SHELLY FREIERMAN

TOOHEY--Edward Joseph, of New York City and Southampton, NY passed away on September 30th at home in Southampton just four months shy of his 80th birthday. Born in Jersey City, NJ on January 15, 1930, he was a graduate of the Peddie School and Yale University, Class of 1954. He served on active duty in the US Marine Corps for three years followed by 18 years in the Marine Corps Reserve attaining the rank of Major. His long and distinguished career at Merrill Lynch spanned 45 years. He was a Board member of many organizations including the New York City Ballet, the Peddie School, the Windham Foundation, and Bunbury Company. He will be deeply missed by Phyllis Toohey, his wife of over 60 years, his daughter and son-in-law Karen and Jeff Hughes and his adored grandchildren Andrew and Alexandra Hughes, as well as his extended family and many friends. The family will receive friends at Frank Campbell Funeral Home in New York City on Tuesday, October 6 from 6-9pm. A funeral service will be held Wednesday, October 7th at 10:30am at The Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest at Fifth Avenue and 90th Street. Burial will be Thursday at 11am at Southampton Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Yale University, Office of Development, P.O. Box 2038, New Haven CT 06521 or the Marine Corps Heritage Foundation in support of the National Museum of the Marine Corps, 3800 Fettler Drive, Dumfries, VA 22025.

The next entry in the White House’s music series will feature Latin artists to honor Hispanic heritage, The Associated Press reported. Among the performers who are expected to appear at the Fiesta Latina event on Tuesday night are the singers Marc Anthony, Gloria Estefan, José Feliciano, Thalia and Tito “El Bambino,” as well as the groups Los Lobos and Aventura, the actor Jimmy Smits, the comedian George Lopez and the percussionist Pete Escovedo. The concert will also feature a house band led by Mr. Escovedo’s daughter, Sheila E. The concert will be shown on PBS on Oct. 15, on Telemundo on Oct. 18 and on V-me on Dec. 25. The White House has previously hosted jazz and country music concerts as well as a poetry jam, and is planning a classical music event in November.

Sites ranging from a monastery in Bhutan to the Merritt Parkway are among the most endangered, according to the World Monuments Fund, which released its biennial list of at-risk sites on Tuesday. The list, called the 2010 World Monuments Watch, features 93 sites in 47 countries, including 9 in the United States and 15 that date from the 20th century. Some of the sites, like Macchu Picchu, are repeats from previous years’ lists.

On “Nova” (8 p.m. on most PBS stations), Charles Darwin faces a publish-or-perish crisis of a sort. Spurred by the news that the naturalist Alfred Wallace was preparing to make public his own theory of natural selection, Darwin must finally confront the fact that publishing “On the Origin of Species” may, in the eyes of the church, put his soul on the express elevator to hell. In the dramatization “Darwin’s Darkest Hour,” Henry Ian Cusick plays the scientist and Frances O’Connor plays Emma, his wife.

Among the risks of waiting nearly two decades between your album releases is that many more artists can spring up in that time to claim later that you’ve plagiarized their work. Guns N’ Roses discovered this when they were sued by Ulrich Schnauss, a German electronic musician who says that the band sampled two of his songs without his permission, The Guardian reported. Lawyers for Mr. Schnauss’s American and British record labels say in the suit that Guns N’ Roses, on its 2008 release “Chinese Democracy,” illegally used portions of Mr. Schnauss’s songs “Wherever You Are” (from 2001) and “A Strangely Isolated Place” (from 2003) on a track called “Riad N’ the Bedouins.” The suit asks for compensation of at least $1 million and for Geffen Records to halt release of “Chinese Democracy”; that album, the first studio release from Guns N’ Roses since 1993, has sold more than 3.2 million copies worldwide. The band’s lead singer, Axl Rose, and Geffen Records did not immediately comment on the suit.

If you haven’t been able to nab tickets for the coming Michael Jackson documentary “This Is It,” for which some preview screenings have already sold out, you could always try seeing it in China. An executive for Sony Pictures told The Associated Press that the Chinese government had approved “This Is It” to be shown in that country later this month, in time for the film’s planned two-week worldwide release beginning on Oct. 28. China allows only 20 foreign films to be shown on its screens each year; among the American films that have already played there this year is “Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen,” which broke a Chinese box-office record set by another American film, “Titanic.” Sony Pictures told The A.P. that it would produce “as many prints as possible” of “This Is It,” which is compiled from footage of the concert tour that Mr. Jackson was rehearsing when he died in June.

This week, A. O. Scott looks back at David O. Russell‘s 1999 film about the Gulf War “Three Kings,” which was released, Mr. Scott says, “at a high point of America’s pre-9/11 imperial ambivalence.” The tone of the film shifts between slapstick comedy and grotesque violence and asks whether or not America as a superpower is motivated by greed or generosity.

More than 150 years later, Edgar Allan Poe will finally receive a proper funeral — two of them, in fact. The city of Baltimore is planning two ceremonial burials for Poe, the author and postmodern fashion plate, to recognize the 200th anniversary of his birth, The Associated Press reported. The events offer more than just a good afternoon’s entertainment for local goths: they are meant to make up for the fact that when Poe died in 1849, his funeral was attended by fewer than 10 people. (His cousin Neilson Poe never publicly announced his death.) To accommodate the expected turnout, two funerals will be held on Sunday at Westminster Hall, the former church near his family plot in Westminster Graveyard. If those events are not sufficiently gloomy for you, they will be preceded on Wednesday by a public viewing of a replica of Poe’s body, and on Thursday by an all-night vigil at the Poe Monument in Westminster Graveyard. (The official florist for the Poe funerals can be found here.)

Donna McKechnie will forever be known for her Tony Award-winning performance as the iconic Cassie — she of the red wrap dress, character shoes and the famous “Music and the Mirror” number — in the original Broadway production of “A Chorus Line.”

The daughter of the actor Tony Roberts said that he had a minor seizure during a Sunday performance of the Broadway play “The Royal Family,” but is expected to return to the show. In a statement on Tuesday, Nicole Roberts said: “My father is feeling great and looks forward to returning to the show. He experienced a minor seizure and regrets that it had to happen so publicly. He is taking medication now which should prevent any further incidents. He is grateful for the impeccable and thorough care he received at St. Luke’s-Roosevelt Hospital, and feels especially thankful for all the good wishes that have come flooding in since Sunday afternoon.”

PHILADELPHIA - As if the late-afternoon shadows weren't hazardous enough, it looks as if the Phillies and Rockies will be dealing with treacherous winds on Wednesday, too. The National Weather Service here has issued a wind advisory for Wednesday afternoon - first pitch is scheduled for 2:37 p.m. - with speeds increasing to 20-25 m.p.h. and gusts up to 45 m.p.h. According to the advisory, the winds will come in from the west and signal a cold front moving into the area.

In the last 5,000 years, the Squamish Valley of British Columbia has seen all kinds of people come and go. Long ago there were native bands who lived on salmon and shellfish and gave the region their name, followed in the 19th century by European traders, trappers, farmers, loggers and prospectors, who brought Chinese and Sikh laborers to build dikes and to work sawmills.

Being downsized stinks, as the millions of Americans who've been canned in the past year know. My own employment debacle involved getting laid off, getting another gig, losing that one, then getting and losing another and another as each company I found employment with went out of business in the tanking economy, almost on cue as I arrived. It seemed like a sick joke. But I wasn't laughing.

On The Lede blog, Robert Mackey shares a video report from Britain's Channel 4 News that illustrates the vulnerability of the isolated American bases in Afghanistan's Nuristan Province, where eight U.S. soldiers were killed in a battle with insurgents on Saturday.

People with a taste for high-end fashion items at deep discounts have turned Gilt into a guiltless addiction. The Gilt.com Web site sells premium goods to its by-invitation-only members, and guarantees all items are of authentic pedigree.

The Edith Andrews Logan Residence, a 19th century neo-Federal-style town house that is now home to a showroom for beauty salon equipment, has been designated a New York City landmark.

Lickshot, a new scrapbook by the photographer Ben Watts, arrived in bookstores today. Like Watts's 2004 effort, "Big Up," this is a relaxed photo diary in which movie stars, bikers and bikinied plain janes convey a curious in-your-face approachability. Watts makes use of handwritten annotations in Magic Marker and lots of two-dimensional ephemera -- airline boarding passes, masking tape, thumbtacks, receipts and concert tickets -- to lend lo-fi cred to his photo collages.

A group of centrist Democratic senators, who could determine the fate of the major health care legislation, sent a letter Tuesday to the majority leader, Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, urging that the public be given at least 72 hours to review the legislation before debate begins on the Senate floor.
The auto parts maker Delphi ended four years in bankruptcy on Tuesday, emerging from Chapter 11 as a privately owned company.

CHICAGO - The places had names like Perv's House, Pepper's Hide Out and the Five Fingers Social Club. Homes away from home where patrons dressed in their best, usually gold and mink, burning away the week's problems in cigarette smoke, Crown Royal and the electric chords of guitars. For the photographer Michael Abramson, they were oases on Chicago's rough-and-tumble South Side, where neon Schlitz signs beckoned from behind caged windows.

With interest in his sex and blackmail tale still at a high pitch, David Letterman posted another strong performance in late-night ratings Monday, ­taking in more viewers than his old NBC rival Jay Leno did in prime time­ -- and indeed more viewers than anything offered all night on the NBC network.

Video shot this summer in Afghanistan by a British television crew near an American military base that was attacked on Saturday -- in a battle that left eight Americans and four Afghan security officers dead -- illustrates quite dramatically how tough the fight there is for soldiers trying to secure villages nestled in high mountains.
Ruth Reichl was completely surprised at the closing of Gourmet, our colleague Kim Severson from the Dining section wrote after talking to Ms. Reichl this afternoon.

Today we received an offer from a Maplewood PTA person offering to send us photos and a write-up of an event happening tomorrow. Hooray, yes, thanks, we said. And then we thought, shoot, how can we encourage similar offers from schools in Millburn, Short Hills and South Orange? Well, for starters, we could ask. To keep us from having lopsided coverage (I can send my kids to just one district at a time, so I hear less news from outside Maplewood), please send us news about what's happening soon, or what happened today, to southmountainlocal@nytimes.com. Something as simple as a picture with a caption would be great (so long as you have parental permission for the publication of any pictures of children.) Thanks! -- Tina Kelley

The World Monument Fund, a nonprofit devoted to preserving historic places and structures, released its bi-annual list of the world's most endangered sites. Among them are tourist meccas like Machu Picchu, as well as little-known places like the desert castles of ancient Khorezm in Uzbekistan.
After closing four magazines on Monday, Condé Nast Publications, a unit of Advance Publications, is making changes in publisher offices.

The failure of a New-York company to conduct safety recalls on hundreds of school buses has prompted the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to hold a hearing later to month into what the agency considers the company's inaction and whether it tried to avoid its responsibility by switching names.

The folks at Artist as Citizen, who were inspired by a recent Dot Earth post to hold a contest seeking fresh ways to convey the climate challenge, have announced the winners. The finalist entries included video, flash animation and photography, but the winning one, by two Pratt Institute architecture students, employed good old-fashioned paper and other nonvirtual materials to build three-dimensional flow charts illustrating the links between human activities, emissions and possible global climatic outcomes.

Four years ago, Dennis Rivera was so angry at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg that he promised that his powerful health care workers' union, 1199 S.E.I.U., would bounce the mayor out of office. "We don't get mad -- we get even," Mr. Rivera memorably said during his union's endorsement of Mr. Bloomberg's Democratic opponent, Fernando Ferrer.

The judge in the trial of Brooke Astor's son has rejected the defense's request for a mistrial in the case after a juror said she felt "personally threatened" and wanted to be removed from the panel. The details of the juror's request were released on Tuesday.

On a flawless morning, I joined Grace Fornabaio, 63, and her son Joe on a trip to their old neighborhood to buy four bushels of plum tomatoes. We arrived at a corner grocer on Bay Ridge Avenue and 18th Avenue in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn. Grace burst from the car as she spotted the cases of tomatoes still stacked in the street from the morning delivery. Before I had slipped a few quarters in the parking meter, Grace was negotiating the price and a young man with a hand truck was helping pack the car with the crates.

Our cousins at The New York Times's small business blog, You're the Boss, continue to drill into the implications of the health care legislation for employers. In a new post, Robb Mandelbaum explains how the Senate Finance Committee's "employer mandate" - the requirement that companies either provide health benefits or pay the government a penalty - could have the unintended consequence of encouraging some employers to stop offering health coverage, especially to their lowest paid employees. Even though there are signs that the economy may be starting to turn around, this has been and continues to be a stressful year for most business owners. I often think stress should be spelled $tre$$. I cannot think of many jobs that pay a good amount of money that don't also offer a good amount of stress. The interesting thing about entrepreneurship is that you can encounter stress either because you are busy and growing and making money - or because you are not. After many years of ups and downs, I have some tips on how to deal with stress in productive ways:

ESPN prepares to telecast a documentary on the 1988 deal that sent Wayne Gretzky from Edmonton to Los Angeles, a watershed moment in the history of hockey in North America. "Kings Ransom," directed by the longtime actor, screenwriter, director and friend of Gretzky Peter Berg, includes interviews with the Great One as well as former Oilers owner Peter Pocklington and former Kings owner Bruce McNall (both of whom were convicted of fraud in cases unconnected to Gretzky or the trade). At a recent screening in Beverly Hills, Gretzky told the audience it was untrue that his wife, Janet Jones, influenced her husband to leave Canada for L.A., as was widely believed by Canadians in the aftermath of the trade.

The result could be a reprieve, at least for a while, from the recent stretch of remarkable summer meltdowns.

The Times reported on Tuesday morning that a tree that some people believe was 600 years old was felled in Douglaston, Queens. Imagine what changes it witnessed since it was a mere sapling at the beginning of the 15th century, when native Americans were at peace with nature while Europeans were peering through a distant mirror and reflecting on one economic, social and political calamity after another.

As Karl Lagerfeld pointed out after the Chanel show today, "I spent part of my childhood on a farm." Well, he's come along way from the family farm, no? Inside the Grand Palais, Chanel built its version of Marie Antoinette's barn, with a straw mound that contained a hidden door for the models to come and go in their natural-looking tweeds, clogs, egg basket purses, and lovely white crocheted outfits with French blue and red flowers. The barn-yard show, with Tammy Wynette on the soundtrack and Lily Allen performing live, was completely charming; the clothes were great, too.

In the face of mounting support for clean coal and the billions being invested in carbon capture and storage, or C.C.S., technology, a new assessment from the University of Toronto's Munk Center for International Studies has a stern warning for policy-makers: there could be dramatic unintended environmental consequences to sequestering huge amounts of carbon dioxide in the earth's mantle.

One interesting comment on last week's post about proposed employer mandates for health care coverage came from someone who called herself "AnnS." AnnS seemed to know a lot about health insurance decision-making, and she led us through the calculation that one low-wage firm, apparently a regional convenience store chain, would make if faced with an employer mandate. AnnS is pessimistic. "Employers like this - who have a large number of uninsured low-wage workers - WILL NOT provide those workers with coverage and WILL BE motivated to drop coverage for the lower-ranking employees who do have coverage," she wrote.
On the heels of Friday's job report showing unemployment at a quarter-century high, President Obama and Congressional Democrats are examining a range of ideas in their attempts to spark job creation.

Insurance exchanges -- or marketplaces -- are the fallback position for every health care bill now pending in Congress. Whatever the other particulars, all the bills assume that small employers and individuals will be able to find more insurance options, at more affordable prices, through creation of exchanges in which insurers compete for their businesses.

Jimmy McMillan is running for mayor of New York City. Yesterday afternoon, around 4p.m., the Place Vendôme was so jammed with cars that it recalled photographs of the square when parking was permitted. People were on their way to see Phoebe Philo's first show for Celine, and the mood felt genuinely festive-not the mean celebrity scene that usually awaits you, with guards furiously telling store chiefs and editors to step aside for (inevitably) a minor celebrity. This happens so often that a friend of mine suggested that all the celebrity designers (Gwen Stefani, et al) get together with their friends and have Celebrity Fashion Week. They can get their business out of the way, knock themselves out, and then the rest of us can do ours.

In the late 1940s, Bohuslav Martinu was the living composer whose works were most played by U.S. symphony orchestras, according to the Martinu Institute here in Prague. Never heard of him? Chock that up to Cold War politics and a fickle public.

Goldman Sachs looks set to come out well from its involvement in yet another failing company that is costing taxpayers dearly, Breakingviews.com says. Its success in avoiding any losses on the crumbling American International Group incited a surge of criticism culminating in the Wall Street firm being called a "vampire squid wrapped around the face of humanity" by Rolling Stone magazine. Now the firm is in line to make at least $1 billion if the midmarket lender CIT Group files for bankruptcy. But, Breakingviews.com says, CIT is no A.I.G.

One of the first things I saw then on the way to the town, 47 miles north of Baghdad, was a charred Russian armored vehicle abandoned on the side of the road by the Iraqi Army. Someone had painted on it: "Saddam's hell is better than the Americans' paradise."
