An obituary on Monday about Shoichi Nakagawa, the former Japanese finance minister who resigned after his erratic behavior at an international meeting in February, misspelled the given name of his wife. It is Yuko, not Ikuko.

The Really column last Tuesday, about the possibility that the loss of sight might heighten other senses, referred incorrectly to the main character in “Daredevil,” a film adaptation of a comic book series. Radioactive material that caused the character, a lawyer, to go blind enhanced his remaining senses; his senses were not enhanced because he went blind.

A picture caption on Friday with a theater review of “Superior Donuts,” at the Music Box Theater, misstated the surname of the actor who plays Franco Wicks. As the review and a listing of credits noted, he is Jon Michael Hill, not Hall.

A pop music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the New York Cabaret Convention, Wednesday through Friday this week at the Rose Theater, misstated the telephone number for tickets. It is (212) 721-6500.

An article on Monday about Isaiah Sheffer’s decision to step down as artistic director of Symphony Space misidentified the radio distributor of a Symphony Space program he is closely identified with, the Selected Shorts story readings. It is Public Radio International, not National Public Radio.

A theater review on Thursday about “Two Unrelated Plays by David Mamet,” at the Linda Gross Theater in Chelsea, omitted a co-writer of the script of the musical “A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum” in describing the tone of one of the Mamet plays reviewed, “Keep Your Pantheon,” as an uneasy cross between the “Forum” script and Mr. Mamet’s play “A Life in the Theater” from 1977. Burt Shevelove wrote “Forum” with Larry Gelbart; it was not solely Mr. Gelbart’s script.

An article on Saturday about the Rangers’ 3-2 loss to Pittsburgh in their N.H.L. season opener misstated the time of Evgeni Malkin’s goal for the Penguins. It was 7 minutes 48 seconds into the game, not 8:48.

An article on Thursday about the end of talks between General Motors and the Penske Automotive Group over the potential sale of the Saturn brand misstated the status of G.M.’s deal to sell Saab to the Koenigsegg Group of Sweden. The deal is awaiting financing; it has not been completed.

An article on Saturday about a free-speech lawsuit brought by Allergan, the maker of Botox, against the federal government quoted incorrectly from a comment by Jeffrey N. Gibbs, a lawyer in Washington who specializes in food and drug law. Mr. Gibbs said of Allergan, “They are seeking relief which would invalidate a number of the F.D.A. regulations which restrict the promotion of drugs.” He did not say that Allergan was seeking relief that would invalidate “all of the F.D.A. regulations” on the promotion of drugs.

The Off Broadway show “Love, Loss and What I Wore,” written by Nora and Delia Ephron, has extended its run at the Westside Theater, its producers said on Monday. The play, a collection of stories in which articles of clothing and fashion accessories play prominent roles, opened on Thursday and was scheduled to run through Dec. 13. The producers said it would be extended into next year but did not give a new closing date or announce new casting for the play, which is performed by a rotating cycle of actresses.

An etching put up for auction on Thursday that purports to depict Hitler and Lenin playing chess failed to attract any bidders, according to Richard Westwood-Brookes, the curator of the auction. The auction was held by Mullock’s Specialist Auctioneers & Valuers in Shropshire, England. The presale estimate was about $63,000 to $95,000. A 300-page dossier compiled by the father of the etching’s current owner said it was made in Vienna in 1909 by an artist named Emma Lowenstramm as the two men sat playing in her house. The dossier said that Lowenstramm was Hitler’s art teacher. Academic experts have said they have serious doubts that the men ever met or played chess together.

Show business, take note: there just may be increased demand for horror offerings in the weeks before Halloween. Paramount has become the latest studio to stumble onto this truism with the limited release of its micro-budget film “Paranormal Activity,” whose midnight screenings have proved so successful that the company said it was expanding the film’s showings at theaters this weekend. In the spirit of inexpensive thrillers like “The Blair Witch Project,” “Paranormal Activity” is presented as found footage recorded by a man and a woman who hear inexplicable noises in their San Diego home. The film, written and directed by Oren Peli and made for about $10,000, was released on Sept. 25 with midnight-only screenings in 13 college towns. It later expanded to 20 metropolitan areas (including New York) after audiences voted for the film on the Web site eventful.com. Over the weekend, Paramount said, “Paranormal Activity” sold out all its midnight screenings in 33 cities, earning $535,000 in ticket sales, or about $16,000 per screen. Starting Friday, the studio said, it will expand the film to 40 markets in which it will be shown at all hours.

Want frites with your Mona Lisa? Visitors to the Louvre in Paris soon won’t have to travel far to enjoy the works of Leonardo, Delacroix and Géricault after dining on le Big Mac: a McDonald’s restaurant and McCafé are planned to open near the Louvre in November, The Telegraph of London reported. Though the two McDonald’s will be in the underground shopping area below the museum, called the Carrousel du Louvre, and not the Louvre itself, the impending opening is already causing indigestion among some art aficionados. “I’m not against eating in a museum, but McDonald’s is hardly the height of gastronomy,” Didier Rykner, the editor of the Web site The Art Tribune (thearttribune.com), told The Telegraph, adding, “Today McDonald’s, tomorrow low-cost clothes shops.” In a statement, the Louvre said it welcomed the fact that its visitors, “French or foreign,” would be able to enjoy “a rich and varied” selection of restaurants. Last year, Louvre employees and art admirers sent the museum a petition to protest a Starbucks planned near the museum but were unable to stop the coffee shop from opening.

The Metropolitan Opera and its stagehands are in a dispute over who is to build the huge set for the Met’s new Wagner “Ring” cycle, scheduled to open next season. Robert Lepage, right, the Canadian director who has been assigned the task of developing a new version of the “Ring,” creates all his productions in Quebec. In this case the Met and the stagehands’ union, Local 1, agreed that some of the work could be done in Quebec and some in New York. Mr. Lepage’s shop is nonunion, so the agreement called for sending union workers from the Met to Quebec. On Monday, after Mr. Lepage’s team had changed plans for the set — using steel instead of a lightweight material and moving the construction of a piece of machinery to Quebec, according to the Met — the union filed a grievance. (The Met stagehands include welders.) “I believe this will all be resolved,” said Peter Gelb, the Met’s general manager. “We certainly are interested in having a harmonious working relationship with Local 1 and at the same time realizing the theatrical imagination of one of the world’s great directors and designers.” Mr. Lepage’s designs, Mr. Gelb said, are experimental and evolving as construction proceeds. A spokesman for Local 1, Bruce Cohen, had no further comment except to say that the union “expects a satisfactory resolution.”.

Gen. David H. Petraeus, commander of American military forces in the Middle East, learned in February that he had early-stage prostate cancer but has undergone ''successful'' radiation treatment for the illness, according to a statement issued late Monday. General Petraeus, 56, who as head of the United States Central Command oversees operations in Afghanistan and Iraq, underwent two months of radiation treatment at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, the statement said.

The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, told the visiting Chinese prime minister that his government was ready to return to six-nation talks on ending its nuclear weapons program if it first saw progress in one-on-one talks with the United States, state-run media in North Korea and China reported Tuesday. North Korea is ''close to completing'' the restoration of its main nuclear facilities in Yongbyon, the South Korean news agency Yonhap said Tuesday.

HAUER--Rose Muscatine, RN, MA. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, in acknowledging with great sadness the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Rose Muscatine Hauer, RN, MA, former Vice President for Nursing at Beth Israel and Dean Emerita of the Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing. Mrs. Hauer was a tremendous source of inspiration to the nursing field, demonstrating an unsurpassed commitment to care. During her 50-year career at Beth Israel, which began as a nursing student at the school she eventually led, she helped set standards of excellence and created models of nursing care that were exemplary and many of which are still followed today. After her retirement, she continued to be an active member of the Beth Israel family, participating in nursing and fundraising activities and maintaining close ties with many Trustees, donors, physicians and staff. We extend most heartfelt condolences to her children, Jerome and Deborah, her sister Blanche, her grandchildren and all who loved her. Lawrence S. 8 P.M. (13, 49) DARWIN'S DARKEST HOUR ''Nova'' and National Geographic Television collaborate on this dramatization of Charles Darwin's greatest personal crisis: the decision over whether to present his theory of natural selection to the public. Henry Ian Cusick, above with Frances O'Connor, plays Darwin, who, having spent years refining his ideas and writing his book ''On the Origin of Species,'' delayed publication because of concerns about a religious backlash until 1858, when he learned that the naturalist Alfred Wallace was about to publish ideas similar to his own. Ms. O'Connor portrays Darwin's wife, Emma, who clung tightly to her Unitarian beliefs. John Goldsmith (''Victoria and Albert'') wrote the screenplay. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS The experts explain what various body sounds mean and how to quiet them. Also, why cracking your back hurts more than it helps.

SOMMER--Viola Sommer, nee Landsberg, wife of Sigmund Sommer, the well-known New York real estate developer and noted race horse owner, succumbed to a long illness after having just turned 88 with her three loving children and grandchildren at her side on Sunday, October 4, 2009. Born in New York City on September 19, 1921, she attended the Julia Richman High School and Hunter College. During World War II, she worked for the USO, interviewing servicemen for the military upon their return from the front. Mrs. Sommer lived in the New York metropolitan area for almost all of her life, and with Sigmund, ran one of the most successful thoroughbred racing stables of its time, during the 1960s and 70s. With Frank Martin as trainer, they were leading money winners in North America for ten consecutive years. They owned Sham, who won the 1973 Santa Anita Derby, and who took second place in the Wood Memorial Stakes over Secretariat, who finished third. He placed in two of the three legs of the Triple Crown in the same year, when Secretariat won the three races. In the Kentucky Derby, Sham placed second to Secretariat, yet still broke the track record after stumbling in the gate. Even after Sigmund Sommer's death, Viola Sommer remained active in the company he founded, Sigmund Sommer Properties. She also distinguished herself by winning the Eclipse Award for outstanding owner in 1982, and serving as a trustee with the New York Racing Association (NYRA) and the Jockey Club for many years. She is survived by her older brother Eugene, 94, her 3 children, Jack Sommer, Susan Sommer Schweitzman, and Dr. Barbara Sommer Fisher, and by 10 grandchildren. Mrs. Sommer's memorial service will take place on Tuesday, October 6, 2009 at 12 noon at The Riverside Memorial Chapel on the corner of 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Memorial gifts may be made to NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and sent to the Office of Development, 525 East 68 Street, Box 123, NYC 10065.

President Obama will speak to a gathering of gay rights activists in Washington on Saturday, the day before thousands are to march on the capital seeking greater legal protections for gay men, lesbians and transgender people. Mr. Obama's appearance, at the annual dinner of the Human Rights Campaign, amounts to a significant show of support at a time when many gay rights advocates have become increasingly vocal about what they see as his tepid backing for their causes.

Rogers Redding, the Southeastern Conference coordinator of football officials, said Monday that Georgia receiver A. J. Green was incorrectly penalized late in Saturday's game against Louisiana State for excessive celebration. Green's 16-yard touchdown reception with a little more than a minute to play put the Bulldogs ahead. But after the infraction, they were penalized 15 yards on the kickoff. L.S.U. got the ball in good field position and scored with 46 seconds left to win, 20-13. Redding said the back judge made the call and wrote in a postgame report that Green called attention to himself after his touchdown with a gesture toward the crowd. The official scoring summary lists the back judge as Michael Watson. Redding said the SEC reviewed video of the game and did not see Green make a gesture that was excessive celebration.
LICHT--Helen A.,at 89, after a valiant battle against dementia. She is survived by her loving children Nora G. and Jonathan D. Licht.

HAUER--Rose Muscatine. The Nurses Alumni Association of the Phillips Beth Israel School of nursing is deeply saddened by the passing of Rose Muscatine Hauer, R.N., Dean Emeritus of the Beth Israel School of Nursing and Vice President Emeritus of Nursing Service of Beth Israel Medical Center, and nationally recognized in the nursing profession. She was the epitome of nursing, for all who knew and worked with her. She was our mentor, our friend and an inspiration to us all. She always was available to each and every one of us. She truly was the Best of Beth Israel. She gave unstintingly of herself to all who asked or needed advice. No one can replace her; she will always live in our hearts. Rosewe truly loved you. We extend our deepest and heartfelt sympathy to her children, son and daughter-in-law Jerry and Tracy Hauer, and her daughter Deborah Schwartz and her three grandchildren, Lauren and Daniel Schwartz and Michael Hauer. Sandra Winer, R.N. President Rochelle Bronson, R.N. President Elect

HAUER--Rose Muscatine, RN, MA. It is with profound sadness that the members of the Trustee Committee, the faculty, the staff and the students of the Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing join with the entire Beth Israel Medical Center community in mourning the passing of our beloved friend and inspirational leader, Rose Muscatine Hauer, RN, MA, former Dean of our School and Dean Emerita following her retirement. She had an extraordinary influence on thousands of nursing students who studied at our School and who went on to distinguished careers in the nursing profession. KEY--David McKendree, Jr.,died October 3 in Vero Beach FL. Born in Antwerp, Belgium in 1927, he was the second son of Ambassador and Mrs. David M. Key. David is survived by Jacqueline, his wife of twenty-eight years, his son Timothy, daughters Caroline, Alexandra and Linda and four grandchildren. Nine days into its deliberations, the jury deciding the fate of Brooke Astor's son showed signs of strain, as a juror's safety concerns led the judge on Monday to encourage all of them to ''hang in there a bit longer.'' After receiving two notes from the jury around lunchtime on Monday and consulting with the lawyers in the case, Justice A. Kirke Bartley Jr. summoned the jurors into the courtroom in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. He told them he understood that after a five-month trial, ''emotions may run high.''

STRAUS--Robert V. New York producer and general manager Robert V. Straus of New York City died peacefully on October 4, 2009. Devoted husband to his wife, Marguerite, for 36 years, brother of Harold Straus of Overland Park, Kansas, uncle and great-uncle to many. Family and friends cherished him for his loving generosity, vibrant personality and brilliant wit. Robert was the producer of the shows "Food Chain" and "Band in Berlin". He has endless credits as general manager for shows such as "A Chorus Line" and "The Sound of Music" with Marie Osmond. A memorial service will be held at a date to be announced shortly. Donations may be made in his memory to the Actors Fund of America, 729 7th Ave., 10th Fl, New York, NY 10019.

Eli Manning was found to have plantar fasciitis in his right foot on Monday, which means he will probably be able to continue playing, but it is going to be painful. Manning sustained the injury during the Giants' 27-16 victory Sunday at Kansas City. He arrived at Giants Stadium on Monday wearing no protective boot or using crutches and said he was not worried about it as he headed for a magnetic resonance imaging test. That test revealed the extent of the inflammation in his foot.

Ben Feder, a winemaker whose crisp seyval blancs from Clinton Vineyards helped establish the Hudson Valley as a serious winemaking region, died Sept. 24 at his home in Clinton Corners, N.Y. He was 86. The cause was brain cancer, said his wife, Phyllis.

MEYER--Charles H.,82, of Boynton Beach, Florida died at Hospice of Palm Beach County on October 4th, 2009. After a lengthy illness, he died peacefully, surrounded by his family. Known as Chuck, he was born on November 16th, 1926 in Brooklyn, New York to immigrants Harry and Beatrice (Kessler) Meyer. After graduating from Weequahic High School in Newark, New Jersey, he served in the military at the end of World War II. He graduated from New York University, Phi Beta Kappa in 1950 and then received a Master's Degree from Cornell University in 1952. In 1954, he began a long and distinguished career in the healthcare field which culminated in his appointment as CEO of The Brookdale Hospital Medical Center in Brooklyn, New York. He served as President of the League of Voluntary Hospitals in New York, and was Chairman of the Greater New York Hospital Association. He was also a fellow of the American College of Hospital Administrators and honored with a lifetime fellowship from the American College of Healthcare Executives. He lectured in Hospital Administration at the Columbia University School of Public Health. All of his professional achievements were accomplished despite the premature death of his wife, Miriam, leaving him to raise two young children. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife of 29 years, Joan, son Keith (Sharon) of Palm Beach Gardens, Florida, and daughter Janice (Michael) of New York City, New York. He also leaves his memories to five grandchildren, Meredith, Benjamin, Amanda, Bradley and Maxine. Funeral services will be handled through Beth Israel Memorial Chapel of Boynton Beach, Florida. Special thanks to Dr. Stacey Shinder, Dr. Mathew Zaltzman and all of the other doctors, nurses and healthcare professionals who provided superb medical care and treated him with dignity and respect.
BELLIN--Betty. Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns our esteemed member and sends heartfelt sympathy to her family. Andrew Warmflash, Rabbi

During the Jets' flight home from Sunday's loss at New Orleans, Coach Rex Ryan sat briefly next to the rookie quarterback Mark Sanchez hours after Sanchez posted the franchise's worst passer rating (27.0) in nearly three years. Can't get much worse, kid, Ryan reminded him as they shared a laugh. The Jets' first loss of the season, 24-10 to the Saints, served to highlight the difference between this team and the one that stumbled the year before. Because as poorly as Sanchez played Sunday, the Jets (3-1) contend they have established an identity.

Expanding health insurance to cover everyone over the age of 51 might help save costs to Medicare in the long run, according to a new study reported in The Annals of Internal Medicine. People between the ages of 51 and 65 who lack health insurance end up costing Medicare about $1,000 more per year when they turn 65 than people who have had coverage all along, the report says.

President Obama, seeking to pitch his plan for a health care overhaul, invited a group of white-coated doctors to the Rose Garden on Monday, telling them that ''nobody has more credibility with the American people on this issue than you do.'' PETERFREUND--Harold, 93, died Monday, October 5, 2009. Beloved husband of the late Shirley Peterfreund and the late Gloria Peterfreund; loving father of Stuart (Chris), Mallie (Allen), Zarina (Tim), and Jay; beloved grandfather of Sara, Marissa (Jason), Alisa, Shina, Tara, Talia and Sarah. Retired founder and president of Future Motors. He was known by all as "Mr. Taxicab," as he was the pioneer of the passenger car taxicab used all over the United States, even today. Born in Brooklyn, raised in Ellenville, NY and the Lower East Side of Manhattan. Jury selection began on Monday in a class-action lawsuit brought by investors accusing the French conglomerate Vivendi and two of its former top executives of making false and misleading statements about its financial position. The case, being tried in New York, could win shareholders compensation for the decline in the value of their holdings after the dot-com boom or help lift the cloud of litigation that has dogged Vivendi since its aggressive expansion at the start of the decade.

In an interview, Ms. Mantel said that she’s going to spend the prize of about $80,000 on “sex, drugs and rock and roll,” then added: “To be a little less stupid, living, I think. It buys time. That’s what an author wants.”

The manager of the rock band Guns N’ Roses said that the group did not use any unauthorized samples on a song that a German musician says uses portions of his work illegally. Ulrich Schnauss, a German electronic artist, filed suit against Guns N’ Roses, saying that its song “Riad N’ the Bedouins” includes unauthorized samples of his tracks “Wherever You Are” and “A Strangely Isolated Place.” But in a statement, the manager, Irving Azoff, said that the band “vigorously contests these claims.”

The sheriff’s office of Monterey County, Calif., said that a reported theft of millions of dollars’ worth of artworks from a home in Pebble Beach appears to be a scam perpetrated by the alleged victims, The San Francisco Chronicle reported. On Sept. 25, A. Benjamin Amadio and Dr. Ralph Kennaugh reported that 13 works, including pieces by Matisse, Miró, Rembrandt, Renoir, van Gogh and Jackson Pollock, had been stolen from their home. They later said that a ransom note had been found in their home, demanding money for the return of the works. But at a news conference, Cmdr. Mike Richards said that the two collectors were the only suspects in the case. “This whole thing stinks,” he said, according to The Chronicle. He added that the collectors had not responded to repeated requests to provide documentation that the paintings exist, or even told detectives the dimensions of the stolen works. David St. John, an insurance broker for the collectors, told The Chronicle that he had seen the paintings and the documents establishing their lines of ownership. The collectors, he said, “don’t need the money.” “They want the art back,” he said. “It’s really unfair what’s happening to these guys.”

Harvard University has acquired the archives of John Updike, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author and Harvard alumnus who died in January, The Boston Globe reported. Mr. Updike, a member of Harvard’s Class of 1954, whose works included the autobiographical Olinger short stories and Rabbit novels, retained a Harvard library card after graduating and continued to visit the campus for his research. Harvard’s Houghton Library is expected to house the John Updike Archive, which includes his collection of his own work, in English and foreign-language editions, as well as annotated copies of books that he reviewed, dust-jacket designs, research files and correspondence from fellow authors and fans. The Houghton Library said on its blog that, for decades, Mr. Updike had been depositing his manuscripts, letters and even his golf score cards at the library, but that this material was available only with Mr. Updike’s permission. The Globe said that Harvard officials would not disclose how much was paid to acquire the archive.

Good news for anyone who enjoys the misadventures of hipsters posing as private investigators, or who just likes seeing authentic Brooklyn environs on television: HBO has ordered a second season of its comedy series “Bored to Death.”The show, created by the author Jonathan Ames (“The Double Life Is Twice as Good”), stars Jason Schwartzman as a creatively blocked novelist, also named Jonathan Ames, who begins offering his services as an unlicensed detective on Craigslist after he is dumped by his girlfriend.

Who is the biggest diva of them all? Barbra Streisand‘s latest record, “Love Is the Answer” (Columbia), promoted with an interview on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” and a performance at the tiny Village Vanguard in Manhattan, opened at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, ahead of new albums by Mariah Carey, Madonna and Paramore, the band led by 20-year-old Hayley Williams. “Love Is the Answer” sold 180,000 copies in the United States last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, while Paramore’s “Brand New Eyes” (Fueled by Ramen) moved 175,000 and Ms. Carey’s “Memoirs of an Imperfect Angel” (Island) 168,000.

A new play by Rinne Groff about a man’s obsession with the diary of Anne Frank will star Mandy Patinkin when it makes its premiere at Yale Repertory Theater next year. The Yale Rep said on Wednesday that the play, called “Compulsion,” would star Mr. Patinkin as a character inspired by Meyer Levin, the journalist and screenwriter who helped publicize the existence of the diary, and who came to believe that the chance to adapt it for the stage had been stolen from him.

Irving Penn, one of the century’s most prolific and influential photographers of fashion and the famous, died at his home in Manhattan on Wednesday morning, said Peter MacGill, his friend and representative. He was 92.

“Idol Gives Back,” the charity fund-raiser sponsored by “American Idol” and its producers, will return next season for a third installment of raising money for impoverished children around the world. The charity event will take place on April 21 during the “American Idol” results show featuring the top seven contestants from the annual talent competition. “American Idol” is scheduled to begin broadcasting its ninth season in January.

It sounds like something Washington's pay czar might propose to rein in runaway bonuses on Wall Street, The New York Times's Louise Story writes. Irving Penn, a modern master and one of the most celebrated photographers of the 20th century, died on Wednesday morning. He was 92. Renowned for his fashion photos and studio portraits, he captured the famous of his time including Pablo Picasso, Georgia O'Keeffe and Truman Capote. He is also recognized for his portfolio of fleshy abstractions of the human nude and still lifes.

PARIS - A couple of days ago a friend was saying, and not without reason, that while this season had produced beautiful clothes, it had also lacked real energy. Yesterday, two collections went a long way to counter that. At Chanel, Karl Lagerfeld put on a masterful spectacle backed up with light, wearable luxury. He created a farmhouse in the middle of Paris, reminiscent of Marie Antoinette's Petit Trianon; coquettish country courtesans wearing peppy tailleurs in earthy shades, logo clogs, hemp bags, dirndls and naughty aprons rose from a giant haystack in the middle of the setup. The clothes were certainly enough to hold the audience's attention, but toward the end of the show the singer Lily Allen emerged from the ground and performed one song in a rustic stage decorated with flowers. As if this wasn't enough, Lagerfeld's models of the moment - Lara Stone, Freja Beja Erichsen and Baptiste Giabiconi - wrapped things up with a roll in the hay. Who says fashion isn't fun anymore?

Filed next to the Umbros and slap bracelets in my catalog of suppressed memories of the 1980s is Showbiz Pizza, a precursor to Chuck E. Cheese's and a franchise perhaps best known for its creepy animatronic band, the Rock-afire Explosion. Apparently I'm not the only one who cherishes that strange grouping of robotics, fake fur and music. After video surfaced on YouTube showing a complete Explosion ensemble performing Lil Wayne's "Lollipop" and MGMT's "Electric Feel" in the home of an avid Explosionista, the Rock-afire Explosion exploded again. A documentary devoted to the band, its maker and its legend, aptly titled "The Rock-afire Explosion" briefly made the festival circuit in 2008 and earned a four-star review from Film Threat. The film is part "Anvil" and part "King of Kong," a musical "Ubu Roi" with feeling. And tomorrow, it comes to the Anthology Film Archives for a rare screening. There will, of course, be pizza (courtesy of Li'l Frankies).

For a guide to the differences among various health care bills in the House and Senate, check out this newly updated interactive tool from the Kaiser Family Foundation. The tool allows readers to compare all the health bills on Capitol Hill, including the recently amended bill from the Senate Finance Committee, the Senate HELP bill, the main House bill, and various other drafts and proposals - 12, in all. It allows a side-by-side comparisons of the entire bills or specific aspects of each bill, such as how they handle long-term care, what they require of employers or how they would affect taxes. Before the (valanced) window closes on Thursday, when Tepper Galleries begins to auction off 1,103 lots from the estate of David Barrett, you can still dine out on a top New York decorator's tricks of the trade. Barrett's heyday was probably in the 1960s and '70s, although he worked right up to his death last year at the age of 85. Still, from the boiserie panels to the animal skin rugs, from the Rococo daybeds to the stag heads and blackamoors, you get to see all the tropes that have dominated interior design forever.Francophiles will have a field day, since there is every variety of French furniture, from country to Louis, with Barrett's copies thrown in. There are scores and scores of chairs - occasional chairs, Grotto chairs, slipper chairs, easy chairs, Adirondack chairs and campaign chairs - most stripped down to the frame, waiting for some posh upholsterer from Great Neck to affix the passementerie. All this had been stored in a Long Island City warehouse, where the auction's coordinator, Tiffany Dubin, and staff spent the summer combing through a 60-year career.

It turns out I have more cred here than I would as a "normal" food writer. Thirty years after Schwartzberg's closed my mother revealed to me that I had Kosher restaurants in my bloodline.

I very much appreciated Joan Nathan's piece on Kosher delis today. We had several in my neighborhood when I was growing up, which was not far from the Second Avenue Deli, considered a joint of last resort, and Katz's (not actually Kosher) considered not as good as Henry's (actually Kosher), which was down the block.

In Moscow, nightclubs control who gets in and when according to a strict and often opaque system of what is called "face control," a culture of quick-draw aesthetics I wrote about in T's fall travel issue. The elder statesman of the profession is Pavel Pichugin, aka Pasha Face Control, a 28-year-old dentist whose presence in front of a club is a guarantee that it will become the city's most glamorous and, just as often, impenetrable venue. In Russia, figures like Pasha are sought-after - and well-remunerated - clubland mercenaries, who command high fees and frequently become local celebrities.

A U.S. bill that would triple aid to Pakistan has unleashed a flood of criticism among Pakistanis, who say conditions in the bill compromise their country’s sovereignty.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan - As the Obama administration weighs a shift in its military strategy in Afghanistan, it is also stepping up its efforts to increase aid to neighboring Pakistan. The Senate on Sept. 24 approved legislation to triple nonmilitary aid to Pakistan to about $1.5 billion a year for the next five years. However, conditions laid out in the bill, authored by Senators John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Richard Lugar, Republican of Indiana, have unleashed street protests and a flood of criticism from Pakistanis who say the bill compromises their country's sovereignty.

Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, sounded quite open to the idea of a value-added tax during her recent appearance on Charlie Rose. (James Pethokoukis of Reuters has the details.) As I briefly explained in my column today, a value-added tax -- or VAT -- is essentially a national sales tax. It has the advantage of taxing consumption rather than income, which should encourage savings. Savings, in turn, leads to corporate investment, and investment leads to economic growth. As taxes go, the VAT has much to recommend it.

A Rural Life article on Thursday referred to the rotations of Earth and Venus. It is imprecise to say, as the article did, that Earth rotates clockwise and Venus rotates counterclockwise because that depends entirely on the observer’s perspective. It is more accurate to say that Earth rotates eastward. Venus does, indeed, rotate in the opposite direction — the only one of the planets in our solar system that does so.

For a while, it looked as if quercetin might be the next super-supplement, one of the few legal substances able to improve athletic performance. Quercetin is a flavonoid found naturally in apple skins, berries, red wine, black tea and some leafy vegetables. Like other flavonoids, it is believed to be an antioxidant, a substance that can lessen or prevent certain kinds of cell damage, and an anti-inflammatory. But of even more importance to athletes, it has shown evidence of being a potent performance enhancer in mice.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Friday about Mahlon Hoagland, whose research helped explain how DNA is translated into the proteins that carry out its coded message, misstated his date of death. It was Sept. 18, not “last Friday” (Sept. 25). The obituary also referred incorrectly to the role of James Watson and Francis Crick in earlier DNA research. They discovered the structure of DNA — not DNA itself, which was first identified in 1869, by Johann Friedrich Miescher.

A film review on Friday about the Ricky Gervais movie “The Invention of Lying” referred incorrectly to Oscar Wilde, whose reference to “dreary realism” was likened to Mr. Gervais’s view. He was Irish, not British.

Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 28 about the arrest of Roman Polanski in Switzerland referred incorrectly to his acceptance of an Oscar in 2003 for directing “The Pianist.” Mr. Polanski, who was not at the Oscar ceremony because of an outstanding warrant for his arrest, issued a statement from Europe the following day. He did not give an acceptance speech via satellite.

A Sports of The Times column on Sunday, about the role that the New York Giants and the Polo Grounds played in shaping the Mets, referred incorrectly to the ownership of the property on which the Polo Grounds was eventually built. The property, which became known as Coogan’s Bluff and Hollow, was inherited by Harriet G. Coogan; it was not farmland that belonged to her husband, James J. Coogan. The column also erroneously attributed a distinction to Mr. Coogan. He was the second Manhattan borough president, not the first. (Augustus W. Peters was the first.).

An article on June 5 about a warning by Russia’s prime minister, Vladimir V. Putin, to businessmen who owned the only company in Pikalevo, a small town where their workers had not been paid in three months, referred incorrectly to alumina, one of the company’s products. Alumina is a chemical compound used in the smelting of aluminum metal and in a broad range of advanced ceramic products. It is not a “component of aluminum.” A reader recently pointed out the error in an e-mail message.

More than 150 years after his death, Edgar Allan Poe, below, will finally receive a proper funeral — two, in fact. Baltimore is planning two ceremonial burials for Poe, the author and postmodern fashion plate, to commemorate the 200th anniversary of his birth, The Associated Press reported. The events offer more than just a good afternoon’s entertainment for goths: they are meant to make up for the fact that when Poe died in 1849, his funeral was attended by fewer than 10 people. (His cousin Neilson Poe never publicly announced his death.) To accommodate the expected turnout of hundreds of people, two funerals will be held on Sunday at Westminster Hall, the former church near his burial site in Westminster graveyard. Those events will be preceded on Wednesday by a public viewing of an effigy of Poe’s body, and on Thursday by an all-night vigil at the Poe Monument in Westminster graveyard.

Among the risks of waiting almost two decades between album releases is that many more artists can spring up in that time to claim that you’ve plagiarized their work. Guns N’ Roses learned this when it was sued by Ulrich Schnauss, a German electronic musician who says the band sampled two of his songs without his permission, The Guardian of London reported. Lawyers for Mr. Schnauss’s American and British record labels say in the suit that Guns N’ Roses, on its 2008 release, “Chinese Democracy,” illegally used portions of Mr. Schnauss’s songs “Wherever You Are” (from 2001) and “A Strangely Isolated Place” (from 2003) on the track “Riad N’ the Bedouins.” The suit requests compensation of at least $1 million and for Geffen Records, which put out “Chinese Democracy,” to halt its release. That album, the first new studio release from Guns N’ Roses since 1993, has sold more than 3.2 million copies worldwide. The band’s lead singer, Axl Rose, and Geffen Records did not immediately comment on the suit.

The daughter of the actor Tony Roberts said that he had a minor seizure during a Sunday preview performance of “The Royal Family,” but that he was expected to return to that Broadway production. In a statement on Tuesday Nicole Roberts said: “My father is feeling great and looks forward to returning to the show. He experienced a minor seizure and regrets that it had to happen so publicly. He is taking medication now, which should prevent any further incidents.” Mr. Roberts, 69, fell ill during a matinee of “The Royal Family,” a 1927 comedy by George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber, and that performance was canceled. The Manhattan Theater Club, which is presenting the play, said on Monday that the official opening, scheduled for Thursday at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater, would still take place. No announcement was made about who would take over Mr. Roberts’s role for that performance; his understudy, Anthony Newfield, has been filling in for him. A spokesman for the play said its producers were taking it “day by day” in regards to Mr. Roberts’s return.

Havana’s loss is New York’s gain, sort of. The cancellation of the New York Philharmonic’s trip to Cuba planned for the end of this month created a hole in the orchestra’s schedule. On Tuesday the Philharmonic announced plans to fill it, choosing programs that do not require a lot of heavy lifting. On the evenings of Oct. 30 and Oct. 31 the orchestra will play Beethoven’s “Egmont” Overture and Piano Concerto No. 3, with Emanuel Ax as the soloist; Bernstein’s symphonic dances from “West Side Story”; and Falla’s Suite No. 2 from “The Three-Cornered Hat.” At a Saturday matinee performance, in place of the Bernstein and Falla pieces, Alan Gilbert, the orchestra’s new music director, will join members of the orchestra and Mr. Ax for a performance of Schumann’s Piano Quintet in E flat. Mr. Gilbert will play second violin. The move is not altogether surprising, as Mr. Gilbert’s father is a retired member of the violin section and his mother still plays in it.
From Japanese wing joints to carbon copies of Korean fast food, there’s far more to taste in fried chicken than just the standard Southern-style crust.

The Swiss Justice Ministry has rejected Roman Polanski’s request that it reconsider his arrest, and has also recommended that a court decline his appeal for release from detention on bail. “The reason is that we still think there is a considerable risk that he will escape and that liberation on bail and other security measures can’t guarantee his presence in the extradition procedure,” Folco Galli, a Justice Ministry spokesman, said on Tuesday in a telephone interview. He added that he did not know when the court would rule on the matter. The Swiss police arrested Mr. Polanski on Sept. 26, and are holding him pending hearings on an application for his extradition to the United States, which he fled more than 30 years ago before being sentenced for having sex with a 13-year-old girl. Mr. Galli said the United States had not applied for Mr. Polanski’s extradition, but had 40 days to do so starting from the time of his arrest.
AT&T said it would not prevent iPhone users from using Web telephone services that bypass its own voice network.

Sites including a monastery in Bhutan and the Merritt Parkway, right, in Connecticut are among the most endangered in the world, according to the World Monuments Fund, which issued its biennial report on at-risk sites on Tuesday. The list, called the 2010 World Monuments Watch, names 93 sites in 47 countries, including 9 in the United States and 15 from the 20th century. Some, like Machu Picchu, appeared on previous lists. Among the sites cited this year are Phajoding, a Bhutan monastery; Frank Lloyd Wright’s Taliesin in Wisconsin and Taliesin West in Arizona; the gingerbread houses of Port-au-Prince, Haiti; the desert castles of ancient Khorezm, Uzbekistan; and two New Orleans sites damaged by Hurricane Katrina, St. Louis Cemetery No. 2 and the Phillis Wheatley Elementary School. The World Monuments Watch is the flagship advocacy program for the fund, a nonprofit organization that works to preserve cultural heritage around the world.

STRAUS--Robert V. New York producer and general manager Robert V. Straus of New York City died peacefully on October 4, 2009. Devoted husband to his wife, Marguerite, for 36 years, brother of Harold Straus of Overland Park, Kansas, uncle and great-uncle to many. Family and friends cherished him for his loving generosity, vibrant personality and brilliant wit. Robert was the producer of the shows "Food Chain" and "Band in Berlin". He has endless credits as general manager for shows such as "A Chorus Line" and "The Sound of Music" with Marie Osmond. A memorial service will be held at a date to be announced shortly. Donations may be made in his memory to the Actors Fund of America, 729 7th Ave., 10th Fl, New York, NY 10019.

THE religion of Southern fried chicken is spreading fast in New York City, with pilgrims making stops at the Redhead in the East Village, Locanda Verde in TriBeCa and Buttermilk Channel in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. But while adherents may argue about buttermilk or brine, batter or dredge and shallow fry or deep fry, dissenters say there's a more fundamental question -- is Southern fried chicken ever that inspiring?

IN my ongoing quest to make baking easier, I thought I might try making a flourless, crustless tart that was more than a custard and not a cake, either. I had an idea for a mostly stovetop dish that resembled a tart, a kind of dessert frittata that was as simple to make as an omelet, but rich, chewy and sweet. Once I had the concept, the execution wasn't that difficult. I started with a base of eggs (not surprising) and chose almonds, pulverized in the food processor, instead of flour; I was after flavor, not lightness. For a more interesting texture, I tossed in a handful of sliced almonds as well.

After Clayton Kershaw finished talking with several reporters, he fiddled with his P.D.A. for a moment, then stood up to look around a Dodgers clubhouse that was filled with members of the news media. ''Hey, where is everybody?'' Kershaw said, dashing out of the clubhouse to join his teammates in a meeting.

The Angels have the most stolen bases of any playoff team, and that's bad news for the Boston catchers. Jason Varitek caught just 8.5 percent of would-be base stealers, the worst percentage of his career. The other Red Sox catcher, Victor Martinez, nabbed only 10.5 percent after being traded from Cleveland. Expect the aggressive Angels to run every chance they can. GOING STREAKING Boston's Josh Beckett had an 8.79 earned run average in three playoff starts last fall, but he kept alive his postseason winning streak, which reached six. The record for a starter is eight, held by Orlando Hernandez, with Bob Gibson, Orel Hershiser and David Wells at seven. Beckett will try to tie them when he starts Game 2 on Friday against Jered Weaver.

Can the Titans, who went 13-3 last season, come back from 0-4? The 1992 Chargers are the only N.F.L. team to start 0-4 and make the playoffs. ... It has seemingly been all or nothing for rookie coaches. Jim Caldwell's Colts and Josh McDaniels's Broncos are 4-0. Raheem Morris's Buccaneers, Todd Haley's Chiefs and Steve Spagnuolo's Rams are 0-4. Jim Schwartz of the Lions is 1-3, and Rex Ryan and the Jets are 3-1. ... Eli Manning has a better regular-season record on the road (24-14) than he does at home (22-15), and the same goes for the postseason (3-1 on the road, 0-2 at home). (NYT)

WHEN the Four Seasons opened 50 years ago, it set the tone for seasonal restaurants. Since then, it has maintained a Euro-American sensibility, with classically trained Swiss chefs holding sway in the kitchen until the death of Christian Albin in June, after 19 years as its chef. That is why many were surprised when Fabio Trabocchi was named his replacement on Oct. 1. Mr. Trabocchi, 35, is from the rustic Italian region of the Marches, and Italy informed his cooking at Fiamma in SoHo and Maestro in suburban Washington.

DREXLER--Dr. Milton. Calm, wise and beloved doctor of the Mamaroneck community, cherished friend of four generations of our family spanning eight decades. He served his nation with great distinction in WWII. He healed and comforted us. It was an honor and a great pleasure to be his friend and in his company. Our sincere condolences to Molly, Andy, Teddi and Sam. Helen Heller, Morris Propp, Melvin and Jack, Marni and Adrienne.

The idea of a tax credit for companies that create new jobs, something the federal government has not tried since the 1970s, is gaining support among economists and Washington officials grappling with the highest unemployment in a generation. The proposal has some bipartisan appeal among politicians eager both to help their unemployed constituents and to encourage small-business development. Legislators on Capitol Hill and President Obama's economic team have been quietly researching the policy for several weeks.

HAUER--Rose Muscatine. The Nurses Alumni Association of the Phillips Beth Israel School of nursing is deeply saddened by the passing of Rose Muscatine Hauer, R.N., Dean Emeritus of the Beth Israel School of Nursing and Vice President Emeritus of Nursing Service of Beth Israel Medical Center, and nationally recognized in the nursing profession. She was the epitome of nursing, for all who knew and worked with her. She was our mentor, our friend and an inspiration to us all. She always was available to each and every one of us. She truly was the Best of Beth Israel. She gave unstintingly of herself to all who asked or needed advice. No one can replace her; she will always live in our hearts. Rosewe truly loved you. We extend our deepest and heartfelt sympathy to her children, son and daughter-in-law Jerry and Tracy Hauer, and her daughter Deborah Schwartz and her three grandchildren, Lauren and Daniel Schwartz and Michael Hauer. Sandra Winer, R.N. President Rochelle Bronson, R.N. President Elect

The Senate Finance Committee still intends to vote this week on its health care bill, possibly as soon as Thursday. But the panel's 10 Republicans want to have some budget and tax experts weigh in first. In a letter on Tuesday to the committee's chairman, Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, the Republicans demanded that officials from the Congressional Budget Office and the Joint Committee on Taxation be brought before the panel to answer any questions ahead of any changes or a final vote on the health care bill.

Société Générale, the French bank, said on Tuesday that it intended to raise 4.8 billion euros ($7.1 billion) by issuing new shares to pay back aid received from the French government and to complete its acquisition of Credit du Nord. The lender said it would repay the 3.4 billion euros it owed the state, half in subordinated debt and half in preferred stock.

A battle that killed eight Americans at a pair of remote military bases in Afghanistan last weekend also left more than 100 insurgents dead, NATO said in a statement released on Tuesday. The statement said that insurgent forces suffered ''significantly higher losses than originally thought,'' but it provided no details of how NATO had reached that number. A senior NATO spokesman in Afghanistan, Rear Adm. Gregory J. Smith, said in a subsequent e-mail message that NATO had based its calculation on interviews in the area after the attack, intelligence sources and aerial surveillance.

For more than half a century heroin has been carried over the jungle-shrouded hills here, the first leg of a journey that delivers the drugs to cities as far off as Sydney and Tokyo. But antinarcotics officials are rubbing their eyes at the spectacle they are now witnessing: a flood of heroin and methamphetamine is spilling out of Myanmar as traffickers slash their inventories in a panicked sell-off. ''It's a clearance sale,'' said Pornthep Eamprapai, director of the northern branch of the Thai Office of Narcotics Control, who has nearly three decades of experience tracking illicit drugs from Myanmar. ''Some dealers at the border are buying on credit. They don't even need to pay in cash. This is the first time I've seen this.''

The interior minister said Tuesday that the government was expecting more attacks by the Taliban as the military prepared to begin a major offensive in South Waziristan, the rugged northwestern tribal region considered a stronghold of the Taliban. The minister, A. Rehman Malik, left, said the Taliban had orchestrated the suicide bombing that killed five people at the headquarters of the World Food Program in Islamabad on Monday, a statement that a Taliban spokesman confirmed.

The European Commission is expected to introduce a plan to reduce greenhouse gas emissions that directs the largest slices of 50 billion euros available for research and development to solar power and capturing and burying emissions from coal plants. The plan, to be released on Wednesday, is partly intended to show that the European Union is taking the additional steps needed to meet ambitious goals to cut greenhouse gases before a summit meeting in Copenhagen in December on reaching a new global agreement to curb climate change.

OSTACHER--Sidney, died October 5, 2009 from complications after heart surgery at age 79. Retired Director of Finance at the Commodities Exchange Center. His grandchildren, Sally and Jack Podhoretz and Jacob and Talia Ostacher, will forever have their Papa's memory in their hearts. (49) CRAFT IN AMERICA Season 2 of this Peabody Award-winning series continues its exploration of the country's craft culture, starting with the movement's origins and several artists whose work has its genesis in early techniques -- and who generously pass on their expertise to others. Among those featured are Philip Simmons, a South Carolina blacksmith; Vernon Owens, a North Carolina potter; Teri Greeves, a Kiowa tribe bead worker; Jim Bassler, a California weaver and world cultures professor; and Paul J. Stankard, a New Jersey glass artist. PROCESS, the second installment, at 9 on Channel 13 and at 10 on Channel 49, explores the inspiration behind craft careers and shows how artists acquire skills at schools like the Kansas City Art Institute, where the ceramicist Cary Esser teaches (above left, with a student), and the North Bennet Street School in Boston, which offers classes in subjects like violin making.

FIOL--Suzanne, 49, died October 5, 2009. Beloved daughter of Arlene and Lawrence Perlstein, mother of Sarah, sister of Nancy Goldspink, aunt to Emily Goldspink and dear friend to countless others and she will be missed by all.

DUBERSTEIN--Justice Maxine K.,86, passed away October 4th in Stamford, CT. Born in Brooklyn on March 21, 1923, she was the first woman President of the NY State and NYC Association of Justices of the Supreme Court. Maxine graduated from St. John's Law School in 1946. She was appointed to the Family Court by Mayor Lindsay in 1966. Justice Duberstein was elected twice to the NY Supreme Court. Prior to her time as a judge, Maxine became a Democratic Party district leader, representing Flatbush. She served as Kings County Campaign Coordinator for Adlai Stevenson, John Kennedy, Robert Kennedy, and Lyndon Johnson. Maxine was the proud mother of Dr. Elizabeth Cohen of Los Angeles, CA and Dr. Cathrine Troy of Stamford, CT and proud grandmother of Joshua Troy, Esq. of New York, NY and Jessica Troy of Stamford, CT. Her beloved husband of 55 years, Daniel M. Cohen, passed away in 2005. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service and The Rex Foundation.

ROSENBLUM--Elliott, passed away after a protracted battle with lung cancer on August 31, 2009 at his home in Hawaii. Beloved partner of 31 years to Mark Nesselson, M.D. Beloved father of children Ella and Cole. Beloved brother of David (Paula) and uncle of Mitchell and Andrew Rosenblum. Distinguished career as an architect. Graduated from Rhode Island School of Design. Worked under Edward Durell Stone early in his career. Worked as an architectural consultant for the West Side Development Corporation and the West Side Federation for Senior Housing, establishing that affordable housing can be beautiful. His rich career continued in the realm of retail, designing stores for Barneys New York, Hugo Boss, Calvin Klein, Coach, Gear and Saks Fifth Avenue. Subsequently he found his niche doing renovation and new construction of residences in New York City, Westchester, The Hamptons, Upstate New York, Connecticut, Nantucket, Maine and Hawaii. A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, October 11 at 2pm at the Tillman/U.N. Chapel at 44th Street and First Avenue.

It takes some nerve, not to mention diabolical intelligence and financial resources, to pull off the elaborate pranks devised by Andy Bichlbaum and Mike Bonanno (who are in real life Jack Servin and Igor Vamos), the antiglobalization activists and satirical performance artists known as the Yes Men. Whether their high jinks accomplish much beyond momentarily embarrassing the corporations and government agencies they misrepresent at business conferences and public forums is an open question. But it is great fun to watch them do their dirty work. In their second film, ''The Yes Men Fix the World,'' they pose as representatives of Dow Chemical, Halliburton, Exxon and the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development. The most outrageous of the modest proposals offered by these impostors might have made Jonathan Swift smile.

The Yankees won all seven games against the Twins this season, and have lost the season series to Minnesota just once since 1993. Since 2002, the Twins are 3-22 in the Bronx in the regular season (and 2-2 in the postseason). All of these Yankees own a career average of .300 or better against Minnesota: Mark Teixeira, Alex Rodriguez, Hideki Matsui, Derek Jeter, Johnny Damon, Robinson Cano, Melky Cabrera and Jose Molina.

MALONEY--Clifton H.W. The Board of Directors and staff of New York Foundation for Senior Citizens deeply mourn the passing of our outstanding Board Member and dear friend Clif Maloney and express our sympathy to his wife, Carolyn, daughters, Christina and Virginia, his mother, Mrs. Paul Maloney and sister, Ginger. A wise and genuinely caring gentleman of exemplary integrity, Clif's invaluable expertise and support has helped the Foundation develop senior citizen housing and social service programs for three decades. He was a true friend to so many and will be greatly missed. The family will be receiving visitors between 2 and 4pm and 6 and 8pm today at 49 East 92nd Street, New York, NY. Linda Hoffman, President William N. Hubbard, Chairman Edward N. Costikyan, Chairman Emeritus

The Yankees were unable to regularly fill their premium seats this season. With prices as high as $2,500 for the fanciest seats, fans found them just too expensive. So the team is cutting the price of some of the seats and rebranding them.

TOOHEY--Edward. The President, Trustees, current and former employees of the Windham Foundation and its subsidiaries are saddened by the death of our emeritus colleague, Ed Toohey, after his long and courageous battle with illness. A Board member for over 27 years, he served as Chair of the Finance Committee and as Foundation Treasurer. His financial expertise and business acumen provided great confidence and clarity and helped create the platform for many years of growth and philanthropy. He is remembered fondly for his sharp wit and wonderful sense of style. He is sorely missed and we extend our sincere condolences to his wife Phyllis, daughter Karen and the entire family.
STAUB--Bernard. The community of West End Synagogue, A Reconstructionist Congregation, mourns the loss of the intelligence of this enlightened, learned, sweet man. Blessings to his family.

TAYLOR--Alan L.,October 2, 2009. International corporate identity and branding expert. He is mourned by his many friends around the world, and especially by his wife, Paula, his loving children Lauren and Christopher, and his twin sister, Barbara. For the past 12 years he served as a committed and valued Member of the Advisory Board of the Auburn University College of Human Sciences. A graveside service will be held for the family in Delaware, followed by a memorial celebration of his life in New York City on November 7, 2009. Contributions in his memory may be made to: Auburn University Foundation-College of Human Sciences, Alan Taylor Fund for Excellence (210 Spidle Hall, Auburn University, AL 36849; 334-844-3790).

HOBBY'S DELICATESSEN & RESTAURANT in downtown Newark may have lost much of its more traditional clientele over the years, but it has held on to tradition. The corned beef and the tongue are cured for 14 days in stainless steel bins in the basement. The salamis hanging on the wall look as if they've been drying there, their flavor intensifying, since the Brummer family bought the place in 1962. Samuel Brummer and his sons, Michael and Marc, even make their own matzo ball soup and potato pancakes.

The Philadelphia Phillies open the division series with two left-handed starters, Cliff Lee and Cole Hamels, hoping to neutralize some of the Colorado Rockies' best hitters. Todd Helton hits about the same against lefties as righties, but Brad Hawpe is far less dangerous: .303 against right-handers, 60 points worse against left-handers. The Rockies were 8-16 against left-handed starters away from Coors Field, and in August, they managed just one run in losing consecutive games to J. A. Happ and Lee in Philadelphia. The Colorado left-hander Jorge De La Rosa, who went 16-3 after starting 0-6, has an injured groin muscle and was left off the roster for the first round.

There will be a memorial service held at 10am on October 10, 2009 at Grace Baptist Church located on 223 New Jersey Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. He will be remembered for his love of politics and for his loyalty and dedication to helping others. All of those who knew him as friend or colleague are invited to attend. Hilary Mantel won the 41st annual Man Booker Prize on Tuesday night for ''Wolf Hall,'' a historical novel about Henry VIII's court centered on the king's adviser, Thomas Cromwell. In the run-up to Tuesday's ceremony at the Guildhall in London, Ms. Mantel, 57, was the overwhelming favorite, with the bookmakers William Hill giving ''Wolf Hall'' odds of 10-11, the shortest odds ever for a nominee.

As both sides hurl insults at each other in the three-month-old political crisis in Honduras, a radio talk show host's anti-Semitic comments have reverberated far beyond Central America. The remarks by the Honduran radio host, David Romero, have ricocheted through the media and the blogosphere since they were published by the Anti-Defamation League over the weekend. The league's national director, Abraham H. Foxman, said that Jews appeared to have become a ''convenient scapegoat'' during a period of turmoil.

Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel spent almost 20 minutes Tuesday fielding questions about his team's pitching plans but answered hardly any of them. Who will start Game 3 of Philadelphia's division series against Colorado? What role will Pedro Martinez play? Will there be a designated closer? To that last question, Manuel smiled and said: ''Hard to tell. I'll answer that when we get there. Whoever you see walking out there.''

Good lighting is even more necessary onstage than it is in life. But a few fortunate actors require little in the way of flattering illumination. Instead of reflecting light, their faces seem to emit it. Charlayne Woodard is among them. I don't want to steal any credit from her lighting designer, Geoff Korf, but in her latest solo performance, ''The Night Watcher,'' Ms. Woodard roams the stage of the 59E59 Theaters like a human searchlight, casting a permanent glow that reaches all the way to the back rows.

Three Democratic Congressional committee chairmen said Tuesday that they would move to overturn a four-month-old Supreme Court ruling that made it significantly harder for workers to win many age discrimination cases. The three chairmen criticized the court's decision in a case involving a 54-year-old man who was demoted, saying the ruling flouted Congress's intent and created unfair obstacles to the victims of age discrimination.

HOLLINGSWORTH--Bob, a reporter, editor and editorial board member for more than 40 years, 30 of then with Newsday, died October 6 of complications related to a series of lumbar and cervical spine problems. He was 84. Hollingsworth began his newspaper career in 1948 as weekend reporter for Newsday while he was editor of the Hofstra Chronicle, the college newspaper. He rose rapidly through the Newsday ranks and became day city editor. Hollingsworth left Newsday in 1965, became managing editor of the Middletown, NY, Time-Herald Record and two years later joined the copy desk at the Providence, RI, Journal and became managing editor of the Journal's now-defunct sister newspaper, The Evening Bulletin. After a year as editor of Facts on File's annual yearbook, he rejoined Newsday in 1977, then became a member of the editorial board and wrote all of the editorials on New York City. He retired in 1989 and helped publicize Harrison J. Goldin's losing mayoral campaign. Then he and his wife, magazine writer Abby Rand, bought a small mountain weekly in Snowmass Village, CO, part of the Aspen resort complex. Selling it in 1995, they returned to their apartment in NYC. Hollingsworth was born May 30, 1925, in Leominster, MA to the former Lyndall Weidner and Lawrence I. Hollingsworth. During World War II, Hollingsworth joined the US Maritime Service and became a Merchant Marine Radio Office, serving on convoys in the North Atlantic and Pacific. In addition to Ms. Rand, Hollingsworth is survived by four children, Lois of Warwick, RI; Lawrence of Goleta, CA; Lori Murphy of Northport, NY, and Lynne of Wading River, NY; a brother, Richard Corali of Bradenton, FL; a half sister, Joan Eager of Massapequa and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a time to be announced.

McKENNA--Paul. It is with much sadness we announce the death of Paul J. McKenna on Friday, October 2nd, dear brother of Michael McKenna of Berkeley, CA, Dennis McKenna of Mount Pleasant, SC and Kevin McKenna of New York, NY and the son of the late Luinda and James McKenna of Providence, RI. Paul was Director of Expatriate Services at Turner Broadcasting, Atlanta. Previously, he held the same position at Ernst & Young, New York. A graduate of the University of Rhode Island, Bryant College and a former principal dancer for Festival Ballet of Rhode Island, Paul was a resident of New York City and Quonochontaug, RI, Paul is survived by his partner, Michael Mahana of New York City and his beloved pets Lucky, Lulu, Peaches and Tuffy. A private memorial will be conducted in Rhode Island on October 11, 2009. Friends are invited to a gathering at his former home on Friday, October 23rd from 6-8pm.

The Minnesota Vikings' 30-23 victory over the Green Bay Packers on Monday night on ESPN attracted an average of 21.8 million viewers, the biggest audience in the history of cable television, exceeding the 18.6 million who watched the Philadelphia Eagles-Dallas Cowboys game in September 2008 on ESPN. The Monday night game featured Brett Favre's first game as a Viking against his former team. The game was the highest-rated program on broadcast or cable TV and swept the important male and adult demographics.

How devastating is a tandem like the Cardinals' Chris Carpenter (17-4, 2.24 earned run average) and Adam Wainwright (19-8, 2.63)? In the last 10 years, only two other sets of teammates entered the postseason with at least 17 victories each and E.R.A.'s less than 3.00. They were Randy Johnson and Curt Schilling of the 2001 Diamondbacks, and Roy Oswalt and Andy Pettitte of the 2005 Astros. Both teams reached the World Series. RAMIREZ SLUMPING Manny Ramirez hit .370 in the final month of 2008, then went 13 for 25 in the playoffs. He is not as hot this time, hitting .218 since Sept. 1. The good thing for Ramirez is that his fellow Dodgers outfielders help carry the load. Matt Kemp and Andre Ethier each topped 25 homers and 100 runs batted in.

SOMMER--Viola Sommer nee Landsberg, wife of Sigmund Sommer, the well-known New York real estate developer and noted race horse owner, succumbed to a long illness after having just turned 88 with her three loving children and grandchildren at her side on Sunday, October 4, 2009. Born in New York City on September 19, 1921, she attended the Julia Richman High School and Hunter College. During World War II, she worked for the USO, interviewing servicemen for the military upon their return from the front. Mrs. Sommer lived in the New York metropolitan area for almost all of her life, and with Sigmund, ran one of the most successful thoroughbred racing stables of its time, during the 1960s and 70s. With Frank Martin as trainer, they were leading money winners in North America for ten consecutive years. They owned Sham, who won the 1973 Santa Anita Derby, and who took second place in the Wood Memorial Stakes over Secretariat, who finished third. He placed in two of the three legs of the Triple Crown in the same year, when Secretariat won the three races. In the Kentucky Derby, Sham placed second to Secretariat, yet still broke the track record after stumbling in the gate. Even after Sigmund Sommer's death, Viola Sommer remained active in the company he founded, Sigmund Sommer Properties. She also distinguished herself by winning the Eclipse Award for outstanding owner in 1982, and serving as a trustee with the New York Racing Association (NYRA) and the Jockey Club for many years. She is survived by her older brother Eugene, 94, her 3 children, Jack Sommer, Susan Sommer Schweitzman, and Dr. Barbara Sommer Fisher, and by 10 grandchildren. Mrs. Sommer's memorial service took place on Tuesday, October 6, 2009 at The Riverside Memorial Chapel. Memorial gifts may be made to NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and sent to the Office of Development, 525 East 68 Street, Box 123, NYC 10065.

Chechnya's strongman leader, Ramzan A. Kadyrov, won a libel suit on Tuesday against the director of a prominent human rights group who had linked him to the killing of a human rights worker. The verdict by a district court in Moscow seemed to reinforce a message already sent by the killings of several of Mr. Kadyrov's prominent critics: that there were limits to the tolerance of criticism of political officials.

WANGH--Martin, M.D. We mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Martin Wangh, a Training and Supervising Analyst and valued faculty member. In the 1950s and 60s, he worked closely with Charles Brenner, Jacob Arlow and David Beres in leading the Kris Study Group. We offer our condolences to his family and friends. Dr. Roger Rahtz, President Dr. Philip Herschenfeld, Dean New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute

DENBURG--Mollie Bregman, 101. Beloved wife of the late Abraham I. Denburg; loving mother of Howard S. and his wife Dorothy; loving grandmother of Michelle (Terence), Elizabeth (Jake) and Abigail; great-grandmother of Leo. Contributions may be made to Barnard College.

WEINSTEIN--Ida Winaker Loewenberg, 92, of Brooklyn and Neponsit, died September 29, 2009, in Boca Raton, Florida. She was the loving and beloved wife of the late Stanley A. Loewenberg and Jacob M. Weinstein. She was predeceased also by her parents Minnie and Harry Winaker and her brother Oscar. Left to mourn her are her cherished children Susan L. Shulman (Victor Shulman), Paul H. Weinstein (Wendi Glassman) and Andrew Z. Weinstein (the late Etta Sanders), her adored grandchildren Stephanie A. Shulman (Amir Bronstein), David J. Shulman (Fernanda Cohen-Shulman), Nicholas and Jonah Weinstein, her special great-grandchildren Mia and Liam Bronstein, her beloved sister Sylvia Ayes (the late Theodore) and brother Laurence Winaker (Rhea), many nieces and nephews and all those who were fortunate enough to have known her and to have been touched by her gentle nature, kindness and generosity. A Girls High School graduate at the age of 16, she earned bachelors and masters degrees from NYU. After working as a hospital dietitian, she had a long career as a Home Economics and then substitute teacher in several Brooklyn public schools. She was an intrepid, inspired cook; a master storyteller (especially in Yiddish); a shrewd political observer and proud Liberal. Her intelligence showed through in her sense of humor and wit, which were extraordinary. But above all, her love for her family and her friends was unconditional and her loyalty to us all was fierce. We have lost a woman beyond measure. Services were held privately in New York.

As Capitol Hill froths with controversy over the cost of a health care overhaul, many readers posting comments on Health Care Conversations, The New York Times's new online forum, have been discussing a sensitive subset of that topic: what should be done to improve, and to pay for, care at the end of life. ''At what point should we stop trying to prevent the inevitable? Is keeping someone alive for three more days worth the pain and suffering?'' wrote Jeff, a poster from Wyoming. ''This is a complex issue to be sure, and unfortunately one that is going to get overlooked due to partisan bickering and name-calling.''

President Obama told Congressional leaders on Tuesday that he would not substantially reduce American forces in Afghanistan or shift the mission to just hunting terrorists there, but he indicated that he remained undecided about the major troop buildup proposed by his commanding general. Meeting with leaders from both parties at the White House, Mr. Obama seemed to be searching for some sort of middle ground, saying he wanted to ''dispense with the straw man argument that this is about either doubling down or leaving Afghanistan,'' as White House officials later described his remarks.

While many metropolitan markets around the country are enduring steep increases in vacancies in their office and retail sectors, the Rosslyn-Ballston corridor in the Northern Virginia suburbs of Washington is an oasis of stability -- and even of prosperity. Served by five Metro subway stops within four miles, the corridor continues to attract new tenants, buyers and developers in the face of the deepest recession since the Great Depression. ''It's really an anomaly, considering the tough economy we've been in since December 2007,'' said Sigrid G. Zialcita, managing research director for Cushman & Wakefield, a global real estate services firm.

SCHANZER--Karen. The Sapirman-Gorelick family and all of us at the Saparn Realty organization mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend and colleague Karen Schanzer. We send our heartfelt condolences to her entire family. Anita Sapirman, President Saparn Realty, Inc.

SLOAN--Susan, on October 3, 2009. Deeply loved by her husband Joaquin Diaz. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to The American Cancer Society or Gilda's Club.

When Brian Wilson sang that he “just wasn’t made for these times,” apparently he wasn’t just being wistful. For his next album, Mr. Wilson, the former front man of the Beach Boys, will be collaborating with a pop star who preceded him by a generation or three: George Gershwin. As part of a two-album deal with Walt Disney Records, Mr. Wilson will create new pieces of music based on unfinished Gershwin works, the record label said Thursday in a news release. The new compositions, which Disney said that Mr. Wilson would “Brian-ize with his trademark vocal stacks and unique arrangements,” will appear on an album that will also include Mr. Wilson’s covers of other classic songs by George and Ira Gershwin. The estates of both Gershwin siblings have given their approval for the project, which a representative for Mr. Wilson said he would begin recording with his band on Oct. 18 and finish after Thanksgiving. In a statement, Mr. Wilson called the album “the most spiritual project I’ve ever worked on.”

The announcement this morning that the Romanian-born German writer Herta Müller has won the 2009 Nobel Prize for Literature has generated a number of responses from New York Times readers. Some are pleased that a woman was chosen. Others think the selection is too obscure. And many commented that the choice of Ms. Müller was a sign that not enough foreign works are translated into English — “Why hadn’t we heard of her before?”

Kaufman-Edna Ferber comedy, became ill during Sunday’s matinee performance at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater, resulting in the performance’s cancellation. He was taken to St. Luke’s-Roosevelt Hospital Center and his daughter, Nicole Roberts, said later that he had had a minor seizure.

BERLIN — Herta Müller was at home in Berlin when the Nobel committee called to tell her that she won the highest prize in literature. Reporters thronged outside the red-brick apartment building in the quaint but hardly high-class neighborhood of Friedenau where she lives almost immediately after the announcement Thursday.They rang and rang. She didn’t answer.

Ran Ortner, a painter from Brooklyn, was named the grand-prize winner Thursday night in the ArtPrize, a public competition in Grand Rapids, Mich. Mr. Ortner’s work, “Open Water No. 24,” received the highest number of votes among 10 finalists on display across Grand Rapids, a city of 200,000 in western Michigan. He will receive $250,000. In all, the finalists shared $449,000 in awards.

Get your subterranean church organs tuned and make sure your chandeliers are firmly affixed to the ceiling: The Phantom is returning to the theater. On Thursday, Andrew Lloyd Webber announced the initial details of “Love Never Dies,” his long-in-the-works sequel to “The Phantom of the Opera.” As Phantophiles already know, the new musical moves the story from a Paris opera house to the Coney Island boardwalk, where the Phantom and his love, Christine, once again cross paths (presumably not in line for the Cyclone, though the show is billed as “a rollercoaster ride of obsession and intrigue”).

The rapper Adam Yauch said that he is “feeling healthy, strong and hopeful” that he has beaten cancer after returning from a recent trip to India, but a coming album by his band the Beastie Boys remains without a release date.

The role of Lina in the Metropolitan Opera‘s coming production of Verdi’s “Stiffelio” will be shared between the American sopranos Sondra Radvanovsky and Julianna Di Giacomo. They are replacing Angela Marambio, the Chilean soprano, who has withdrawn, the Met said in a news release. Ms. Radvanovsky will sing the performances on Jan. 11 and 14, and the matinee of Jan. 30; Ms. Di Giacomo will sing the role on Jan. 19, 23 and 26. Both are performing the role for the first time at the Met. Ms. Radvanovsky previously sang Lina at London’s Royal Opera Covent Garden in 2007, and has performed in Verdi operas including “Il Trovatore” at the Met. Ms. Di Giacomo made her Met debut as Clotilde in “Norma” in 2007, and made her La Scala debut this past season as Lucrezia in Verdi’s “I Due Foscari.”

The fall television season has reached that improbable moment when the number of new series that have been picked up for a full year exceeds the number that have been canceled. On Tuesday, CBS announced that it was giving full season orders to its new dramas “NCIS: Los Angeles” and “The Good Wife,” both of which are shown on Tuesday nights. The decision should come as absolutely no surprise to anyone who keeps an eye on Nielsen ratings: “NCIS: Los Angeles,” a spinoff of CBS’s hit police procedural “NCIS” that stars LL Cool J and Chris O’Donnell, is already the most-viewed new show of the fall season (CBS said it averages just under 17.5 million viewers a week). “The Good Wife” is no slouch, either: that show, which stars Julianna Margulies as the purely fictional spouse of a politician embroiled in a sex scandal, has been drawing about 13.7 million viewers a week, according to CBS.

Last week, The Washington Post ran a front-page story that said most stay-at-home moms aren't S.U.V.-driving, daily yoga-doing, latte-drinking white, upper-middle-class women who choose to leave their high-powered careers to answer the call to motherhood. Instead, they are disproportionately low-income, non-college educated, young and Hispanic or foreign-born; in other words, they are women whose horizons are greatly limited and for whom the cost of child care, very often, makes work not a workable choice at all.
