The show opens with the aftermath of a powerful suicide attack in Kabul, Afghanistan. The blast killed 17 people near the Indian Embassy, in what India's foreign secretary said was a direct attack on the embassy compound, the second in two years. The attack underscored the powerful reach of Afghanistan's insurgency, which is strongest in the countryside but has also proved capable of carrying out attacks in heavily guarded areas of the capital.

PARIS - The shows ended here with four completely different takes on fashion. At Louis Vuitton, Marc Jacobs's ode to sporty travelers as seen through kooky Japanese eyes piled on upholstery fabrics with beading; lingerie hybrids with fluorescent accents; backpacks with totes; and feathered clogs with Teva-like sandals. (Did we mention the giant Afros with bows?) At Miu Miu, the mood was '70s sexy, with lots of sheer, bejeweled dresses decorated with prints by the artist John Wesley. Hermès scored an ace with an easy tennis-inspired collection that included the most luxurious racquet bags in memory; and John Galliano capped off the spring 2010 season with demure short chiffon dresses, shown on a laser-lit runway that was anything but. Who won the day? You be the judge.

Second of all, I'd just like to take this time to thank the Cleveland Browns, owner Randy Lerner (and) Romeo Crennel, who was the head coach at the time I was drafted. I just appreciated them for giving me the opportunity to play in Cleveland (and) taking a chance on me third over all in 2005. It's a great organization over there and I wish them nothing but the best. I really appreciate them giving me the opportunity. Third of all, as it relates to the incident I was allegedly a part of this past Sunday, right now, it is a legal matter. There is nothing I can talk about. Nutella, the chocolaty, hazelnutty spread, has a cultlike following. People love Nutella for its balance of savory and sweet, and its versatility: You can put it inside crepes or atop waffles, or eat it straight out of the jar with a spoon. Its decadent creamy goodness has inspired poetry, love songs and amateur music videos.

(President Obama prefers it for lunch.) So it is with sad eyes that we report the death of Ben Ali, the Trinidad-born restaurant genius who founded the place in 1958. Order up!

Gov. Jon S. Corzine announced today that the state will set up a new electronic registry for children with autism, ostensibly to help the children and their families connect with treatment and support services in the communities. The registry will also be used to help measure the prevalence of the disorder in New Jersey, which was believed to have the highest rate of the disorder in the country. Recent research in the Journal of Pediatrics shows that the prevalence rate nationally is 1 case for every 100 children, up from an earlier estimate of 1 in 150. One in 94 New Jersey children has autism. Early interventions such as physical, occupational and speech therapies have been shown to help the majority of young children with autism. Under a state law signed this summer, the first of its kind, insurance companies must provide up to $36,000 a year for early interventions. -- Tina Kelley

When the calendar turns to October, baseball strategy changes in a few significant ways (above and beyond pressure, ticket prices, and the like). For position players, this distinction is minimal, but for pitchers, it's key.

Harvard University has acquired the archives of John Updike, right, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author and Harvard alumnus who died in January, The Boston Globe reported. Mr. Updike, a member of Harvard’s Class of 1954 whose works included the autobiographical Olinger short stories and Rabbit novels, retained a Harvard library card after graduating and continued to visit the campus to do research. The Houghton Library at Harvard is expected to house the John Updike Archive, which includes his collection of his own work, in English and foreign-language editions, as well as annotated copies of books that he reviewed, dust-jacket designs, research files and correspondence from fellow authors and fans. The Houghton Library said on its blog that for decades Mr. Updike deposited his manuscripts, his letters and even his golf score cards at the library, but that the material was available only with Mr. Updike’s permission. The Globe said Harvard officials would not disclose how much was paid to acquire the archive.

A new play by Rinne Groff about a man’s obsession with the diary of Anne Frank will star Mandy Patinkin and have its premiere at the Yale Repertory Theater next year. On Wednesday the theater said the play, “Compulsion,” would star Mr. Patinkin, above, as a character based on Meyer Levin, the journalist and screenwriter who helped publicize the existence of the diary and came to believe that the opportunity to adapt it for the stage had been stolen from him. “Everything Anne Frank represents was extremely powerful to him,” Mr. Patinkin said in a telephone interview, “and what he felt was manipulated in various places by various sources concerned him greatly. He went on this quest to try to purify what he felt her journey was all about.” The play is to be directed by Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater. It will begin preview performances on Jan. 29, with an official opening set for Feb. 4.

Who is the biggest diva of them all? Barbra Streisand, right. Her latest record, “Love Is the Answer” (Columbia), opened at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, ahead of new albums by Mariah Carey, Madonna and Paramore, the band led by Hayley Williams. “Love Is the Answer” sold 180,000 copies in the United States last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, while Paramore’s “Brand New Eyes” (Fueled by Ramen) moved 175,000 and Ms. Carey’s “Memoirs of an Imperfect Angel” (Island) 168,000. In a week packed with new releases, the rock band Breaking Benjamin reached No. 4 with 134,000 sales of “Dear Agony” (Hollywood), Alice in Chains opened at No. 5 with “Black Gives Way to Blue” (Virgin/EMI) selling 126,000, and Madonna’s new hits compilation, “Celebration” (Warner Brothers), sold 72,000 to reach No. 7. “Revolution” (Columbia Nashville) by the country singer Miranda Lambert is in eighth place with sales of 66,000, slightly more than “Kiss & Tell” (Hollywood), the debut album by the Disney Channel star Selena Gomez and her band, the Scene.

The manager of the rock band Guns N’ Roses said the group did not use unauthorized samples, after a German musician filed suit contending that the band had used his work. In his suit Ulrich Schnauss, a German electronic artist, asserts that the Guns N’ Roses song “Riad N’ the Bedouins” includes unauthorized samples of his tracks “Wherever You Are” and “A Strangely Isolated Place.” But in a statement, Guns N’ Roses’s manager, Irving Azoff, said the band “vigorously contests these claims.” Mr. Azoff said Guns N’ Roses “believed when the record came out and still believes that there are no unauthorized samples on the track.” The statement continued, “The snippets of ‘ambient noise’ in question were provided by a member of the album’s production team who has assured us that these few seconds of sound were obtained legitimately.” Mr. Azoff also said lawyers for the band and its production team would file a formal response soon.

The lengthy holdout of receiver Michael Crabtree ended early Wednesday, when he agreed to a deal with the San Francisco 49ers only hours before the Jets completed a trade for Braylon Edwards. Whether the two events are connected -- the Niners had accused the Jets of tampering with Crabtree during his holdout -- only a few Jets executives know. But with Crabtree finally in the fold, the Niners (3-1), who lead the National Football Conference West with a conservative offense, now have a game-breaking threat, that is, if he can learn the offense quickly. That may take awhile because Crabtree, the 10th overall pick in the 2009 N.F.L. draft, missed the team's minicamps and off-season organized activities while recovering from a foot injury. Then his holdout consumed all of training camp and the first month of the regular season. The holdout was based on his belief that he should be paid like the first receiver picked in the draft, Darrius Heyward-Bey, who was taken seventh over all and received $23.5 million guaranteed, rather than like a player at his slotted spot.

The ING Group said Wednesday that it had agreed to sell its Swiss private banking unit to the wealth manager Julius Baer Holding for 520 million Swiss francs ($505 million). The sale is just one step in ING's global retreat, with units in Asia and possibly North America for sale. Last month, it sold its stake in its Australian joint venture to ANZ.

The Yankees' old shrine still stands on 161st Street in the Bronx, dark and cold and gutted. The October games that made it so famous have moved across the street, where the new Yankee Stadium hosted its first playoff game in style Wednesday night. The bright lights twinkled above the signature frieze, and three decks of seats thumped on a night when nearly everything went perfectly for the Yankees. They snuffed the Minnesota Twins, 7-2, in the first game of their division series, benefiting from the kind of shutdown pitching they lacked in October for much of this decade.

Maybe William Ayers, the 1960s radical, has decided to have a little fun with all the conspiracies spooling out about him on the Internet. This week, Anne Leary, a blogger who writes under the moniker BackyardConservative, posted a breathless account of the admission she said she wrested from Mr. Ayers at Reagan National Airport recently, after he had attended an education conference in Arlington, Va.

HERNON--Vivian L.,passed away October 6, 2009. Born Vivian Anne Ferracci in the Bronx. Professional name, Vivian Farrar. Lived in Pelham Manor and NYC. Among her many professional accomplishments: the country's first female TV news anchor and weather person (WPIX); actress in TV soap operas, including Edge of Night and Secret Storm; actress and voice-over for numerous national TV commercials; appeared on the popular TV panel shows To Tell The Truth, and Girl Talk; voice dubbing in many foreign films, most famously Fellini's 8 1/2. Married to William J. Lyons. Later to Patrick S. Hernon. A graduate of The College of New Rochelle (B.A.) and Columbia University (M.A.). Vivian was a masterful cook, loved to travel and garden, and was an avid reader who enjoyed the camaraderie of her book club. Vivian deeply loved her friends and family, all of whom will miss her greatly. She is survived by children William Lyons and wife Carol, Mark Lyons and wife Barbara, Tracey Davidson and husband Philip, Laurie Boyce and husband Dale, and Andrew Lyons; and by grandchildren Margaret Lyons, Grace Lyons, Harris Davidson, and Sarah Davidson. Funeral service is today, October 8, at Church of Our Savior, 59 Park Ave. at 10am. Following the ceremony Vivian will be buried at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers please consider a donation to Vivian's favorite charities: City Meals-on-Wheels and City Harvest.

A large blast went off in central Kabul on Thursday, sending clouds of dust and smoke into the air, and leaving at least six dead. The bomb went off near the Indian Embassy, the Interior Ministry and a hotel, and it left a crater and debris scattered around the area.

WHEN it comes to buying a pair of soccer cleats, it is often a matter of rounding up offerings from the usual suspects: Adidas, Nike or Puma. They have the huge advertising budgets and hefty player endorsements that are the costs of doing business in soccer's global stratosphere. Beyond those industry giants, a handful of companies that are flying under the radar (for now) offer interesting, innovative and comfortable cleats that deserve consideration.

MAESTRONE--Gianpaolo (Paul), DVM (October 5, 2009). The directors and staff of the American Parkinson Disease Association (APDA) mourn the loss of Dr. Paul Maestrone, Director of Scientific & Medical Affairs, and a guiding force in the organization's growth into the country's largest grassroots organization serving people with Parkinson's disease and their families. Dr. Maestrone was a Fulbright Scholar, industry research leader, and holder of four U.S. patents before joining APDA in 1987. Under his direction, APDA created nine Centers for Advanced Research, 60 Information & Referral Centers, and funded millions of dollars for research and patient/caregiver support and education programs. He was a member of the New York Academy of Medicine and awarded Vigevano, Italy's Emeritus Citizen Medal. We will miss his knowledge and wisdom, and extend our sincerest condolences to his wife of 53 years, Sophia; children, Frank, Elizabeth Braun, and Elena Imperato, and his entire family. Joel A. Miele Sr., P.E, President Joel Gerstel, Executive Director

News on Wednesday that the Congressional Budget Office had issued its cost analysis of the Senate Finance Committee's health legislation prompted dozens of reader comments. Here is a sampling, in some cases condensed from longer postings: I am glad the report came out and had the cost analysis. Now, we can move forward with the legislation. I believe the Sen. Majority Reid will put together a stronger bill, possibly (hopefully) with an employer mandate, along with an individual mandate maybe, and go forward. Although I am hopeful that a public option will be included, I think Reid may let the option come to the floor to be voted on. I believe this time we will get health care reform finally in the U.S. It may not be what I want all at once, but will set the ground work for a better one later.

To combat Al Qaeda's growing influence and presence in Afghanistan's prisons, the Pentagon is creating a military task force to oversee a planned overhaul of the troubled detention operations there. The Defense Department on Wednesday named Vice Adm. Robert S. Harward, who commanded Special Operations forces in Iraq and Afghanistan, to lead the task force. He is currently deputy commander of the military's Joint Forces Command.

McKenna on Friday, October 2nd, dear brother of Michael McKenna of Berkeley, CA, Dennis McKenna of Mount Pleasant, SC and Kevin McKenna of New York, NY and the son of the late Luinda and James McKenna of Providence, RI. Paul was Director of Expatriate Services at Turner Broadcasting, Atlanta. Previously, he held the same position at Ernst & Young, New York. A graduate of the University of Rhode Island, Bryant College and a former principal dancer for Festival Ballet of Rhode Island, Paul was a resident of New York City and Quonochontaug, RI, Paul is survived by his partner, Michael Mahana of New York City and his beloved pets Lucky, Lulu, Peaches and Tuffy. TOOHEY--Edward. The President, Trustees, current and former employees of the Windham Foundation and its subsidiaries are saddened by the death of our emeritus colleague, Ed Toohey, after his long and courageous battle with illness. A Board member for over 27 years, he served as Chair of the Finance Committee and as Foundation Treasurer. His financial expertise and business acumen provided great confidence and clarity and helped create the platform for many years of growth and philanthropy. He is remembered fondly for his sharp wit and wonderful sense of style. He is sorely missed and we extend our sincere condolences to his wife Phyllis, daughter Karen and the entire family.

FRIEDLANDER--Miriam. Former City Council member Miriam Friedlander, 95, passed away October 4th. Born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania to David and Hannah Sigel, the family moved to the Bronx and she graduated Hunter High School and New York University. She was elected to the Council from District 2 in 1973 and served for 18 years. Following her retirement Ms. Friedlander remained active in lower Manhattan politics until her death. She is survived by son Paul Friedlander, a Professor of Music and grandson David, both of Chico, California.

France said on Friday that it would return relics to Egypt that were apparently stolen and sold to the Louvre, and Egypt said it would restore its ties to the museum as soon as that restitution occurs, Agence France-Presse reported. On Wednesday, Egypt suspended its cooperation with the Louvre, saying that five fresco fragments in its collection were stolen from Luxor’s Valley of the Kings, and that the museum was not honoring a longstanding agreement to return any smuggled or stolen Egyptian artifacts. The French government had said the Louvre acted in good faith when it bought the relics in 2000 and 2003, but a commission that oversees the nation’s museums voted unanimously to return them, saying that significant doubts about their origins had been raised. In November, archaeologists rediscovered the tomb from which the relics seem to have come from, raising the question of whether they had been taken legally from Egypt.

If you want proof that graphic novels can be about anything, behold “Logicomix: An Epic Search for Truth,” which chronicles the philosopher Bertrand Russell‘s journey to establish the logical foundations of mathematics. The book is No. 1 on our softcover list this week; it was reviewed by Jim Holt in The New York Times Book Review on Sept. 25 and was an Editor’s Choice on Oct. 4.

A little open-heart surgery isn’t going to keep Robin Williams from making good on plans to bring his “Weapons of Self-Destruction” tour to New York. Mr. Williams, the comedian and actor, will perform six shows at Town Hall on Nov. 23 through 25, and Dec. 1 through 3, his publicists said in a news release. He had previously been scheduled to play five shows at Broadway’s Neil Simon Theater in April and May, but those dates were postponed along with the rest of his tour when he had surgery on March 13 to replace his aortic valve, repair his mitral valve and correct his irregular heartbeat. Mr. Williams resumed his live performances on Sept. 30 in Bloomington, Ind., and his performances in November at DAR Constitution Hall in Washington are slated to be taped for an HBO special that will be shown in December.

On Thursday, we brazenly observed that, incredibly, more new network television series were getting season-long pickups than getting canceled. Hours later, NBC’s surprise cancellation of “Southland” (which, technically, is a returning show and not a new series) threatened to upset that balance. But now ABC has cast three more votes in favor of promising new programs: The Hollywood Reporter said that the network has ordered full seasons of its comedies “Modern Family,” “Cougar Town” and “The Middle.” “Cougar Town,” which stars the “Friends” alumna Courteney Cox, and “Modern Family,” an ensemble series, drew strong ratings for their September premieres but have faded slightly in recent weeks; “The Middle,” which stars Patricia Heaton (of “Everybody Loves Raymond”), has averaged fewer than 7 million viewers a week. Ominously, ABC made no announcement about its new Kelsey Grammer sitcom “Hank,” which airs side-by-side with “The Middle,” or its new series “Eastwick,” adapted from “The Witches of Eastwick.”

Clayton Patterson has been documenting Manhattan’s Lower East Side in photographs and videos since the 1980s. He caught what he has called “the last of the wild, free, outlaw, utopian, visionary spirit” of the neighborhood, before the real estate boom drove out many of its artists and anarchists, drug crews and drag queens, working class families and the bodegas that served them.

Hold onto your beehive hairdos, people: you’re about to read an update on Amy Winehouse that in no way involves her interacting with law enforcement officials. The co-president of the record label that releases the work of Ms. Winehouse, the popular if perennially troubled British soul singer, said that she would release a new album next year, The Guardian reported. “I’ve heard a couple of song demos that absolutely floored me,” Darcus Beese, the co-president of Island Records told The Guardian. “Hopefully, we’ll have her album next year.” Ms. Winehouse, 26, released her last album, “Back to Black,” in the United States in 2007, after which she sold more than 5 million copies of that record; won five Grammy Awards; was videotaped apparently using drugs; entered a drug rehabilitation program; was arrested on various drug and assault charges; was hospitalized; and got married and divorced, among other milestones. A title for the new album was not given, and, though it would seem to go without saying, The Guardian wrote that Ms. Winehouse “is not known for her punctuality.”

A 22-inch figurine from “King Kong,” used in the climactic sequence from the original 1933 film when its title character ascends the Empire State Building, will be sold at auction on Nov. 24, The Associated Press reported. The auction house Christie’s expects to get about $240,000 for the figurine, or about $10,900 per inch of Kong.

The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts plans to create a long-range arts education plan for students in grades K-8, starting in Sacramento, the center announced on Friday. After a six-month evaluation of existing arts education resources, the Kennedy Center — along with Sacramento’s school system and local arts organizations — will design a plan for arts education specific to the area.

Brian Leetch, one of the greatest defenseman in N.H.L. history, is the only American-born player to win the Conn Smythe Trophy as the most valuable player in the playoffs when he helped lead the Rangers to the Stanley Cup in 1994. He was awarded the Norris Trophy twice as the league's top defenseman and was inducted into the U.S. Hockey Hall of Fame in 2008 and the Hockey Hall of Fame in 2009.

As Tony Oliva approached the batting cage to say hello to some Yankees Friday, Jorge Posada did not say hello. Instead, Posada pointed his bat toward Oliva, the three-time batting champion from the Minnesota Twins, crouched and imitated Oliva's stance. Oliva smiled.

After missing the playoffs last season, the Yankees appear to be unstoppable heading into this year's postseason, boasting the best record in baseball. Fans can point to the performances of pitchers C.C. Sabathia and A.J. Burnett and the hitting of Derek Jeter, Robinson Cano and Mark Teixeira as reasons for the team's success. However, style watchers will argue that a men's accessory - also worn by sports stars like Sergio Garcia and Lleyton Hewitt - may well be responsible for the team's winning ways. Several players, including Joba Chamberlain, Nick Swisher and Cano, are wearing Phiten (appropriately pronounced "fightin' ") necklaces, not just for style but for strength. The baubles, braided layers of nylon and polyester, contain titanium, a metal that the manufacturer claims permits a greater flow of energy in the body. Color combinations abound, including Yankee navy and white.

It all began when Emil Corsillo was looking for a tie to wear with his favorite vintage work shirt. He had some dead-stock fabric and created a simple square-end necktie. Friends started to clamor for ones just like it, and so he started amassing old fabric: denim, chambray, hand-woven linen, even old canvas dropcloths. That's how Hill-side was born. Named after the street he grew up on, the collection has been snapped up by Blackbird in Seattle, Steven Alan and United Arrows in Japan. Corsillo has also added pocket squares and handkerchiefs, and most items retail for under $100. A great find, in other words, for the guy who loves his Filson, Quoddy and L.L. Bean duck boots.

It should be noted that, in their current cameo appearances at the Deitch Projects gallery in SoHo, the president of the United States and the first lady are fully, tastefully clothed. It'd be easy to suspect otherwise of Kurt Kauper's "Barack and Michelle Obama" (on view through Oct. 31), given that his last show at Deitch, 2007's "Everybody Knew That Canadians Were the Best Hockey Players," featured, yes, Canadian hockey stars in full-frontal glory, while his 2003 Carey Grant series (you can find selected images here) didn't leave much to the imagination. The works were disarming because of the relaxed postures of his subjects - e.g., a naked Cary Grant leaning casually against a fireplace - but also a bit overwhelming given their larger-than-life size. (The Canadian hockey gods were painted on panels nearly eight feet tall.) Kauper even painted himself naked (not particularly flatteringly on a smaller-than-life panel) back in 1995.

The Giants got a badly needed dose of good injury news Friday, when quarterback Eli Manning practiced for the first time all week. With his right heel heavily taped, Manning took about half the snaps and had no trouble dropping back or launching deep passes, in addition to running and stretching with the team. He is listed as questionable for Sunday's game against the Raiders, and Coach Tom Coughlin said he was "absolutely" encouraged by what he saw from Manning, who injured the plantar fascia during last Sunday's victory over the Chiefs.

With a serious art scene, rollicking nightlife and no H1N1 in sight, Mexico City is back on the style set's radar. And luring travelers southward are two new hotels, the St. Regis and Distrito Capital. Distrito, a sister hotel to the tastemaker magnet Condesa df, is way out in the neighborhood of Santa Fe (imagine Wilshire Boulevard at the edge of nowhere), but that doesn't stop the city's pretty young things with ripped jeans and money to burn from crowding the poolside lounge. Amid a mostly black and white scheme, there's plenty of boxy furniture and kitschy design tricks of the sort that the Standard Hotels have been serving up for years. The St. Regis, on the other hand, is a glass behemoth by the Argentine-American starchitect César Pelli, where silver foxes in khakis come to drink highballs in a sea of tasteful neutrals. The most notable thing about the hotel just might be the service. Not too many people still have butlers these days, even if they can afford them, but if you book a suite here, you get one of your very own.

On the Economix blog on Friday, the economist Uwe E. Reinhardt is worked up over a recent appearance by Betsy McCaughey, the former lieutenant governor of New York, on the MSNBC program "Morning Meeting." Ms. McCaughey was proffering her theories of how the health care bills pending in Congress "are devastating care for seniors, and the Baucus bill is the deadliest of them all." Mr. Reinhardt takes exception to that -- and to Ms. McCaughey's seemingly contradictory proposal that Medicare eligibility be gradually moved up to age 70. Read all about it.

Have you gotten your kids their seasonal flu shots? Have you gotten yourself one? I called the pediatrician last week -- when it was still September for heaven's sake -- and was told that they were all out. Then I tried my internist, and they said the same thing. I took my son off to Walgreen's where they are offering them at $25 a shot, but only for those over 18 (Alex is 15) and only when a pharmacist happens to be onsite and available, which was not the case when I came by.

The International Ice Hockey Federation finally approves Kirill Kabanov's transfer from Salavat Yulaev Ufa of the K.H.L. to the Moncton Wildcats of the Quebec junior league. The 17-year-old Kabanov, widely touted as the next No. 1 overall pick in the N.H.L. entry draft, left Salavat seven weeks ago to join the L.H.J.M.Q. Wildcats, despite the Russian club's claim that they had a binding contract with Kabanov. But the I.I.H.F. rules on Friday that they could find no validation of such a contract, leaving Kabanov free to play wherever he chooses without penalty or sanction.

Growing up in New York City made me feel a bit disconnected from the other parts of the country, but when I sat in front of the television on some Saturdays, I would feel as if I were communing with the rest of America. This is one of those Saturdays. The afternoon starts off in Oxford, Miss., when the Crimson Tide (one of the most storied programs in the nation) travels to play a Mississippi team that is hoping to live up to its preseason hype. Meanwhile, in Columbus, Ohio, a classic Big Ten battle will feature the conference's best rushing offense (Wisconsin) against its best rushing defense (Ohio State). Huge linemen going after one another in the trenches for your enjoyment? Yes, please. Out west, Oregon will try to keep rising in the rankings when the Ducks travel to Los Angeles. Then the real magic happens. The game of the year: No. 1 Florida at No. 4 L.S.U. in Death Valley on Saturday night. One of the most electric atmospheres in college football. The last two national title winners. Will Tebow play? John Brantley?! (Oh, and during the commercial breaks of L.S.U.-Florida, be sure to check in on Michigan at Iowa.) College football never fails to surprise. This weekend will be no different. God Bless America.

The only play anyone will remember from Game 2 of this year's Dodgers-Cardinals division series was Matt Holliday's gut-wrenching error that turned a certain St. Louis victory into an eventual defeat. Cruising into shallow left to snare a routine soft fly ball by James Loney that would have been the contest's final out, Holliday, the Cardinals' prized midseason acquisition, let the ball bounce off his body onto the grass and promptly followed suit, falling headfirst in pursuit. The rest, it seemed, was preordained: the baseball gods do not forgive such miscues.

The pair was speaking in Beijing to representatives from 170 media outlets from 80 countries at a meeting to investigate whether the Web is a platform full of promise or, perhaps, a gallows for professionally gathered content. The rhetoric is rather breathtaking, although getting content back into a (paid) bottle is going to be an onerous task. Google is obviously the gigantic aggregating elephant in the room, but when Eric Schmidt was asked about The A.P. on Wednesday in a meeting with reporters, he pointed out that Google already had an agreement with the wire service, albeit one that expired this year, and said that as a matter of practice, the company did not discuss renewal arrangements.But speaking with Danny Sullivan of Search Engine Land last week in a far-ranging discussion about the production and dissemination of content, Mr. Schmidt said that Google was often indicted for offenses that really derived from the very existence of the Web.

When Brian Wilson, below, sang that he “just wasn’t made for these times,” apparently he wasn’t just being wistful. For his next album, Mr. Wilson, the former front man of the Beach Boys, will be collaborating with a pop star who preceded him by a generation or three: George Gershwin. As part of a two-album deal with Walt Disney Records, Mr. Wilson will create new pieces of music based on unfinished Gershwin works, the record label said Thursday. The new compositions, which Disney said Mr. Wilson would “Brian-ize with his trademark vocal stacks and unique arrangements,” are to appear on an album that will also include Mr. Wilson’s covers of other classic songs by George and Ira Gershwin. The estates of both Gershwin siblings have given their approval for the project, which a representative for Mr. Wilson said he would begin recording with his band on Oct. 18 and finish after Thanksgiving. In a statement, Mr. Wilson called the album “the most spiritual project I’ve ever worked on.”.

Get your subterranean church organs tuned and make sure your chandeliers are firmly affixed to the ceiling: the Phantom is extending his reach. On Thursday, Andrew Lloyd Webber disclosed the initial details of “Love Never Dies,” his long-in-the-works sequel to “The Phantom of the Opera.” As Phantophiles already know, the musical moves the story from a Paris opera house to the Coney Island boardwalk, where the Phantom and his love, Christine, once again cross paths (presumably not in line for the Cyclone). In a release, press representatives for “Love Never Dies” said that its world premiere would take place at the Adelphi Theater in London on March 9. Its Broadway opening is scheduled for Nov. 11, 2010, at a theater to be determined, followed by an Australian run in 2011. The London production is to star Ramin Karimloo (of London’s “Phantom” and “Les Misérables”) as the Phantom and Sierra Boggess (of Broadway’s “Little Mermaid”) as Christine. It will be directed by Jack O’Brien (“Hairspray,” “The Coast of Utopia”). Above from left, Mr. Lloyd Webber, Ms. Boggess and Mr. Karimloo.
The fall television season has reached an improbable moment: the number of new series that have been picked up for a full year exceeds the number that have been canceled.

The role of Lina in the Metropolitan Opera’s production of Verdi’s “Stiffelio” will be shared between the American sopranos Sondra Radvanovsky and Julianna Di Giacomo. They replace Angela Marambio, the Chilean soprano, who has withdrawn, the Met said in a release. Ms. Radvanovsky will sing the performances on Jan. 11 and 14 and the matinee of Jan. 30; Ms. Di Giacomo will sing the role on Jan. 19, 23 and 26. Both will be performing the role for the first time at the Met. Ms. Radvanovsky previously sang Lina at London’s Royal Opera Covent Garden in 2007 and has performed in Verdi operas including “Il Trovatore” at the Met. Ms. Di Giacomo made her Met debut as Clotilde in “Norma” in 2007 and made her La Scala debut this past season as Lucrezia in Verdi’s “I Due Foscari.” The Met’s performances of “Stiffelio” will be conducted by Plácido Domingo.

The rapper Adam Yauch, below, said that he was “feeling healthy, strong and hopeful” that he had beaten cancer after returning from a recent trip to India, but a coming album by his band, the Beastie Boys, remains without a release date. Mr. Yauch, better known by his stage name, MCA, made his announcement in an e-mail message sent to fans and also posted on the band’s Web site. He announced in July that he had received a diagnosis of cancer, and underwent surgery and began radiation treatment. In a statement Wednesday, publicists for the Beastie Boys said that Mr. Yauch “underwent surgery to remove a cancerous tumor in his left parotid (salivary) gland” that was found “in a location that will not affect Yauch’s vocal chords.” The statement said that a new release date for the Beastie Boys album “Hot Sauce Committee Part 1” had not been determined. The album had originally been planned for Sept. 15 but was postponed after Mr. Yauch disclosed the diagnosis.

SACKLER--Muriel Lazarus, (1917-2009), died peacefully surrounded by her family on October 7, 2009. Born in Glasgow, Scotland to Fanny and David Lazarus. Graduate of Brooklyn College, B.A. 1939; M.S.c from M.I.T. 1945. Research scientist at the frontier of biochemical human genetics; Ph.D. from Columbia University, 1963 and retired faculty member of Cornell University Medical College. A passionate learner, reader, and practicing psychoanalyst; founding member of the Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies N.Y.C.; dedicated to her patients over the past 30 years. Loving companion of the late Oscar Schachter. Devoted mother of Ilene Sackler Lefcourt, Kathe A. Sackler, M.D., and the late Robert Mortimer Sackler. Loving mother-in-law of Susan Shack Sackler, M.D. Devoted grandmother of Jeffrey, Karen, Benjamin and Julia; grandmother-in-law of Heather and Ben; and great-grandmother of Kaia and Isaac.

Chekhov's ''Seagull'' is given a splash of cool absurdism in the National Asian American Theater Company's new version, and it's bracing. What can sometimes be presented as a glum panorama of bourgeois delusion and tragedy (Chekhov insisted, as this troupe does, that the play is a comedy) is here a lively production punctuated by touches of vaudeville and the grotesque. Of course Chekhov's densely populated classic has much to say about literature, fame and the vanities of show business, not to mention crossed romantic intentions among human beings. But sometimes the play's layers of frustration, betrayal and disillusionment could benefit from fresh air, and at the Theater for the New City they get it.
XU ZHEN Lonely Miracle: Middle East Contemporary Art Exhibition

His passing leaves sadness but his legacy will live for years to come. With love: Nancy, Robert, Rene and the entire Repertorio family. A celebration of his life will take place at Repertorio Espanol, 138 E. 27th St., on Friday, October 9 from 2pm-10pm.

ZALDIVAR--Gilberto, was born in March 28, 1934 and passed on Tuesday, October 6, 2009. His outstanding career as a theater producer spanned 37 years from the time he co-founded Repertorio Espanol in 1968. With his passing, we've lost a passionate impresario and a wonderful friend. Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Thursday that House Democrats were considering a ''windfall profits tax'' on insurance companies to help pay for legislation that would provide coverage to most of the uninsured. The idea, she said, is to capture some of the profits that insurance companies might reap if the government required nearly everyone to have insurance and subsidized premiums for millions of low- and middle-income people.

SHIENTAG--Florence Perlow. The New York Women's Bar Association mourns the passing of Hon. Florence Perlow Shientag, a founder (1934), Past President (1941-42) and mentor. Judge Shientag became the first female Assistant US Attorney in the Southern District of NY. She was Law Aide to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Law Secretary to Mayor Fiorello LaGuardia, and Justice of the Domestic Relations Court. Thereafter Judge Shientag maintained a private law practice. We honor the life and legacy of this beloved pioneer. Donna M. Praiss, President, NYWBA

ROSENBLUM--Elliott, passed away after a protracted battle with lung cancer on August 31, 2009 at his home in Hawaii. Beloved partner of 31 years to Mark Nesselson, M.D. Beloved father of children Ella and Cole. Beloved brother of David (Paula) and uncle of Mitchell and Andrew Rosenblum. Distinguished career as an architect. Graduated from Rhode Island School of Design. Worked under Edward Durell Stone early in his career. Worked as an architectural consultant for the West Side Development Corporation and the West Side Federation for Senior Housing, establishing that affordable housing can be beautiful. His rich career continued in the realm of retail, designing stores for Barneys New York, Hugo Boss, Calvin Klein, Coach, Gear and Saks Fifth Avenue. Subsequently he found his niche doing renovation and new construction of residences in New York City, Westchester, The Hamptons, Upstate New York, Connecticut, Nantucket, Maine and Hawaii. A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, October 11 at 2pm at the Tillman/U.N. Chapel at 44th Street and First Avenue. Donations to medinsight.org in his memory are appreciated and should be designated "For 3BP cancer research."

'RISK!' Now that we're fully ensconced in the age of the overshare, we might as well get some (intentional) laughs out of it. 'RISK!' Now that we're fully ensconced in the age of the overshare, we might as well get some (intentional) laughs out of it. HEEKIN--James Robson Jr.,82, of 41 Oblong Rd., Williamstown, MA died Monday, October 5, 2009 at North Adams Regional Hospital. He was born in Cincinnati, OH on October 30, 1926, son of James and Alice (Peters) Heekin. He attended Walnut Hills High School and later Williams College graduating in 1948. He served in the U.S. Army Air Corps during World War II. He is survived by his loving wife of 61 years, Jane Jessup Heekin and their four children, James R. Heekin III of Stamford, CT, Margaret Kensinger of State College, PA, Elizabeth Bartels of Williamstown, MA and Timothy Heekin of Manchester, VT. He is also survived by eight grandchildren, two great-grandchildren and his Irish Setter, Paddy. He enjoyed a most distinguished career in the advertising profession serving as president of Ogilvy and Mather in New York where he worked with the legendary ad man, David Ogilvy. He also served as president of Doyle Dane Bernbach Advertising, and later as a partner in his own firm, Canter, Achenbaum, Heekin. In 1985 he and his wife, Jannie, returned to live in Williamstown full time. He launched James Heekin Associates, Inc., a marketing firm serving many Berkshire businesses, including The Orchards, City Savings Bank, Sweetwood, Jiminy Peak and the North Adams Regional Hospital. He also became very involved in developing a leadership curriculum program at Williams College. He was a Director of the Roper Public Opinion Research Center, a member of the South Williamstown Association Board and of the St. Patrick's Parish Council. Funeral Mass will take place Saturday, October 10, 2009 at 10:30am at St. Patrick's Church, Williamstown, MA.

PENN--Irving. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of Irving Penn, whose unbroken stream of creative invention spanned seven decades and established an indelible standard of clarity, grace, wit, and elegance. The Museum has collected and exhibited his photographs since 1943, and in 1984 was proud to present the magisterial retrospective organized by his friend John Szarkowski, then head of the department of photography. We shall forever miss this remarkable man, who made discipline and kindness seem one and the same. We extend our deepest sympathies to his son Tom and his family. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

If a 20 percent discount on your health insurance premium is good, then a 30 percent discount must be better, right? But what if the bigger discount is tied to health goals you might not be able to meet? Some patient advocacy groups are wary of provisions in Congressional health care legislation that would let employers and insurers offer premium discounts of as much as 50 percent to employees in workplace ''wellness'' programs who meet specific health targets, like keeping their weight, cholesterol and blood pressure within healthy ranges.
EATING OUT 3 All You Can Eat

When a sensitive Iranian writer, Mahida (Roxanna Hope), meets a sweetly amiable American painter, Thomas (a charming James Wallert), on a pier in a small town in the United States, the conversation quickly turns metaphorical. ''I think about borders all the time,'' she says, inspired by a bench dividing the attractive couple. ''What is the boundary, I wonder, between what lasts and what does not?'' Depending on your tolerance for soulful ruminations, the musings of Russell Davis's ''Mahida's Extra Key to Heaven'' will make you scratch either your chin or your head. In a seamless staging by Will Pomerantz at the Peter Norton Space that papers over some of the script's problems, this play aims for a vague, enigmatic tone that is the enemy of specificity. It takes place in an unnamed town in the ''recent past'' and features sincere small talk like ''I'm just thinking about destiny.''

With the Senate Finance Committee on track to approve its health care legislation on Tuesday, Democratic leaders are turning to the tricky task of melding that bill with an alternate measure approved by the health committee in July. There are some big differences, both in policy and cost.

When the calendar turns to October, baseball strategy changes in significant ways. While the previous six months are a grueling 162-game marathon, in which a team's depth and a manager's ability to keep his players rested are key, the postseason is a win-or-go-home sprint. For position players, this distinction is minimal; for pitchers, it is crucial. Because the fifth starter drops out of the rotation and the fourth misses his turn whenever possible, conventional wisdom emphasizes the importance of front-line starting pitching in the postseason. Be it Sandy Koufax and Don Drysdale, or Randy Johnson and Curt Schilling, it is widely thought that two bona fide aces can determine a best-of-seven series. As a result, many analysts had dismissed the Dodgers' postseason chances -- even though they finished with the National League's best record -- noting that they lack a one-two punch to match St. Louis's Chris Carpenter and Adam Wainwright or Philadelphia's Cole Hamels and Cliff Lee.

When Abraham Lincoln visited New York in February 1861, Walt Whitman noticed that an ''ominous silence'' greeted the president-elect as he arrived at the Astor House hotel. There was no overt hostility or shouted insult, Whitman wrote, but the ''silence of the crowd was very significant,'' compared with the ''wild, tumultuous hurrahs'' that typically greeted distinguished personages. Harold Holzer, the chief historian for the compellingly informative exhibition ''Lincoln and New York,'' opening on Friday at the New-York Historical Society, explains in the equally incisive companion catalog that when Lincoln attended a performance of Verdi's new opera ''Un Ballo in Maschera'' on that visit, he received a thundering ovation from the audience at the Academy of Music. But he left before the final scene in which the governor of Colonial Boston is assassinated by conspirators. That might have been because of fatigue, Mr. Holzer suggests, but The New-York Herald reported that the police had received notice of a plot to kill Lincoln at the same moment as the onstage murder.

Hard-core disciples of the religion known as the Theater are scarce on the grounds these days. But two evangelists of that embattled creed have set up camp at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater to attest that the faith lives on. Portraying 1920s stage stars in the Manhattan Theater Club's Broadway revival of George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber's ''Royal Family,'' which opened on Thursday night, Jan Maxwell and Rosemary Harris are giving the kinds of performances that turn agnostics into true believers. Ms. Harris is Fanny Cavendish, the matriarch of an acting dynasty, and Ms. Maxwell is her daughter, Julie, the reigning goddess of Broadway. And when, in the play's second act, this mother and daughter start to preach the family gospel to an apostate in their midst, something close to a miracle occurs.

NATIONAL A report in The Caucus column on Thursday about the naming of David Huebner, an openly gay lawyer, as ambassador to New Zealand and Samoa misstated part of the name of the advocacy group for which he is general counsel. It is the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation -- not Against ''Discrimination.''

You can tell that ''Imelda: A New Musical'' is not ''Evita'' because when the actress playing Imelda Marcos greets her public, she raises only one arm. Yes, it's the old story of a poor, young country girl with ambition who marries a future dictator, becomes an idol of the poor and gets carried away with herself. In its East Coast premiere, presented by the Pan Asian Repertory Theater and directed by Tim Dang, the show often seems to be trying too hard. The result is pretty shaky but rich with promise.

The L.P.G.A., beset by losses and management turmoil, has laid off eight employees, including its deputy commissioner, Libba Galloway. The L.P.G.A. has seen its revenues shrink along with its tour schedule this year. The L.P.G.A. is hosting 27 tournaments this year with prize money of about $47 million, down from 34 events in 2008, when players competed for a record $64 million. Next year, the tour is expected to include between 23 and 25 events, potentially the fewest since 1971, when there were 21.

HESS--Scott, an account manager for the Chicago bureau of The New York Times, died suddenly on the morning of Tuesday, October 6, from congestive heart failure. He was 52. Mr. Hess passed away in New York City, the day after the funeral of his mother, Esta Hess. Mr. Hess will be remembered at The Times as a devoted worker, a gentle soul, and as someone whose deep and serious know-how at work was always leavened by his unstoppable wit. His infectious sense of humor came as welcome relief to clients and colleagues alike; there seemed no situation too formal for it. Colleagues remember Scott's upbeat personality, his always optimistic outlook, and his love for his family. He began his career at The Times in telesales in 1982, though his ties to the newspaper ran still deeper. His father, William Hess, was an avid supporter of The Times, and the younger Mr. Hess recalled his father subscribing to newspaper even through years when it strained the family's then-meager budget. Mr. Hess was born on April 16, 1957, and grew up in the Bronx. He attended the Bronx High School of Math and Science and Queens Community College in New York, graduating with an accounting degree, cum laude, in 1978. While working for B. Altman & Co., he met his wife, Jean LaMonica. They married on June 28, 1981. At The Times, Mr. Hess rose through the ranks of telesales into advertising sales. He left the newspaper briefly to work in a start-up programming company, then returned to The Times in 1986, the same year that he was asked to move to Chicago, and committed to it immediately, though he had never even visited the city. He came to have a great affinity for Chicago, and spent much of his career there. He spent lunch breaks taking in architectural tours, riding the water taxi along the Chicago River, and visiting the city's endless parks and beaches. It was in Chicago that Mr. Hess established himself as one of the company's premier account managers. His knowledge, in particular, of the financial sector was second to none. He was legendary among co-workers for his ability to put together financial presentations that were effective, concise and, all the while, entertaining. In 2005, he was awarded The New York Times Salesman of the Year. At heart, Mr. Hess was a family man. His successes at work were rarely discussed at home, though at work, he always spoke of his family. He is survived by his two sons, or, as he referred to them, his two "hobbies," Justin and Taylor, his wife, Jean, and his brother, Milo. In addition to being a proud parent, Mr. Hess was a zealous dog lover. He was known around his neighborhood, in Clarendon Hills, Ill, for his ability to identify residents by their dog's names and breeds. His perspectives and observations could be childlike at times, a reflection of his gentle nature. He often scolded his children for crushing kitchen ants with too much force, and he took pleasure in open displays of affection for his family - especially displays involving his dog, Rocco - at what some might have seen as inappropriate moments. His warm nature, love for animals, and his genuine curiosity about life and living will be remembered by all whose lives he touched. A Memorial Mass will be held at Notre Dame Church in Clarendon Hills, Ill, at 10am on Monday, October 12.

PENN--Irving. The Lauder family and Clinique send their heartfelt condolences on the passing of Irving Penn. Irving Penn was an iconic photographer who had tremendous and inspirational impact on the beauty industry. He revolutionized the advertising for Clinique when he began photographing for the brand in 1974. The beautifully stark, pristine image of a clear glass holding a large toothbrush under the headline "Twice A Day" was first placed in the New York Times and remains one of the most recognized images in Clinique's history. Mrs. Estee Lauder described Irving Penn's work as "The Perfect Picture." His Clinique photography eventually went on display at the Modern Museum of Art in New York City. Irving Penn was a treasure and a trailblazer. The Lauder family and Clinique give their condolences to his family and many friends. Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Ronald Lauder, Chairman, Clinique Laboratories William P. Lauder, Executive Chairman Fabrizio Freda, President and CEO Lynne Greene, Global Brand President, Clinique, Origins, Ojon

SAN FRANCISCO — Litquake, the warmly raucous festival that celebrates this city’s formidable book-loving scene, is 10 years old this year, and it was inaugurated Friday night at “Black, White and Read,” a masked ball upstairs at the Herbst Theater. Well, actually, it was only semi-masked. Some people went all out and dressed to recall Truman Capote’s Black and White Ball at the Plaza Hotel in New York in 1966. Others just pretended, carrying cardboard face masks of Allen Ginsberg, Gertrude Stein, Lawrence Ferlinghetti, Amy Tan or other recognizable literary locals. It was funny and cute.

A capsule summary on Friday for an article about new findings on the earliest ancestry of birds described incorrectly the scientific study on which the article was based. The study, of a fossil of Archaeopteryx, which had generally been accepted as the earliest known bird, found that Archaeopteryx did not have one characteristic of modern birds, a fast growth rate. The study did not challenge the idea that Archaeopteryx had other characteristics of birds.

The Metropolitan Opera’s new and loudly booed production of the Puccini staple “Tosca,” which opened the company’s season, dominated a panel discussion at the New York Public Library on Thursday night that featured the Met’s general manager, Peter Gelb, and three directors of productions being presented this season: Luc Bondy, Patrice Chéreau and Bartlett Sher. Mr. Bondy said he was surprised by the reaction to “Tosca,” which he directed. (A scene from that production, with George Gagnidze and Karita Mattila in the foreground, is above.) “I was scandalized that they were so scandalized,” Mr. Bondy said of the audience. “I didn’t know that ‘Tosca’ was like the Bible in New York,” he said at another point, addressing complaints that he had violated the composer’s intentions. Mr. Gelb, who said he was trying to renew the Met’s dramatic offerings, said the instructions in the libretto should not be treated like a “religious manuscript.”.

The actress Lynn Redgrave, below, who is scheduled to begin preview performances of her play “Nightingale” at Manhattan Theater Club on Thursday, will still perform the show, with script in hand, despite receiving a diagnosis of a condition that required immediate treatment. Representatives for Ms. Redgrave and the show declined to specify the condition. In a statement, the show’s publicists said Ms. Redgrave “was diagnosed this week with a medical condition that requires immediate treatment at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.” The statement added, “Side effects of the treatment necessitate that Ms. Redgrave rely on her script for the entire run of the play at M.T.C.” A spokesman for Ms. Redgrave, who is a breast cancer survivor, said she had not had a recurrence of cancer. The one-woman play, about Ms. Redgrave’s maternal grandmother, opens on Nov. 3 and runs through Dec. 13.

France said on Friday that it would return relics to Egypt that were apparently stolen and sold to the Louvre, and Egypt said it would restore its ties to the museum as soon as that restitution occurs, Agence France-Presse reported. On Wednesday, Egypt suspended its cooperation with the Louvre, saying that five fresco fragments in its collection were stolen from the Valley of the Kings at Luxor, and that the museum was not honoring a longstanding agreement to return any smuggled or stolen Egyptian artifacts. The French government had said the Louvre acted in good faith when it bought the relics in 2000 and 2003, but members of a commission that oversees the nation’s museums voted unanimously to return them, saying that significant doubts about their origins had been raised. In November archaeologists rediscovered the tomb from which the relics seem to have come from, raising the question of whether they had been taken legally from Egypt.

The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts plans to create an arts education plan for students from kindergarten through eighth grade, starting in Sacramento, the center announced on Friday. After a six-month evaluation of existing arts education resources, the Kennedy Center, along with Sacramento’s school system and local arts organizations, will design a plan for arts education specific to the area. The program, called Any Given Child, aims to bring “access, balance and equity” to arts education, using an affordable model. The Kennedy Center is accepting applications from other school systems around the country.

Tony Roberts, below with Jan Maxwell, returned to the Manhattan Theater Club production of “The Royal Family” on Thursday night, four days after a matinee preview performance of the show was canceled when he fell ill during the first act. Mr. Roberts is expected to remain with the show until its run ends on Nov. 29, a press representative said on Friday. Mr. Roberts, 69, drew applause from the audience on his first stage entrance on Thursday, the production’s opening night. Lynne Meadow, the artistic director of Manhattan Theater Club, said in an interview on Tuesday that Mr. Roberts’s illness, described by his daughter as a minor seizure, had come as a surprise. “When we cast Tony we were assured he was in good shape, and he appeared to us in very good shape,” Ms. Meadow said. She added, “It was pretty amazing to have him back so quickly.”.

In a case involving an 87-year-old man convicted of racketeering, a federal judge in Manhattan rejected a plea for leniency last year, giving the man a five-year sentence. The judge in this case had a special perspective: He was 84 himself. But in another case this spring, an 85-year-old man who admitted providing sensitive military information to Israel was spared prison by a judge, who cited the man's advanced age and said sending him to prison would ''serve no purpose.''

HEEKIN--James Robson Jr.,82, of 41 Oblong Rd., Williamstown, MA died Monday, October 5, 2009 at North Adams Regional Hospital. He was born in Cincinnati, OH on October 30, 1926, son of James and Alice (Peters) Heekin. He attended Walnut Hills High School and later Williams College graduating in 1948. He served in the U.S. Army Air Corps during World War II. He is survived by his loving wife of 61 years, Jane Jessup Heekin and their four children, James R. Heekin III of Stamford, CT, Margaret Kensinger of State College, PA, Elizabeth Bartels of Williamstown, MA and Timothy Heekin of Manchester, VT. He is also survived by eight grandchildren, two great-grandchildren and his Irish Setter, Paddy. He enjoyed a most distinguished career in the advertising profession serving as president of Ogilvy and Mather in New York where he worked with the legendary ad man, David Ogilvy. He also served as president of Doyle Dane Bernbach Advertising, and later as a partner in his own firm, Canter, Achenbaum, Heekin. In 1985 he and his wife, Jannie, returned to live in Williamstown full time. He launched James Heekin Associates, Inc., a marketing firm serving many Berkshire businesses, including The Orchards, City Savings Bank, Sweetwood, Jiminy Peak and the North Adams Regional Hospital. He also became very involved in developing a leadership curriculum program at Williams College. He was a Director of the Roper Public Opinion Research Center, a member of the South Williamstown Association Board and of the St. Patrick's Parish Council. Funeral Mass will take place Saturday, October 10, 2009 at 10:30am at St. Patrick's Church, Williamstown, MA.

John A Herrmann, President Paul Levine, Executive VP & CEO Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

Public health departments across the country have had to cancel vaccination clinics. Doctors have had to turn away patients. And consumers have had to make extra efforts to get immunized.

(13) THE THIS OLD HOUSE HOUR For its 30th-anniversary season, ''This Old House,'' which recently won its 17th Emmy, for outstanding lifestyle program, returns to its home base, Boston, to undertake two projects. The first is the modest renovation of a 1915 Dutch colonial, above, in the suburb of Newton Centre, whose owners, Bill and Gillian Pierce, held off on sprucing up the home, purchased in 2004, until they could save some money. The second, to be shown later this season, is a foreclosed and vacant Second Empire building, from about the 1870s, in urban Roxbury, which will be transformed into two separate units of affordable homes. In this premiere episode Kevin O'Connor, the show's host; the general contractor Tom Silva; and the master carpenter Norm Abram meet with Paul Rovinelli, the architect for the Newton Centre project, and begin work -- which can be viewed round the clock at thisoldhouse.com/webcams. In a new season of ''Ask This Old House,'' at 7:30, the crew helps homeowners tackle common projects, starting with a backyard fire pit and a stovetop hood. 10:30 A.M. Two people died and at least 16 more were hospitalized after they fell ill while sitting in a sweat lodge at a New Age retreat center in Arizona, the authorities said Friday. The dead and injured were part of a group of about 48 people who were taking part in a ceremony on Thursday evening inside a sweat lodge resembling a large sauna at the Angel Valley Retreat Center in Sedona, the red-rocks-clustered resort town about 115 miles north of Phoenix. Officials with the Verde Valley fire department said Friday that the event had been going on for about two hours when several people fell sick, complaining of feeling light-headed.

President Vaclav Klaus insisted Friday that the Czech Republic needed a special exemption to the European Union's Lisbon Treaty to protect the country from a potential flood of postwar property claims. Mr. Klaus said he wanted to opt out of the treaty's Charter of Fundamental Rights, which includes property rights. He said he feared that the charter could be used as a legal basis for claims related to the expulsion of three million Germans from Czechoslovakia after World War II. His objection threatens to unhinge the treaty's ratification process. If the Polish president, Lech Kaczynski, signs the treaty on Saturday, as expected, Mr. Klaus will be the last holdout on the document.

Patience is not just a virtue for Franklin E. Kameny. It is the essence of his being. After he was fired from his job as an astronomer at the Army Map Service in 1957 on suspicion of being gay, he fought the federal government to end its ban on gay employees in the civil service. It was 18 more years before the government reversed that policy.

The first doses of vaccine for the H1N1 2009 influenza, commonly called swine flu, began arriving at hospitals and doctors' offices this week. But fear and confusion about the vaccine are spreading almost as quickly as the virus itself. The earliest vaccine shipments came in the form of a nasal spray, which is now a priority for health care workers and children. The number of children who have died of the new virus climbed rapidly to 76 this week, already nearing the 88 child deaths for the entire 2007-8 flu season. A flu shot form of the vaccine is expected next week.

President Obama is given to big events at big moments, replete with stirring speeches, lofty backdrops and stadium-size crowds. But when Mr. Obama walked into the Rose Garden on Friday morning, having just been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize -- an honor that would normally be a moment of high celebration, if not the culmination of a life's work -- he was humble and self-deprecatory, popping a hole in the balloon of his own accomplishment. He talked about being congratulated by his daughter Malia, who proceeded to remind him that it was the family dog's birthday, and he suggested that he was undeserving of the award.

Experts generally agree on the need to change how doctors and hospitals are paid in this country. Currently, most are reimbursed for every service they provide. But this so-called fee-for-service payment system does do little to encourage cost control or -- because, typically, no single health care provider is in charge -- to coordinate patient care effectively. Now a new approach that aims to do a better job of ''aligning incentives,'' as the wonks like to say, has grabbed the attention of policy experts and legislators. They talk about the ''accountable care organization,'' an approach in which doctors and hospitals agree to take joint responsibility for helping patients get well, or keeping them healthy in the first place, and to share in any financial benefits that result.

The choice of Barack Obama on Friday as the recipient of the 2009 Nobel Peace Prize, less than nine months into his eventful presidency, was an unexpected honor that elicited praise and puzzlement around the globe. Normally the prize has been presented, even controversially, for accomplishment. This prize, to a 48-year-old freshman president, for ''extraordinary efforts to strengthen international diplomacy and cooperation between peoples,'' seemed a kind of prayer and encouragement by the Nobel committee for future endeavor and more consensual American leadership.

Following are excerpts from comments by people from around the world on Friday on the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize to President Obama, gathered by correspondents for The New York Times:

The five-member Norwegian Nobel committee spent seven months winnowing the dossiers on dissident monks, human rights advocates, field surgeons and other nominees -- 205 names in all, most of them obscure -- before deciding to give the Nobel Peace Prize to perhaps the most famous man on the planet, Barack Obama. While in recent decades the selection process has produced many winners better known for their suffering or their environmental zeal than for peacemaking, the panel's new chairman, Thorbjorn Jagland, said that members this year took a more practical approach in their unanimous vote for President Obama.

The Giants received a dose of good injury news Friday, when quarterback Eli Manning practiced for the first time this week. With his right heel heavily taped, Manning took about half the snaps and had no trouble dropping back or launching deep passes, in addition to running and stretching with the team. He is listed as questionable for Sunday's game against the Oakland Raiders, but Coach Tom Coughlin said he was ''absolutely'' encouraged by what he saw from Manning, who injured the plantar fascia during last Sunday's victory against the Chiefs.

Tim DeChristopher became convinced last year that global warming's potential effects were so urgent and dire that direct action was needed. The niceties of debate and environmental lobbying were not getting the job done, he said. So in December Mr. DeChristopher went to a federal auction of oil and gas leases -- offered in the Bush administration's closing days and even then the subject of protests and lawsuits -- and bid on contracts that he had neither the money nor intent to actually fulfill.

The Philadelphia Phillies have picked Pedro Martinez to start Game 3 of their National League division series against the Colorado Rockies. Now the only question is whether the game, in Denver, will be played as scheduled. The first pitch is set for 7:37 p.m. Mountain time, and the setting is expected to be wintry. The Penn State Department of Meteorology said the temperature would dip into the upper 20s during the game, with a breeze of 10 to 15 miles per hour adding an unwelcome wind-chill factor. Snow flurries are also expected.

Richard Zabel, who took over on Monday as head of the criminal division for the federal prosecutor's office in New York, will not play any role in its continuing investigation of Bernard L. Madoff's Ponzi scheme. His recusal was confirmed without comment on Friday by a spokesman for the United States Attorney's Office in Manhattan. Mr. Zabel's father, William D. Zabel, is a lawyer for Jeffry M. Picower, one of the largest investors in the Ponzi scheme and a defendant in a civil lawsuit filed by the Madoff bankruptcy trustee. That suit seeks to recover $6.7 billion the Picower family withdrew from its Madoff accounts. No criminal allegations have been made against the Picowers, but several criminal cases related to the Madoff fraud are pending and the investigation continues. Routinely, any staff member with a close relative involved in an investigation in any way -- as a witness, a victim, a suspect or a defense lawyer -- will be excused from any role in the case.

FIGGE--John Kahl, of Sea Island, GA, formerly of Davenport, IA and Washington, DC on October 9, 2009. Born in Davenport, IA on January 22, 1938 to Elizabeth (Kahl) and V.O. Figge. Beloved husband for 49 years of Patricia Anne (Joyce) Figge, devoted father of Mary Power (John), Wellesley, MA, Patricia Glowacki, (Tony), Chevy Chase, MD, Elizabeth Lemek (Brian), Chevy Chase, MD, Ann Nawn (Jim), Princeton, NJ, John O. Figge (Lisa), Bryn Mawr, PA, and Michael J. Figge (Jennifer), Princeton, NJ. Also survived by 20 adoring grandchildren, two sisters; Ann Brawley, Colorado Springs, CO, Marie Wise, Houston, TX, two brothers; James K. Figge, Sun Valley, ID, Thomas K. Figge, Aspen, CO and Santa Barbara, CA, and 40 nieces and nephews. He graduated from Georgetown Preparatory School in 1955 and The College of the Holy Cross in 1959. He holds degrees from the Graduate School of Banking of the University of Wisconsin, as well as an honorary doctorate degree from Saint Ambrose University, Davenport, IA. He began his career at Davenport Bank and Trust Company in 1960. He became a member of the Board of Directors in 1969, was made President of the Bank in 1980, and was CEO at the time of the sale of the bank to Norwest Corp. in 1990. He was active in community banking in eastern Iowa and western Illinois for many years. After retiring in 1990, he focused his time on several successful entrepreneurial ventures including Panera Bread franchises in New Jersey and Maryland, several real estate investments in the Boston area, and Wealthengine, a marketing services firm in Bethesda, MD. His dedication to faith and family was lived through his service to many charitable organizations. At the time of his death he served as a trustee of the College of the Holy Cross, Worcester, MA, Catholic Charities Foundation, Washington, DC, Woodstock Theological Center at Georgetown University, Washington, DC, and Loyola Retreat House, Faulkner, MD. He was a member of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta. He was a past board member of Georgetown Preparatory School, Bethesda, MD, and St. Ambrose University, Davenport, IA, as well as a member of the board of fellows for the University of Iowa's religion department. He was also a board member of the Foundation for K-12 Catholic Schools, Davenport, IA, and the Gregorian University Foundation, New York, NY. He served as President of the Iowa-Illinois Council of Boy Scouts in the early 70s and was a member of the Rotary Club of Davenport, IA. He made many good friends through his lifelong love of the game of golf, and will be missed at his favorite clubs including Ocean Forest Club, Sea Island, GA, and Burning Tree Club, Bethesda, MD. The family will receive visitors at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY on Tuesday, October 13 at 2-4:30pm followed by Mass of Christian Burial at 5pm, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Ave., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of John K. Figge to The College of the Holy Cross, Worcester, MA, and the Catholic Charities Foundation, Washington, DC.

The sellout crowd at Jobing.com Arena for Phoenix's home opener -- where ticket prices were reduced to just $25 or $15 to draw fans -- is kept quiet in Saturday night's 2-0 loss to Columbus. Among the spectators watching the financially troubled Coyotes: Daryl Jones, chief operating officer of Ice Edge Holdings, a group that dropped its bid for the team at the bankruptcy court-imposed deadline last summer. Jones says that Ice Edge is still interested in buying the club. Under its initial $150 million bid, it would have kept the team in Glendale, Ariz., while moving some games to Saskatoon.

At our sib-blog Prescriptions, Katharine Q. Seelye has learned that former Senator Bob Dole is none too pleased with the Democrats' TV ad featuring him and other Republicans, who have endorsed some form of overhauling health care. A spokesman for Mr. Dole said that he found it misleading, and has demanded that the commercial not be broadcast. Read the full post.

BERLIN | Berlin is a cyclist's town. Of the city's approximately 3.4 million residents, at least 2.85 million own bicycles, according to a survey released by the Berlin-Brandenburg Office of Statistics in June. The study showed that 76 percent of all Berlin households have at least one bicycle on hand -- and most have at least two.

East of Lexington Avenue and north toward Spanish Harlem, newer condos and more dressed-down restaurants in areas like Yorkville have made the Upper East Side more widely affordable.
The Vows column last Sunday, about the marriage of Kathleen Marshall and Scott Landis, misspelled the breed of dog owned by the bride. It is a wheaten terrier, not Wheaton.
Two weeks after sustaining a concussion, Tim Tebow — and Florida’s swarming defense — silenced L.S.U.

The “Sunday Routine” feature last Sunday, about Padma Lakshmi, the host of “Top Chef,” referred incorrectly to Ganesh, the Hindu deity whom Ms. Lakshmi honors during a monthly visit to the Ganesh Temple in Flushing, Queens. Ganesh is a god, not a goddess.

An article last Sunday about the possibility that the Cayman Islands, a tax haven, may have to impose taxes to close a budget gap misstated the date that the leader of the Cayman government, W. McKeeva Bush, was holed up in a hotel conference room for a meeting with business leaders. It was on Sept. 24, not “late last week” (the week of Sept. 27).
A city bus swerved to avoid a car that stopped suddenly, struck parked cars and caused a pileup in an intersection in Crown Heights.

An article last Sunday about extrajudicial killings by the police in India overstated what is known about the cause of a train fire in 2002 that killed Hindu pilgrims in the Indian state of Gujarat, which led to deadly anti-Muslim riots there and may have contributed to what rights activists called an atmosphere in which extrajudicial police killings of Muslim suspects were encouraged. While the Gujarat government concluded the fire was a Muslim attack, that finding has been disputed by a central government investigation, which concluded the fire was an accident.
The Devils, who took the lead against the Florida Panthers on a goal by David Clarkson late in the third period, have won the first two games of a three-game trip.

The Streetscapes column last Sunday, responding to a reader’s question about the German Savings Bank, referred incorrectly to a 1913 article in The New York Times that described a meeting of the architect Stanford White and the sculptor Augustus Saint-Gaudens at the bank, which was at 14th Street and Fourth Avenue. The article got the anecdote from Saint-Gaudens’s memoirs — not from a contemporaneous interview with him. (The sculptor died in 1907.).
The United States Presidents Cup team built a 12 ½-9 ½ lead over the International team in an event at which the winner has never come from behind on Sunday.

An article last Sunday about reaction to the arrest of the filmmaker Roman Polanski misstated the response of the Polish prime minister, Donald Tusk. Mr. Tusk has said Mr. Polanski should seek Polish consular help; he has not “heroized the director as a great artist victimized by vengeful bureaucrats in America and toadying Swiss.” The article also misidentified Mr. Polanski’s place of birth. It was Paris, not Poland.

SASSOON--Rahmo, died October 4 at home peacefully in his sleep of natural causes at the age of 97, cared for to the end by Renee, his devoted wife of 58 years. He was born into the ancient Jewish community of Aleppo, Syria in 1912. From 1936-1964, he lived in Japan as an independent businessman, where he founded the Ohel Shelomo synagogue in Kobe, and served as a leader of the Jewish community in Japan during WWII and after. He moved to Manhattan in 1964 with his family where with an open heart and generous hand he continued his life of integrity, honor, wisdom, courage and multilingual wit. He will be deeply missed by his wife and his children, Salomon, Andree and David; their spouses, Evelyn, Jean-Francois and Stephanie; his granddaughters, Nina, Danielle, Lily and Hannah. Much beloved and admired around the globe, he lived a storied life, and with his speech and actions improved the portion of the world he touched.

9 P.M. (Discovery) DISCOVERING ARDI ''Ardipithecus is not a chimp,'' says Tim White, a paleontologist with the Human Evolution Research Center at the University of California, Berkeley. ''It's not a human. It's what we used to be.'' And what we used to be, right, was apparently a woodland creature with a small brain, long arms and short legs that could walk but also climb trees, using its long fingers and big toes to grasp like an ape. This two-hour program reports on the 4.4-million-year-old female partial skeleton -- now the oldest remains from the hominid branch of the primate family -- that was discovered in an Ethiopian desert 17 years ago and has opened a new chapter in human evolution. At 11, Paula Zahn hosts ''Understanding Ardi,'' an hourlong panel with members of the research team, including Mr. White, Yohannes Haile-Selassie, Giday WoldeGabriel and Owen Lovejoy, and Ann Gibbons, a science journalist. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH JOHN KING Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, speaks about the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize to President Obama.

SLOSS--David A.,real estate lawyer with Sterling Equities, died Thursday at his home after battling cancer. David leaves his loving wife Elyse Goldweber; beautiful daughter Gaby, who attends his beloved alma mater Tufts University; sisters Katherine and Virginia; mother Rosalyn; father-in-law Max Goldweber; brother-in-law Terry Sousek; and sister-in-law Ann Goldweber. David, 63, was an avid collector of sports memorabilia and a voracious reader. His warmth, generosity and intellect will be missed greatly by his family and friends. The funeral will be Sunday, 2:30pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street. Donations in David's memory may be sent to Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Avenue, Montgomery, AL 36104.

MUDGE--Lewis Seymour, Jr.,Christian theologian and ecumenist, died September 11, 2009, at his home in Berkeley, California. He was Professor of Theology Emeritus at the San Francisco Theological Seminary and at the Graduate Theological Union, Berkeley. Born on October 22, 1929, he graduated from the Haverford School, Princeton University (B.A., Ph.D.), Princeton Seminary (M.A.), and as a Rhodes Scholar, from Oxford University (M.A.). In a distinguished 50-year career, he taught at Amherst College and McCormick Theological Seminary, authored 12 books, mentored countless students and devoted much time to the ecumenical movement and interfaith dialogue. He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Jean McClure Mudge and three children: Robert Mudge of Washington, DC, William Mudge of Mesa, AZ, Anne Mudge of Oakland, CA and four grandchildren, Alison, Benjamin, Lillian and Isaac. His family and friends will lovingly remember his keen mind, gentle strength and unwavering integrity. Gifts may made to San Francisco Theological Seminary, San Anselmo, CA, and to the Graduate Theological Union, Berkeley. Memorial services will be held at the Nassau Presbyterian Church, 61 Nassau Street, Princeton, NJ at 11am on October 19, and at First Presbyterian Church, 72 Kensington Rd., San Anselmo, CA at 11am on November 28.
