To the Sports Editor: Re ''10 Feet,'' Oct. 2: What the Mets have with Citi Field is an opportunity to create a tremendous home-field advantage as well as a chance to differentiate themselves from that team in the Bronx. The solution: build the team to suit the field.

POWERS--David Alexander, a resident of New York City, died peacefully on Monday, October 5, 2009 at The Lillian Booth Actors Home, Englewood, NJ. Mr. Powers was born on July 14, 1921, in Bristol, TN to the late Gordon Rush Powers and Edwin Reeder Powers. He was predeceased in death by his siblings, Ruth Powers Davis, Edwin R. Powers, Jr., Hugh W. Powers, II and Benjamin R. Powers, Sr. He is survived by his loving sister, Dorothy Powers Wright of Bristol, VA and several cousins, nieces nephews and dear friends. He was cared for in his last illness by his nieces, Dorothy Ruth Wright of Atlanta, GA and Dorothy Davis Napier of Richmond, VA. Mr. Powers graduated from King College in Bristol, TN in 1943 and then served in the U.S. Navy during WWII. He then began a long and distinguished career of 45 years as a press agent and publicist representing many Broadway and Off-Broadway plays and actors including "Annie", "Driving Miss Daisy" and "The Fantastiks". The family wishes to express sincere appreciation to the wonderful staff of The Lillian Booth Actors Home for their devoted care of Mr. Powers. A private memorial service will be held in Bristol, TN. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Actors Fund Homes, 155 W. Hudson Ave., Englewood, NJ 07631.

CLARK--James Cameron Jr.,"Jimmie", died at home in San Francisco, September 25, 2009 at age ninety. The cause of death was cancer. Jimmie Clark was born at home, 7 East 95th Street, New York City in November, 1918 to Teresa (Fabbri) and James C. Clark Sr. of Coats & Clark. He was the grandson of Edith Shepard Fabbri, daughter of Margaret Louisa Vanderbilt. He attended Lycee Francais de New York and Institut Le Rosey in Rolle, Switzerland. He and sister Edith Clark spent summers at the Fabbri cottage in Bar Harbor, Maine. William McCormick "Bill" Blair was a lifelong friend from Maine days. Jimmie Clark was a Harvard graduate, class of 1940. His flatmate at college was Alan J. Lerner, the lyricist. Jimmie served as best man in most of his marriages. Jimmie and Esme O'Brien were lifelong friends as well. Esme's daughter, Rosita Sarnoff, and Jimmie have continued that friendship. Marina Torlonia di Civitella-Cesi was also a woman that Jimmie loved dearly and a close friend of his family. Jimmie was a founding contributor to the Actors' Studio. He was an investor in several New York theater productions and enjoyed regular poker games with Elia Kazan, Kurt Weill, and Lotte Lenya. Jimmie was an able tennis player and a lifelong member of New York's Racquet and Tennis Club. In World War II, Jimmie served as an officer in the U.S. Army Air Corps. Stationed initially in North Africa, he participated in the invasion of Europe by the allied forces. Jimmie lived in Florida and California after the war. He and partner John Mills were real estate investors in Coral Gables and Coconut Grove. A San Franciscan since 1969, Jimmie renewed family ties with niece Daphne Milliken Webbe there. In 1983, Jimmie founded the John Henry Mills Memorial Echocardiography Laboratory at Moffitt Hospital, UCSF. In later years Jimmie contributed to the Save the Redwoods League, donating a grove of redwoods. Jimmie was a lifelong contributor to the arts, and always an avid theater goer. James Cameron Clark Jr. is survived by his partner, Michael Fulton, niece Daphne Milliken Webbe, nephews Christopher, Alexander, and Seth Milliken, and twelve great-nephews and -nieces. He is predeceased by his sister, Edith Clark Milliken, and nephew, Minot K. "Kim" Milliken, Jr. A memorial service for James Cameron Clark Jr. will be held at The Chapel of Grace at Grace Cathedral, 1100 California Street, San Francisco, California on Saturday, October 24, at 4pm. A reception will follow at the residence. Donations may be made to Doctors without Borders, or Save the Redwoods League. Jimmie's ashes will be interred in Bar Harbor, Maine. The funeral home is McAvoy O'Hara Evergreen Mortuary, San Francisco. Inquiries to Michael Fulton, Phone 415-563-9589 or Robert123@aol.com.

CHAST--Elizabeth (nee Buchman), 97, of Ridgefield, CT, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Wife of the late George Chast. She was an inspiring and gifted educator and assistant principal of the Brooklyn Public School system for forty-two years and an accomplished classical pianist. A lifelong member of the Workmen's Circle, B'Nai Brith and Hadassah. Survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Roz Chast and Bill Franzen and their children, Ian and Nina, a brother Samuel Buchman and sister Evelyn Tutunjian. Services were private.

AHH, the bike lane. Another common-sense initiative to turn New York into a little Copenhagen. If only the city bred people as courteous as Danes. If only we had a culture defined by a friendly homogeneity of purpose, a place where content commuters shared the street with neighbors, friends and distant cousins. What we have instead are men and women clad in miracle-fabric athletic gear and yellow ''Live Strong'' bracelets imagining themselves breaking out in the final stretch of the Tour de France. What we have are yoga devotees, blissed out in their iPod bubbles, oblivious to the floating world of traffic signals. What we have are mothers and fathers with a child in the baby seat, talking on the phone, if not texting, while riding south on Avenue of the Americas and swearing at pedestrians in the crosswalk.
Film Mike Hale

The W Barcelona, a sail-shaped glass tower, opened this month in the city's trendy beachside neighborhood of Barceloneta. It is the first hotel in Barcelona with direct access to the beach, and the first major hotel on the Passeig de Joan de Borbó, an up-and-coming waterfront district of luxury retails, theaters and nightclubs. Designed by Ricardo Bofill, the Spanish architect behind Barcelona Airport's new Terminal T1, the 26-story hotel would not look out of place in Dubai. It has 473 rooms (including 70 suites), a Bliss Spa and gym, a restaurant by the Catalan chef Carles Abellan, a rooftop bar, an infinity pool, terraces and cabanas.

LEVINSON--John M.,M.D., of Rockland, DE and Kennedyville, MD died on October 4, 2009 at the age of 82. While he was a practicing physician and very active in the Delaware community for nearly sixty years, he may be remembered best for his pioneering medical and humanitarian work around the globe, most notably for his efforts with wartime refugees and civilians in Southeast Asia, Afghanistan, and Nicaragua. Born in Atlantic City, NJ, he enlisted in the U.S. Navy at the age of 17. He graduated from Lafayette College and Jefferson Medical College. He later served as a colonel in the USAF Reserve during the Cold War. An obstetrician-gynecologist, Dr. Levinson made his first of 26 trips to Southeast Asia in 1963. He taught surgery at the University of Saigon, worked in small jungle hospitals, and wrote the first paper in American medical literature on Medicine in South Vietnam. Dr. Levinson was among the first to assist provincial hospitals, establishing Volunteer Physicians in Vietnam. In 1971, he initiated laparoscopic surgery in Delaware and in 1979 performed the first laparoscopic surgery in China, returning later as an official guest of the Chinese Ministry of Health to establish clinics. As guests of the Kingdom of Bhutan, Dr. Levinson and Aid for International Medicine (AIM), in conjunction with The Explorers Club, retrained their basic health workers. He established the first ob/gyn surgical unit for the Afghanistan freedom fighters in 1986. Dr. Levinson was the founder of AIM, an organization that has provided millions of dollars of aid to the developing world. As its president he accepted the Dept. of State's A.I.D. Commendation from President Richard Nixon in 1971 and the Eisenhower Award, presented by People to People International "for significant contribution to the advancement of international understanding." From 1967 onward, he was a medical consultant to the US Senate, working closely with Senator Edward M. Kennedy as well as testifying six times before Senate committees and the Veterans Administration on health issues. For over 40 years he was a member of the Explorers Club, serving as president from 1985 to 1987. He was also a Rotarian, organizing the first Rotary meeting held at the North Pole. He served on countless boards, most notably The Explorers Club, The Royal Geographical Society of London, the World Affairs Council of Wilmington, Planned Parenthood, Blue Cross and Blue Shield and the State of Delaware's Board of Professional Responsibility. Having served as the ship's surgeon on numerous US and Russian tours to the Arctic and Antarctica, he organized and chaired the world's first conference on polar medicine. In 2007 he became the fourth Delawarean to receive the prestigious Ellis Island Medal of Honor--preceded by Vice President Joe Biden; Louis French, the former director of the FBI; and Ned Carpenter, a distinguished American and legal scholar. The Explorers Club honored him "for outstanding contributions to third world medicine." The Rotary Club of Wilmington gave him their distinguished service award twice and the Medical Society of Delaware gave him a special citation for his charitable service. Because of his international teaching, Jefferson Medical College gave him the singular honor of elevating him to Honorary Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology. Dr. Levinson lectured on five continents and did medical work on all seven. He published 31 medical papers, edited two medical texts and authored a book on shorebird decoys. He enjoyed sailing, the tranquility of the Eastern Shore of Maryland, and carving wildfowl decoys. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Elizabeth Carl Bell; his daughter, Patricia Anne, and her two daughters of Mountain View, CA; his son, John Carl, and his wife, Ellen, and their two sons of Southport, CT; and his son, Mark Jay, and his wife, Frances, and their three daughters of Double Bay, Australia. Private services will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to his current favorite charities: Doctors Without Borders (doctorswithoutborders.com or 1-888-392-0392) or The Chesapeake Bay Foundation (cbf.org or 1-410-268-8816). Services by Chandler Funeral Homes & Crematory. www. chandlerfuneralhome.com

KESSEL--Jerilyn, raised in Ocean Township, NJ, passed away suddenly of natural causes at her home in Los Angeles, CA on Tuesday, October 6th. She was predeceased by her adoring father Arthur D. Kessel and her beloved cocker spaniel, Zoey. She is survived by her forever grieving mother Phyllis Kessel of Ocean Township, her brother Steven L. Kessel of Red Bank, NJ and her best friend Robert Olins. Jerilyn was an honor student both at Ocean Township High School and at the Wharton School of Finance of the University of Pennsylvania, from which she graduated. She began her professional career as Director of Research at Warner Amex Satellite Entertainment, then as Director of Research at Showtime Network. Jerilyn was co-founder and senior analyst at Video Flash at Alexander & Associates, Senior Vice-President of Programming and Marketing of Entertainment Made Convenient (EMC3), and Vice President of Strategic Marketing & Research at American Interactive Media. More recently, she co-founded CENTRIS, a research organization focused on voice, video and data markets. Jerilyn was one of the foremost experts in strategic marketing for the entertainment industry and was a much trusted advisor to the "captains" of her industry. Funeral services will be private and have been entrusted to Bloomfield-Cooper Funeral Chapel in Ocean, NJ.

Fashion as a form of self-expression, although greatly diminished from the peacock pride of the 1970s and '80s, was discernible during New York Fashion Week last month on Park Avenue, left. A few devotees pasted on mustaches to attend a show. One man's statement was a hand-painted suit worthy of Braque and Picasso. For others, the expression was through color, often fluorescent chartreuse. Two men wore sportswear with high heels, a combination not for the corporate world. And for many, it was a pair of sneakers that seemed to have been dipped in a rainbow.

SONNENFELDT--Richard W.,86, passed away on October 9, 2009. Born in Berlin and raised in Gardelegen, Germany, Richard served as the chief interpreter for the American prosecution at the Nuremberg War Trials in 1945, and personally interrogated and delivered the indictments to the top-ranking Nazi criminals. A past senior vice president at RCA and executive vice president at NBC, Richard was one of the principal developers of color TV at RCA and computer technology for NASA, as well as the inventor of the video disc, a precursor to the DVD. Later in his career Richard became the Dean of the Graduate School of Management, Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, and served on numerous boards including Lee Enterprises. A distinguished alumnus of Johns Hopkins University, Richard was a life fellow of the IEEE. He was a member of the Council of Foreign Relations and the American Council on Germany. He was a frequent lecturer at the Harvard Business School and MIT's Sloan School of Management. He was also an avid sailor, crossing the Atlantic three times in his 45 foot sailboat in his 70's. In 2002 he wrote his autobiography, "Witness to Nuremberg," which was published in Germany as well as the U.S. He often lectured about his war time experiences, time spent in a detention center in Australia and surviving a torpedo attack on a troop transport ship. A loving husband, father and grandfather Richard is survived by his second wife Barbara of 29 years, their six children, Ann Goldberg (Sam), Larry Sonnenfeldt (Barbara), Michael Sonnenfeldt (Katja), Elizabeth Holdstein (Michael), Catherine Hausman and Marguerite DeNicola, and 15 grandchildren, Sara, Adam, Gillian, Andrew, Joya, Patricia, Margaret, Forrest, Alex, Peter, Ellen, Henry, Daniel, Isaac and Sophia. He is also survived by his brother Helmut Sonnenfeldt (Marjorie). His first wife Shirley predeceased him. The funeral will be Monday at 10.30am, Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY. Internment will be private. Donations in Richard's memory may be made to the Johns Hopkins School of Engineering or Hospice Care Network of Woodbury, NY.
ALMGREN--David W.,73, of Concord, MA, died on Monday, September 28, 2009. Princeton class of 1957.

MERLIS--Dr. Sidney, 84, died July 7, 2009 at Good Samaritan Hospital, West, NY. He is survived by his loving and treasured family, his wife of 63 years, Annette, Bay Shore, NY, children, Gale and Peter Tauberer, Michael and Sharon Merlis, Plainview, NY, Larry and Ryder Merlis, Baltimore, MD; grandchildren, Jamie and Gregory Aranoff, Evan Merlis, New York, NY and Joshua Tauberer, Philadelphia, PA; brother-in-law and sister-in-law Marshall and Toby Forbes of Milwaukee, WI, nieces and nephews. After receiving his undergraduate and graduate degrees from Creighton University School of Medicine, Omaha, NE, he entered the U.S. Navy Medical Corps, serving at naval hospitals at sea in the Pacific caring for service personnel and their families. After completing his naval service he began his career as a general practitioner in St. Edward, NE. He subsequently left general practice for post graduate training in psychiatry at Central Islip State Hospital, Central Islip, NY, New York Psychiatric Institute, Mt. Sinai Hospital, New York, NY and Montreal Neurological Institute, Montreal, Canada. As Director of Psychiatric Research, Department of mental Health at Central Islip State Hospital, his focus was on the understanding and utilization of new agents for the treatment of the mentally ill. He and his group, working with other research physicians worldwide, were among the first clinicians in the United States to use Thorazine, Tofranil, Librium, Valium and their subsequent derivatives in the treatment of psychoses, depression and neurosis. These drugs dramatically altered the course of the traditional psychiatric care previously given and ushered in a new era of understanding and acceptance of mental illness as a medical problem that is treatable. He authored more than 300 articles and scientific presentations and edited and contributed to books on psychiatric subjects. Dr. Merlis was in practice for more than forty years.

LaNeve, who had a long career at General Motors, serving most recently as vice president for sales in the United States, will leave the company on Oct. 15.

ONE spring day, I was riding to work on the West Street bike path. At the southern end of the path, which runs alongside the West Side Highway, a young man had brought what appeared to be a preschool day care class to practice their soccer skills. They were lined up in twos, cute little kids passing the ball between them, kicking it to the teacher and then running to the end of the line. The children filled both lanes of the bike path -- so as I turned onto the path from the street I could not swerve around them, and had to brake pretty hard. There is a nice stretch of soft, tempting grass just a block or so north of the path's southern end -- perfect for, say, kicking around a soccer ball. So why were they playing in the bike lane?

WARD--Ralph E.,88, died peacefully at Greenwich Hospital on October 7, 2009 after a brief illness. He is survived by his wife of twenty-eight years, Elaine Simon Ward of Darien, CT, and Manhattan, and his five children, Sarah Ward Hogan of Mont Vernon, NH, Richard R. Ward of River Falls, WI, Thomas D. Ward of Sarasota, FL, John B. Ward, of Darien, CT and James R. Ward of Easton, CT. from his marriage to the late Eugenia E. McManigal as well as fifteen grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Born in Scotch Plains, NJ. February 26, 1921, the only child of Margaret Reynolds Ward and Ralph E. Ward Sr. He was a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy '40 where he captained the undefeated football team of 1939. He was also a member of the varsity hockey and lacrosse teams, a member of the Senior Council, the Christian Fraternity, and the Golden Branch Debating Society. At the onset of World War II while attending Williams College, he applied to the Army Air Corps Flying Cadet program. He was commissioned and served as a USAAF fighter pilot and squadron commander in the 90th Fighter Squadron 80th Fighter Group serving two tours in the China-Burna-India Theater, flying 88 combat missions in P-40 and P-47 fighter aircraft. As of record he was awarded the Distinguished Service Cross for extraordinary heroism in connection with military operations against an armed military force on March 27, 1944. As Flight Leader of his formation with four P-40's they intercepted an enemy force of nine bombers and multiple fighters successfully destroying eight aircraft before returning to base safely. He also was awarded the Distinguished flying Cross, Air Medal with one oak leaf cluster, Distinguished Unit Citation, Asiatic Pacific Theater Ribbon with two battle stars, American Theater Ribbon and the Victory Ribbon. After the war, he attended Lafayette College where he later received an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws. While at Lafayette he was recruited by Chesebrough Manufacturing Company which became Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., as an international management trainee. He established the Australian Branch in Melbourne, Australia serving as General manager, 1948-1957. Upon returning to the United States he was appointed Vice President of the International Division, Far East. In the succeeding years he rose to become President and Chief Executive Officer in may, 1968, and was elected to the additional post of Chairman of the Board in May, 1976 serving in those positions for 19 years until his retirement in 1987. He was a former Director of The Chase Manhattan Corporation and The Chase Manhattan Bank, N.A., Stauffer Chemical Company, CPC Inc., and the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., and a member of the Lafayette College Board of Trustees, the Board of Govenors of Ford's Theater Society, Washington, DC, The Economic Club of New York, The Conference Board, The Business Roundtable, and The American Australian Association. He was the firth corporate sponsor of the Jackie Robinson Foundation, and in 1989 established the Ralph E. Ward Achievement Award which he gave annually to recognize the graduating JRF Scholar with the highest cumulative grade point average. An avid golfer, he was a member of Victoria Golf Club, Melbourne, Australia, Milbrook Club, Greenwich, CT, Winged Foot Golf Club, Mamaroneck, NY, Wee Burn Country Club, Darien, CT, Wentworth Club, Virginia Water, UK. As well he was a member of The Tokeneke Club, Darien, CT, The Union League Club, NY, and Coral Beach & Tennis Club, Bermuda. Funeral services will be private. He will be buried at Arlington National Cemetery with full military honors. He was admired, respected and loved by all in his family. He will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in his memory to one of the following: St. Vincent's Medical Center Foundation, Ronald J. Bianchi, President/CEO, 2800 Main Street, Bridgeport, CT 06606 for the "Elaine S. & Ralph E. Ward Endowment Fund" for Cardiac Services; or Greenwich Hospital, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT 06830 for the Oncology Fund, Dickerman Hollister, Jr., MD, Head Hematology/Oncology; or Philips Exeter Academy, Gift Recording, Exeter, NH 03833.

THE INCREASE IN CALORIES IN MEALS ordered by customers at fast food outlets in New York City after restaurants began posting calorie counts of their menu offerings, according to a study in the journal Health Affairs. City officials hoped consumers would moderate their eating habits after a law took effect in July 2008 requiring restaurants to post calorie figures. The study of four fast food chains in poor neighborhoods with high rates of obesity found that meals ordered for lunch and dinner after the law went on the books had a mean of 846 calories -- up from 825 calories before the law.

It is Babe Ruth, but maybe not Lou Gehrig. It is probably 1928. And it may just be Sept. 9, part of a doubleheader against the Philadelphia Athletics at Yankee Stadium, rather than an October World Series game against the St. Louis Cardinals. A newly discovered home film acquired by Major League Baseball Productions shows Ruth playing the outfield, a first for the vast moving-image archive. It also shows Ruth striking out on a check swing, arguing with an umpire and walking away while dragging his bat through the dirt.

When evaluating a Baby Belichick like Josh McDaniels, it is best to withhold judgment for a season or two. Bill Belichick's protégés often start out strong -- Eric Mangini was once Mangenius and Charlie Weis earned a Golden Dome-size contract after one season at Notre Dame -- but none have had sustained N.F.L. or college success. McDaniels, like Weis, Mangini and Romeo Crennel, has an X's-and-O's doctorate but an associate's degree in personnel management. But with Denver off to a 4-0 start, skeptics who thought McDaniels received too much supreme power too soon are starting to amend their theories. McDaniels is an offensive coach, but the Broncos are winning with defense. The defensive coordinator Mike Nolan installed a 3-4 system that makes proper use of the talents of pass rusher Elvis Dumervil (8 sacks) and linebacker Andra Davis (21 solo tackles). The turnaround has been drastic: the Broncos allowed 26 points in four games after allowing 117 points through the first four games of 2008. McDaniels's offense has not kept pace, but he has demonstrated an adaptability he appeared to lack during the off-season Jay Cutler drama. The Broncos overcame a 10-0 deficit against the Dallas Cowboys when McDaniels scrapped his beloved spread in favor of two-tight end running plays.

GORE VIDAL might balk at being designated a style icon, but his new book, ''Gore Vidal: Snapshots in History's Glare'' (Abrams, $40), is described as a ''visual memoir,'' and reminds us of not only the place he holds in literature, film and politics, but also in the style world. From his days in Rock Creek Park in Washington to his homes in upstate New York, the Italian countryside and the Hollywood Hills, he has chronicled his life with photographs of him and his partner, the late Howard Auster, and their many famous friends and visitors.

NEW YORK witnessed yesterday one of the greatest aerial flights, both in spectacular interest and personal daring, that has ever been accomplished in the history of aviation. Wilbur Wright, to whom the title King of the Air has frequently been applied, but never with more justice than yesterday, fulfilled the expectations that have been hovering about him for more than a week by sailing with the grace of a seagull and the strength of an eagle up the Hudson River from Governors Island to Grant's Tomb and back. He was in the air 33 minutes and 33 seconds and traveled twenty miles, attaining a maximum height of 250 feet. nytimes.com/timestraveler

THE German artist Robert Knoke insists that people wear their souls on their sleeves. And in the case of his fashionable subjects -- including the interior designer Andrée Putman (pictured) -- he has a point. ''All I'm interested in is the surface,'' said Mr. Knoke, who shuttles between Paris, New York and Berlin. ''Even what and how we wear things becomes a part of who we are.''

FIGGE--John Kahl, of Sea Island, GA, formerly of Davenport, IA and Washington, DC on October 9, 2009. Born in Davenport, IA on January 22, 1938 to Elizabeth (Kahl) and V.O. Figge. Beloved husband for 49 years of Patricia Anne (Joyce) Figge, devoted father of Mary Power (John), Wellesley, MA, Patricia Glowacki, (Tony), Chevy Chase, MD, Elizabeth Lemek (Brian), Chevy Chase, MD, Ann Nawn (Jim), Princeton, NJ, John O. Figge (Lisa), Bryn Mawr, PA, and Michael J. Figge (Jennifer), Princeton, NJ. Also survived by 20 adoring grandchildren, two sisters; Ann Brawley, Colorado Springs, CO, Marie Wise, Houston, TX, two brothers; James K. Figge, Sun Valley, ID, Thomas K. Figge, Aspen, CO and Santa Barbara, CA, and 40 nieces and nephews. He graduated from Georgetown Preparatory School in 1955 and The College of the Holy Cross in 1959. He holds degrees from the Graduate School of Banking of the University of Wisconsin, as well as an honorary doctorate degree from Saint Ambrose University, Davenport, IA. He began his career at Davenport Bank and Trust Company in 1960. He became a member of the Board of Directors in 1969, was made President of the Bank in 1980, and was CEO at the time of the sale of the bank to Norwest Corp. in 1990. He was active in community banking in eastern Iowa and western Illinois for many years. After retiring in 1990, he focused his time on several successful entrepreneurial ventures including Panera Bread franchises in New Jersey and Maryland, several real estate investments in the Boston area, and Wealthengine, a marketing services firm in Bethesda, MD. His dedication to faith and family was lived through his service to many charitable organizations. At the time of his death he served as a trustee of the College of the Holy Cross, Worcester, MA, Catholic Charities Foundation, Washington, DC, Woodstock Theological Center at Georgetown University, Washington, DC, and Loyola Retreat House, Faulkner, MD. He was a member of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta. He was a past board member of Georgetown Preparatory School, Bethesda, MD, and St. Ambrose University, Davenport, IA, as well as a member of the board of fellows for the University of Iowa's religion department. He was also a board member of the Foundation for K-12 Catholic Schools, Davenport, IA, and the Gregorian University Foundation, New York, NY. He served as President of the Iowa-Illinois Council of Boy Scouts in the early 70s and was a member of the Rotary Club of Davenport, IA. He made many good friends through his lifelong love of the game of golf, and will be missed at his favorite clubs including Ocean Forest Club, Sea Island, GA, and Burning Tree Club, Bethesda, MD. The family will receive visitors at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY on Tuesday, October 13 at 2-4:30pm followed by Mass of Christian Burial at 5pm, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Ave., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of John K. Figge to The College of the Holy Cross, Worcester, MA, and the Catholic Charities Foundation, Washington, DC.

THE WILD SIDE Paying attention to the cries and hoots of others can be particularly important for animals that have a bad view of the neighborhood, or that spend a lot of time alone and thus don't get warnings from their own kind. An example: Gunther's dik-dik, a species of miniature antelope. These creatures live in pairs, in large territories. They have many enemies -- leopards, lions, eagles, hyenas, vultures and the like -- and spend much of their time hiding in thickets of undergrowth where they don't have a good view. So perhaps it's not surprising that they tune into the alarm calls of go-away birds -- which sit high in the tree-tops, announcing passing predators. All of this makes sense. You'd expect animals to evolve to pay attention to all the information available to them, especially in matters of life and death.

It wasn't just about Vogue. True, Irving Penn, the photographic maestro of classical elegance who died last week at the age of 92, gave us striking images of models and celebrities. But in 1950 and 1951, in studios in Paris, London and New York, he invited in people who were less celebrated. Penn's idea was to immortalize the practitioners of small -- and sometimes disappearing -- trades. So, in came a knife grinder, a chimney sweep, a chair caner, a tinker. Above, is perhaps London's last street seller of chamois -- a nonabrasive leather used for polishing. An audio slideshow at: nytimes.com/weekinreview

THE NEWSPresident Obama considered a troop buildup in Afghanistan as his national security advisers moved to reframe the war strategy to focus on Al Qaeda in Pakistan. BEHIND THE NEWS The White House said the president was several weeks away from deciding on an increase of up to 40,000 troops urged by his top military general in Afghanistan. But the internal White House debate over threats to American security posed by the Taliban and Al Qaeda suggested that he might not increase troops significantly.

ECKE-PAS--Patricia, 53, passed away Thursday, October 8, 2009 after a long and valiant battle with cancer. She was born in Brooklyn, New York on October 6, 1956. Pat is survived by her loving husband Tom Pas, stepchildren Chantalle and Jerry and Cedric and Tania and grandchildren Jean-Luc, Brita and Isabella, her mother Leonora Liotta Ecke, brothers and sisters Tom and Liz, John and Denise, Susan and Rob, aunts, uncles, nieces and nephews. Pat started her career at The New York Times in 1979 as communications coordinator in Syndication Sales. She became Vice President of Marketing for Syndication Sales in 1986 where she was responsible for the marketing and sales of TimesFax. In 1997, she moved to Miami to head the Miami National Sales Office as Advertising Director. Pat's dedication and expertise to Caribbean tourism was legendary. She joined the Board of Directors of the Caribbean Hotel & Tourism Association, to support the hospitality community and give back energy to the industry that she so dearly loved. To the countries of the Caribbean, Pat was a friend, a partner and a person who cared deeply and understood their needs and concerns. So much so that in 2002, Pat was the first media salesperson to be recognized by the Caribbean Hotel and Tourism Association as Allied Member of the Year, for her dedication and professionalism in the travel industry for the Caribbean. Pat was fun loving, gregarious, full of life and always selling. She was deeply loved by all who were fortunate enough to know her. Visitation will be held from 2-5pm and 7-9:30pm Tuesday, October 13 and Wednesday, October 14 at William E. Law Funeral Home, 1 Jerusalem Avenue, Massapequa, NY, 11758, 516-541-8070. Funeral Mass at 10:30am Thursday, October 15 at Maria Regina RC Church, 3945 Jerusalem Avenue, Seaford, NY, 516-798-2415. In lieu of flowers, donations in Pat's memory can be made to Caribbean Hotel & Tourism Association Education Foundation (CHTAEF) at 2655 LeJeune Road, Suite 910, Coral Gables, FL 33134. This scholarship fund will benefit the further education of hospitality students in the Caribbean.

HOMERS TO REMEMBER Mark Teixeira's winning home run in the 11th inning Friday was the fastest any ball has left the park in the majors this season. According to hittrackeronline.com, Teixeira's screamer down the left-field line cleared the wall in 2.88 seconds at 110 miles per hour. Teixeira's sprint out of the box, more than the force of his hit, stood out to his 3-year-old son, Jack. ''He said, 'Daddy -- run fast!' '' Teixeira said. ''It was awesome.''

JOHNSON--Craig Winfield, passed away on Saturday night, October 3, at 9:18pm at Stanford Hospital surrounded by those he loved, the victim of a sudden and unexpected stroke. Craig was born in Pasadena, California on December 28, 1946, to Marian and Roger Johnson. He grew up in nearby Arcadia, where he excelled in track and debate before matriculating at Yale College, from which he graduated Magna Cum Laude in 1968. After college, he served in the Peace Corps in Ethiopia, and while there met and married Deborah Kendall, another Peace Corps volunteer, in Addis Ababa before returning to the States. Upon his return he attended Stanford Law School, graduating in 1974. As Silicon Valley began to boom, he joined the law firm of Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati as its 14th attorney. With Deborah he raised three sons: Scott, Matthew, and Erik. Craig was a true visionary, quickly grasping the unique intersection of law, technology, and venture capital that the Bay Area afforded. He specialized in working with Silicon Valley's abundant technology startups, and left WSGR in 1993 to form Venture Law Group, a firm designed around his interest in funding and structuring fledgling companies. He was instrumental in bringing to market such companies as Yahoo!, Hotmail, and Rosetta Inpharmatics, and cofounded Garage Technology Ventures, Concept2Company, and Financial Engines. Craig's latest venture was cofounding Virtual Law Partners in 2008, yet another visionary advance in the provision of legal services. In this labor of love he found his heart's desire, and on August 15th of this year he married RoseAnn Rotandaro, one of his cofounders, in a beautiful and celebratory ceremony at his house in Portola Valley. Craig and RoseAnn had just completed a magical honeymoon, sailing the Mediterranean and cycling in the Slovenian Alps, shortly before Craig's untimely death. He was only 62. Craig's impact far exceeded his legal accomplishments. His goal was always to bring together the best people and brightest ideas, and see that both flourished. He was selfless in his work, and universally regarded as fair, honest, brilliant, and caring. He inspired the best in all around him, and helped them to believe in themselves as much as he believed in them. His friends will miss him dearly, and his family will miss him desperately. He leaves behind his sons Matt and Scott, Matt's wife Desdemona, his loving wife RoseAnn and her son Noah Rogers, his brother Brian and sister-in-law Joan, his nephew Derek and niece Kaitlin, his Uncle Ken Scott and his wife Sunny, and his father Roger. He goes into the embrace of his son Erik, his nephew Christopher, and his mother Marion, who left this earth before him. Craig will live on in the hearts of the innumerable family, friends, and associates whose lives he graced. A memorial service in honor of Craig's life will be held at the Stanford Arrillaga Alumni Center (326 Galvez St., Stanford, CA) on Sunday, October 11 at 2:30pm. Guests are invited to arrive an hour early to share memories and love. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you consider making a tax-deductible donation to the Craig Winfield Johnson Memorial Fund at Silicon Valley Community Foundation to support the causes that Craig has championed. Please make checks payable to: Silicon Valley Community Foundation, for the Benefit of: Craig Winfield Johnson Memorial Fund, 2440 W. El Camino Real, Ste 300, Mountain View, CA 94040.

GREENWALD--William Irving, 88, died October 9th surrounded by his loving wife and family. Born 1920 in Cumberland, MD, he lived most of his life in New York City. Graduate of Brooklyn College with a Ph.D. in economics from New York University, he went on to become full Professor at City College of New York where he taught for 59 years. He retired in 2004, age 82. In addition he is the author of countless books and articles on economics. He fully enjoyed world travel and the rich culture of his city. He considered his greatest accomplishment his 68 year marriage to his beloved Shirley E. Greenwald, who survives him. A devoted, loving father of four, Ted Greenwald, wife Joan McClusky and Alison Gold of New York City, Nancy Greenwald of High Falls, NY and Maggie Greenwald, husband David Mansfield of Maplewood, NJ. Kanye West let the BET Hip-Hop Awards finish without interruption on Saturday by abstaining from the event, The Associated Press reported. Mr. West, who was widely criticized by his fellow performers after interrupting an acceptance speech by Taylor Swift at the MTV Video Music Awards in September, had been nominated for nine awards at the BET event, which was taped in Atlanta. The rapper T.I. was also absent as he is serving a prison sentence on a weapons conviction, but his fiancée, Tameka (Tiny) Cottle, was in attendance to accept his awards for album of the year (for “Paper Trail”) and best collaboration (for “Live Your Life” with Rihanna). Jay-Z won MVP of the year, Drake was rookie of the year and Ice Cube was given the “I Am Hip-Hop” icon award. DJ AM, who died of a drug overdose in August, was posthumously given the DJ of the Year award. BET will broadcast the awards show on Oct. 27.

Normally, a gathering of hundreds of British men and women dressed in bathrobes and toting towels would not be all that remarkable an occurrence. But on Sunday, one such event was held to mark the 30th anniversary of “The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy,” the comedic science-fiction franchise created by Douglas Adams, and the publication of a new book in the series, The Guardian reported. At Hitchcon 09, held at the Royal Festival Hall in London, fans assembled (many of them dressed in the shabby costume of the series’s hapless hero, Arthur Dent) to pay tribute to Mr. Adams, the author of the original “Hitchhiker’s” radio plays and the five-book sequence they spawned, who died in 2001. The convention also served as a kickoff for “And Another Thing…,” a new novel by the “Artemis Fowl” author Eoin Colfer that is cheekily being billed as the sixth entry in the “Hitchhiker’s Guide” trilogy. The American edition of “And Another Thing…” was released by Hyperion on Monday.

When it is not being used to bust cheating college students, a computer program used to detect plagiarism may have helped show that Shakespeare was an author of an unattributed play about Edward III, The Times of London reported. Brian Vickers, a professor at the Institute of English Studies at the University of London, told the newspaper that a comparison of phrases used in “The Reign of King Edward III,” a play published anonymously in 1596, with other works by Shakespeare published before then showed 200 matches of phrases of three or more words. The comparisons were made using the software program Pl@giarism, which the University of Maastricht developed to keep its students honest. Mr. Vickers also said that the program turned up 200 matches between the play and the works of Thomas Kyd, the Elizabethan playwright of “The Spanish Tragedy” who probably collaborated with Shakespeare on “The Reign of King Edward III.” Shakespeare’s authorship of the play has been widely debated, though it is included in “The Riverside Shakespeare” and “The Oxford Shakespeare” anthologies.

A lawyer for Roman Polanski said Sunday that his client realized that some of the support he has received since his arrest has not been helpful to securing his release, and added that he was concerned for Mr. Polanski’s health, Agence France-Presse reported. The lawyer, Hervé Temime, spoke to the wire service after visiting Mr. Polanski on Friday in the Swiss prison where he is being held for possible extradition to the United States more than three decades after fleeing sentencing on sex charges in 1978. In the interview, Mr. Temime said that Mr. Polanski was “very touched by the support he has received.” He added, “He also knows that some of it is counterproductive,” but did not elaborate. After Mr. Polanski’s arrest on Sept. 26, the French cultural minister, Frederic Mitterrand, called the arrest “absolutely horrifying” but later softened his remarks. Many filmmakers, actors and other personalities have signed petitions seeking Mr. Polanski’s release. Mr. Temime also said he found the 76-year-old Mr. Polanski to be “very worn out” during his visit.

Lauren Graham, a star of the long-running WB and CW show “Gilmore Girls,” has been added to the cast of the coming NBC series “Parenthood,” Variety reported. She is replacing Maura Tierney, the “E.R.” and “NewsRadio” star who withdrew from the show after she received a diagnosis of breast cancer. A premiere date for “Parenthood,” which is based on the 1989 Ron Howard comedy, has not been announced.

A few more fans and admirers turned out Sunday to see Edgar Allan Poe buried for the second (and third) time than were present at his original funeral, The Baltimore Sun reported. The ceremonies held on Sunday were to mark the 200th anniversary of the birth of Poe, the morbidly fixated man of letters, and drew 700 ticket holders as well as many other curious observers, some dressed in period costumes and others in T-shirts that read “Evermore!” (By comparison, fewer than 10 people were reported to have attended Poe’s actual burial in 1849.) The Sun reported that a horse-drawn undertaker’s carriage delivered Poe’s coffin to Westminster Hall, where Poe was memorialized by guest speakers as well as actors portraying Poe’s contemporaries. The actor and author Michael N. Langford, who spoke at the services, told The Sun, “I think Edgar Allan Poe would have been bemused by it, shocked by it. But I think it was what he deserved.”

It looks as if the producers of “FlashForward” will be spared the indignity of their show never actually reaching April 29, 2010, the mysterious future date that’s central to its unwinding mythology: Variety reports that ABC has picked up the science-fiction suspense series for a full season. As recently as 1979, legal academics Virginia Nordin and Harry Edwards were able to say that "historically American courts have adhered fairly consistently to the doctrine of academic abstention in order to avoid excessive judicial oversight of academic institutions" (Higher Education and the Law). Academic abstention is the doctrine (never formally promulgated) that courts should defer to colleges and universities when it comes to matters like promotions, curricula, admission policies, grading, tenure, etc. The reasoning is that courts lack the competence to monitor academic behavior; they should get out of the way and let the professionals do the job. "Courts are particularly ill-equipped," Chief Justice Rehnquist declared in 1978, "to evaluate academic performance." (Board of Curators of the University of Missouri v. Horowitz)

First it was Tim Gunn. Now it's Bloomingdale's. The venerable department store is the latest fashion tastemaker to find its muse in comic books. To get the party started for the 75th anniversary of DC Comics, Bloomingdale's is unveiling a collection of superhero-inspired clothing and accessories by such designers as Psycho Bunny, Jack Spade and John Varvatos. The fun begins on Wednesday with a "New York Nights" cocktail bash at Bloomingdale's around the country, including the Men's Store at the flagship on 59th street and Third Avenue in Manhattan. Be there from 6 to 8 p.m. to whet your whistle and see the merch, which includes everything from t-shirts, socks and scarves to tote bags, wallets, ties and cuff links (thankfully, no leotards). The gear will be available through the holiday season. I have my eye on a t-shirt emblazoned with the Justice League, as drawn by the legendary comic book artist George Perez. Some other favorites are the Jack Spade "Robin" wallet ($80), the Superman and Batman cuff links ($125 a pair) and some super socks, including the Flash, of course ($30 a pair). Unfortunately, neither the Batman scarf ($225), the All-Star Comics t-shirt ($62) nor the Superman tee ($38) include the hunky model above, so maybe villainy wins the day after all.

True ragù is a magnificent pasta sauce, a slow-simmered blend of meat, tomatoes and, usually, milk. The real thing takes hours, for the meat must become tender and contribute its silkiness to the sauce, the tomatoes must dissolve, and the milk must pull the whole thing together. But a reasonable approximation of ragù can be produced using ground beef or pork or, even better, prepared Italian sausage.

There I was, feeling slightly sheepish, thinking that I was the only person on my cubicle block here at T who now includes stretch-mark cream as part of her daily beauty routine. (I'm nine months pregnant.) Then, over the transom, my colleague, who is a man, tells me he uses stretch-mark cream, too, and promptly pulls a tube out of his desk drawer and applies some. To his face. My remedy of choice is Mama Mio's Tummy Rub Butter, which has the consistency of Crisco but smells divine. (Rosehip seed and borage oil are two of its active ingredients.) It's doing wonders for my torso, but I wouldn't recommend using it above the breast line. My male colleague, on the other hand, swears by StriVectin. This topical cream was originally conceived to combat stretch marks, but an informal employee test proved it to be equally effective on crow's-feet and laugh lines on men and women alike - and a brilliant new market strategy was born. (Another guy in our office admitted to having stretch marks on his knees; I wasn't entirely sure which of the two creams to recommend.) Mama Mio's cheeky instructions suggest other ways you and your partner can "share" the experience of its products, but maybe I'll just buy my boyfriend his own tube of StriVectin and call it a day.

PARIS | Scouting out an adorable sidewalk cafe in Paris is hardly a difficult task -- but finding a charming, cheap, pretension-free hub that's equal parts alfresco cafe and indoor dance hall wonder, can seem, well, impossible. But tucked away in Parc Buttes Chaumont in the mostly residential 19th Arrondissement, such a venue does indeed exist: Rosa Bonheur.

PARIS | Once upon a time, chocolate companies would send spies into their competitor's factories in an attempt to steal trade secrets. But at the Chocolate Show (Paris Expo, Pavillons 5-2 et 5-3, Porte de Versailles, 75015; www.salonduchocolat.fr), running from Oct. 14 to 18, over 400 exhibitors will be sharing their innovations with other chocolate industry professionals, connoisseurs and amateur lovers alike. And in the general spirit of Willy Wonka's chocolate palace, artisans will be working to create around an operatic theme.

A year after Washington rescued the banks considered too big to fail, the ones deemed too small to save are approaching a grim milestone: the 100th bank failure of 2009. TEPPER--Hazel Levine, 95, on October 10, 2009. Wife of the late Benjamin. Mother of Maxine and Lewis Krulwich and Anne and Jeffrey Pearl.

BARRETT--Amy Elizabeth. Passed away October 9, 2009. Beloved wife of Bob Gold and cherished mother of John, David, Liz, Tom and Danny. The eighth of nine children of Dr. Robert C. and Elizabeth Wallace Barrett (deceased). Sister of Nora, Bobby, Martha, Billy, Katie, Libby, Sarah and John. Devoted aunt to many and loved daughter-in-law. Amy graduated Smith College in 1981 and NYU School of Law, Order of the Coif, in 1985. Previous jobs included Regional Director for Senator Daniel Moyinhan then, after a long absence to raise her five children, partner in Darrison Barrett and Associates, a political consulting firm. A beautiful, kind woman dedicated to her children who spent her life doing good works for others, even when it was difficult. Her spirit touched so many and she will live on in the hearts of all who loved her. She will be terribly missed. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Adventures in Learning, Manhasset, NY or the Institute for Creative Problem Solving at SUNY Westbury. A memorial service will be held at Sacred Heart Church, Bayside 215-35 38th Avenue in Bayside, Queens at 10am on Monday, October 12th.

KOEPPEL--Pamela R.,56, passed away, October 7th in Manhattan. Beloved daughter, of Rhoda Koeppel; sister of Lesley Hirsch, mother of Melissa Grubb, Jennifer Parham, and Tara Robinson; son-in-law Steven Parham; surrogate son Kenneth Doyle; and grandmother to Parker Doyle and Etienne Parham. Her family and friends will profoundly miss her. She was a poet, creative writer, and freedom fighter. Pamela graduated from NYU with a degree in Theology. She practiced many different faiths during her life and considered herself to be a Christian-Buddhist-Jew. Service will be held on Wednesday, October 14th, from 12-4, at Old Westbury Gardens, 71 Old Westbury Road, 11568. For more information call 516-902-7623. In lieu of flowers please make donations to Southern Poverty Law Center. "Thanks for the positive energy that flows from the universe." - P.K.

8 P.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: LESLIE CARONTurner Classic Movies continues its Mondays-in-October tribute to Ms. Caron (above, with Cary Grant), the French ballerina turned Academy Award-nominated actress, whose on-screen dance card included Gene Kelly, Fred Astaire, Mikhail Baryshnikov and Rudolf Nureyev. Tonight's installment begins with ''The Man Who Understood Women'' (1959), in which she plays a producer's wife who runs from Hollywood in search of her roots. It continues at 10:30 with ''Fanny'' (1961), about an elderly merchant (Maurice Chevalier) who tries to help a pregnant young woman (Ms. Caron) deserted by her lover (Horst Buchholz), and at 1 a.m. with ''Father Goose'' (1964), about a World War II drifter (Grant) charged with protecting a beautiful teacher (Ms. Caron) and her pupils. The evening ends at 3:15 a.m. with ''The Story of Three Loves'' (1953), in which Ms. Caron plays the French governess of an American boy in Rome, in a tale told as passengers on an ocean liner recount their passions. 8 P.M. (Fox) HOUSE When a teenager (Tanner Maguire) starts suffering from unexplained stomach pain, his wealthy father (Lee Tergesen) believes that it's karmic payback for his own success.

Cisco Systems has found a way to accelerate its push into the server market. The company is simply turning many of the millions of routers it has already sold into servers. Typically, a router sits in a data center or communications closet somewhere just pushing around data packets. It's sort of like a policeman on traffic duty. Meanwhile, the servers -- the detectives, if you will -- are back in the office working on grander things.

You are safe in my heart, wherever you are, my prince of a man, my partner, the most noble of men. Firyal.

BEN ALLISON ''Think Free'' (Palmetto) For about the last dozen years, the bassist Ben Allison has been a bandleader-composer of reliable intelligence and modest but meaningful surprises. ''Think Free,'' his ninth album, continues his custom of broadening the jazz conversation, with an investment in atmospheric rock but with no particular ax to grind. There's a straightforward impulse behind this album's foregrounding of melody, and there's a lot of soulful musicianship all around, on both an individual and a collective scale.

Condé Nast announced the closing of several magazines last week, including Gourmet. In ad pages, the November issue of Gourmet was ranked No. 6 out of eight titles in the food category tracked by Mediaweek, down 37 percent from November 2008 (table below). Condé Nast will continue to publish Bon Appétit. The top online magazines -- those for news, business and entertainment -- draw upwards of two million visitors a month. By comparison, Cooking Light's Web site had 236,000 visitors in August, and Bon Appétit, 142,000.

SONNENFELDT--Richard W.,86, passed away on October 9, 2009. Born in Berlin and raised in Gardelegen, Germany, Richard served as the chief interpreter for the American prosecution at the Nuremberg War Trials in 1945, and personally interrogated and delivered the indictments to the top-ranking Nazi criminals. A past senior vice president at RCA and executive vice president at NBC, Richard was one of the principal developers of color TV at RCA and computer technology for NASA, as well as the inventor of the video disc, a precursor to the DVD. Later in his career Richard became the Dean of the Graduate School of Management, Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, and served on numerous boards including Lee Enterprises. A distinguished alumnus of Johns Hopkins University, Richard was a life fellow of the IEEE. He was a member of the Council of Foreign Relations and the American Council on Germany. He was a frequent lecturer at the Harvard Business School and MIT's Sloan School of Management. He was also an avid sailor, crossing the Atlantic three times in his 45 foot sailboat in his 70's. In 2002 he wrote his autobiography, "Witness to Nuremberg," which was published in Germany as well as the U.S. He often lectured about his war time experiences, time spent in a detention center in Australia and surviving a torpedo attack on a troop transport ship. A loving husband, father and grandfather Richard is survived by his second wife Barbara of 29 years, their six children, Ann Goldberg (Sam), Larry Sonnenfeldt (Barbara), Michael Sonnenfeldt (Katja), Elizabeth Holdstein (Michael), Catherine Hausman and Marguerite DeNicola, and 15 grandchildren, Sara, Adam, Gillian, Andrew, Joya, Patricia, Margaret, Forrest, Alex, Peter, Ellen, Henry, Daniel, Isaac and Sophia. He is also survived by his brother Helmut Sonnenfeldt (Marjorie). His first wife Shirley predeceased him. The funeral will be Monday at 10.30am, Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Internment will be private. Donations in Richard's memory may be made to the Johns Hopkins School of Engineering or Hospice Care Network of Woodbury, NY.

PINCUS--Lionel I. Founder and retired Chairman of the investment firm Warburg Pincus LLC and a financial pioneer credited with helping to create the modern-day venture capital and private equity industry, died peacefully at home in Manhattan on October 10, 2009 after a long illness. He was 78. For more than 40 years, Mr. Pincus played a major role in the evolution of the private equity industry in the United States and abroad, helping both to define its institutional role and sculpt its professional standards. The firm he founded, Warburg Pincus, today is one of the world's leading private equity firms, having invested more than $29 billion in more than 600 companies in 30 countries. In addition to his business accomplishments, Mr. Pincus' life has been marked by an extraordinary commitment to civic, educational, cultural, and philanthropic institutions both close to his home in New York and throughout the world. He was a Director or Trustee for the American Museum of Natural History, Montefiore Medical Center, New York-Presbyterian Hospital, the German Marshall fund of the United States, the Citizens Budget Commission and the School of American Ballet. He was Chair Emeritus of the Trustees of Columbia University and a member of the Board of Overseers of Columbia Business School, the Council of Foreign Relations, the New York City Investment Fund and the World Wildlife Fund National Council. Mr. Pincus was a founding Director of the National Venture Capital Association and was honored with the association's Lifetime Achievement in Venture Capital Award in 2002. Mr. Pincus was married to the former Suzanne Storrs Poulton, who passed away in 1995. He is survived by two sons, Henry A. and Matthew S., both of Manhattan, and three grandchildren. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Donations in his memory may be made to New York Presbyterian Hospital, Division of Geriatrics and Gerontology, care of Dr. Herb Pardes, 525 East 68th Street, New York, NY 10065

HERLANDS--James O. We have lost our Uncle Jimmy, a spark in our lives. Forever, we will cherish memories of a fun-loving, gentle man who loved us but not nearly as much as we loved him. Raquel, Stephen and Jeffrey

Loving father-in-law of Dr. Elliot Winston. Devoted son of the late Rabbi Ben Zion and Sarah Eisenstadt. Predeceased by his dear siblings, Dorothy, Joseph and Dr. Abraham. WARD--Ralph E.,88, died peacefully at Greenwich Hospital on October 7, 2009 after a brief illness. He is survived by his wife of twenty-eight years, Elaine Simon Ward of Darien, CT, and Manhattan, and his five children, Sarah Ward Hogan of Mont Vernon, NH, Richard R. Ward of River Falls, WI, Thomas D. Ward of Sarasota, FL, John B. Ward, of Darien, CT and James R. Ward of Easton, CT. from his marriage to the late Eugenia E. McManigal as well as fifteen grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Born in Scotch Plains, NJ. February 26, 1921, the only child of Margaret Reynolds Ward and Ralph E. Ward Sr. He was a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy '40 where he captained the undefeated football team of 1939. He was also a member of the varsity hockey and lacrosse teams, a member of the Senior Council, the Christian Fraternity, and the Golden Branch Debating Society. At the onset of World War II while attending Williams College, he applied to the Army Air Corps Flying Cadet program. He was commissioned and served as a USAAF fighter pilot and squadron commander in the 90th Fighter Squadron 80th Fighter Group serving two tours in the China-Burna-India Theater, flying 88 combat missions in P-40 and P-47 fighter aircraft. As of record he was awarded the Distinguished Service Cross for extraordinary heroism in connection with military operations against an armed military force on March 27, 1944. As Flight Leader of his formation with four P-40's they intercepted an enemy force of nine bombers and multiple fighters successfully destroying eight aircraft before returning to base safely. He also was awarded the Distinguished flying Cross, Air Medal with one oak leaf cluster, Distinguished Unit Citation, Asiatic Pacific Theater Ribbon with two battle stars, American Theater Ribbon and the Victory Ribbon. After the war, he attended Lafayette College where he later received an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws. While at Lafayette he was recruited by Chesebrough Manufacturing Company which became Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., as an international management trainee. He established the Australian Branch in Melbourne, Australia serving as General manager, 1948-1957. Upon returning to the United States he was appointed Vice President of the International Division, Far East. In the succeeding years he rose to become President and Chief Executive Officer in may, 1968, and was elected to the additional post of Chairman of the Board in May, 1976 serving in those positions for 19 years until his retirement in 1987. He was a former Director of The Chase Manhattan Corporation and The Chase Manhattan Bank, N.A., Stauffer Chemical Company, CPC Inc., and the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., and a member of the Lafayette College Board of Trustees, the Board of Govenors of Ford's Theater Society, Washington, DC, The Economic Club of New York, The Conference Board, The Business Roundtable, and The American Australian Association. He was the firth corporate sponsor of the Jackie Robinson Foundation, and in 1989 established the Ralph E. Ward Achievement Award which he gave annually to recognize the graduating JRF Scholar with the highest cumulative grade point average. An avid golfer, he was a member of Victoria Golf Club, Melbourne, Australia, Milbrook Club, Greenwich, CT, Winged Foot Golf Club, Mamaroneck, NY, Wee Burn Country Club, Darien, CT, Wentworth Club, Virginia Water, UK. As well he was a member of The Tokeneke Club, Darien, CT, The Union League Club, NY, and Coral Beach & Tennis Club, Bermuda. Funeral services will be private. He will be buried at Arlington National Cemetery with full military honors. He was admired, respected and loved by all in his family. He will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in his memory to one of the following: St. Vincent's Medical Center Foundation, Ronald J. Bianchi, President/CEO, 2800 Main Street, Bridgeport, CT 06606 for the "Elaine S. & Ralph E. Ward Endowment Fund" for Cardiac Services; or Greenwich Hospital, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT 06830 for the Oncology Fund, Dickerman Hollister, Jr., MD, Head Hematology/Oncology; or Philips Exeter Academy, Gift Recording, Exeter, NH 03833.

Adding to its list of grievances with the West, Iran on Monday said that the British Museum had broken a promise to lend it an artifact from the 6th century B.C., Reuters reported. Hassan Qashqavi, a spokesman for Iran’s foreign ministry, threatened reduced cooperation from Iran on art-related matters if the British Museum did not meet a two-month deadline to provide a relic called the Cyrus Cylinder, a clay cylinder believed to date to Cyrus of Persia’s conquest of Babylon in 539 B.C. In a news conference, Mr. Qashqavi suggested that the museum was reluctant to hand over the artifact because of the turmoil after Iran’s disputed presidential election in June. “Unfortunately, the British party did not honor its pledge on illogical, illegal and unethical grounds allegedly due to political developments in Iran,” he said, according to Reuters. “What does cultural heritage have to do with our domestic political developments?” A spokeswoman for the British Museum said that it still intends to send the cylinder to Iran.

The Sante Fe Opera, which plans to drill for oil and gas in two New Mexico counties, is meeting with resistance from local residents, The Associated Press reported. In 2002, the Santa Fe Opera was given permission to drill on nearly 27,000 acres in Mora and San Miguel counties as part of a bequest from a donor, who wanted any revenue to be used to support an apprentice program for young singers.

Back when Junichiro Koizumi, the former prime minster of Japan, serenaded President Bush with “Love Me Tender” on a visit to Graceland, he was clearly laying the groundwork for a show business career. On the next step in his transition from politics to entertainment, Mr. Koizumi will lend his voice to a coming Japanese action movie, Agence France-Presse reported. In the film, “MegaMonsterBattle: Ultra Galaxy Legends,” the latest entry in Japan’s long-running “Ultraman” franchise, Mr. Kozumi portrays an extraterrestrial hero who battles outer-space aliens and monsters with flashing lights and a battle cry of “Pay for your transgression!” Mr. Koizumi, who retired from politics in 2006, had planned to turn down the role, but he was encouraged to take it by his son Shinjiro, who took over his seat in parliament. “No one else can play this significant role,” said Junko Kitazawa of Tsuburaya Productions, which is releasing the film in Japan on Dec. 12.

A stray fingerprint is not something you generally want to find on a valuable artwork — unless it was left there by Leonardo da Vinci. An art historian and a forensic art expert are among those saying that a fingerprint detected in a vellum portrait shows that it is the work of da Vinci, and not an early 19th-century German work as previously categorized, Antiques Trade Gazette reported. The work — a chalk, pen and ink portrait on vellum — was sold in 2007 for about $19,000 to a collector who took it to Martin Kemp, an emeritus professor of art history at Oxford University. Mr. Kemp, with the help of the forensic analyst Peter Paul Biro, found a fingerprint near the top of the work that they say is “highly comparable” to one found on da Vinci’s painting of St. Jerome in the Vatican. A chalk palm print in the neck of the portrait’s subject, believed to be the daughter of a 15th-century Milanese duke, is another piece of evidence the experts say supports the case that the work is by Leonardo da Vinci.

SAN FRANCISCO — When Noël Coward’s “Brief Encounter,” the Kneehigh Theater’s adaptation of the David Lean 1946 film of the same name and its antecedent, Coward’s play “Still Life,” arrives at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn in December, it may be a little briefer.

A Richard Prince exhibition has reopened at the Tate Modern museum in London without a photograph of Brooke Shields that drew the attention of the police, Bloomberg News reported. The Tate Modern was to show Mr. Prince’s exhibition “Spiritual America” as part of its program Pop Life: Art in a Material World but closed it from view after Scotland Yard warned that a photograph it included, taken of Ms. Shields in the nude when she was 10 years old, could violate obscenity laws. The picture, which was included in “Spiritual America” when it was shown at the Guggenheim Museum in 2007, was taken by Mr. Prince from another photograph made by Gary Gross in 1976 and authorized by Ms. Shields’s mother. In a statement, the Tate Modern said the photograph had been replaced with another of Ms. Shields as an adult, dressed in a bikini and leaning against a motorbike. The statement added that the change was made “in consultation with the artist.”

Michael Jackson’s new song “This Is It” could prove a significant payday for Paul Anka. Although the song had been advertised as an unheard recording left behind by Mr. Jackson — and written by him alone — it became clear after it was released on Sunday night that “This Is It” was not new at all: it had been written by Mr. Jackson and Mr. Anka 26 years ago, and recorded by the singer Safire in 1991 as “I Never Heard.” Late Monday afternoon, the Jackson estate acknowledged Mr. Anka’s role and said he would be given credit. On Tuesday, the estate also confirmed that Mr. Anka would receive half of all due royalties for the song, which could be substantial. The song will play over the end credits of the film “This Is It” and feature prominently on its soundtrack. In addition, Mr. Anka would be owed fees for any licensed use of the song to commercials or other films. The Jackson estate is said to be in talks with Coca-Cola about possible use of “This Is It” in a large ad campaign, according to people with knowledge of the discussion who were not authorized to speak about it.

Among the hottest games of Broadway casting roulette this month is who will be in the upcoming replacement cast of “God of Carnage,” the hit Yasmina Reza play starring Marcia Gay Harden (who won the Tony for best actress for her role), James Gandolfini, Hope Davis, and Jeff Daniels. The word from theater industry sources working on the show is that the replacement cast will be announced any day now and soon start rehearsals, before taking the stage on the week of Nov. 15. Contrary to hot rumors on the Rialto, Mr. Gandolfini will not be staying with the production past mid-November, one of these sources confirmed Tuesday afternoon.

When it comes to the finer points of nature, I often feel at a loss. When I see a bird turning lazy circles in the sky, the feathers at the tips of its wings spread like fingers, I am pretty sure it's a hawk - though what kind, I have no idea. A rose is a rose is a rose, I know, but what is it if it's not a rose? I can tell deciduous from conifer with all the certainty of a sixth-grader, but about the only way I recognize a maple tree is by the sap bucket attached to its trunk in fall.

In retrospect, my 11 months and two weeks in Ramadi, Iraq, felt stretched to their absolute fullest length across the continuum of time. Now I recall them in thousands of digital photographs or by the folded flag in a wooden case here, in my living room, some three years later. I have made major changes both personally and professionally since getting home, and it is kind of strange now to look at that person in the photos. Hard to think about what was really going on behind my own eyes, my phony smile.

I'm calling it a Spicoli tank, whether or not the character Jeff Spicoli actually wore one in "Fast Times at Ridgemont High." He should have. This very '80s tank top, which often came with neon accents and always with an exaggerated dropped armhole, is back. When I'm in a class at the gym, I'm surrounded by buff guys who have customized their T-shirts into split-side tank tops that are barely attached at the bottom and reveal most of their worked-out upper bodies. K.H.L. president Alexander Medvedev is in the news again, proposing a 56-team superleague to start in 2011. The league, with teams stretching from the Russian Far East all the way to Germany, would unite European club hockey under one umbrella.

U.S. men's national team forward Charlie Davies was seriously injured in a car accident early Tuesday morning in Virginia. Davies spent more than three hours in surgery at the Washington Hospital Center in Washington, D.C., according to a U.S. Soccer spokesman. Another person in the car was killed.

For most of the previous century, wire-service photographers would rarely - and we mean rarely - receive personal bylines for pictures published in The New York Times. One notable exception was Paul Sakuma, then freelancing for The Associated Press, who was individually credited on the front page of Sept. 20, 1975, for his enterprising and memorable photograph of a smiling and handcuffed Patricia Hearst. Mr. Sakuma became a staff photographer in A.P.'s San Francisco bureau in 1980 and has covered the San Francisco earthquake, the Los Angeles riots, the Nagano Olympics and Silicon Valley. Today, he seems to be as busy as ever. In fact, Slide 11 is his delightful picture of what looks like the world's most ineffectual umbrella.

Since its opening last year, I've wanted to stay at Cavallo Point Lodge, an environmentally friendly luxury resort just over the Golden Gate Bridge from San Francisco - yet a world away - in the Marin Headlands. The product of a public-private initiative that supports sustainable development, Cavallo Point occupies the former Fort Baker Army base that was built between 1901 and 1910 and which is now part of the Golden Gate National Parks. The resort consists of 24 Colonial Revival buildings (housing guest rooms, reception, a restaurant, bar and meeting rooms) grouped around a 10-acre parade ground, as well as newer guest-room buildings and a spa. The entire ensemble nestles into the spectacular landscape.

I wrote a Science Times feature two years ago on the emerging reality that the Burmese python, a giant constricting snake from southern Asia, was enjoying a new and expanding range in South Florida thanks to the relatively ungoverned global trade in exotic reptiles as pets. Now the United States Geological Survey has issued a report concluding that the Burmese python and four other species of giant constricting snakes pose a high risk of disrupting important ecological webs should they become established in the United States.

With the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn inching closer to a ground-breaking, opponents of the 22-acre development filed another lawsuit on Tuesday morning challenging the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's decision to sell the developer a portion of the land in what it says is a sweetheart deal that violates state law.

Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, joined 13 Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee to approve the committee's health care bill, the only Republican to do so. For months, her support seemed pivotal to health care's overhaul in the Senate. For much of the public, it's puzzling that the politics of reshaping a sector that accounts for 16 percent of the G.D.P. should seemingly hinge on one senator.

Hiking with me is like hiking with a small child: slow and clumsy, with occasional whining. So when our friends Gabe and Bridget invited my husband, Andy, and me up to the Johns Brook Lodge in the Adirondacks for Columbus Day weekend, I was more focused on what we'd eat for dinner than the number of miles we'd get under our feet. The Johns Brook Lodge is a 28-bed non-winterized cabin run by the Adirondack Mountain Club that requires a 3 ½ mile hike just to get there from the parking lot. We'd have to pack in all of our food, though we would have access to a fully outfitted kitchen where we could cook it.

In his new book, "Bicycle Diaries" (Viking), David Byrne chronicles his experiences and musings bicycling not just in New York City, but also in the world's great metropolises, including Berlin, Istanbul, Buenos Aires, Manila, Sydney and London.

It is a crisp fall day, and David Byrne is worried about helmet hair. Pedaling up the Hudson River bike path, helmetless, the former Talking Heads frontman keeps a leisurely pace as his large brown eyes dart about and take in the world slipping past. He has agreed to let me tag along during his morning commute north from Canal Street to Midtown. Though he is lanky, there is a graceful flow to his movements, born of more than 30 years and many miles riding here and abroad.

John F. Burns will answer your questions this week on the American military's use of private contractors in the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. It became one of the most contentious aspects of the Iraqi war, with complaints that contractors were trigger-happy, that the use of them masked the true scale and cost of the war and that their presence tangled up the war effort with unclear accountability and lines of authority. With the war expanding in Afghanistan, it is clear that the reliance on contractors is no less. A recent Congressional report noted that contractors in Afghanistan outnumber uniformed troops. In Pakistan, the reliance on contractors is driving fears that America is establishing its own security and intelligence force, with what some Pakistanis see as mercenaries.

As Greg Bishop noted in his game story last night, Jets Coach Rex Ryan seemed on the verge of tears in his postgame news conference. He looked like, and spoke like, a man whose shiny new sports car had just been totaled. It was a reflection of the pride he has taken in his defenses over the years. Even as a head coach, with expanded duties, his identity still seems tied up in it.

From the safety of a window seat 30,000 feet above the ground aboard a commercial flight to Kabul, the dangerous tribal areas and mountain ranges that separate Pakistan from southern Afghanistan are a truly majestic sight. This is one of the most rugged and dangerous parts of the world, a vast area that is completely off limits to Westerners because it is controlled by an array of Pashtun tribes loyal to Al Qaeda and the Taliban. Some experts believe that Osama bin Laden continues to find refuge somewhere along these forbidding mountains eight years after the attacks of Sept. 11.

When not being used to bust cheating college students, a computer program that detects plagiarism may have helped show that Shakespeare, below, was an author of an unattributed play about Edward III, The Times of London reported. Brian Vickers, a professor at the Institute of English Studies at the University of London, told the newspaper that a comparison of the language in “The Reign of King Edward III,” published anonymously in 1596, with that of other works by Shakespeare published before it showed 200 matches of phrases of three or more words. The comparisons were made using the software program Pl@giarism, developed by the University of Maastricht to keep its students honest. Mr. Vickers also said the program turned up 200 matches of the play with the works of Thomas Kyd, the Elizabethan playwright of “The Spanish Tragedy” who probably collaborated with Shakespeare on “The Reign of King Edward III.” Shakespeare’s authorship of the play has been widely debated, though it is included in “The Riverside Shakespeare” and “The Oxford Shakespeare” anthologies.

Apparently it is not standard practice for British men and women to gather dressed in bathrobes and toting towels. When hundreds of fans thus clad assembled in London on Sunday, it was to celebrate the 30th anniversary of “The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy,” the comedic science-fiction franchise created by Douglas Adams, and the publication of a new book in the series, The Guardian reported. At Hitchcon 09, held at the Royal Festival Hall in London, fans assembled (many of them dressed in the shabby costume of the series’s hapless hero, Arthur Dent) to pay tribute to Mr. Adams, who died in 2001. He was the author of the original “Hitchhiker’s Guide” radio plays and the five-book sequence they spawned. The convention also served as a kickoff for “And Another Thing...,” a new novel by the “Artemis Fowl” author Eoin Colfer that is cheekily being billed as the sixth entry in the “Hitchhiker’s Guide” trilogy. The American edition of “And Another Thing...” was released by Hyperion on Monday.

Kanye West let the BET Hip-Hop Awards finish without interruption on Saturday by abstaining from the event, The Associated Press reported. Mr. West, who was widely criticized by fellow performers after interrupting an acceptance speech by Taylor Swift at the MTV Video Music Awards in September, had been nominated for nine awards. The rapper T.I. was also absent, as he is serving a prison sentence on a weapons conviction. But T.I.’s fiancée, Tameka Cottle, known as Tiny, attended, accepting his awards for album of the year (for “Paper Trail”) and best collaboration (for “Live Your Life” with Rihanna). Jay-Z won M.V.P. of the year, Drake was rookie of the year and Ice Cube, above, was given the “I Am Hip-Hop” Icon Award. DJ AM, who died of a drug overdose in August, was posthumously given the D.J. of the Year award. BET will broadcast the show, which was taped in Atlanta, on Oct. 27.
