More fans and admirers, above, turned out on Sunday to see Edgar Allan Poe buried for the second (and then the third) time than were present at his original funeral, The Baltimore Sun reported. Two ceremonies were held on Sunday to honor the 200th anniversary of the birth of Poe, the morbidly fixated man of letters, and drew 700 ticket holders as well as many other curious observers, some dressed in period costumes and others in T-shirts that read “Evermore!” (Fewer than 10 people were reported to have attended Poe’s first burial in 1849.) The Sun reported that a horse-drawn undertaker’s carriage delivered a coffin to Westminster Hall, where Poe was memorialized by guest speakers and actors portraying his contemporaries. The actor and author Michael N. Langford, who spoke at the services, told The Sun: “I think Edgar Allan Poe would have been bemused by it, shocked by it. But I think it was what he deserved.”.

Koch Theater, according to the company’s publicists. Mr. Wainwright will perform a number from his Judy Garland tribute, during an evening of scenes featuring works of Stravinsky, Weill, Bernstein and Gershwin. Mr. Wainwright is no stranger to opera: he wrote a French-language work, “Prima Donna,” as a commission for the Metropolitan Opera and Lincoln Center Theater, though the Met later withdrew, saying it was seeking works in English. The opera had its premiere in July in Britain.

More than a year after an explosion of sparks, soot and frigid helium shut it down, the world's biggest and most expensive physics experiment, known as the Large Hadron Collider, is poised to start up again. In December, if all goes well, protons will start smashing together in an underground racetrack outside Geneva in a search for forces and particles that reigned during the first trillionth of a second of the Big Bang. Then it will be time to test one of the most bizarre and revolutionary theories in science. I'm not talking about extra dimensions of space-time, dark matter or even black holes that eat the Earth. No, I'm talking about the notion that the troubled collider is being sabotaged by its own future. A pair of otherwise distinguished physicists have suggested that the hypothesized Higgs boson, which physicists hope to produce with the collider, might be so abhorrent to nature that its creation would ripple backward through time and stop the collider before it could make one, like a time traveler who goes back in time to kill his grandfather.

Peter J. Awn, Dean Columbia University School of General Studies

CLARKE--George P.,Advertising Pioneer and Founder of Clarke Advertising in Manhattan, died peacefully on October 10, 2009 from complications of cancer. He was a longtime resident of the Hudson Valley and Huntington, Long Island. Born in Brooklyn, New York on February 29, 1923, George Clarke, the son of Michael Henry and Mary (O'Hara) Clarke, was a WWII veteran, and a graduate of Pratt Institute. He began his noted advertising career at Remington Rand where he wrote the first computer ad for the Univac, the world's first supercomputer. George joined the J. Walter Thompson agency in 1952 where he worked with some of their most prestigious accounts, one of which was Purolator Filters. In 1965 he founded George P. Clarke Advertising, Inc. where he became a leading expert in marketing and advertising to automotive and financial clients. The agency continues to this day under the stewardship of his son, Richard A. Clarke. He was an accomplished impressionistic (oil on canvas) painter and leaves behind his life's works of art. His last work was his view of the Hudson River from his home in Rhinebeck. George will always be remembered for his wit and storytelling skills. He could never say no to a worthy cause, and donated advertising services and his original works of art to fundraising events for the Grace Smith House and the Junior League of Poughkeepsie. George was a member of the Barrett House School of Art and spent many enjoyable hours painting with Seth Nadel and his art class. He is survived by his lovely and devoted wife Juliana Ruhland-Clarke and his stepdaughter Eva-Maria (Nate) Dickinson. He is also survived by his children Betsy, Diane Delehanty (Kevin), James (Catherine), Richard (Nanci) and son Robert and their mother Judy Jones Clarke. George will be missed by brother James (Joyce) Clarke, brother-in-law to John Ruhland, sister-in-law Pierrette Ruhlnad, his grandchildren, Julia, Brian, Patrick, Eric, Maria and Nicole and many nieces and nephews. He was preceded in death by his sister, Helen, his daughter-in-law, Gigi Czechanski, and his nephew Frank Joyce. Donations may be made to the 2 BigHearts Foundation (www.2bighearts.org) and the Barrett House School of Art in Poughkeepsie, NY. A Funeral Mass will be conducted today at 10am at St. Joseph's Church, Rhinecliff, NY.

Services at Temple Sinai, Tenafly, NJ, October 13th, 12pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Mount Sinai Hospital Department of Ophthalmology, Steven M. Podos Lectureship would be appreciated; for details: 212-241-7659.

WARD--Ralph E.,88, died peacefully at Greenwich Hospital on October 7, 2009 after a brief illness. He is survived by his wife of twenty-eight years, Elaine Simon Ward of Darien, CT, and Manhattan, and his five children, Sarah Ward Hogan of Mont Vernon, NH, Richard R. Ward of River Falls, WI, Thomas D. Ward of Sarasota, FL, John B. Ward, of Darien, CT and James R. Ward of Easton, CT. from his marriage to the late Eugenia E. McManigal as well as fifteen grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Born in Scotch Plains, NJ. February 26, 1921, the only child of Margaret Reynolds Ward and Ralph E. Ward Sr. He was a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy '40 where he captained the undefeated football team of 1939. He was also a member of the varsity hockey and lacrosse teams, a member of the Senior Council, the Christian Fraternity, and the Golden Branch Debating Society. At the onset of World War II while attending Williams College, he applied to the Army Air Corps Flying Cadet program. He was commissioned and served as a USAAF fighter pilot and squadron commander in the 90th Fighter Squadron 80th Fighter Group serving two tours in the China-Burma-India Theater, flying 88 combat missions in P-40 and P-47 fighter aircraft. As of record he was awarded the Distinguished Service Cross for extraordinary heroism in connection with military operations against an armed military force on March 27, 1944. As Flight Leader of his formation with four P-40's they intercepted an enemy force of nine bombers and multiple fighters successfully destroying eight aircraft before returning to base safely. He also was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross, Air Medal with one oak leaf cluster, Distinguished Unit Citation, Asiatic Pacific Theater Ribbon with two battle stars, American Theater Ribbon and the Victory Ribbon. After the war, he attended Lafayette College where he later received an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws. While at Lafayette he was recruited by Chesebrough Manufacturing Company which became Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., as an international management trainee. He established the Australian Branch in Melbourne, Australia serving as General manager, 1948-1957. Upon returning to the United States he was appointed Vice President of the International Division, Far East. In the succeeding years he rose to become President and Chief Executive Officer in May, 1968, and was elected to the additional post of Chairman of the Board in May, 1976 serving in those positions for 19 years until his retirement in 1987. He was a former Director of The Chase Manhattan Corporation and The Chase Manhattan Bank, N.A., Stauffer Chemical Company, CPC Inc., and the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., and a member of the Lafayette College Board of Trustees, the Board of Govenors of Ford's Theater Society, Washington, DC, The Economic Club of New York, The Conference Board, The Business Roundtable, and The American Australian Association. He was the first corporate sponsor of the Jackie Robinson Foundation, and in 1989 established the Ralph E. Ward Achievement Award which he gave annually to recognize the graduating JRF Scholar with the highest cumulative grade point average. An avid golfer, he was a member of Victoria Golf Club, Melbourne, Australia, Milbrook Club, Greenwich, CT, Winged Foot Golf Club, Mamaroneck, NY, Wee Burn Country Club, Darien, CT, Wentworth Club, Virginia Water, UK. As well he was a member of The Tokeneke Club, Darien, CT, The Union League Club, NY, and Coral Beach & Tennis Club, Bermuda. Funeral services will be private. He will be buried at Arlington National Cemetery with full military honors. He was admired, respected and loved by all in his family. He will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in his memory to one of the following: St. Vincent's Medical Center Foundation, Ronald J. Bianchi, President/CEO, 2800 Main Street, Bridgeport, CT 06606 for the "Elaine S. & Ralph E. Ward Endowment Fund" for Cardiac Services; or Greenwich Hospital, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT 06830 for the Oncology Fund, Dickerman Hollister, Jr., MD, Head Hematology/Oncology; or Philips Exeter Academy, Gift Recording, Exeter, NH 03833.

Militants on Monday launched their fourth assault in a week on strategic targets across Pakistan, this time with a suicide car bombing against a military vehicle in a crowded market in the northwest, killing 41 people and wounding dozens more. The bombing took place in the Shangla District, an area within the Swat Valley but under separate administration. The Pakistani military had declared the valley cleared of militants after an offensive this summer and announced that the Taliban were a shattered force.

A proposed tax on high-cost, or ''Cadillac,'' health insurance plans has touched off a fierce clash between the Senate and the House as they wrestle over how to pay for legislation that would provide health benefits to millions of uninsured Americans. Supporters, including many senators, say that the tax is essential to tamping down medical spending and that over 10 years it would generate more than $200 billion, nearly a fourth of what is needed to pay for the legislation.

The new aid package for Pakistan passed by Congress last month -- a promise of $7.5 billion for civilian needs over the next five years -- has unwittingly thrust the United States into the center of the perennially uneasy relationship between Pakistan's powerful military and its weak civilian governments. In this case, the United States stepped into the middle of what politicians describe as a deteriorating relationship between the head of the army, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, and President Asif Ali Zardari, by insisting on greater civilian oversight of the military as a condition of the aid.

Lemon Andersen says the word ''drive'' as if it were holy. Of course he doesn't mean it in the sense of what people do in cars or on golf courses. ''Drive,'' a noun that stuck and grew in Mr. Andersen's mind when he heard it uttered by a demanding teacher in a children's ballet class, means ambition, discipline and ruling passion. It is a force powerful enough to propel a teenage crack dealer from poverty in Brooklyn to a solo spotlight on a stage at the Public Theater. That's where ''County of Kings,'' Mr. Andersen's gleaming stand-up memoir, opened on Monday night. Seen in an earlier version at the Public as part of the Under the Radar Festival in January, this one-man show has since acquired a formidable team of producers, including the filmmaker Spike Lee, and a seriously enhanced focus, precision and polish. For Mr. Andersen, drive has clearly been a god worth serving.

HERLANDS--James Owen, 67. Jim was a business leader and President of PhibroChem. For almost 50 years, his business knowledge, sense of humor, winning smile and breadth of interests were evident in all he did. Jim was equally at home discussing the products, the P&L, the Arts, or the day-to-day challenges of raising children. He was known in the industry as a "true gentleman" with a fair-minded approach in dealing with all. He had an eye for talent, an open door, and was a gifted mentor. He listened carefully, and willingly offered sage advice and counsel. The swordfish mounted on Jim's office wall and the many pictures of his family at various stages of life were visible signs of his love of life and family. Those of us who worked with him are both grateful for the privilege and deeply saddened by his passing. All his friends at PhibroChem and Phibro Animal Health Corporation.

PODOS--Steven M.,MD. Dr. Dalia Nagel and Dr. Julius Shulman deeply mourn the passing of their revered colleague. Dr. Podos, former Chairman of the Department of Ophthalmology at New York's Mount Sinai Hospital, was the consummate teacher, researcher and clinician. As one of the world's experts on glaucoma, Dr. Podos lectured all over the world, but always returned to his first love, teaching his residents the nuances of glaucoma diagnosis and management. His knowledge of the glaucoma literature was encyclopedic, and more than once he was caught quoting a footnote in some obscure foreign journal. He was notorious for almost unattainable high standards of patient care and a zealous love of learning, all lovingly hammered into his residents over three years of training. We, and his patients, are in his debt and will miss him dearly. Dalia Nagel, MD Julius Shulman, MD

MORRISON--James C.,Jr., 76, a long time resident of Short Hills, NJ and in later years, Summit, NJ, died Thursday, October 8 while attending a benefit golf outing for his favorite charity, the Marine Corps Scholarship Foundation in Little Silver, NJ of which he was co-chairman. This is coincidentally the same time three years ago that his wife of 53 years, Elizabeth, died when he was also attending the Marine Corps benefit. The cause of death was congestive heart failure. Jim Morrison graduated from the Hill School, Pottstown, PA and Babson College, Boston in 1955, and then served in the Marine Corps for four years. For more than 50 years, he was one of the most well-known, if not legendary, figures in Wall Street financial circles, a member of the Bond Club, the Downtown Athletic Club and other associations. His career in institutional sales reads like a chronicle of Wall Street firms that merged into the pages of history. He began his career at Shearson Hamill & Co., then was a founder of Andreson & Co. From there he went on to Harris Upham & Co., and later to First Boston Corp. where his Father had been Executive Vice President for many years. Following that, Jim became Vice President Sales at Donaldson, Lufkin, & Jenrette for 27 years. In the last nine years, after DLJ was acquired by Credit Suisse, he was a Senior Vice President Institutional Sales at Gilford Securities in Manhattan. Above all, he was a family man, a devoted and loving Father to Elizabeth M. Cantrell of Washington, DC and Carolyn Payne, loving Grandfather of Charlotte Payne, Potomac Falls, VA, and brother and friend to Bruce H. Morrison, Chatham, NJ and Douglas Morrison of Atlanta, GA.; also, his sisters, Ann Winsor and Joan Beard of Washington, DC. Jim was a Board member of Squadron A Association in New York and a lifelong member of the Baltusrol Golf Club, Springfield, NJ where he was a frequent golfer and stalwart of the gin rummy table. His friends think of Jim as one of the most endearing characters to grace this part of the world, a man of great loyalty to friends in the East and across the country. Always generous of spirit, he was very kind, with a whimsical sense of humor that pervaded all his conversations. He could--and did--tell stories, good ones, on himself and others, a source of endless laughter and fun. As the larger-than-life man about town that he was, Jim Morrison was loved by many, and leaves a void in the lives of those who knew him. He will be greatly, greatly missed. A memorial service will be held Friday, November 6 at Christ Church of Short Hills. For further information or to send the family a condolence, visit: bradleyfuneralhomes.com. Those who wish to remember him may send contributions to the Marine Corps Scholarship Foundation, NJ Chapter, P.O. Box 245, Little Silver, NJ.

The Democratic National Committee had to backpedal over the weekend, canceling plans to run a television commercial that trumpeted the support of some big-name Republicans for a health care overhaul after one of them, former Senator Bob Dole, protested that the spot was misleading. But other Democratic allies were still using Mr. Dole's name. Such mentions could give political cover to wavering legislators to support an overhaul.

For two months Ehsan Maleki traveled around Iran with a backpack containing his cameras, a few pieces of clothing and his laptop computer, taking pictures of the reformist candidate Mir Hussein Moussavi during the presidential campaign. He did not know that his backpack and his cameras would soon become his only possessions, or that he would be forced to crawl out of the country hiding in a herd of sheep. Mr. Maleki, 29, is one of dozens of reporters, photographers and bloggers who have either fled Iran or are trying to flee in the aftermath of the disputed June presidential election. Reporters Without Borders, a Paris-based organization that promotes press freedom and monitors the safety of journalists, said the number of journalists leaving Iran was the largest since the years after the 1979 Islamic Revolution.

ARNOLD--John Bentley, died at age 87 in his home in San Francisco where he had been residing since 1980. Jack was born in Quincy, IL in 1922. He attended Phillips Academy Andover, graduated from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and immediately joined the Navy as one of its early radar experts. He served on the Aircraft Carrier USS Hancock, finally leaving the ship, as a Lt. Commander, after it was disabled by kamikaze pilots on Okinawa. After the war Jack graduated from Harvard Business School. He served for 30 years with General Telephone and Electronics. As President of GTE International he was responsible for an organization with 35,000 employees throughout the world. During his presidency GTE International sales grew from $500 million to $1.3 billion. He was the architect and mediator of a number of important multinational consortiums that completed telecommunication projects all over the world. He worked with countless nationalities and religions. He lived in Italy for 25 years, was in Tehran the day the Shah took power from Mossadegh, and was there again the day the Shah was deposed by Khomeini. Jack worked in partnership with members of the Israeli, Egyptian, Algerian and, Indian government, to mention a few, and formed enduring bonds of friendship based on mutual trust and respect. His encyclopedic knowledge of history, his keen and sensitive curiosity of other cultures and religions and his open, sensitive and dependable nature fostered a deep trust that allowed very difficult international partnerships to flourish. He worked as consultant with Comsat in Washington, DC for two years; and, in 1980 came to California as President of Farinon Electric Company, later sold to Harris Corporation of Florida. He was subsequently appointed to various Boards of Directors in California and served as interim president of Equipment Technology. He was a devout Catholic and a great supporter of Catholic Charities. In San Francisco, he was active with the Rose Resnik Center for the Blind and served on its Board of Directors. He is survived by his wife Ann to whom he was married for 57 years, by his sons Peter and Stephen Arnold, and his daughter Susan Arnold-Aldea, his son-in-law Gabriel Aldea, and two grandsons, Alexander and Daniel Aldea all of whom will always be guided by his wisdom and generosity.

The Parnas-Serkin Trio embodies the ethos of the Marlboro Music Festival in Vermont, at which established musicians nurture, and perform with, their younger counterparts. The pianist Peter Serkin -- a son of the pianist Rudolf Serkin and grandson of the violinist Adolf Busch, two of the festival's founders -- is mentoring the violinist Madalyn Parnas and the cellist Cicely Parnas, teenage sisters who are themselves granddaughters of the noted cellist Leslie Parnas. Mr. Serkin started coaching the Duo Parnas in 2007 and soon began playing chamber music with them in public, as he did on Saturday evening at Washington Irving High School, in a well-attended event in the Peoples' Symphony Concerts series, which offers brand-name soloists and ensembles at recession-proof prices at halls around the city.

The children of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. settled a longstanding dispute over the slain civil rights leader's estate, a lawyer for the corporation that runs the estate said. A lawsuit pitted Bernice King and Martin Luther King III against Dexter King, the president of the corporation, King Inc. They had accused Dexter King of excluding them from the decisions about the corporation and of refusing to hold shareholder meetings since 2004. A jury trial was set to begin soon, threatening to reveal details about the inner-workings of the corporation. Lin Wood, the lawyer for King Inc., said the siblings had agreed not to discuss the details of the settlement.

The Glenn Gould Foundation has awarded its main prize to José Antonio Abreu, the founder of a music education project for poor children in Venezuela called El Sistema, which has spread around the world. The Glenn Gould Prize carries with it an award of about $48,600. The foundation said Mr. Abreu, who is often lionized for his work in establishing a network of music instruction and orchestras, would donate the money to buy new musical instruments for his school in Caracas. Yamaha said it would add about another $97,000 worth of instruments.

The Metropolitan Opera said that Maria Gavrilova will sing the title role in Wednesday evening’s performance of Puccini’s “Tosca.” She is replacing Karita Mattila, who is ill, the Met said in a news release. Ms. Gavrilova, a Russian soprano, made her Met debut in 2007, when she sang the title role of “Madama Butterfly” as a substitute for Patricia Racette. Ms. Mattila is still scheduled to sing “Tosca” on Saturday, the Met said.

The artistic director of the Skylight Opera Theater in Milwaukee, whose firing over the summer triggered waves of resignations and protests from artists and donors who supported him, will return to the theater in his original position. In a news release on Wednesday, the theater said that it had reappointed William Theisen as its artistic director effective immediately through June 30, 2011. In June, the theater said that it was eliminating five positions there including the job of artistic director, which Mr. Theisen had held since 2004; his duties were consolidated under the general director, Eric Dillner, a former opera tenor. Several weeks of turmoil followed as other actors and directors quit the theater and donors threatened to withhold funding, after which Mr. Dillner resigned in August. In its statement, the theater said that Mr. Theisen would direct up to two shows next season, reflecting a program he will plan with the outgoing interim artistic director, Colin Cabot.

Kiss cannot be happy with Michael Bublé right now. Last week, Kiss, the veteran costumed rock band, released “Sonic Boom,” its first CD of new music in 11 years, and with little serious competition it seemed destined to become the band’s first No. 1 album. But then Mr. Bublé, the Canadian traditional-pop singer, changed the release date of his new album, “Crazy Love.” It had been scheduled for Tuesday, but with an appearance last Friday on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” — always a huge sales driver — his label, Reprise, put it out four days early, and his sales eclipsed Kiss’s. “Crazy Love” moved 132,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, opening at No. 1 on Billboard’s chart, and “Sonic Boom,” released on the band’s Kiss Records label and available only at Wal-Mart, sold 108,000.

PARIS — A French lawyer for the jailed director Roman Polanski said that his client would not only guarantee to remain in Switzerland under house arrest at his villa in Gstaad if released from jail, but would post his property and a substantial amount of money as bail and agree to wear an ankle bracelet and visit police officials every day.
Every network looks to book talent first: NBC Universal is taking the concept to a new level with the singer Jon Bon Jovi.

In an article on Wednesday my colleague Sam Roberts wrote about nearly two dozen grants given by the Leon Levy Foundation to put historical archives online. The New York Philharmonic is one of the institutions receiving money, $2.4 million in its case. One of the most interesting items from the orchestra’s vast archive that will be in the first batch to be digitized is Mahler’s own 1909 score of his First Symphony, marked by him and then with additional notations by Leonard Bernstein 50 years later.

SAN FRANCISCO — Sandra Bernhard took the stage for her new show at the Rrazz Room here Tuesday night wearing a stylish black cocktail dress with a plunging neckline. Backed by a three-piece band, she launched into a cover of Melanie’s “Beautiful People,” a seemingly sincere, plaintive ballad from the flower-child 1960s that laments the social distance among strangers and the difficulty people have in embracing humankind. It was a cabaret-style beginning, sort of warm and socially acceptable, not what you expect from Ms. Bernhard, ordinarily more of a flaming provocateur. So it was almost reassuring when, little by little, the presentation turned satiric and sneering and familiarly misanthropic.
Gravitación? The Spirit of Gambo? Asteria? Apollo’s Fire? These are not science fantasy titles or laws of nature or vines growing up your house.

Jane Lynch has been a marginal presence on “Glee” the last few weeks, but she should figure more prominently in Wednesday night’s episode (Fox, 9 p.m.) when Sue Sylvester becomes co-director of the glee club.

SAN FRANCISCO — McSweeney’s Quarterly Concern, the 11-year-old literary journal published out of the pleasantly untidy back room of a retail store in the Mission district here, is known, among other things, for experimenting with both content and packaging. Its most recent installment, No. 32, is a hardbound volume of commissioned short stories all set in the year 2024.

You can’t drink Patio diet cola anymore and you probably shouldn’t smoke in your office, but you can still live the “Mad Men” lifestyle by dressing in a new Brooks Brothers suit that is officially endorsed by that hit AMC drama. On Wednesday, Brooks Brothers announced that it would begin selling a limited-edition “Mad Men” suit, designed with the help of the show’s costume designer, Janie Bryant, and inspired by the tailoring favored by Don Draper and Roger Sterling. In a news release, Brooks Brothers said that the hand-finished, American-made suit is made from gray sharkskin fabric and its two-button jacket features narrow lapels, diagonal pockets and side vents. The suit will be on sale from Oct. 19 through Nov. 8 (the date of the “Mad Men” season finale, by the way) and retails for $998 — perfect for those late-night drives when you might run into your daughter’s grade-school teacher.

Bob Dylan‘s holiday CD, “Christmas in the Heart,” was released on Tuesday, and technically you’ve still got two more months to decide whether or not to stuff it in that special someone’s stocking. If you’re still on the fence, you can read reviews of the CD in The Washington Post and in USA Today. Or this cover of Hal Moore and Bill Fredricks’s “Must Be Santa,” rapidly performed by Mr. Dylan, may help you make up your mind:

New York City Ballet, the Joyce Theater Foundation and the New School are among the 18 cultural organizations that have won the Rockefeller Foundation‘s annual New York City Cultural Innovation Fund competition, the foundation said on Wednesday. The winning groups receive grants that range from $50,000 to $250,000, for a total of $2.7 million, which will be awarded over a two-year period. City Ballet will use its grant to commission new ballets for a set designed by the architect Santiago Calatrava; the Joyce Theater Foundation will put its money toward residencies to support projects that combine theater and dance; and the New School will use its funds for a design and public policy partnership that will research and promote community-based solutions for sustainability. Other winners include the Queens Council on the Arts, which is planning an interactive cellphone cultural map for the No. 7 subway line.

Every Broadway musical reported stronger ticket sales for performances last week (Oct. 5-11) compared to the previous one, according to figures released by the Broadway League on Tuesday afternoon, indicating relief from the traditional theatergoing doldrums of early fall. Which leads one to wonder: With “Hair” and “West Side Story” having already recouped their entire start-up investments, what other musical from the 2008-9 season will be next to recoup: “Billy Elliot,” “Next to Normal,” Rock of Ages” or “Shrek”? And, while we’re at it, will any of these four close before recoupment?

Slowly but surely, ABC is adding to its collection of vagabond “Friends” alumni. The Hollywood Reporter said the network had acquired a new comedy series created by and set to star Matthew Perry, who played the more-sarcastic-than-thou roommate Chandler on “Friends.” In the new show, which does not yet have a title, Mr. Perry would play the manager of a sports arena who takes stock of his life after he turns 40. (Mr. Perry himself reached this milestone on Aug. 19.) Among the other bidders for the series, The Hollywood Reporter said, was NBC, which broadcast “Friends” from 1994 to 2004. ABC is also home to the Courteney Cox sitcom “Cougar Town,” which was recently picked up for a full season. Matt LeBlanc is committed to a new series of his own for Showtime and the BBC, but Jennifer Aniston, Lisa Kudrow, David Schwimmer and the actor who played Gunther the coffee-shop barista are still up for grabs.

Being $6.8 million in debt and struggling with diminished fund-raising, leaders of the Shakespeare & Company theater in Lenox, Mass., announced on Tuesday afternoon that they were cutting jobs, restructuring the theater’s business model, and taking other steps in hopes of shoring up its year-round productions and education programs.

My Thursday column returns to education reform, a topic I've become more interested in over the last couple of years. My interest arose largely from the more rigorous research in recent years that has pointed to several findings: The most important force buttressing economic growth in the long run is the caliber of mass education; the most important escalator out of poverty is education; what matters most in education is teacher quality. One of the best books in recent years made some of these points -- "The Race Between Education and Technology" by two Harvard economists.

Reality programs remain the backbone of many cable channels, but apparently there really can been too much of them. The Fox Reality cable channel got a cancellation notice late Wednesday from its parent company, Fox Networks Group.

The United States tied Costa Rica, 2-2, at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in Washington on Wednesday night in its final qualifying game. A couple of talking points to get you through the night.

For years, many environmental groups and experts on the growing human contribution to the planet's heat-trapping greenhouse effect have sought to turn carbon dioxide into a commodity by giving it a rising price. Through a so-called cap and trading system, those making extra-deep cuts in emissions can profit by selling what amounts to their extra credit to those who cannot afford to cut their own gas releases so deeply or quickly.

Behind closed doors during their most recent meeting, members of the Federal Reserve grappled with whether they should expand a crucial program aimed at loosening credit markets, or begin to scale it back as the economy clawed its way back from recession.

Served up at a banquet at the Ritz-Carlton in Washington tonight: Another remembrance of the life of Senator Edward M. Kennedy and another presidential plug for passage of a comprehensive health care bill.

One day after the N.F.L. commissioner, Roger Goodell, said that Rush Limbaugh's bid to buy the St. Louis Rams would receive little support from N.F.L. ownership, Mr. Limbaugh was dropped from the group of investors hoping to buy the team, The New York Times's Judy Battista reported.

On a misty spring night in 2005, I approached my apartment, on a tony block on the Upper West Side facing the Hudson. I felt relaxed and calm. Earlier that day I had attended a yoga workshop with a guru from India, then completed a writing assignment for a health and spirituality magazine about, as it happened, instinct - or antar-jñana, inner knowledge. I opened the outer door to my vestibule, then crossed through its inner door and into my lobby, leaving my back to the entrance. I got a prickly feeling, I don't know why. I turned. There I saw, pushing open the inner door, an ink-black, gloved hand, exaggeratedly large, controlled and deliberate. It charged toward me. It was trailed by a body, the picture of death.It is difficult for me to render the horror of the image of that man entering my building lobby that night, so great is the disparity between its emotional charge for me now and the stereotypical, almost comical picture he presented. He was a figment from a nightmare. I guessed his height and weight at 6'3" and 230 pounds, with the physicality of a boxer. The cops later told me that was right. His clothes were dark and innocuous - clean black jeans, black sneakers, a midnight-blue hoodie - as if chosen to leave no impression whatsoever. In contrast, on his face was a neoprene thermal ski mask, the type that tents in front to create a ridge and thus evokes to most anyone who's heard of him Darth Vader. I later discovered while searching on Google that this type of mask is favored by shoppers also enamored of vigilante-style military clothing and toy AK-47s - in other words it is meant to provoke a reaction. Of the figure's actual face I saw only slit-shaped, yellowed eyes and a broad, acned, coal-black forehead.

Writing and reading -- from newspapers to novels, academic reports to gossip magazines -- are migrating ever faster to digital screens, like laptops, Kindles and cellphones. Traditional book publishers are putting out "vooks," which place videos in electronic text that can be read online or on an iPhone. Others are republishing old books in electronic form. And libraries, responding to demand, are offering more e-books for download.

Clue fans bored with Colonel Mustard with the lead pipe can now move beyond the mansion with CLUE: Secrets & Spies, an international espionage edition of the classic detective game. My colleague Dan Frosch reports that Colorado plans to lower its state minimum wage -- and not because officials think the minimum wage is hurting employment (the usual argument for lowering the floor). Similarly, the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities projects that next year will be the first year in three decades that Social Security checks do not increase -- and not because officials think Social Security obligations are costing taxpayers too much money (the usual argument for reining in entitlements).

With loftlike living and low rent, Bushwick, Brooklyn, has become the urban equivalent of Yaddo, albeit with more broken glass on the street and bedbugs in the couches. But even as creative output outpaced SoHo and Chelsea, Morgantown - as the small development of lofts amid concrete factories off the Morgan Avenue L stop is known - offered little in the way of edible nourishment. Things got better when Roberta's opened in 2008, feeding famished creatives wood-fired pizza and lamb breast, and again with the arrivals of the Archive, a cafe serving bagels, and Brooklyn Natural, an overpriced gourmet deli. But for those suffering from pizza fatigue, writer's block and thin wallet syndrome, lunchtime was the bleakest hour.

Two recent experiments hit rather close to home at this time of year. In the first, published last year in the journal Brain, Behavior, and Immunity, researchers divided mice into two groups. One rested comfortably in their cages. The other ran on little treadmills until they were exhausted. This continued for three days. The mice were then exposed to an influenza virus. After a few days, more of the mice who'd exhausted themselves running came down with the flu than the control mice. They also had more severe symptoms.

A stray fingerprint is not something you generally want to find on a valuable artwork — unless Leonardo da Vinci left it there. An art historian and a forensic art expert are among those saying that a fingerprint detected in a portrait, above, shows that it is the work of Leonardo, and not an early-19th-century German work as previously categorized, Antiques Trade Gazette reported. The work — a chalk, pen and ink portrait on vellum — was sold in 2007 for about $19,000 to a collector who took it to Martin Kemp, an emeritus professor of art history at Oxford University. Mr. Kemp, with the help of the forensic analyst Peter Paul Biro, found a fingerprint near the top of the work that they say is “highly comparable” to one found on Leonardo’s painting of St. Jerome in the Vatican. A chalk palm print in the neck of the portrait’s subject, believed to be the daughter of a 15th-century Milanese duke, is another piece of evidence the experts say supports the case that the work is by Leonardo.
The aspiring singers on “Glee” will have more time to practice for regional competitions now.

A Richard Prince room has reopened at the Tate Modern museum in London without a nude photograph of the actress Brooke Shields that drew the attention of the police, Bloomberg News reported. The Tate Modern was to show Mr. Prince’s photograph “Spiritual America” as part of its program Pop Life: Art in a Material World, but closed it after Scotland Yard warned that the photograph, taken of Ms. Shields when she was 10, could violate obscenity laws. The picture, included in an exhibition of Prince works at the Guggenheim Museum in 2007, was taken by Mr. Prince from another photograph made by Gary Gross in 1976 and authorized by Ms. Shields’s mother, Teri Shields. The Tate Modern said the photograph had been replaced with another of Brooke Shields as an adult, dressed in a bikini and leaning against a motorbike. The museum added that the change was made “in consultation with the artist.”.

The Santa Fe Opera’s plan to drill for oil and gas in two New Mexico counties is meeting with resistance from local residents, The Associated Press reported. In 2002 the Santa Fe Opera received permission to drill on nearly 27,000 acres in Mora and San Miguel counties as part of a bequest from a donor, who wanted any revenue to be used to support an apprentice program for young singers. More recently residents learned that in April the opera company signed a lease with an independent company that acquires leases on behalf of oil and gas producers. Opponents say the drilling will harm water, air, wildlife and agriculture in the area. “To see an art company sell out the environment, that was a very egregious act as far as I was concerned,” Kathleen Dudley, the co-chairwoman of the watchdog group Drilling Mora County, told The A.P. Charles MacKay, the general director of the opera, said it would seek a resolution that would address its opponents’ concerns.

Back in 2006 when Junichiro Koizumi, below, then the prime minister of Japan, serenaded President George W. Bush with “Love Me Tender” at Graceland, he laid the groundwork for a career in show business. On the next step in his transition from politics to entertainment, Mr. Koizumi will lend his voice to a Japanese action movie, Agence France-Presse reported. In the film, “Mega Monster Battle: Ultra Galaxy Legends,” the latest entry in the long-running “Ultraman” franchise, Mr. Koizumi plays an extraterrestrial hero who battles outer-space monsters with flashing lights and a battle cry of “Pay for your transgression!” Mr. Koizumi had planned to turn down the role, but was encouraged to accept it by his son Shinjiro, who took over his seat in Parliament. “No one else can play this significant role,” said Junko Kitazawa of Tsuburaya Productions, which is releasing the film in Japan on Dec. 12.

Michael Jackson’s posthumous new song “This Is It” could prove a significant payday for Paul Anka, near right. Though the song had been advertised as an unheard recording left behind by Mr. Jackson — and written by him alone — it became clear after it was released on Sunday night that it had been written by Mr. Jackson, far right, and Mr. Anka 26 years ago and recorded by the singer Safire in 1991 as “I Never Heard.” On Monday afternoon the Jackson estate acknowledged Mr. Anka’s role, and on Tuesday also confirmed that Mr. Anka would receive half of all due royalties for the song, which could be substantial. The song will play over the end credits of the film “This Is It” and is featured on the soundtrack. In addition, Mr. Anka would be owed fees for any licensed use of the song in commercials or other films. The Jackson estate is said to be in talks with Coca-Cola about possible use of “This Is It” in an ad campaign, according to people with knowledge of the discussion who were not authorized to speak about it.

SCHNELL--Seymour, 91. With his brother he owned a business that took them to all parts of the globe for over 50 years, delighting in introducing foods from different corners of the world to people elsewhere. As we mourn his passing, we hold dear and celebrate the memory of his having lived life to its fullest, his love for family and friends, and his generosity of spirit, warmth, intelligence, dignity, enthusiasm and energy. 7 P.M. (HBO) TELL THEM ANYTHING YOU WANT: A PORTRAIT OF MAURICE SENDAK In 1964 Mr. Sendak's ''Where the Wild Things Are'' won the Caldecott Medal for the most distinguished picture book of the year -- and almost overnight became a bedtime classic. On Friday the filmmaker Spike Jonze (''Being John Malkovich'') will bring the book's wolf-suited protagonist, Max, and its fearsome menagerie to the big screen. In this documentary from Mr. Jonze and Lance Bangs, filmed at Mr. Sendak's Connecticut home and studio beginning in 2003, the writer and illustrator, above, now 81, muses on the things that inspired his creations, from his difficult relationship with his parents and his bond with his older siblings, to his fascination with death. He also reveals his philosophy about communicating with children. ''Tell them anything you want,'' he says. ''If it's true, you tell them.'' The film features photographs from Mr. Sendak's early childhood and excerpts from his sometimes controversial works, including ''In the Night Kitchen,'' which features drawings of a naked boy and was No. 25 on the American Library Association's list of the 100 most frequently challenged books from 1990 to 2000. 8 P.M. (13); 9:30 P.M. (49) JOAN BAEZ: HOW SWEET THE SOUND Ms. Baez made her debut at the Newport Folk Festival in 1959; on Aug. 2 she returned to celebrate its 50th anniversary. Filmed during her recent world tour, this ''American Masters'' documentary chronicles the private life and public career of Ms. Baez, who came to symbolize the social movement of the 1960s. The program includes her reunion with Vaclav Havel in Slovakia and a collaboration with Steve Earle in Nashville, while Bob Dylan, David Crosby, Roger McGuinn, Bonnie Raitt, Jackson Browne and the Rev. Jesse Jackson weigh in.

Josh Gibson was one of the best baseball players ever, a catcher who hit as many as 800 home runs and was voted into the National Baseball Hall of Fame in 1972, the second year that Negro Leaguers were inducted. His life off the field was less well known. More often than not, Gibson has been characterized as a drunk and a drug user who was haunted by not making it to the major leagues with Jackie Robinson. Gibson was 35 when he died Jan. 20, 1947, three months before Robinson first took the field for the Brooklyn Dodgers.

N.F.L. coaches are copycats by nature. But it may be a long time before someone copies the trend that swept training camp this summer: firing the offensive coordinator on the eve of the season. The three teams that did it -- the Buffalo Bills, the Kansas City Chiefs and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers -- are a combined 1-14.

French prosecutors announced Tuesday that they had begun a preliminary investigation into several teams at this year's Tour de France to determine if riders had used performance-enhancing drugs or methods. Prosecutors in Paris told The Associated Press that medical equipment collected from teams during the three-week race included ''suspicious'' material, which was seized. Under French law, a preliminary investigation is done to determine if a formal investigation is warranted. A spokeswoman for the Paris prosecutors said the medical equipment was being analyzed ''to determine whether we can find illegal substances and DNA that could possibly link it to riders,'' the A.P. reported.

The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

The sound and vibration of a boat engine make the fish fly. The Illinois River and other waterways flowing into the Mississippi have become infested with invasive Asian fish species, commonly called silver carp, which can turn a leisurely ride on a johnboat into the aquatic version of the running of the bulls. The carp jump out of the water by the hundreds, sometimes soaring 10 feet in the air and often landing in the boat. They have loosened fishermen's teeth, broken their jaws and left them scarred.

von BOTHMER--Dietrich. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn deeply the loss of longtime colleague and friend Dietrich von Bothmer, eminent curator and scholar of classical art. In a career spanning more than six decades in the Museum's Department of Greek and Roman Art, he rose from Assistant Curator in 1946 to Curator in 1959, Chairman in 1973, and Distinguished Research Curator in 1990. He was renowned for his discerning eye as well as his wide-ranging knowledge. As a teacher, he imparted his skills to younger scholars, and with the colleagues in his own department, he was responsible for enhancing greatly the depth, quality, and study of the collections under his care. With his wife Joyce, he was a generous benefactor to the Museum, donating works of art; funds for curatorial salaries, fellowships, and acquisitions; and support for the renovation and reinstallation of the New Greek and Roman Galleries. It is in that recently completed suite of galleries that the two principal rooms for classical pottery bear the Bothmer family name. Dietrich's brilliance, droll wit, and dedication to the Metropolitan Museum will be remembered for many years to come, and we extend our deepest condolences to Joyce, Maria, Bernard, and their entire family. James R. Houghton, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director Emily K. Rafferty, President

WEINSTEIN--Seymour, born August 30, 1924 in NYC, passed away from multiple myeloma, Monday, October 12, 2009. He was in the first four-year graduating class of Bronx High School of Science. After serving as a Lieutenant in the Army Air Corps during World War II, he graduated from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute with a BS in Engineering in 1948. That year, he married Lorraine Crystal, and they enjoyed 61 happy years together. Mr. Weinstein, with two partners, founded Royal Zenith Corp., a major importer and seller of graphic arts machinery. He served as President of the corporation. After going public, Royal Zenith was subsequently sold to Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corp. Until his retirement, Mr. Weinstein was a respected board member of NPES, in Reston, Virginia. He was an accomplished fisherman, skier and tennis player, skiing at Snowbird, Utah and playing tennis at The Racquet Club at Old Westbury (of which he was a founding member) right up until his 85th year. Mr. Weinstein loved opera, ballet and theater, and was an avid reader of history. He brought his wonderful sense of humor, warmth and intellect to all situations. He will be greatly missed by his devoted and loving wife, Lorraine, two children, Cliff and Wendy, their spouses Ann and Andy, and four grandchildren, Jake and Julia Seltzer and Chris and Daniel Weinstein.

von BOTHMER--Dr. Dietrich, 90, died peacefully in his sleep on Monday, October 12, in Manhattan. The Metropolitan Museum's of Art's legendary curator, archaeologist, and historian of classical art is survived by his devoted wife of 43 years, Joyce Blaffer von Bothmer; his son Bernard Nicholas von Bothmer and his wife, Jane, of San Francisco; his daughter Maria Elizabeth Villalba and her husband, Jerome, of New York; and his five adoring grandchildren: Isabel, Victoria, and Charles Villalba, and Athena and Tatiana von Bothmer. Dr. von Bothmer was born on October 26, 1918, in Eisenach, Germany, and in 1938 was awarded the last of that year's two German Rhodes Scholarships before World War Two, allowing him to flee the Nazi dictatorship which he opposed and detested. At Oxford, he studied under Sir John Beazley, earning a diploma in 1939 in Classical Archaeology. Over the next thirty years, he worked closely with Beazley to build up the great works on Attic Black and Red-figure Vase-Painters that changed the way scholars thought about Greek art. And for the rest of his life, he was acknowledged as perhaps the finest connoisseur of Greek vase-painting in the world. While visiting museums in the United States in the summer of 1939 for what was meant to be but a three month stay, World War Two began, preventing Dietrich from returning to Europe. Through a network of generous scholarships and fellowships, he was able to continue his studies at the University of California, Berkeley (interrupted by a brief fellowship at the University of Chicago), where he earned his Ph.D. in 1944. Though not yet a citizen, Dietrich volunteered for the U.S. Army and fought heroically in the South Pacific. There he was awarded both the Bronze Star and the Purple Heart for carrying, while wounded, a fellow soldier back to safety five miles through heavily fortified Japanese lines. Subsequently, he received U.S. citizenship, and in 1946 was appointed a curatorial assistant in the department of Greek and Roman art at the Metropolitan, where he remained for 64 years until his death. He was named curator in 1959, department chairman in 1973, and in 1990 Distinguished Research Curator. In 1965 he began teaching at the Institute of Fine Arts, N.Y.U. Dietrich was the recipient of numerous awards and citations, including a Chevalier de la Legion d'Honneur; a member of the Academie Francaise (one of only two Americans to have this honor); an honorary fellow of Wadham College; and several honorary doctorates. The author of a number of standard monographs and hundreds of articles and reviews, he was a wonderful mentor to his students and a devoted teacher. We will all greatly miss his generosity of spirit, his philanthropic ethos, his unparalleled intellect, his endless passion for Greek antiquities, his unquenchable thirst for knowledge, his encyclopedic knowledge of the history of Western Civilization, his zest for verbal sparring, and his enormous joie de vivre. His passing has left a gaping hole. A true lion has been lost: a polyglot, a patriarch, a patriot, an optimist, a genius. Family will receive friends on Thursday from 2-4 and 6-8pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue. Funeral services will be held at 11am on Friday, October 16, at St. James' Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street.

CAMHI--Joseph. The Sephardic Temple of Cedarhurst, NY records with deep regret the passing of Joseph Camhi, Honorary Life Trustee, Past President and Founder of the Congregation, and a very proud Jew committed to the Sephardic tradition. Humble of spirit, generous of heart he was a gentleman and a congregant beloved by his fellow worshippers. A human being of extraordinary dimension he served our Congregation with consummate enterprise and indefatigable effort involving himself in every aspect of leadership and accomplishment. Patriarch of a most distinguished extended family, he exhibited love and respect to all who entered the shadow of his being. He envisioned the need of establishing a Sephardic Temple Endowment Fund and during these last years successfully persuaded the Congregation to join in this project which will contribute to the prosperity of his beloved Sephardic Temple. His departure has created a vacuum in our midst. Heartfelt condolences to his wife Reggie, children Donna, Sydel, Stanley, Rita, and brother Lewis, and to his entire family. HERLANDS--James O. Aunt Els, the seven B's and their families deeply mourn the untimely passing of our very dear nephew and cousin, Jimmy. As Monopoly games and fishing gave way to working together and building families, we continually relished Jim's fun-loving goodness, creative wit, solid principles and deep loyalty to family. We will greatly miss this beloved and courageous man who lived his life -- and imbued our lives -- with a smile. Min Hashamayim Tenuchamu. The Bendheim Family

The government collapsed Tuesday after a vote of no confidence, further undermining the economy of a country severely buffeted by the global financial crisis. The toppling of Prime Minister Emil Boc's centrist government -- the first time a government in Romania has been dismissed since the fall of Communism in 1989 -- reinforced the sense of political upheaval in Eastern and Central Europe, where the governments of Hungary, the Czech Republic and Latvia have collapsed in recent months amid economic hard times. The vote was 254 to 176. Under the Constitution, Mr. Boc's government can remain in office until a new prime minister is appointed by the president. Mr. Boc said his government ''has lost a battle and not the war.''

We extend our condolences on this great loss to his wife Joyce and his entire family. Judy Steinhardt, Chair, Board of Trustees Patricia Rubin, Judy & Michael Steinhardt Director Institute of Fine Arts-NYU

The Hall of Famer Gary Carter was named the coach of the Palm Beach Atlantic baseball team, the university said on its Web site. Carter, who managed the Long Island Ducks of the independent Atlantic League this season, has lived in Palm Beach County, Fla., since 1982. The Sailfish play in N.C.A.A. Division II. Palm Beach Atlantic, a Christian university, has an enrollment of 3,200. Carter, who also managed for two seasons in the Mets' minor league system and for one year in the independent Golden Baseball League in California, campaigned to replace Willie Randolph as the Mets' manager in 2008.

SEAWEED -- more respectfully, sea greens or sea vegetables -- can be a tough sell. Many of us gobble down seaweed salad and sushi wrapped in nori, which is seaweed, of course, but beyond that it remains underused. I won't get into the health benefits of seaweed, which are legion, but I enjoy finding new ways to prepare it because, quite simply, I like it to eat it.

One quirk of the classical music world is that James Levine, illustrious and productive conductor that he is, has never led Beethoven’s Symphony No. 4. That was to have changed with this year’s sequential cycle of Beethoven symphonies by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, where he is music director. But back surgery earlier this month means the quirk will stand, for now. The Boston Symphony said today that Mr. Levine would not be back on the podium for a concert until Oct. 30 and 31, when he is scheduled to conduct the Sixth and Seventh symphonies of Beethoven, and then move on to the Eighth and Ninth the following week.

Updated | 9:36 a.m. Later tonight, we’ll have a report on the Monty Python reunion taking place this evening at the Ziegfeld Theater. In the meantime, Jimmy Fallon, that lucky, exuberant son-of-a-gun, staged his own reunion Wednesday on his “Late Night” program with four of the six surviving Pythons: John Cleese, Eric Idle, Terry Gilliam and Terry Jones. (Michael Palin was traveling; Graham Chapman, who is dead, was not.) Among the highlights of the program was this performance of “Always Look On the Bright Side of Life” featuring Mr. Idle and the Roots, Mr. Fallon’s house band. Who knew that all the song needed to really come alive was a tubasousaphone?

Updated | 2:49 p.m. The British R&B singer Leona Lewis canceled a promotional trip to Germany planned for Thursday after she was attacked during a book signing on Wednesday, Agence France-Presse reported. Ms. Lewis, 24, a winner of the British talent competition “The X Factor” who topped the United States singles chart in 2008 with her song “Bleeding Love,” was signing copies of her autobiography “Dreams” in London when the attack occurred. A spokesman for Ms. Lewis told Agence France-Presse that “a guy came up and punched her to the side of the head,” leaving a bruise. A man, Peter Kowalczyk 29, was later charged with assaulting Ms. Lewis and was detained under Britain’s Mental Health Act. In a statement, Ms. Lewis said, “Yesterday was a horrible shock and left me extremely hurt and upset. I’m very sorry to those I wasn’t able to meet at the signing.”

The carnage will continue on Broadway with a new quartet of squabbling parents. On Thursday, the producers of “God of Carnage” announced that Jimmy Smits, Annie Potts, Christine Lahti and Ken Stott would take over the Broadway production of that Yasmina Reza comedy on Nov. 17. Mr. Smits (“L. A. Law,” “NYPD Blue”) will inherit the role of Alan, the cell-phone abusing lawyer currently played by Jeff Daniels; Ms. Potts (“Designing Women,” “Any Day Now”) will play his nauseous wife, Annette, now played by Hope Davis; Ms. Lahti (“Chicago Hope”) will play the art-history author Veronica, the role for which Marcia Gay Harden won a Tony Award; and Mr. Stott will play her volcanic husband, Michael, a role he originated in the show’s London production before passing it on to James Gandolfini. “God of Carnage,” which won the Tony Award for best play, is directed by Matthew Warchus and runs at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater.

I'm a little late on this great Calvin Trillin piece, but it accords with my own more specialized memories from grad school. The year I got my PhD (1977), there was a very clear ranking of desirable career paths. The best economics grad students went into academic jobs; the middle went to the Fed or the IMF; the bottom went, poor souls, to Wall Street.

To follow up on our earlier post about when swine flu vaccinations are coming to our towns, we reached John Festa, the health officer in South Orange today (thanks for staying with those volleys of phone tag!). He said he ordered 2,500 doses for the village from the state, in addition to 55 that were part of an advanced shipment that he will use for health care employees, nurses at the seven schools, and the Emergency Medical Services squad. Two thousand of the vaccines he will be receiving have thimerosal in it, the preservative that includes mercury. He is also trying to get thimerosal-free vaccines; 500 have trace amounts of thimerosal. Pregnant women will require notes from their physicians before receiving the vaccine. He will be releasing more information about the timing and location of the vaccines as it becomes available, he said. --Tina Kelley

Tarrytown, which sits high on a hill and has majestic views of the Hudson River, claims as a native son none other than Washington Irving, the author of "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow" and other spooky tales. Its sister village, North Tarrytown, voted to rename itself Sleepy Hollow in 1996. So a visit to both villages is worthwhile, especially as Halloween looms and Irving's tales come to life - at least in the imagination.

Few countries take their autumn harvests as seriously as Italy. Visit any hilltop town or small city on a weekend in October and you're likely to find a sagra, a gastronomic spectacle venerating pumpkins or chestnuts or just about any vegetable, nut or meat that's grown and produced regionally in fresh abundance. Sagre sometimes last all weekend and often culminate on Sunday with a celebratory feast. I recently visited Anguillara, a town built into the Sabatini hills around Lake Bracciano, near Rome, and the Sagra del Fungo was in full tilt. By 1 p.m. the parking lot hosting the festival was in a state of mushroom mania, with hundreds of people queuing up to try porcini sauces and spreads. There were other funghi - trucks pulled up to the event laden with golden chanterelles and purple and bronze flat-capped meadow mushrooms for sale - but porcini ruled the day, featuring prominently in most of the dishes served in mess-hall fashion beneath a giant white tent. If you're in Italy this fall, it's worth attending a sagra, if only to witness the unique customs of Italian food culture. You can find a complete listing of all the harvest festivals in Italy at this site (unfortunately only in Italian) or check out a few highlights of October and November sagre on the map below.

A new sign in the women's locker room of my neighborhood gym tells me "boys over the age of 5 are not permitted." I am told there is a similar sign about girls in the men's changing area. When my boys were younger I remember wondering whether the rules should be different for girls and boys; I felt comfortable taking my sons into the Ladies Room long after I might have been comfortable having my husband accompany a daughter into the men's room, for the simple reason that men do what they have to do out in the open and women do it behind stall doors. A father in Nashville is wondering about the timing, too, and asked me to share his question with readers. He grew up in Europe, and is trying to find his way around American norms:
When President Obama won the White House, the grassroots network that helped get him there, Obama for America, changed its name to Organizing for America.

Just on the heels of our English Eccentrics issue, Barneys toasts its new men's-wear collaboration with Paul Smith on Monday on the store's third floor, starting at 6:45 p.m. The dapper designer is the expert on all things Anglo, so Simon Doonan will lead a Q&A with Sir Paul, posing that eternal question, "Are the Brits as cool as they think they are?" -- or, rather, "Are British blokes more stylish than their American counterparts?" Doonan will throw some zingers: Who was cooler, the Kinks or the Beach Boys? What is the coolest British look - '50s Ted? '60s Mod? '80s Yardi? While you wait for Sir Paul's answers, you can check out his sharply tailored suits and scarf down a few mini shepherd's pies.

To celebrate the 15th birthday of his eponymous makeup and skin care line, François Nars photographed 15 of his favorite celebrities and fashion people in situations inspired by the names of his products, which are culled from film and fashion history. The resulting portraits have been compiled in "15x15," a limited-edition tome whose proceeds will go to charity.

Amazon has announced that it will begin offering same-day delivery in several major U.S. cities. If something is ordered between 10 a.m. and 1 p.m. - the exact cut-off time differs by city - it can be delivered the same day in New York, Philadelphia, Boston, Washington, Baltimore, Las Vegas and Seattle. Three more cities - Chicago, Indianapolis and Phoenix - will be added soon.
A long-running television comedy show once known for its wicked satires of commercials is going deeper into the realm of branded entertainment.

Sir Richard Branson, the entrepreneur, balloonist, spaceflight booster and social-environmental campaigner, held forth in a conversation with Alan Murray of The Wall Street Journal today, touching on a host of ways to make and lose money and try to build a better planet. Mr. Branson spoke excitedly about the planned December rollout of his commercial spacecraft and plans for his family, including his parents, to be the first to take a suborbital ride. He also spoke of the importance, whether riding a balloon in the jet stream or going up against British Airways as an aviation upstart 25 years ago, of "protecting the downside" and mused on why humans seemed to have a hard time with that kind of risk management when it was on the planetary scale. Here are some highlights:

Although the Dodgers won only two more games than the Phillies in the regular season, there is no doubt that they were the class of this year's National League. Los Angeles's run differential of 780 to 611 was easily the game's best, and its underlying statistics are consistent with such a performance. Meanwhile, Philadelphia's ratio of 820 runs scored to 709 allowed is misleading, since its pitching staff managed to strand an unsustainably high 75 percent of opposing runners on base. According to Baseball Prospectus, a team with the Phillies' component numbers (like doubles hit or walks allowed) and average luck at bunching them together would win only 86 games, versus 100 for the Dodgers.

Baseball spoils us in the first round of the playoffs with double- and triple-headers almost every night. After that initial deluge, we're stuck with two days in a row of no baseball and we get a little antsy. There's not much better than the amplified pressure and tension of October baseball. Tonight, the National League Championship series starts and it has a ton of intriguing characters and story lines. LONDON -- On Wednesday morning, the start of a mild gray day, the final participant in the famous Fourth Plinth experiment in Trafalgar Square had her say. The experiment -- Antony Gormley's project allowing 2,400 people to spend an hour each on the plinth (a pedestal on which a statue usually stands) over 100 days -- was eccentric, but it gave ordinary people the power to perform or preach in a great public space.

The number of households projected to use charcoal as an energy source in Cambodia will rise to more than 1 million in 2015 from about 500,000 now, according to a 2008 study conducted jointly by Cambodia's Ministry of Industry, Mines and Energy, the United Nations Development Program and the environmental group Geres.

As another day of militant attacks in Pakistan unfolded on Thursday, Pakistani television once again broadcast video of chaotic scenes in a major city, and the country's bloggers expressed outrage at both the Taliban and the government for failing to stop the violence.

Our cousins at the You're the Boss Blog continue to provide a valuable service by analyzing the likely impact on employer health benefits from the legislation circulating in Congress. The newest post analyzes the three proposals for employer mandates -- requirements that companies must provide health coverage to their workers, or pay penalties -- in the Senate health committee's bill and the two mandates proposed over in the House. Brace for the melding of mandates as Congress tries to reconcile the various bills.

When Nieves Gonzalez's mortgage payments spiked to nearly $4,000 a month, the stress of possible foreclosure on her two-unit family home in the Bronx took its toll. Her hypertension landed her in the hospital; there, she found out she was diabetic.

A collective tip of the hat from Decoder to Nan Robertson, a former New York Times reporter who died on Tuesday. Ms. Robertson's coverage of workplace parity at The Times helped prepare the newspaper for a future where women lead, write and report in every corner of its coverage. Ms. Robertson wrote frankly about her alcoholism, reminding that booze has no respect for class or gender. And when toxic shock put her in a coma and robbed her of the tips of her fingers, she used what remained of her hands to type her way to a Pulitzer Prize in describing her ordeal.

Beef industry executives raised a ruckus recently when they learned that Michael Pollan, the author of the book "The Omnivore's Dilemma" and a critic of industrial agriculture, would be giving a lecture on Thursday at California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo.

The McClatchy Company's decline in revenues slowed somewhat in the third quarter, resulting in improved earnings as it continued to slash costs, the company reported Thursday morning. McClatchy reported net income of $23.6 million in the quarter, or 28 cents per share, up from $4.2 million a year earlier.

Now that the Senate Finance Committee has passed a health reform bill, it must now be melded with the variation passed by the Senate Heath, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee. And that amalgamation, should it pass the Senate, will then have to be reconciled with the version that passes the House - itself the product of three separate committees. Much is the same across the three bills, but not the employer mandate.

Back when New York Magazine was for sale, all manner of moneyed types lined up to get their hands on the weekly, in part because owning such a thing would position their hands over the levers of power. It was a messy, tangled fight for the prize, which seemed to be long on social and business cachet while lacking the characteristics of something that might actually make money.

I'm from Atlanta and have lived in Harlem for the past eight years, where I've been block president three years running. I'm in the loop on the soul-food tip (Hey, Melba's!) and am familiar with the jazz clubs (snaps to St. Nik's Pub!). But one thing I have never quite figured out is the hair culture in Harlem. It's like a secret society in which men from all races are excluded. Needless to say when Chris Rock's documentary "Good Hair" made its debut, I was eager to check it out. Afterward, I chatted with a local, Maresa Asma, to get her take. "It was funny and true, yet sad and true," she said. "I don't wear weave, but I am rethinking my career. Did you hear that man say he makes as much as a doctor or lawyer selling weave?!"

Seven starters took the mound last fall for the Phillies and the Dodgers in the National League Championship Series, won by Philadelphia in five games. So far in this year's playoffs, only one of those pitchers has made a start: the Phillies' Cole Hamels, who lost to Colorado. The Dodgers have added Randy Wolf and Vicente Padilla since last October, and the Phillies have added Cliff Lee and Pedro Martinez, who did not pitch against the Rockies. Two lefties who pitched in relief in the last N.L.C.S., the Dodgers' Clayton Kershaw and the Phillies' J. A. Happ, also emerged as strong starters this season. The Dodgers' Hiroki Kuroda, who missed the first round with a herniated disk in his neck, returns to start Game 3.

International roots characterize the fiction finalists for this year’s National Book Awards, who were announced on Wednesday. Among the five finalists are Colum McCann, the Irish-born author of “Let the Great World Spin,” a novel about a sprawling cast of characters in New York City in the 1970s; Daniyal Mueenuddin, who lives on a farm in the Punjab region of Pakistan, for “In Other Rooms, Other Wonders”; and Marcel Theroux, who was born in Uganda and lives in London, for “Far North.” The other two finalists are Bonnie Jo Campbell, for “American Salvage,” a collection of short stories set in rural Michigan, and Jayne Anne Phillips, for “Lark and Termite,” a novel about a family buffeted by the fallout from the Korean and Vietnam Wars. The nonfiction finalists focus on history and the natural world. Their books are “Following the Water: A Hydromancer’s Notebook,” a chronicle of the author David M. Carroll’s sojourn in the wetlands of New Hampshire; “Remarkable Creatures: Epic Adventures in the Search for the Origins of the Species,” by Sean B. Carroll, about various people who have made important discoveries in evolutionary biology; Greg Grandin, for “Fordlandia: The Rise and Fall of Henry Ford’s Forgotten Jungle City,” about the automaker’s failed experiment to build a community in the Brazilian Amazon; Adrienne Mayor, for “The Poison King: The Life and Legend of Mithradates, Rome’s Deadliest Enemy,” a history of a brutal ruler in ancient times; and T. J. Stiles, for “The First Tycoon: The Epic Life of Cornelius Vanderbilt,” a biography of the man who founded a dynasty, presided over a railroad empire and built Grand Central Terminal in New York. The winners, chosen by panels of authors in each category, are to be announced at a ceremony on Nov. 18.

Being $6.8 million in debt and struggling with diminished fund-raising, leaders of the Shakespeare & Company theater in Lenox, Mass., say they are cutting jobs, restructuring the theater’s business model and taking other steps in hopes of shoring up its year-round productions and education programs. The company has been in a financial downward spiral for years, according to an independent study of its finances that was released on Tuesday. The theater needs approximately $2.3 million in immediate cash to cover operation expenses through March; in the long term, it has to wrestle with a $4.75 million operating deficit that has accumulated since 2005. Partly in response to the study, by the Nonprofit Finance Fund, which was commissioned by the theater, Shakespeare & Company announced that it would shift more staff members from full-year to seasonal status; eliminate some jobs in addition to the seven full-time positions already trimmed; devise a new business model to streamline operations; and continue a hiring freeze that began this year.
A French lawyer for the jailed director Roman Polanski said that his client, if released from jail, would promise to remain in Switzerland under house arrest.

The artistic director of the Skylight Opera Theater in Milwaukee, whose firing over the summer prompted resignations and protests from artists and donors who supported him, will return to the theater in his original position. In a news release on Wednesday, the theater said it had reappointed William Theisen as its artistic director, effective immediately, through June 30, 2011. In June the theater said it was eliminating five positions there, including the job of artistic director, which Mr. Theisen had held since 2004; his duties were consolidated under the general director, Eric Dillner, a former opera tenor. Several weeks of turmoil followed, and Mr. Dillner resigned in August. In its statement the theater said Mr. Theisen would direct up to two shows next season, reflecting a program he will plan with the departing interim artistic director, Colin Cabot.

The Glenn Gould Foundation has awarded its main prize to José Antonio Abreu, below, the founder of a music education project for poor children in Venezuela, called El Sistema, which has spread around the world. The prize carries with it an award of about $48,600. The foundation said Mr. Abreu would donate the money to buy new instruments for his school in Caracas, the capital. Yamaha said it would add about another $97,000 worth of instruments. Mr. Abreu chose El Sistema’s most famous graduate, the conductor Gustavo Dudamel, to receive the Toronto Glenn Gould Protégé Award, also sponsored by the foundation. Mr. Dudamel is the new music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic.

Last week Kiss, the veteran costumed rock band, released “Sonic Boom,” its first CD of new music in 11 years, and with little serious competition it seemed destined to become the band’s first No. 1 album. But then Michael Bublé, right, the Canadian pop singer, changed the release date of his new album, “Crazy Love,” and his sales have eclipsed Kiss’s. “Crazy Love” moved 132,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, opening at No. 1 on Billboard’s chart, and “Sonic Boom,” released on the band’s Kiss Records label and available only at Wal-Mart, sold 108,000. Also on this week’s chart, Toby Keith’s “American Ride” (Show Dog Nashville) opened at No. 3 with 90,000 sales; Barbra Streisand’s “Love Is the Answer” (Columbia) dropped three spots to No. 4, with 75,000; and Jay-Z’s “Blueprint 3” (Roc Nation/Atlantic) was in fifth place, with 65,000, pushing that album’s five-week sales total past one million.

SALZMAN--Regina. Beloved wife of Marty Salzman and beloved mother of Myra Frost and Margaret Brower, passed away Wednesday, October 14, 2009. Memorial services will be held at 11:30am at the Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck.

Seven starters took the mound last fall for the Phillies and the Dodgers in the National League Championship Series, won by Philadelphia in five games. So far in this year's playoffs, only one of those pitchers has made a start: the Phillies' Cole Hamels, who lost to Colorado. The Dodgers have added Randy Wolf and Vicente Padilla since last October, and the Phillies have added Cliff Lee and Pedro Martinez, who did not pitch against the Rockies. Two lefties who pitched in relief in the last N.L.C.S., the Dodgers' Clayton Kershaw and the Phillies' J. A. Happ, also emerged as strong starters this season. The Dodgers' Hiroki Kuroda, who missed the first round with a herniated disk in his neck, returns to start Game 3. RARE REPEAT The Phillies are trying to become the first National League team to win consecutive World Series since the 1975-76 Cincinnati Reds. But first, they'll try to be the first N.L. team to win back-to-back pennants since the 1995-96 Atlanta Braves. The N.L. has seen extraordinary parity lately, with 10 different champions in the last 11 seasons. Only St. Louis has won twice, in 2004 and 2006.
TAKING QUESTIONS

BREIER--Ralph. The members of the Yiddish Theatrical Alliance extend their deepest sympathy to our President, Corey Breier on the loss of his beloved father Ralph Breier. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Koved zayn ondenk.

One day after Commissioner Roger Goodell said that Rush Limbaugh's bid to buy the St. Louis Rams would receive little support from N.F.L. ownership, Limbaugh was dropped from the group of investors hoping to buy the team. ''Rush was to be a limited partner -- as such, he would have had no say in the direction of the club or in any decisions regarding personnel or operations,'' said Dave Checketts, the former Madison Square Garden executive who is leading the group that included Limbaugh. ''This was a role he enthusiastically embraced. However, it has become clear that his involvement in our group has become a complication and a distraction to our intentions, endangering our bid to keep the team in St. Louis. As such, we have decided to move forward without him and hope it will eventually lead us to a successful conclusion.''
