PERNICK--Frances. The American Committee for Shenkar College in Israel records with deep sorrow the passing of Frances Pernick, beloved wife of David Pernick, life chancellor of Shenkar College of Engineering and Design, loving mother of Bruce Pernick, president of the American Committee and his wife Susan, and loving mother of Jill Friedman and her husband Mitchell. Frances was a devoted supporter of the College in Ramat Gan, Israel, where the main campus building, the Frances and David Pernick building, is named in their honor. Inspired by her leadership, her grandchildren Pamela Ollendorff and Jocelyn Steelman are dedicated members of our board. To her entire family, we offer our sincere and heartfelt condolences. Frances will be remembered for her graciousness, dignity and commitment to education in Israel. She will be missed. Charlotte A. Fainblatt, Executive Director of the American Committee for Shenkar College

BALCHEN--Audrey, passed away peacefully at her home in New York City Saturday morning, October 10th. Her life of 93 years was distinguished and elegant. She was the devoted wife of Colonel Bernt Balchen, Polar Aviator, who predeceased her in 1973. She was born in New York City August 1, 1916, the daughter of John Edward Schipper and Marie B Schipper. The family soon established residence in Barberry Bend, Pleasantville, NY where she spent her youth and studied art and sculpture. She then attended George Washington University in the mid 1930s studying International Affairs and soon after was one of three women to graduate from Columbia University with a degree in business. She rose to Research Director at Fairchild Publications where she was not only employed but frequently published. Although living and working in New York City, her roots were in Westchester and she maintained a home in Chappaqua, NY where she enjoyed gardening and her flowers. It was here that she met her late husband and with her talents in research dedicated her time to assuring his legacy with exhibits in the Smithsonian, Library of Congress and Air Force Academy. She was as kind as she was generous and she supported many causes, especially Native Americans, the arts, and the New York Public Library. Her love of travel included many trips on the Queen Mary and QE2 and she regularly attended the symphony and ballet. She is survived by her brother Robert of Stratton, Maine, numerous nieces and nephews and a stepson Lauritz and predeceased by her brother Edward, Paul and sister Marie. Memorial Services at Crestwood Memorial Chapel are Thursday, 7-9pm with burial Friday at the family plot at Kensico Cemetery Valhalla, NY.

von BOTHMER--Dr. Dietrich, 90, died peacefully in his sleep on Monday, October 12, in Manhattan. The Metropolitan Museum's of Art's legendary curator, archaeologist, and historian of classical art is survived by his devoted wife of 43 years, Joyce Blaffer von Bothmer; his son Bernard Nicholas von Bothmer and his wife, Jane, of San Francisco; his daughter Maria Elizabeth Villalba and her husband, Jerome, of New York; and his five adoring grandchildren: Isabel, Victoria, and Charles Villalba, and Athena and Tatiana von Bothmer. Dr. von Bothmer was born on October 26, 1918, in Eisenach, Germany, and in 1938 was awarded the last of that year's two German Rhodes Scholarships before World War Two, allowing him to flee the Nazi dictatorship which he opposed and detested. At Oxford, he studied under Sir John Beazley, earning a diploma in 1939 in Classical Archaeology. Over the next thirty years, he worked closely with Beazley to build up the great works on Attic Black and Red-figure Vase-Painters that changed the way scholars thought about Greek art. And for the rest of his life, he was acknowledged as perhaps the finest connoisseur of Greek vase-painting in the world. While visiting museums in the United States in the summer of 1939 for what was meant to be but a three month stay, World War Two began, preventing Dietrich from returning to Europe. Through a network of generous scholarships and fellowships, he was able to continue his studies at the University of California, Berkeley (interrupted by a brief fellowship at the University of Chicago), where he earned his Ph.D. in 1944. Though not yet a citizen, Dietrich volunteered for the U.S. Army and fought heroically in the South Pacific. There he was awarded both the Bronze Star and the Purple Heart for carrying, while wounded, a fellow soldier back to safety five miles through heavily fortified Japanese lines. Subsequently, he received U.S. citizenship, and in 1946 was appointed a curatorial assistant in the department of Greek and Roman art at the Metropolitan, where he remained for 64 years until his death. He was named curator in 1959, department chairman in 1973, and in 1990 Distinguished Research Curator. In 1965 he began teaching at the Institute of Fine Arts, N.Y.U. Dietrich was the recipient of numerous awards and citations, including a Chevalier de la Legion d'Honneur; a member of the Academie Francaise (one of only two Americans to have this honor); an honorary fellow of Wadham College; and several honorary doctorates. The author of a number of standard monographs and hundreds of articles and reviews, he was a wonderful mentor to his students and a devoted teacher. We will all greatly miss his piercing wit, generosity of spirit, his philanthropic ethos, his unparalleled intellect, his endless passion for Greek antiquities, his unquenchable thirst for knowledge, his encyclopedic knowledge of the history of Western Civilization, his zest for verbal sparring, and his enormous joie de vivre. His passing has left a gaping hole. A true lion has been lost: a polyglot, a patriarch, a patriot, an optimist, a genius. Family will receive friends on Thursday from 2-4 and 6-8pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue. Funeral services will be held at 11am on Friday, October 16, at St. James' Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street.

Like presents that take more time to wrap than to buy, the attractive actors in ''The Archery Contest'' make less of an impression than the stunning white box that contains them. On the second floor of Performance Space 122 the audience members surround the enclosed playing area, watching the action through a horizontal strip that has been sliced out of the box. What they see at first, in this refined fairy tale by the Hotel Savant company about the eternal problem of monogamy, is a couple having a marital spat. And true to life, everything appears partially obscured, including the inhabitants of the diorama.

One of the biggest challenges facing lawmakers who favor universal health care coverage is coming up with a plan for 20-somethings, the so-called young invincibles. A government-run insurance plan might be one way to bring this group into the fold, but its future is uncertain, to say the least. Still, provisions tucked into health care bills moving through Congress would make it easier for this group to afford health coverage.

AXINN--Donald E. The Hofstra community is deeply saddened by the passing of Donald E. Axinn, trustee emeritus of the Hofstra University Board of Trustees. Mr. Axinn was the founder and chairman of the Donald E. Axinn Companies, an investment firm and developer of office and industrial parks throughout the New York metropolitan area. Mr. Axinn combined his two great passions, flying and writing, in many of his published works: his three novels, eleven books of poetry and published articles and essays. Mr. Axinn first served on Hofstra's Board of Trustees from 1970 to 1979, including terms as Secretary and Vice Chair. He took a leave from the Board in 1971-1972 to assume, on a pro bono basis, the Associate Deanship of the Hofstra College of Liberal Arts and Sciences and to be Director of the Institute of the Arts. He was made a Trustee Emeritus in 1979. He joined the University's 50th Anniversary Committee in 1983, and he rejoined the Board of Trustees as an active trustee in 1984. In 1987, he received the Estabrook Award from the Alumni Organization. In 1988, in recognition of his many accomplishments and his service as a valued advisor to the University, the Hofstra University Library was named the Joan and Donald E. Axinn Library. He retired from the Board of Trustees in 1990 and once again became a Trustee Emeritus. In addition, at the time of the library naming, the annual Axinn Lecture and a fund in support of ecology and conservation were created from an endowment Mr. and Mrs. Axinn provided. In 2003, Mr. Axinn was honored at the annual Hofstra University Gala with the Hofstra University Presidential Medal, the highest honor the University bestows upon an individual. Mr. Axinn was renowned for his support of the arts and of the metropolitan New York area, having co-founded the Interfaith Nutrition Network, and served on a number of boards for the past three decades, including the Cradle of Aviation, which named an exhibit hall in honor of his generosity. He is a graduate of Middlebury College and has a master of arts in humanities (with distinction) from Hofstra, and he has also been awarded five honorary doctorates. In tribute to the memory of Mr. Axinn, all Hofstra University flags will be lowered to half staff. Marilyn Monter Chair, Board of Trustees Stuart Rabinowitz President Hofstra University

During much of the health care debate this year, the insurance industry has been the dog that didn't bark. But with the emergence of specific legislation from the Senate Finance Committee, that has changed. On the eve of the bill's passage through the committee on Tuesday, the industry's lobbying group, America's Health Insurance Plans, issued a report arguing that under the legislation, the cost of premiums would soar. That report was bolstered by another on Wednesday from the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association that essentially reached the same conclusion.

PLANSKY--Carl, artist, teacher, paint maker, died on October 10, 2009 of heart failure at the age of 58. He was a resident of East Meredith and Brooklyn, NY. Born in Miami Beach, Carl moved to New York in 1970 to attend Hans Hofmann's New York Studio School. He also studied with artist Joan Mitchell, a close personal friend and strong influence on his work. His paintings are drawn from direct observation, and revel in pitch-perfect color, compositional elegance, and highly expressive brushwork. Also a respected and influential teacher, he guided students at many institutions, including a return to the New York Studio School from 2004 to the present. Forever dedicated to the craft of oil painting, he began making small batches of handmade paint in the 1980s for himself and artist friends. This would eventually become Williamsburg Oil Paint, now widely regarded as one of the premier oil paint makers in the world and used by some of the most respected artists working today. Carl believed the only life worth living was based in salvation through individualism. Throughout his life, Carl was intensely committed to the honest, almost cathartic, personal expression found through paint, an idea often at odds with contemporary art world trends. It was a position he found equally frustrating and empowering, as he said recently, "the art world is cool and hip. [I am] too hot and passionate." At the time of his death, Carl had become an esteemed and successful artist on his own terms, without compromise or regret. He is survived by his mother, Mitzi Miller, sisters Beverly Plansky and Mary Beth Makias, and partner Chris Brown. A memorial will be held 3pm, Sunday, October 18 at the New York Studio School (8 West 8th Street), where his exhibition Sacred Monsters: Carl Plansky's Divas, is currently on view through Saturday.

REYNOLDS--Erin Elizabeth, Financial Advisor, 48, of West Hartford, CT succumbed October 12th after an extended battle with blood disease and intestinal illness. Ms. Reynolds was born May 7, 1961 in New Milford, CT to James Reynolds and Catherine MacCarthy Reynolds, New Milford Tax Collector. She is survived by her parents, as well as her daughters Jacqueline, 23, of New York City and Alexandra, 18, of Washington, DC; her elder brother Stephen, sister-in-law Hilary Sterne and nephew Tynan of New York City; and her younger brother Patrick, sister-in-law Michelle Crawford Reynolds, nephew Sean and niece Colleen of Charlotte, NC. Ms. Reynolds attended Canterbury School in New Milford and was active as Alumni Agent for the Class of 1979. She held a BS from University of Florida and received her MBS from American University. She followed a long and successful career in finance, earning CFP, RIA, and CEP certifications. During her career she help positions at Kidder Peabody, Phoenix Home Life and New England Financial as an insurance and estate-planning specialist, and later advised in private practice in the New York, California and Connecticut areas. After settling in West Hartford she was active in many charitable organizations, including My Sister's Place and The Jewish Federation of Greater Hartford. Known for her pluck, humor, and forthright style, she in recent years fought bravely through a succession of physical complications that nonetheless did not diminish her spirit. She is remembered by her family and friends as a beloved mother, daughter, and sister whose energy and sense of life will always survive. The family will receive visitors and friends this Friday, October 16th from 4 to 6:00pm at Weinstein Mortuary, 640 Farmington Avenue in Hartford, CT. A Memorial Service and luncheon is tentatively planned for Saturday, October 31st, at 11am in the Chapel of Our Lady at Canterbury School, New Milford, CT. To confirm details please call (800) 526-1710.

Gunmen attacked three government buildings and took hostages at one of them on Thursday. Unidentified gunmen stormed into a regional building of Federal Investigation Agency and took at least five people hostage in the eastern city of Lahore on Thursday, officials said. Two gunmen were killed in the ensuing battle with police officials, and at least three agency officials were reported dead. Gunmen also attacked two other police training centers on the outskirts of Lahore, officials said. Also on Thursday, a suicide bomber rammed his explosives-laden vehicle into a police station in the northwestern city of Kohat. At least eight people were killed in the suicide attack that destroyed the police station. There were no immediate claims of responsibility.

SHOCKEY WAITING FOR GIANTS Among the many subplots for Sunday's game between the Giants and the New Orleans Saints is the issue of tight end Jeremy Shockey, the former Giant who is the leading receiver for the Saints (4-0). Earlier this week, Shockey told The Times-Picayune of New Orleans that he left the Giants with a ''bitter taste in my mouth'' when he was traded before the 2008 season. One of the many things that annoyed Shockey was being told to sit in the stands at the Super Bowl in Glendale, Ariz., when the Giants defeated the New England Patriots for the championship after the 2007 season. Shockey was out with a broken leg and wanted to stand on the sideline with his teammates. Mathias Kiwanuka, a defensive end for the Giants, said after practice that Shockey was not the only player asked to sit in the stands.

Q.Do any portable MP3 players support music files in the FLAC format? A. While popular players like the Apple iPod and the Microsoft Zune HD do not naturally play files in the open-source FLAC (Free Lossless Audio Codec) format, you can still find plenty of portable music players out there that do. Samsung, SanDisk, iRiver and Cowon are among the companies that make players that support FLAC and other less common audio formats like Ogg Vorbis as well.

SURFERS who want to paddle into cold water must slip into something more substantial than board shorts: namely, a wetsuit. The insulating thickness of the neoprene keeps surfers warm, but also limits mobility. These days a new generation of wetsuits makes it easier to spend hours in the ocean -- regardless of the season or the latitude -- without hindering movement. One manufacturer solved the problem by building a suit that uses battery power to generate warmth. Another used a seemingly old-fashioned solution, lining the suit with wool, which is actually a bit high-tech: the merino blend uses recycled polyester to maximize wicking. And several companies have come up with alternatives to oil-based neoprene, all of which they advertise as environmentally friendly.

When the reconstructed Neues Museum in Berlin opened last March for a sneak preview — minus any works — 35,000 people lined up over three days to take a look. As of this weekend, they can all come back to see the art and artifacts. The museum, which was heavily damaged in World War II, is reopening after a more than $300 million remaking, a crowning moment for the German city.

Sotheby’s has told government regulators that it could not release information on bonuses paid to executives because of fears that its archival, Christie’s, would use it to make better offers and lure them away. The statement came in a June 22 letter to the Securities Exchange Commission, which had asked for details on Sotheby’s compensation system along with other matters.

The Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington has received a $5 million gift, to be bestowed over the next decade, to support musical theater productions. The Adrienne Arsht Musical Theater Fund made the gift, which was reported on Friday by The Washington Post; Mr. Arsht is treasurer of the Kennedy Center’s board of trustees. Washington-area theaters have been incubators of American musical for years; a new revival of “Ragtime” was a popular hit at the Kennedy Center earlier this year and is transferring to Broadway, with an official opening scheduled for Nov. 15.

Update | 5:37 p.m. The TLC channel on Friday sued Jon Gosselin, a star of its show “Jon & Kate Plus Eight,” for allegedly breaching his contract by giving unauthorized interviews. The suit was filed in the circuit court in Montgomery County, Md. Jon and Kate Gosselin, who appear alongside their eight children on the reality show, had signed contracts with the channel that stipulated how and when they could grant interviews and make public appearances. After the couple filed for divorce, TLC last month said it would retool the show as “Kate Plus Eight,” diminishing Mr. Gosselin’s role.

Comic fans can start creating their holiday wish lists now, as several noteworthy hardcover collections hit our list this week. When Daniel Roth went to work in his father's law practice, in Youngstown, Ohio, in the mid-1950s, his first assignment was to read the diary his father had kept during the Great Depression. Benjamin Roth wanted his son to understand the trauma most of his clients had been through, so that he could give them legal advice that would take into account their Depression experience. Daniel Roth had long known that his father had kept a diary, but he was startled by it nonetheless -- by its literary power, and also by the amount of sheer effort his father had put in trying simply to understand the events he was living through.

Some very impressive Greek vases live at the Toledo Museum of Art in Ohio. The last two times the Book Review has gone looking for an appropriately striking vase painting to illustrate reviews about the classical world, we've chosen examples that turned out to be from their collection. The first was a serene red-figure painting of a woman sacrificing at an altar that illustrated a review of Joan Breton Connelly's "Portrait of a Priestess." The second, with our review of Caroline Alexander's "War That Killed Achilles," in the issue of Oct. 18, is a different animal. Occupying one side of a magnificent Athenian amphora of about 515 B.C., it is a fearfully dark, passion-filled black-figure panel, attributed to the Rycroft Painter. It shows the aged Trojan king, Priam, begging a sinister Achilles for the body of his son Hector, whom Achilles has killed and whose corpse lies beside Achilles' banqueting couch. This is the most crucial scene in the "Iliad," from the final Book 24. As expressed in a highly detailed account of the scene on the Web site of the Perseus Project, a classics database at Tufts University, "Among Greek vases depicting the ransom of Hector, the Toledo amphora is remarkable for the intense emotion expressed in the plaintive figure of Priam and for the attention focused on the pitiful figure of this bereaved king."

Have Americans' eating (and smoking) habits changed in the last year? Not much. Notable on this chart from Information Resources Inc. are increases in sales of carbonated beverages (already responsible for seven percent of our caloric intake), alcoholic beverages (no surprise there), salty snacks, and so-called natural cheese (another salty snack, really). Down is that all-important staple, the cigarette, and milk - probably the closest thing to a natural food product in this whole list. Fruits, vegetables, even real meat and poultry, doesn't make the cut; we eat all of those in the form of frozen dinners I guess.

An elite pitcher with a grudge is dangerous. Pedro Martinez still holds one against the Dodgers, who traded him to Montreal in 1993 amid concerns that his body would not hold up. It is one of the worst trades -- if not the worst -- in Dodgers history, haunting them through the rest of that decade as it changed the trajectory of the franchise. The Dodgers made the playoffs twice, in 1995 and 1996, but did not win a game either time, undermined by a paucity of strong starting pitching.

"A Schoolgirl's Odyssey" (19:57)For six months, my colleague Adam B. Ellick followed the story of a Pakistani family forced from their home in the Swat Valley. Ziaudin Yousafzai runs a girl's school in Mingora and wants his daughter Malala to pursue her dream of becoming a doctor. But the Taliban have closed the school and forced thousands of people to flee the city. Malala moves from place to place - four cities in two months - living with relatives, while Mr. Yousafzai heads to Peshawar to stage protests in the hope of pressuring the government to rescue the city from the Taliban. They will return to Swat, but everything will be different. It is heart-rending; beautifully told and beautifully shot. Be warned, however, that there are several disturbing scenes. Though long (nearly 20 minutes), the story moves quickly toward its poignant, hopeful conclusion. (E.O.)

On the Economix blog today, the economist Uwe E. Reinhardt deconstructs the widely shared complaint among hospital executives that Medicare and Medicaid pay less than their full share of hospital costs. The corollary argument, he writes, is that hospitals must therefore "recoup the shortfall by charging higher prices to private health insurers." It is an argument at the heart of the widely disputed cost analysis the insurance industry's trade group, America's Health Insurance Plans, issued this week, and Mr. Reinhardt finds that it is "a tall tale that taxes credulity." This is a city of people who are constantly on the move. But lately I have noticed many who are completely immobile. Their favorite places to stand are on the subway stairs, either at the top, bottom or halfway up; at times, they camp smack-dab in the middle of the sidewalk. Regardless of where these people choose to stop, they are all engaged in the same activity: talking on their cellphones. And while they chatter away, like statues newly bestowed with the gift of speech, the rest of us are obliged to perform something akin to interpretive dance to make our way around them.

O.K., any nation that indulges in the pastime of tea trolley dancing qualifies as eccentric. Why this should be so is usually attributed to England's island mentality. Or, as Kathleen Egan writes in T's winter fashion issue, out this Sunday: "Why leave when you've got so much interesting stuff going on here?" From the genuine nutters (Lady Wemyss really does drill holes in her head) to the exquisitely colorful (Vivienne Westwood) to the thoughtfully perverse (Julia Lohmann's lamps are made from cow stomachs -- how chic), T has assembled a pantheon of out-of-control Anglomaniacs. Samantha Morton, famously mute in "Sweet and Lowdown," graces our cover. Alice Dellal and her fellow aristobrats add heft to Jean-Baptiste Mondino's portfolio of batty Brits. And let's not forget the English design critic Stephen Bayley, whose new book deconstructs the female body and finds that its most provocative part looks like the grillwork of a 1959 Edsel. We ask you: how can you not love the English?

Sutton Foster will trade her tiara for a nurse’s cap in the Encores! revival of “Anyone Can Whistle” at City Center this spring. Ms. Foster, below, who is currently playing Princess Fiona in the Broadway production of “Shrek the Musical,” will play Nurse Fay Apple, a sanitarium manager skeptical of a dubious miracle in a fictional small town, a publicist for Encores! said Thursday in a news release. “Anyone Can Whistle,” the Arthur Laurents-Stephen Sondheim musical that had an abrupt nine-show run in 1964, will be performed at City Center from April 8 through April 11. A press representative for “Shrek” said Ms. Foster was under contract to that show through Jan. 24.

The carnage will continue on Broadway with a new quartet of squabbling parents. On Thursday the producers of “God of Carnage” announced that Jimmy Smits, Annie Potts, Christine Lahti and Ken Stott, clockwise from top left, would take over the Broadway production of that Yasmina Reza comedy, at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, on Nov. 17. Mr. Smits (“L.A. Law,” “NYPD Blue”) will inherit the role of Alan, the cellphone-abusing lawyer currently played by Jeff Daniels; Ms. Potts (“Designing Women,” “Any Day Now”) will play his nauseous wife, Annette, now played by Hope Davis; Ms. Lahti (“Chicago Hope”) will play the art-history author Veronica, the role for which Marcia Gay Harden won a Tony in June; and Mr. Stott will play her volcanic husband, Michael, a role he originated in the show’s London production before passing it on to James Gandolfini. “God of Carnage,” which won the Tony for best play, is directed by Matthew Warchus.

Garth Brooks, above, the cowboy-hatted country superstar who displaced Elvis Presley as the top-selling solo artist in United States history, said at a news conference in Nashville on Thursday that he was coming out of an eight-year retirement amid reports that he would play an extended run at a Las Vegas hotel. “We’re going to take the retirement roof off over our head, and I already feel taller,” Mr. Brooks said, according to The Associated Press. Mr. Brooks, 47, said that he had no immediate plans to record and release new material, adding, “As for touring, if I can’t eat it, sleep it, breathe it, then it ain’t me.” His last new studio album, “Scarecrow,” was released in 2001.

Carol Lombardini, a veteran Hollywood labor negotiator, was named president of the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, the group said in a statement. Ms. Lombardini had been acting president of the alliance since April, after the retirement of J. Nicholas Counter, her predecessor. The alliance represents about 300 movie and television companies in negotiations with Hollywood unions. Ms. Lombardini joined the group in 1982 and has served in various positions, including general counsel.

A Massachusetts judge has denied a motion by Brandeis University to dismiss a lawsuit brought by three overseers of the school’s Rose Art Museum who are seeking to stop the university from closing the museum and selling its works. In January, as Brandeis’s finances worsened, its trustees voted to “transition” the museum into a teaching center and gallery, followed by “an orderly sale or other disposition” of work from its highly regarded collection. The decision was met with widespread criticism. After the vote the university backtracked, saying that no works were to be sold in the immediate future. In court on Tuesday the university pledged not to sell any artwork that had been donated by the overseers, Meryl Rose, Jonathan Lee and Lois Foster, and said it would give the Massachusetts attorney general an opportunity for review if it decided to sell works donated by others.

One quirk of the classical music world is that James Levine has never conducted Beethoven’s Symphony No. 4. That was to have changed with this year’s cycle of Beethoven symphonies by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, where he is music director. But back surgery earlier this month means the quirk will stand, for now. The Boston Symphony said on Thursday that Mr. Levine would not be back on the podium for a concert until Oct. 30 and 31, when he is scheduled to conduct Beethoven’s Symphonies Nos. 6 and 7 at Symphony Hall, and then move on to the Eighth and Ninth the following week. Rafael Frühbeck de Burgos will substitute for Mr. Levine in the first program of the cycle, featuring Symphonies Nos. 1, 2 and 5, from Oct. 22 through Oct. 24. The orchestra’s assistant conductor, Julian Kuerti, will step in for the second program, which consists of Symphonies Nos. 3 and 4, on Oct. 27 and 29. Mr. Levine was to have led the orchestra at Carnegie Hall’s opening night this month, but the surgery forced him to withdraw. The Boston Symphony said he expected to conduct it at Carnegie on Nov. 2., when he will repeat performances of the Sixth and Seventh. Mr. Levine is also music director of the Metropolitan Opera, where he is expected to return for his engagements to lead “Les Contes d’Hoffmann,” opening on Dec. 3.

The sustainable growth rate is a formula set by law for reimbursing doctors for treating patients covered by Medicare as part of an effort to control the steep rise in Medicare costs. Because of quirks in the formula, doctors have faced the prospect of severe reductions and Congress has stepped in repeatedly to prevent those cuts by enacting laws now known as the annual ''doc fix.'' Under current law, doctors face cuts of 21.5 percent in January and about 5.5 percent in each of the next four years.

WASSERSTEIN--Bruce. Harvard Law School mourns the passing of Bruce Wasserstein, one of the school's most brilliant and influential graduates and a transformative figure in the history of investment banking and corporate finance. Bruce served on the Dean's Advisory Board and was a member of the HLS Visiting Committee. His unwavering belief in what a Harvard Law School education makes possible, not only for those pursuing their own dreams but also for those who use the law to pursue justice, inspired his extraordinary devotion and great generosity to the school's public interest program, including the Morris Wasserstein Public Interest Fellows Program. We are honored that his magnificent legacy at Harvard Law School includes Wasserstein Hall. Our deepest sympathy is with his wife, Angela, his children and the entire Wasserstein family.

THE SURVEY SAYS ... The Yankees should come home with their 27th World Series championship, according to fans. Forty-one percent of baseball fans surveyed by Marist College expect the Yankees to win. Ten percent anticipated a repeat by the Philadelphia Phillies, 8 percent picked the Los Angeles Dodgers and 5 percent selected the Angels. A quarter, 24 percent, mentioned teams that have since been eliminated, and 12 percent had no opinion.

JENKINS--George Pollock, 94, died peacefully on Wednesday, October 14. He is survived by his wife of 64 years, Marian, his three sons, James, Robert and Richard, their spouses Nevitt, Heidi and Jackie and seven grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister, Ellen J. Smith. A graduate of Blair Academy, Princeton University and The Harvard Graduate School of Business, George spent virtually his entire professional career at The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, ultimately serving as the Chairman of the Board. He also served as a trustee of numerous corporations, non-profits and educational institutions. He was passionate about finance, education, the Presbyterian Church and his family. Funeral services will he held Saturday, October 17 at 12 noon at The Presbyterian Church of Upper Montclair, 53 Norwood Avenue, Upper Montclair, NJ 07043. In lieu of flowers, donations may be directed to Blair Academy, Blairstown, NJ 07825; or The Board of Pensions of the Presbyterian Church, Assistance Program, Room 3024, 2000 Market Street, Philadelphia, PA 19103.

von BOTHMER--Dr. Dietrich, 90, died peacefully in his sleep on Monday, October 12, in Manhattan. The Metropolitan Museum's of Art's legendary curator, archaeologist, and historian of classical art is survived by his devoted wife of 43 years, Joyce Blaffer von Bothmer; his son Bernard Nicholas von Bothmer and his wife, Jane, of San Francisco; his daughter Maria Elizabeth Villalba and her husband, Jerome, of New York; and his five adoring grandchildren: Isabel, Victoria, and Charles Villalba, and Athena and Tatiana von Bothmer. Dr. von Bothmer was born on October 26, 1918, in Eisenach, Germany, and in 1938 was awarded the last of that year's two German Rhodes Scholarships before World War Two, allowing him to flee the Nazi dictatorship which he opposed and detested. At Oxford, he studied under Sir John Beazley, earning a diploma in 1939 in Classical Archaeology. Over the next thirty years, he worked closely with Beazley to build up the great works on Attic Black and Red-figure Vase-Painters that changed the way scholars thought about Greek art. And for the rest of his life, he was acknowledged as perhaps the finest connoisseur of Greek vase-painting in the world. While visiting museums in the United States in the summer of 1939 for what was meant to be but a three month stay, World War Two began, preventing Dietrich from returning to Europe. Through a network of generous scholarships and fellowships, he was able to continue his studies at the University of California, Berkeley (interrupted by a brief fellowship at the University of Chicago), where he earned his Ph.D. in 1944. Though not yet a citizen, Dietrich volunteered for the U.S. Army and fought heroically in the South Pacific. There he was awarded both the Bronze Star and the Purple Heart for carrying, while wounded, a fellow soldier back to safety five miles through heavily fortified Japanese lines. Subsequently, he received U.S. citizenship, and in 1946 was appointed a curatorial assistant in the department of Greek and Roman art at the Metropolitan, where he remained for 64 years until his death. He was named curator in 1959, department chairman in 1973, and in 1990 Distinguished Research Curator. In 1965 he began teaching at the Institute of Fine Arts, N.Y.U. Dietrich was the recipient of numerous awards and citations, including a Chevalier de la Legion d'Honneur; a member of the Academie Francaise (one of only two Americans to have this honor); an honorary fellow of Wadham College; and several honorary doctorates. The author of a number of standard monographs and hundreds of articles and reviews, he was a wonderful mentor to his students and a devoted teacher. We will all greatly miss his piercing wit, generosity of spirit, his philanthropic ethos, his unparalleled intellect, his endless passion for Greek antiquities, his unquenchable thirst for knowledge, his encyclopedic knowledge of the history of Western Civilization, his zest for verbal sparring, and his enormous joie de vivre. His passing has left a gaping hole. A true lion has been lost: a polyglot, a patriarch, a patriot, an optimist, a genius. Funeral services will be held at 11am on Friday, October 16, at St. James' Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street.

He served in the U.S. Army Signal Corps in Brazil during the Second World War. In 1946, he began a 38-year business association with Leslie R. Samuels of the Auerbachs, L.R. Samuels, and G. Fox department stores. Since its founding in 1959, he served as a director and officer, including President and Chairman, of the Fan Fox & Leslie R. Samuels Foundation, one of New York's foremost philanthropies supporting the city's performing arts institutions, particularly the constituents of Lincoln Center, as well as his special interest in geriatric health care. REYNOLDS--Erin Elizabeth, Financial Advisor, 48, of West Hartford, CT succumbed October 12th after an extended battle with blood disease and intestinal illness. Ms. Reynolds was born May 7, 1961 in New Milford, CT to James Reynolds and Catherine MacCarthy Reynolds, New Milford Tax Collector. She is survived by her parents, as well as her daughters Jacqueline, 23, of New York City and Alexandra, 18, of Washington, DC; her elder brother Stephen, sister-in-law Hilary Sterne and nephew Tynan of New York City; and her younger brother Patrick, sister-in-law Michelle Crawford Reynolds, nephew Sean and niece Colleen of Charlotte, NC. Ms. Reynolds attended Canterbury School in New Milford and was active as Alumni Agent for the Class of 1979. She held a BS from University of Florida and received her MBS from American University. She followed a long and successful career in finance, earning CFP, RIA, and CEP certifications. During her career she help positions at Kidder Peabody, Phoenix Home Life and New England Financial as an insurance and estate-planning specialist, and later advised in private practice in the New York, California and Connecticut areas. After settling in West Hartford she was active in many charitable organizations, including My Sister's Place and The Jewish Federation of Greater Hartford. Known for her pluck, humor, and forthright style, she in recent years fought bravely through a succession of physical complications that nonetheless did not diminish her spirit. She is remembered by her family and friends as a beloved mother, daughter, and sister whose energy and sense of life will always survive. The family will receive visitors and friends this Friday, October 16th from 4 to 6:00pm at Weinstein Mortuary, 640 Farmington Avenue in Hartford, CT. The sound and vibration of a boat engine make the fish fly. The Illinois River and other waterways flowing into the Mississippi have become infested with invasive Asian fish species, commonly called silver carp, which can turn a leisurely ride on a johnboat into the aquatic version of the running of the bulls. The carp jump out of the water by the hundreds, sometimes soaring 10 feet in the air and often landing in the boat. They have loosened fishermen's teeth, broken their jaws and left them scarred.

The Yankees purchased Freddy Guzman from the Baltimore Orioles in late August because they wanted an extra pinch-runner for the playoffs for the days Brett Gardner starts in the outfield. Guzman did not make the roster for the division series, but he is on the team for the American League Championship Series, replacing Eric Hinske. ''We thought we could use another speed guy in this round,'' Manager Joe Girardi said. ''We've had some success doing those types of things late in games, and in a seven-game series, we felt that it could come up late in games. As we saw, the games against Minnesota were very close, and sometimes you could use a couple of pinch-runners. And if Gardy gets a start, then you don't have a pinch-runner. It just frees us up to do some more things.''

SHAW--Iris Azian, 1927-2009, a pioneering child advocate and loving wife and mother, died on October 9 in Pasadena, California at age 82. The cause was complications from leukemia and arterial disease. Though she earned two law degrees in her lifetime, Mrs. Shaw chose not to practice law but to use her knowledge and skills as an informed volunteer to help the abused and neglected children caught up in the foster care and juvenile justice systems. Mrs. Shaw was born in Hartford, Connecticut, on January 15, 1927 to parents of Armenian descent. Her shopkeeper father, like many immigrants of that time, believed in the American Dream and told his daughter that she could make anything of herself in this country. She went on to graduate from Boston Latin School, trained as a concert pianist, and became one of the first women to earn a JD from Boston University Law School. Immediately afterward she passed the Massachusetts bar exam with the highest score to that date. In 1949, a Harvard student named Anthony Shaw working as a waiter the summer before his senior year took her order, and they married six years later. In 1970, with three children in tow they moved to Charlottesville, Virginia, where Dr. Shaw became a professor of pediatric surgery at the University of Virginia and Mrs. Shaw devoted herself to helping children in the web of the dependency court and foster care systems. She used her knowledge of the law and her devotion to child welfare to help found Community Attention, group homes that provided adolescent offenders an alternative to more punitive, and less effective, detention facilities. This rehabilitation option was controversial at the time but proved extremely effective in lowering recidivism rates and became a much-replicated model. During these years Mrs. Shaw also chaired the board that oversaw the regional jail, taught law through the University of Virginia to law enforcement and security officers and advised the governor of Virginia on juvenile justice issues. She and Dr. Shaw moved to Pasadena, California, in 1981, where she joined the ranks of volunteers at CASA (Court Appointed Special Advocates) in Los Angeles. Though only five feet tall, she often traveled alone into many of the city's roughest neighborhoods to interview relatives of children whose fate lay with the courts so she could represent those children as effectively as possible. Her tireless advocacy moved Los Angeles County to name her its Volunteer of the Year in 1994. She discovered late in life that she loved nothing more than zipping around icebergs and glaciers in an inflatable Zodiac boat in the Arctic and Antarctic, and she and Dr. Shaw made numerous trips to the far north and far south. She did all she did with profound humility, always giving and never expecting anything in return. She is survived by Dr. Anthony Shaw, her husband of 54 years; three children, Dr. Brian Shaw of Roanoke, Virginia, Diana Shaw Clark of London, UK, and Daniel Shaw of Woody Creek, Colorado; eight grandchildren; and a sister, Mrs. Seda Dennis of Manomet, Massachusetts. In lieu of flowers or anything else, the family asks that contributions be made to: The Iris A. Shaw Memorial Fund, CASA of Los Angeles, 201 Centre Plaza Drive, Suite 3, Monterey Park, CA 91754-2142. 323-526-6329

One way Congress hopes to lower health care spending is by authorizing ''biosimilars.'' Those, essentially, would be generic versions of biotechnology drugs, medicines, like the cancer drug Avastin, that currently can cost tens of thousands of dollars a year. But a commentary published online this week by The New England Journal of Medicine says the current provisions in the health care legislation would do little to reduce prices of such drugs. That is because the new rules would not allow the copycat drugs to be sold until the original biotechnology drug had been on the market for 12 years. Such a delay, the authors argue, would discourage would-be competitors.

Five men were convicted Friday in New South Wales of plotting terrorist attacks. Prosecutors said the men, all from Sydney, had stockpiled dangerous chemicals, firearms and ammunition to wage Islamist jihad against the Australian government. The defendants' names were not released on the judge's orders. The jury deliberated more than a month before delivering its verdict. Sentencing proceedings are to begin Dec. 14, with each man facing a maximum sentence of life in prison.

The Angels were the only American League team to have a winning record against the Yankees in the Joe Torre era. They have evolved from the team of Tim Salmon, Garret Anderson and Darin Erstad to the team of Torii Hunter, Vladimir Guerrero and Bobby Abreu, yet they still pester Joe Girardi's Yankees by putting balls in play and running like mad. Four September meetings this season produced three Yankees victories, all by one or two runs. With the pennant on the line, it has the makings of a classic series. HISTORY 4.00 Not one of the Yankees starters has a good career record against the Angels. C. C. Sabathia's earned run average against them is 4.72, A. J. Burnett's is 4.43 and Andy Pettitte's is 4.70. Even closer Mariano Rivera has been ordinary against the Angels, with a 3.56 mark. Then again, it's worth noting that the Angels' Game 1 starter, John Lackey, has a 4.66 E.R.A. against the Yankees.

When the reconstructed Neues Museum in Berlin opened in March for a sneak preview — without any works — 35,000 people lined up over three days to take a look. As of this weekend, they can all come back to see the art and artifacts. The museum, which was heavily damaged in World War II, is reopening after a more than $300 million remaking. “This is a historic moment in the history of museums,” Hermann Parzinger, president of the Foundation of Prussian Cultural Heritage, said, according to Agence France-Presse. “For the first time since the war, the five museums on the Museum Island are open again.” One of the Neues Museum’s most famous holdings is the ancient Egyptian bust of Nefertiti, above.

A new Holocaust center opens on Sunday at Queensborough Community College in Bayside, Queens. Called the Kupferberg Holocaust Resource Center and Archives, the 9,000-square-foot space includes permanent exhibits on other scenes of mass killing, including Armenia, Bosnia, Cambodia, China, Rwanda, Sudan and Ukraine.

The Los Angeles businessman and art collector Richard L. Weisman, who said last month that 11 silk-screen paintings, right, by Andy Warhol had been stolen from his home, has waived the $25 million insurance policy that would reimburse him for the paintings, The Seattle Times reported. The Los Angeles police have described the case as puzzling, saying that there were no signs of a break-in and that the Warhol works were the only valuable items missing from the home. Mr. Weisman, 69, said that he had waived the insurance policy because he did not want insurance investigators searching through his private papers as part of an inquiry, according to the Seattle newspaper. “That’s the only reason, and it’s a good enough reason,” Mr. Weisman said. The Los Angeles Times reported that detectives assigned to the case said that they had found Mr. Weisman’s decision curious and planned to question him about it.
TLC sued Jon Gosselin, a star of its show “Jon & Kate Plus 8,” on Friday, saying he breached his contract by giving unauthorized interviews.

Sotheby’s has told government regulators that it could not release information on bonuses paid to executives because of fears that its archrival, Christie’s, would use it to make better offers and lure them away. The statement came in a June 22 letter to the Securities and Exchange Commission, which had asked for details on Sotheby’s compensation system, along with other matters. The letter pointed out that Sotheby’s — a publicly traded company that is required to release financial data — competes fiercely with Christie’s, a private company not subject to the same regulations. Disclosing details of its compensation practices “would result in significant competitive harm,” Sotheby’s said. The commission responded with a letter saying it had “no further comments at this time” on the issues the letter had raised. The commission this week released the correspondence, which Bloomberg News reported, through its Web site, sec.gov.

The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington has received a $5 million gift, to be bestowed over the next decade, to support musical theater productions. The Adrienne Arsht Musical Theater Fund made the gift, which was reported on Friday by The Washington Post; Ms. Arsht is treasurer of the Kennedy Center’s board. Washington-area theaters have been incubators of American musicals for years; a revival of “Ragtime” was a hit at the Kennedy Center this year and is transferring to Broadway, with an official opening scheduled for Nov. 15. The donation comes on the heels of another major gift to a Washington cultural institution; the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation announced on Thursday that it was donating $10 million for the design and construction of the Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of African American History and Culture, which is scheduled to be completed in 2015.

A county coroner said a police officer shot and killed a high school student who had stabbed the officer as school started. A spokeswoman for the Horry County schools, Teal Britton, said the student had asked to speak to the officer. Ms. Britton said the student, Trevor Varinecz, 16, stabbed the officer after the two had gone into an office at Carolina Forest High School in Conway. A hospital spokeswoman said the officer, who was not identified, was treated for his wounds and was released in good condition. A woman who answered the phone at the student's house said the family had no comment.

WERBEL--Morton. It is with great sadness that the law firm of Werbel, Werbel & Verchick mourns the passing of its founder, Morton Werbel. Morty is survived by his beautiful wife, Harriet, devoted children, Traci, Jimmy, Shelly and Andrew and wonderful grandchildren, Katie and Josh. As a member of the New York State Bar for over 50 years, he also served as an Arbitrator for the Civil Court of the City of New York. He was a member Brooklyn Bar Assn., Jewish Lawyers Guild, NYSBA, American Judges Assn., Adath Israel, UJA, Rockwood Park Jewish Center, The Hamptons Synagogue, Seaview Jewish Center, Seagate Masonic Lodge, Knights of Pythias' Crossbay Lodge, Local 802 of A F of M and the Brownsville Boys Club.

SCHALL--Rhoda Miller, 89, passed away peacefully at home on Friday, October 16, 2009. A Latin teacher who tutored students until her 88th year and loved all things Italian, she taught in Wilmington, Delaware and New York City. On October 7, she celebrated her 64th wedding anniversary with her loving husband, Edward W. Schall. She is survived by Edward and her four children: Ellen (Steven); Richard (Marie); Lawrence (Betty); Steven (Alyce); and seven beloved grandchildren. Services Sunday, October 18, 11:15am, Riverside Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to University Settlement, 184 Eldridge St. New York, NY 10002.

Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said Friday that the Obama administration expected President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan to win an anticipated runoff election and that the vote would not affect President Obama's decision about whether to send more troops to the country. But other administration officials said it was possible that if the runoff was held quickly and the results were known by mid-November, Mr. Obama might delay his decision on troops until then. Until now, White House advisers have said they expect Mr. Obama to make his decision by late October or early November.
LAZARUS-MILLER--Lillian, was born 100 years ago today. Sharp-witted, lovely and devoted wife, mother, teacher, saleswoman and community volunteer, she will be forever loved by her family and friends.

In the space of just four months, Russia has gone from a strategic priority to an afterthought at Carrefour, the giant French retailer. In a sales update released late Thursday, Carrefour said it was withdrawing from Russia.

Senator Tom Harkin, the chairman of the Senate health committee, predicted Friday that Congress would pass sweeping health care legislation before Christmas. And he said it would include a new government insurance plan -- the so-called public option -- that would compete with private insurers. ''The vast majority of the Senate Democratic caucus is for the public option we have in our bill,'' which was approved by the health committee in July, Mr. Harkin said.

BERNSTEIN--Morton J. The Directors and Staff of The Fan Fox and Leslie R. Samuels Foundation mourn the loss of their beloved colleague and friend Mort Bernstein on October 8, 2009. Mort served the Foundation as an officer and director for more than 50 years. As the first President after the death of the founders, Mort designed the Foundation's performing arts program, which today supports over 120 arts organizations in New York City each year. He also led the effort to expand the Foundation's grant-making into healthcare and the social services. At the time of his death, he held the title of Chairman Emeritus in recognition of his leadership and contribution to the Foundation's mission. We will miss Mort for the hallmarks of his service: sound judgment, common sense, and great consideration for others. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Muriel, his children, Eva and Adam, and his granddaughter, Sarah.
SALZMAN--Regina. We will miss you always. Lynn, Justin, Barbara and Allan

The Irish tenor Ronan Tynan, a fixture at Yankee Stadium for years with his stirring rendition of ''God Bless America,'' was scheduled to belt out the song again during Game 1 of the American League Championship Series on Friday. Instead, he was disinvited by the Yankees after he admitted making an anti-Semitic remark at his Manhattan apartment building a day earlier. Howard Rubenstein, a spokesman for the Yankees, said the team took action as soon as Tynan acknowledged making the comment.

Two American soldiers were instantly killed and two others died of their wounds after their patrol vehicle hit a roadside bomb in southern Afghanistan, military officials said Friday. The explosion took place on Thursday, but no other information was released, pending notification of family members, said Lt. j.g. Tommy Groves, a spokesman for the American forces.

STANTON--John J.,Jr., of Greenwich, CT, formerly of Rye, NY, died on October 15, 2009. Born on August 23, 1932 in New York City he grew up in Mamaroneck, NY and Portland, OR. A graduate of Santa Clara University and Georgetown Law School. He proudly served as a Lieutenant in US Marine Corps. He practiced law with the National Labor Relations Board, was Labor Counsel and head of the legal department of the New York Times and served of Counsel with Cahill, Gordon and Reindel. He also taught law at the University of the District of Columbia. Member of American Yacht Club. Parishioner of Resurrection Church in Rye, and a religious education teacher there. He enjoyed traveling, gardening and cooking. He is survived by his wife of 49 years, Mary-Jane (Handler), his children: John, Sue Ann (Gail Romano), Gregory (Maria Del Guercio) and Hugh as well as his grandchildren, Isobella, Luke and Nina. A devoted friend, Jack guided those close to him with his sharp intellect, dry wit, and gentle laugh. Jack Stanton was never one to suffer fools gladly. Friends may call at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580 on Sunday, October 18, from 3 to 7pm. A mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY on Monday at 11am.

For a commuter rushing to catch a train, a minute can mean the difference between dinner with the family and leftovers in the microwave. What most passengers do not realize is that their minute is already there.

BUCHSBAUM--Selma Sigler, also known as "Scoot" to business and university friends. Born December 8, 1930 in Stamford, CT is a graduate of the Fine Arts School of Washington University in St. Louis, MO. Member of the William Greenleaf Eliot Society of the University. Selma went on to a career in fashion, culminating as a designer and stylist of a children's wear company Prim 'n Pretty. Wife of advertising and marketing executive Sanford "Sandy" Buchsbaum she became an adjunct member of many of the industry organizations he served on. He is chairman emeritus of the Advertising Council and past chairman of the Association of National Advertisers, the National Advertising Review Board and Vice-Chairman of the Audit Bureau of Circulations. He was Executive Vice President of Revlon Inc. and Chairman of Stevens & Buchsbaum, an advertising agency. Selma was a passionate advocate for the mentally ill, one of the original members of NARSAD (National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression), a longtime member of the Southwest Regional Mental Health Board of Connecticut and a member of NAMI (National Alliance for the Mentally Ill) and lifetime member of Hadassah. Selma is the loving mother of Susan, Ann, and Gordon, Gordon's wife Elisa and grandmother to Sarah and Jessica. She is also survived by her brother Dr. Arnold Sigler and his wife Tammra.

The House Judiciary Committee announced that its hearing on football head injuries would take place Oct. 28. The hearing is in response to a study commissioned by the NF.L. that suggested its retirees had early-onset Alzheimer's disease, dementia and other memory-related diseases at rates far exceeding those of the general population. ''The N.F.L.'s recently commissioned study by the University of Michigan regarding head injuries among former players raises significant health concerns,'' Representative John Conyers Jr., a Michigan Democrat and the chairman of the committee, said in a statement. ''The committee expects to hear from medical experts, former players, and others about the prevalence of these injuries.''
Fred Bierman handicaps Saturday's best college matchups. All times Eastern.

The hit men moved in on their target, shot him dead and then disappeared in a matter of seconds. It would have been a perfect case for José Ibarra Limón, one of this violent border city's most dogged crime investigators -- had he not been the victim. Mexico has never been particularly adept at bringing criminals to justice, and the drug war has made things worse. Investigators are now swamped with homicides and other drug crimes, most of which they will never crack. On top of the standard obstacles -- too little expertise, too much corruption -- is one that seems to grow by the day: outright fear of becoming the next body in the street.

The Yankees and the Los Angeles Angels waited four days to play Game 1 of the American League Championship Series on Friday. Now they are facing a possible time crunch between Games 2 and 3. With a foreboding forecast for Game 2 on Saturday, the teams might have to play that game on Sunday, probably at 4:40 p.m. They would then travel overnight and play Game 3 on Monday at Angel Stadium at 4:15 p.m. Eastern. Baseball might move the start time later, but probably not more than a half-hour.

CURRY--Bernard Francis, on October 16, 2009 at age 91. Devoted husband for fifty-nine years of the late Lorraine Vocco Curry; cherished father of Catherine V. Curry, father-in-law of Andres V. Gil and grandfather of Elizabeth Curry Gil; youngest son of the late John F. Curry and the late Mary F. McKiernan. The last of his generation, he was predeceased by his sister, Veronica McCarthy, and his brothers, John F. Curry, Jr., Francis R. Curry and Robert E. Curry and was a much-loved surrogate father to numerous nephews and nieces. The family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), Madison Avenue at 81st Street, from 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm on Sunday, October 18th. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue, on Monday, October 19th at 10am. A memorial service will be held in Palm Beach at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to All Hallows High School, 111 East 164th Street, Bronx, NY 10452.

Health officials on Friday predicted a shortfall in the supply of swine flu vaccine, as the numbers of cases, hospitalizations and deaths grow to levels unprecedented for this time of year. Flu caused by the H1N1 virus is now widespread in 41 states, and flulike illnesses account for 6.1 percent of all doctor visits.

JENKINS--George Pollock, 94, died peacefully on Wednesday, October 14. He is survived by his wife of 64 years, Marian, his three sons, James, Robert and Richard, their spouses Nevitt, Heidi and Jackie and seven grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister, Ellen J. Smith. A graduate of Blair Academy, Princeton University and The Harvard Graduate School of Business, George spent virtually his entire professional career at The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, ultimately serving as the Chairman of the Board. He also served as a trustee of numerous corporations, non-profits and educational institutions. He was passionate about finance, education, the Presbyterian Church and his family. Funeral services will he held Saturday, October 17 at 12 noon at The Presbyterian Church of Upper Montclair, 53 Norwood Avenue, Upper Montclair, NJ 07043. In lieu of flowers, donations may be directed to Blair Academy, Blairstown, NJ 07825; or The Board of Pensions of the Presbyterian Church, Assistance Program, Room 3024, 2000 Market Street, Philadelphia, PA 19103.

When House Democrats talk about the public option, there is no single definition of what that means. In fact, there could soon be three definitions. The debate among Democrats over the public option -- a government-run insurance plan to compete with private insurers -- has mainly focused on two proposals. One is a ''robust'' plan, in which payments to doctors, hospitals and other providers would be tied to Medicare's rates. The other would require the government insurance program to negotiate its own payment rates.

(HBO) SLUMDOG MILLIONAIRE (2008) A young man from a poor area near Mumbai (Dev Patel, above left, with Anil Kapoor) becomes a game show contestant and explains how he knows the answers to all those questions in this contemporary fairy tale from Danny Boyle. The film won eight Oscars, including best motion picture, best achievement in directing for Mr. Boyle and best writing for Simon Beaufoy. The film is ''a gaudy, gorgeous rush of color, sound and motion,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''In the end, what gives me reluctant pause about this bright, cheery, hard-to-resist movie is that its joyfulness feels more like a filmmaker's calculation than an honest cry from the heart about the human spirit (or, better yet, a moral tale),'' she said, adding that Mr. Boyle ''plucked my heartstrings'' with ''well-practiced dexterity, coaxing laughter and sobs out of each sweet, sour and false note.'' 10:30 A.M. SAN FRANCISCO — Lit Crawl, the final event of Litquake, the city’s 10th annual celebration of books and writers, animated the street life of the Mission district on Saturday night. Readings featured not only literary novelists and poets, science fiction writers, writers of erotica, Jewish writers, Latino writers, writers associated with particular publications (McSweeney’s, The Threepenny Review, Bomb Magazine), zine contributors, and even bloggers, one of whom was Phil Bronstein, the former editor of The San Francisco Chronicle and former husband of the actress Sharon Stone. (That’s foreshadowing, not gratuitous celebrity name-dropping.)

Though he popularized both the expression and its acronym, WASP, in his 1964 book “The Protestant Establishment,” he did not coin either one.

1 Johnnie Sapong, the London-based hairstylist, has one goal: “I’m all about creating luscious locks,” he says. Known for edgy, layered cuts and supercool styling, Sapong regularly tends to the tresses of celebrities like Natalie Portman, Demi Moore, Jude Law and Daniel Craig. Beginning this month, the rest of us can book appointments with the scissor man at the Studio, his new Fitzrovia salon. “It won’t be your usual salon environment,” Sapong says. “The vibe will be more like you’re on a photo shoot with Johnnie.” Call 011-44- 208-560-2172 for information.

No other country breeds eccentrics like the British. Perhaps, because it is no longer an empire, the country has turned in on itself, to explore possibilities within its borders, as if to say, “Why leave when there is so much interesting stuff going on here?” While this island mentality may have encouraged colorful characters like Edith Sitwell and Lord Byron, it also gave the world genuine nutters like the 20th-century composer, writer and painter Gerald Tyrwhitt-Wilson, the 14th Baron Berners, who built his towering Faringdon Folly on his estate to be “entirely useless.” Herewith, some other peculiar folks from across the pond. From Mayr & More health spa, deep in Austria, the British interior designer extraordinaire and irrepressible party giver and -goer Nicholas Haslam explained his whereabouts: “Well, my dear, I needed to shape up!” Haslam, 70, was there to prepare for the November release of his memoir, “Redeeming Features” (Knopf). The book is set on a planet akin to earth but peopled only with the famous and the fabulous. And so he paints watercolors for Princess Michael of Kent, gives a party for the Rolling Stones and hosts Truman Capote at his horse ranch. “It’s not embarrassing, I think,” he says of the 352-page romp. “Although if the critics hate it, I’ll probably kill myself.” [?][?][?] STEPHEN HEYMAN.
Bunny Roger made exquisite dresses, but his best creation was himself.

O.K., so it’s a classic. Some would call it, like the tuxedo jacket or the little black dress, one of fashion’s most iconic pieces. It came to light in the 1940s when, because of the war and burgeoning modern life, items like the floor-length tea gown became less of an option. But it was in the ’50s that the twin set met its moment. Think of any movie or TV show set back then. Did every woman really, truly wear it every day? I find it hard to believe because here’s the truth: yeah, they work if you’re Grace Kelly or January Jones. If your shoulders are narrow and your waist even smaller and you have the sort of radiant beauty that transforms something inherently plain into the epitome of chic. (Tilda Swinton, check! Dame Judi Dench, check! The Duchess of Devonshire, check!) But if you’re a mere mortal like me, wearing a cardigan over a matching short-sleeve sweater risks making you looking like an elderly aunt from the pages of P. G. Wodehouse. Which makes me all the more envious of all those utterly unflappable, self-confident beauties, who don a twin set (like the Pringle of Scotland one above) and look implacably terrific. [?][?][?] DAISY GARNETT.

O.K., let’s get back to basics on this one. “It,” according to Elinor Glyn, who coined the expression in a novella titled simply “It,” “is that quality possessed by some which draws all others with its magnetic force. With ‘It’ you draw all men if you are a woman — all women if you are a man.” While Glyn arrived at this formulation to describe Clara Bow, an American who played the “It” girl in the eponymous 1927 movie version, the writer was herself British. And although Bow’s sweet creaminess of an ingénue in the steely crucible of a femme fatale became synonymous with sex appeal at the end of the orgasmically yelping ’20s, when the “It” girl tottered back on the scene after World War II, she was a Brit once more.

When it comes to cutting-edge style and pop culture, no city can swing it like London — and this year is the 25th anniversary of the British Fashion Council, which has helped promote some of the country’s most iconoclastic designers. It was in the fall of 1984, during London’s first fashion week, that a young unknown named John Galliano presented a groundbreaking collection titled “Afghanistan Repudiates Western Ideals.” Other innovative designers would follow, like the duo behind Bodymap, who turned club-kid wear into high fashion; Alexander McQueen, who gave the world the super-low-riding “bumster pant”; and Hussein Chalayan, who ended one show with models shattering paste dresses with little hammers. It seems apt that with the current wave of homegrown talent — Giles Deacon, Jonathan Saunders, Christopher Kane, Marios Schwab, Louise Goldin and Mary Katrantzou, among others — making international headlines, a British superstar would return home for the council’s silver anniversary. After years of showing in Milan, Christopher Bailey brought Burberry, the ultimate heritage label, back to London for his spring 2010 show. Indeed, Britannia still rules. [?][?][?] ARMAND LIMNANDER.

PERNICK--Frances. The American Committee for Shenkar College in Israel records with deep sorrow the passing of Frances Pernick, beloved wife of David Pernick, life chancellor of Shenkar College of Engineering and Design, loving mother of Bruce Pernick, president of the American Committee and his wife Susan, and loving mother of Jill Friedman and her husband Mitchell. Frances was a devoted supporter of the College in Ramat Gan, Israel, where the main campus building, the Frances and David Pernick building, is named in their honor. Inspired by her leadership, her grandchildren Pamela Ollendorff and Jocelyn Steelman are dedicated members of our board. To her entire family, we offer our sincere and heartfelt condolences. Frances will be remembered for her graciousness, dignity and commitment to education in Israel. She will be missed. Charlotte A. Fainblatt, Executive Director of the American Committee for Shenkar College

SHAW--Iris Azian, 1927-2009, a pioneering child advocate and loving wife and mother, died on October 9 in Pasadena, California at age 82. The cause was complications from leukemia and arterial disease. Though she earned two law degrees in her lifetime, Mrs. Shaw chose not to practice law but to use her knowledge and skills as an informed volunteer to help the abused and neglected children caught up in the foster care and juvenile justice systems. Mrs. Shaw was born in Hartford, Connecticut, on January 15, 1927 to parents of Armenian descent. Her shopkeeper father, like many immigrants of that time, believed in the American Dream and told his daughter that she could make anything of herself in this country. She went on to graduate from Boston Latin School, trained as a concert pianist, and became one of the first women to earn a JD from Boston University Law School. Immediately afterward she passed the Massachusetts bar exam with the highest score to that date. In 1949, a Harvard student named Anthony Shaw working as a waiter the summer before his senior year took her order, and they married six years later. In 1970, with three children in tow they moved to Charlottesville, Virginia, where Dr. Shaw became a professor of pediatric surgery at the University of Virginia and Mrs. Shaw devoted herself to helping children in the web of the dependency court and foster care systems. She used her knowledge of the law and her devotion to child welfare to help found Community Attention, group homes that provided adolescent offenders an alternative to more punitive, and less effective, detention facilities. This rehabilitation option was controversial at the time but proved extremely effective in lowering recidivism rates and became a much-replicated model. During these years Mrs. Shaw also chaired the board that oversaw the regional jail, taught law through the University of Virginia to law enforcement and security officers and advised the governor of Virginia on juvenile justice issues. She and Dr. Shaw moved to Pasadena, California, in 1981, where she joined the ranks of volunteers at CASA (Court Appointed Special Advocates) in Los Angeles. Though only five feet tall, she often traveled alone into many of the city's roughest neighborhoods to interview relatives of children whose fate lay with the courts so she could represent those children as effectively as possible. Her tireless advocacy moved Los Angeles County to name her its Volunteer of the Year in 1994. She discovered late in life that she loved nothing more than zipping around icebergs and glaciers in an inflatable Zodiac boat in the Arctic and Antarctic, and she and Dr. Shaw made numerous trips to the far north and far south. She did all she did with profound humility, always giving and never expecting anything in return. She is survived by Dr. Anthony Shaw, her husband of 54 years; three children, Dr. Brian Shaw of Roanoke, Virginia, Diana Shaw Clark of London, UK, and Daniel Shaw of Woody Creek, Colorado; eight grandchildren; and a sister, Mrs. Seda Dennis of Manomet, Massachusetts. In lieu of flowers or anything else, the family asks that contributions be made to: The Iris A. Shaw Memorial Fund, CASA of Los Angeles, 201 Centre Plaza Drive, Suite 3, Monterey Park, CA 91754-2142. 323-526-6329

Outside the walls of Yankee Stadium, underneath the elevated subway tracks, the former Yankee Jim Leyritz sat at a table underneath a sign with his name written in black marker selling his autograph. Leyritz, who has been kept at arms' length by the Yankees and Major League Baseball since he was arrested on charges of driving under the influence and vehicular manslaughter on Dec. 28, 2007, in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., set up outside Stan's Sporting Goods on River Avenue before both Games 1 and 2 of the American League Championship Series.

BROGAN--Patricia Kelly, passed away peacefully on Saturday, October 10th, in West Palm Beach, Florida, after a short illness at the age of 84. She lived in New York City and Southampton, New York, but had recently moved to Florida to be close to her children living there. She is survived by her twin daughters Kelly Brogan and Susan Brogan, as well as the joy of her life, grandson Nicholas Brogan. After graduating from Finch College, Pat was married in 1951 to Thomas J. Brogan, Jr., until his death in 2001. Her family and friends remember her for her generosity of spirit, loyalty, thoughtfulness, and great sense of humor. She will be remembered as well for her dedication and work as a former president of the Youth Counseling League in New York. The family will celebrate Pat's life at a memorial mass at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th Street, on Tuesday, October 27th at 10:30. In lieu of flowers, donations to Youth Counseling League, 386 Park Avenue South, New York, New York 10016-8836 would be greatly appreciated.

BIG cities like New York are both deeply convenient -- two steps to the deli for milk in the morning -- and deeply inconvenient. It is possible to live in the same city as the person you are dating, and have to travel an hour, or even two, to get together. Those long subway rides are so annoying that they shape not only dating patterns, but real estate choices. And interborough dating has become more common with the dispersal of single New Yorkers throughout the city.

RIEDER--Edward Elliott. Physical Therapist. March 13, 1921-October 13, 2009. Beloved husband of Sarah Grace Orleans Rieder. Cherished father of Susan and Robert. Delighted grandfather of William, Peter, Jessica, Mitchell and Maddie. His gentle presence is deeply missed. A man of kindness, humor and wisdom, who cared greatly for others.

An article on Page 4 this weekend about Sienna Miller misstates the nature of the relationships that she had with Heath Ledger and Sean Combs. She was friends with both of them; she did not have romantic flings with them.

Sales of new autos may have plunged, but sales of old autos -- from around 30 to 100 years old, that is -- were brisk last weekend at the Vintage Motor Cars of Hershey annual auction in Pennsylvania. The event, run by RM Auctions, posted about $9 million in sales, and, almost in defiance of the recession, 94 percent of the 136 cars on offer were sold. The top seller was a 1931 Marmon Sixteen convertible coupe, which brought a winning bid of $517,000.

BERNSTEIN--Morton J. The Directors and Staff of The Fan Fox and Leslie R. Samuels Foundation mourn the loss of their beloved colleague and friend Mort Bernstein on October 8, 2009. Mort served the Foundation as an officer and director for more than 50 years. As the first President after the death of the founders, Mort designed the Foundation's performing arts program, which today supports over 120 arts organizations in New York City each year. He also led the effort to expand the Foundation's grant-making into healthcare and the social services. At the time of his death, he held the title of Chairman Emeritus in recognition of his leadership and contribution to the Foundation's mission. We will miss Mort for the hallmarks of his service: sound judgment, common sense, and great consideration for others. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Muriel, his children, Eva and Adam, and his granddaughter, Sarah.

Loving father of Jessica Vitrouk of Moscow, Russia, Helen Perera of New York City and Margaret Phelps of Waltham, MA. Caring grandfather of Polina and Sophie Vitrouk and Elizabeth Phelps. Devoted brother of Lawrence T. and Ronald C. Perera and the late Phillips Perera. Funeral Service, Saturday, October 24 at 2pm in St. Anne's-in-the-Fields Church, 147 Concord Rd., Lincoln, MA. For obituary, donations and online guestbook visit www.concordfuneral.com

COME next spring, flounce and flou can drop and give us 20. Given the recent fashion collections, army fatigues will be our uniform. With washed leather flak jackets at Haider Ackermann (center left), olive-drab shirts at Balmain (below left) and tailored military tops at Celine (far left), a surplus supply of the stuff came marching down the Paris runways. And lately the French Vogue editor Carine Roitfeld (seated) has been dressing like a drill sergeant in khaki-colored button-downs and an army-green parka. But, of course, the look is no new thing. Military style regularly appears, in some degree, on the runways. For this fall, Comme des Garçons sent out an array of fleece-lined military jackets and olive-drab coats. Dsquared did cargo pants. For more authentic and far less expensive options, there are Army-Navy stores, where the stylist Kate Young, an army fatigues devotee, has been shopping since she was a teenager.
BAUM--Elihu M. Husband of 60 years, Father, Grandfather, Brother, Uncle, Cousin, The "E" of W&E Baum, WWII Vet, World Traveler, Sculptor, Fisherman, Artist, Mentor, Friend. Beloved by all.

CONAN O'BRIEN The Nobel committee is saying the reason they gave Obama the peace prize is for reducing tension around the world. So, the runners-up for this year's Nobel Prize were red wine and the Brookstone three-speed massaging recliner.

Tarrytown, which sits high on a hill and has majestic views of the Hudson River, claims as a native son none other than Washington Irving, the author of ''The Legend of Sleepy Hollow'' and other spooky tales. Its sister village, North Tarrytown, voted to rename itself Sleepy Hollow in 1996. So a visit to both villages is worthwhile, especially as Halloween looms and Irving's tales come to life -- at least in the imagination. Take the Hudson Line on Metro-North from Grand Central Terminal to Tarrytown. KATE STONE LOMBARDI
