ARNOLD--John Bentley, died at age 87 in his home in San Francisco where he had been residing since 1980. Jack was born in Quincy, IL in 1922. He attended Phillips Academy Andover, graduated from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and immediately joined the Navy as one of its early radar experts. He served on the Aircraft Carrier USS Hancock, finally leaving the ship, as a Lt. Commander, after it was disabled by kamikaze pilots on Okinawa. After the war Jack graduated from Harvard Business School. He served for 30 years with General Telephone and Electronics. As President of GTE International he was responsible for an organization with 35,000 employees throughout the world. During his presidency GTE International sales grew from $500 million to $1.3 billion. He was the architect and mediator of a number of important multinational consortiums that completed telecommunication projects all over the world. He worked with countless nationalities and religions. He lived in Italy for 25 years, was in Tehran the day the Shah took power from Mossadegh, and was there again the day the Shah was deposed by Khomeini. Jack worked in partnership with members of the Israeli, Egyptian, Algerian and, Indian government, to mention a few, and formed enduring bonds of friendship based on mutual trust and respect. His encyclopedic knowledge of history, his keen and sensitive curiosity of other cultures and religions and his open, sensitive and dependable nature fostered a deep trust that allowed very difficult international partnerships to flourish. He worked as consultant with Comsat in Washington, DC for two years; and, in 1980 came to California as President of Farinon Electric Company, later sold to Harris Corporation of Florida. He was subsequently appointed to various Boards of Directors in California and served as interim president of Equipment Technology. He was a devout Catholic and a great supporter of Catholic Charities. In San Francisco, he was active with the Rose Resnik Center for the Blind and served on its Board of Directors. He is survived by his wife Ann to whom he was married for 57 years, by his sons Peter and Stephen Arnold, and his daughter Susan Arnold-Aldea, his son-in-law Gabriel Aldea, and two grandsons, Alexander and Daniel Aldea all of whom will always be guided by his wisdom and generosity.

A week after sustaining a concussion in a loss to Iowa, Michigan's Tate Forcier, left, led the Wolverines to a touchdown on his only drive in a 63-6 victory over Delaware State. ''He still needs reps,'' Coach Rich Rodriguez said. Get your punch lines ready. A season after going 12-2 and playing in a bowl game, Ball State, David Letterman's alma mater, dropped to 0-7 after a 31-17 home loss to Bowling Green.

IN late 2007 Scott Stapp, the frontman of the rock band Creed, walked into the bathroom of his Boca Raton, Fla., home, grabbed a razor and did the unthinkable: He shaved his head. His band had split up three years earlier, and ever since Mr. Stapp had felt adrift, putting out a poorly received solo album and struggling with his self-confessed appetites for alcohol and painkillers. In 2006 he had become sober, reconnected with his family and rededicated himself to Christianity. But with his trademark long brown locks he looked like the same guy he'd always been.

TRANSFORMERS: REVENGE OF THE FALLEN Giant extraterrestrial robots battle under the direction of Michael Bay (''Pearl Harbor'') in the sequel to his 2007 hit inspired by the Hasbro toys. One has to admire ''the perverse genius of Michael Bay,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times in June. ''Despite the tediousness of his stories and inanity of his visual ideas, he always manages to keep you laughing and shaking your head in disbelief at the outlandishness of his cinematic spectacles, with their orange explosions, armament fetishism and even their noxious stereotypes.'' With Shia LaBeouf and Megan Fox. (Paramount, Blu-ray $39.99, two-disc standard definition $34.98, single-disc standard definition $29.98, PG-13) FAWLTY TOWERS: THE COMPLETE COLLECTION Remastered versions of all 12 episodes from the first (1975) and second (1979) series of the beloved Britcom. John Cleese stars as the short-tempered proprietor of a dingy seaside hotel; Connie Booth is his forbearing wife. (BBC Warner, $49.98, not rated)

STANTON--John J.,Jr., of Greenwich, CT, formerly of Rye, NY, died on October 15, 2009. Born on August 23, 1932 in New York City he grew up in Mamaroneck, NY and Portland, OR. A graduate of Santa Clara University and Georgetown Law School. He proudly served as a Lieutenant in US Marine Corps. He practiced law with the National Labor Relations Board, was Labor Counsel and head of the legal department of the New York Times and served of Counsel with Cahill, Gordon and Reindel. He also taught law at the University of the District of Columbia. Member of American Yacht Club. Parishioner of Resurrection Church in Rye, and a religious education teacher there. He enjoyed traveling, gardening and cooking. He is survived by his wife of 49 years, Mary-Jane (Handler), his children: John, Sue Ann (Gail Romano), Gregory (Maria Del Guercio) and Hugh as well as his grandchildren, Isobella, Luke and Nina. A devoted friend, Jack guided those close to him with his sharp intellect, dry wit, and gentle laugh. Jack Stanton was never one to suffer fools gladly. Friends may call at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580 on Sunday, October 18, from 3 to 7pm. A mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY on Monday at 11am.

The spectacle to remember at the Paris fashion collections two weeks ago was without a doubt Chanel. More than 3,000 guests turned out at 10 in the morning, many in full Chanel autumn regalia -- specifically, pleated organza cuffs and collars on black jackets that crisply pronounced the femininity that is a hallmark of French style. Hundreds of women wore variations of the look. Karl Lagerfeld, the house's head designer, created a Marie Antoinette-style barn inside the Grand Palais; the models showing his spring clothes emerged from a giant haystack. The show ended with several models having a romp in the hay with a boyfriend. One itched to give an old-fashioned hoedown in the setting, with guests in lumberjack shirts, jeans and boots dancing away the recession blues. I remember so well square-dancing evenings in America in the late 1930s and '40s, bobbing for apples included.

KAHN--Robert L.,who lived life to the fullest, died on October 16 at the age of 77. Mr. Kahn co-founded the investment management firm of W P Stewart & Co. in 1974. He was a vital contributor to the company's uniquely successful investment philosophy. He continued to serve as a senior member of their investment management group until his recent illness. Robert Kahn was a renaissance man in many fields. He received top accolades as an athlete in tennis, running, and as a pianist. His generous spirit has inspired and empowered innumerable individuals and institutions. In lieu of flowers, consider supporting the non-profits established by his son, Stephen Kahn, M.D. (The Abundance Foundation www.abundance.net) and his daughter-in-law, Heather Williams Psy.D. (Veterans Resource www.veteransresource.org). He is survived by his wife, Helen, sons Stephen and Rocky, daughters-in-law Elizabeth Hodder Kahn and Heather Williams, and grandchildren, Zoe and Noah Kahn.

THE NEWS The Dow Jones industrial average, one of the most watched barometers of the economy, closed above 10,000 points last Wednesday for the first time since Oct. 3, 2008. BEHIND THE NEWS Major stock indexes have rebounded by 50 percent in a rally that began in early March. But they are still well below their record highs. The Dow first closed above 10,000 in March 1999 and peaked above 14,000 in October 2007. Still, said one market watcher, ''The last time we saw 10,000, we were going the wrong way.''
Theater Jason Zinoman

BECAUSE six-inch platform stilettos were not intended for racing to fashion shows, Maryam and Marjan Malakpour, stylists based in Los Angeles, created Newbark, a line of handmade folding leather flats that are as classic and cool as they are comfy. During the recent collections, they offered respite to quite a few hobbling editors. ''Your feet get tired, you pull them out of your bag,'' said Maryam Malakpour. ''They're a luxurious essential you carry everywhere. Kind of like a cashmere scarf.'' And, inspired aesthetically by ''a mélange of characters,'' as she put it, from the Moroccan babouche to an English gentleman's slipper, they are anything but run-of-the-mill ballet flats. ''At this point, people are excited to see something different,'' she said.

Polls show that a majority of people in this country are utterly bewildered by the health care bills Congress is considering, and that they have no idea how each would affect their family budgets or their medical care. Those questions should become somewhat easier to answer as Congress moves closer to producing a single piece of legislation. (Don't hold your breath; that may not be until Christmas.)

THE car's engine roared as the gunman punched the accelerator and we crossed into the open Afghan desert. I was seated in the back between two Afghan colleagues who were accompanying me on a reporting trip when armed men surrounded our car and took us hostage. Another gunman in the passenger seat turned and stared at us as he gripped his Kalashnikov rifle. No one spoke. I glanced at the bleak landscape outside -- reddish soil and black boulders as far as the eye could see -- and feared we would be dead within minutes.

THE Colombian-born fashion photographer Ruven Afanador has built a remarkable career out of capturing the raw and impassioned beauty of his subjects. His latest book, an homage to the women of flamenco entitled ''Mil Besos'' -- 1,000 kisses, in Spanish -- is perhaps his most powerful work yet. The women in these images, dressed in all-black Galliano, Versace and Dolce & Gabbana, their eyes rimmed in inky kohl, emerge from Mr. Afanador's imagination, inspired by the fantastic tales told to him as a child. And photographed under the blinding sun, against the stark terrain of Andalusia, they assume enchanting qualities -- something that is not lost on them. ''I had a very defined image of my flamenco woman,'' Mr. Afanador wrote by e-mail from Granada, Spain, where his work is now on view. ''Amazingly, the women embraced it and allowed me to play with them as I would with a model. Some of them spoke of it as magic surrealism.''

ULLMANN--Samson O. A.,of Schenectady, NY, died on October 11, 2009 at the age of 88 years. He was born in Brooklyn, NY, the only child of Samson O.A. Ullmann, Sr., and Juliette Ullmann (nee Bergman). Sam attended the Brooklyn Poly Prep school, and he earned a BA at Harvard, an MA at Stanford and a Ph.D. at Harvard in 1954. He then taught at the University of Minnesota before moving to Union College, where he was a professor in the English department from 1957 until his retirement in 1992. During the second world war, Sam was an officer in the US Army, serving in the pacific. His scholarly work included "Men, Books, and Mountains" a volume of essays of Sir Leslie Stephen, Hogarth Press, 1956, and "The Yale Manuscript: Matthew Arnold," University of Michigan press 1989. His academic interest were Victorian literature and modern drama. Sam frequently spent winters in London and was very knowledgeable in the theater there. Sam was a very kind and generous person. He loved chamber music both here and at Wigmore Hall in London. He also enjoyed his garden (the azaleus and rhododendrons were extraordinary). He will be fondly remembered by family and friends. Memorials to Union College or Proctor's theater in Schenectady.
Dealing With Bedbugs In a Rented Condo

ASIDE from their carefree cool, there is a simple reason why the youthful, slightly coquettish side-swept hairstyles at Prada (left) and Alexander Wang (above) were the most talked-about looks at the recent fashion shows. ''They're attainable,'' said Guido Palau, the British hairstylist behind both of them. ''Women are attracted to that.'' Indeed, pigtails and a sporty Brooke Shields-circa-1980 side-braid are easy to achieve at home, but do they work on everyone? ''Well, you have to be a bit careful with the pigtails,'' Mr. Palau cautioned. ''Some women can adapt them into a ponytail with the front still swept teasingly to the side, but the braid can be very beautiful on older women. Look at Georgia O'Keeffe.''

In their last 17 postseason games before this October, Yankees starters were 2-9 with a 6.30 earned run average. They have turned that around in unprecedented fashion. C. C. Sabathia, A. J. Burnett and Andy Pettitte all pitched at least six innings while allowing no more than one earned run in the division series sweep of the Minnesota Twins. Then Sabathia went eight innings in Game 1 against the Angels, allowing just one run.

CLARKSON--Evelyn Clark, died peacefully at home in Chester, CT on October 12, 2009. Daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. J. F. A. Clark of New York and Newport, RI and wife of the late Christopher Clarkson. She leaves her daughter, Diana Hitt Potter, her grandson, Horatio Potter and his wife Elizabeth and her great-grandson, Jeffrey Potter. A former president of the board of Austin Riggs Center, she worked at Vogue magazine and as a writer for the Red Cross in Germany after World War II. Contributions in her memory may be made to Austin Riggs Center, Stockbridge, MA 01262.
Art Carol Vogel

MARANTZ--Dr. Harold, died October 7, 2009, age 86. Harvard B.A., N.Y.U. DDS. Served in U.S. Army as Lieutenant in the dental corps in World War II. After advanced study, practiced as dental anesthesiologist and taught at St. Luke's Hospital. Survived by his brother, Kenneth, nieces Susan and Janet, and nephew Alec Marantz, and their children. He should be remembered as an active, curious man who traveled widely and participated in several sports, including years on his sailboat. One of his many friends writes: "He was a true intellectual, a fair person, always examining, studying an issue further; his thinking always so crisp. I will miss our conversations on philosophy, politics, ... history." A memorial service is planned for a future date. Donations would be welcome to the National Yiddish Book Center in Amherst, MA, to honor his value of literature and Jewish culture.

CONTINUING hard times at Harley-Davidson resulted in an announcement Thursday that the company would kill its Buell line of sport bikes and was looking for a buyer for its MV Agusta brand. Buell will shut down later this month, although Harley will continue to supply replacement parts and honor warranty claims. About 180 workers will lose their jobs.

THE bartender at the Summit Bar, a new cocktail lounge on Avenue C, did an interesting thing last week. He talked about the weather. At most bars, of course, this wouldn't even bear noticing. But in the rarefied world of cocktail-centric bars -- the kind of places where, as at the Summit Bar, the drinks are bedizened with ingredients like saffron orange tincture and cardamom-infused agave syrup, and the ice cubes are the size of fuzzy dice -- the bartender's role has, in recent years, made a subtle shift.

COME next spring, flounce and flou can drop and give us 20. Given the recent fashion collections, army fatigues will be our uniform. With washed leather flak jackets at Haider Ackermann (center left), olive-drab shirts at Balmain (below left) and tailored military tops at Celine (far left), a surplus supply of the stuff came marching down the Paris runways. And lately the French Vogue editor Carine Roitfeld (seated) has been dressing like a drill sergeant in khaki-colored button-downs and an army-green parka. But, of course, the look is no new thing. Military style regularly appears, in some degree, on the runways. For this fall, Comme des Garçons sent out an array of fleece-lined military jackets and olive-drab coats. Dsquared did cargo pants. For more authentic and far less expensive options, there are Army-Navy stores, where the stylist Kate Young, an army fatigues devotee, has been shopping since she was a teenager.

Molly Elizabeth Rusten and Peter Charles Rosen were married Saturday at the Mount, Edith Wharton's summer home in Lenox, Mass. The ceremony was led by the bride's paternal grandfather, Paul D. Rusten, who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate. The bride, 30, teaches English as a second language at Public School 183 in New York. She graduated from Cornell and received a master's in English as a second language at New York University. She is a daughter of Caroline Ware Rusten and Jeffrey S. Rusten, who live and work in Ithaca, N.Y. Her father is a classics professor at Cornell. Her mother is a freelance writer.

A picture caption last Sunday in the Evening Hours column misidentified a guest at the benefit gala for the Museum of the City of New York on Oct. 6. She is Melanie Seymour Holland, not Allison Rockefeller.

ELLIS--Dean, was a great friend, a loving husband, a devoted father, a role model, a colleague and a loyal and passionate member of the Society of Illustrators for 51 years. But what he was best at was being an artist. His visions will live on along with the memory of his kindness, his decency, his ever-present fire and his insatiable passion to do good. The Society of Illustrators pays tribute to his decades of devotion.

The weight in pounds (about an ounce) that one cubic foot of helium can lift, at sea level. So let's break out our calculators. Was there enough helium in the errant balloon that escaped into the Colorado sky last Thursday to have whisked the 6-year-old Falcon Heene up and away for a journey across the plains?

People move from New York City to the suburbs along the New Jersey Transit rail lines with dreams of 40-minute commutes, little expecting the occasional whopping delays that cause them to miss tucking their children into bed. The Local, The New York Times blog covering the South Mountain towns, often tracks such delays in detail. Next week, we are beginning an experiment in commuter-assisted reporting: Residents riding to Pennsylvania Station are invited to send in information from their phones about whether their train arrived early, late or on time. (See the blog for details.) In partnership with Clever Commute, a business that sends alerts about delays via e-mail, The Local will compile and analyze the information and report back on the blog.

Few would have predicted this, but after five weeks, Rex Ryan's supposedly swarming defense is tied with Jacksonville for fewest sacks (four) in the N.F.L. Sack totals can be misleading, but in the last two games, the Jets have put little pressure on the quarterback, largely because they have failed to stop the run. In fact, Ryan noted that Buffalo had more sacks in one game (six, against Miami) than the Jets have this season. Help comes in the form of Buffalo's injured offensive line, which has yielded 18 sacks and had 9 false-start penalties last week. Worth noting: Buffalo fired the offensive coordinator Turk Schonert shortly before the season and replaced him with Alex Van Pelt.

GRAFF--Marjorie Sawyer Goodman, 95, died on October 13, 2009 at her home in Bedminster, NJ after an extended illness. She is survived by her husband, Robert D. Graff, three children, Ariane Dewey Dannasch, Christopher C. Dewey and Suzette Graff Dewey, by seven grandchildren, two great-grandchildren as well as by her niece, Sheila King Hixon and Marcia S. Dewey. Predeceased by her son, Kenneth S.G. Dewey in 1972. A memorial service will held Friday, October 23, 2009 at 11am at St. Luke's Church, Gladstone, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the New York Public Library (NYPL) for the Performing Arts Dance Committee, 40 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023 or to the Friends of the New Jersey State Museum, P.O. Box 530, Trenton, NJ 08625.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Right Turn,'' Oct. 11: Thank you for the article on Ted Ginn. What an inspirational man and vision. My only question is why on the sports page? Football is such a small part of this amazing story.

CURRY--Bernard Francis, on October 16, 2009 at age 91. Devoted husband for fifty-nine years of the late Lorraine Vocco Curry; cherished father of Catherine V. Curry, father-in-law of Andres V. Gil and grandfather of Elizabeth Curry Gil; youngest son of the late John F. Curry and the late Mary F. McKiernan. The last of his generation, he was predeceased by his sister, Veronica McCarthy, and his brothers, John F. Curry, Jr., Francis R. Curry and Robert E. Curry and was a much-loved surrogate father to numerous nephews and nieces. The family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), Madison Avenue at 81st Street, from 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm on Sunday, October 18th. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue, on Monday, October 19th at 10am. A memorial service will be held in Palm Beach at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to All Hallows High School, 111 East 164th Street, Bronx, NY 10452.

WOOD--Gabrielle S.,95, widow of Kenneth Wood, passed away October 12. Born in Flushing, NY; resided in Queens, NY 40 plus years; moved to northern Virginia in 1980; then to Clearwater, FL in 2000. Survived by her only child Susan-Jane Howard; four grandchildren; six great- grandchildren. The family requests memorial donations to the Suncoast Hospice Foundation.

PERNICK--Frances. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-LIJ Health System mourn the loss of Frances Pernick, wife of David Pernick, an Honorary Trustee. The Pernicks' generous support has enabled the health system to become a leading healthcare provider over the years, and reflects a dedicated commitment to helping North Shore-LIJ improve the lives of residents in our local communities. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Michael J. Dowling, President & CEO Saul B. Katz, Chairman North Shore-LIJ Health System

McDADE--Robert Alexander, died October 14th after a long struggle with cancer. Born August 11, 1922 in Manhattan, the Old Colonel always said, "you weren't dead until you were in the New York Times." His long military career included infantry service in WW II, Korea and Vietnam, as well as many wounds. After retiring in 1975 he settled with his wife, Elinor, in Sag Harbor, where he served as Trustee on the Village Board and the library. The McDades owned and managed The Goat Alley Gallery in Sag Harbor for twenty three years. He is survived by his wife and many cousins and friends who will miss him. In lieu of flowers and anything else, please donate to East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978.

Bye month is over for the Giants. They beat Tampa Bay, Kansas City and Oakland by a combined score of 95-23 in the last three weeks and outgained them, 1,254 yards to 403. The Giants (5-0) have a flashy record and a mostly healthy roster, but little idea of what they are capable of besides daisy stomping. Their three-week scrimmage did not have a major effect on the standings: the Philadelphia Eagles finish buttering the same three-team short stack this week. Of course, victories are not guaranteed against punching-bag opponents (see Giants-Browns last year), and the road to the Super Bowl is often paved with blowout victories against patsies. The Giants laughed through a similar stretch in 2007, beating four bad opponents by a combined score of 112-59. The brief downhill gave them the momentum needed to coast into the postseason.

SAVAGE--Walter T.,of Madison, NJ, passed away on October 9. A former president of Fairleigh Dickinson University, and Professor Emeritus of English, Walter is survived by his wife, Patricia. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, October 20, 3-5pm, Lenfell Hall in Hennessy Hall, FDU, College at Florham, Madison, NJ.

CONSIDERING that barely a word has been changed from the original, the warning on the cover of a new, illustrated version of the Book of Genesis -- ''Adult Supervision Recommended for Minors'' -- might seem surprising. Until, that is, one reads the name of the illustrator: R. Crumb. Mr. Crumb is known almost as much for his bawdy underground comix featuring characters like Fritz the Cat and Mr. Natural as he is for ''Crumb,'' the 1994 documentary about him. But he has been driven less by his sexual impulses in recent years and more by the 45 minutes he spends in seated meditation every morning in the medieval town house he shares with his wife, Aline (they became grandparents this month), in the south of France.

ROSENBLATT--Jerri. The Board of Governors and Members of The Falls Country Club, Lake Worth, FL, acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Jerri Rosenblatt, wife of our Founding Member, Moe Rosenblatt. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved husband Moe and their family. Ed Levine, President

TANENBAUM--Charles J.,died on October 17, 2009 at age 94, devoted husband of Szilvia Szmuk-Tanenbaum and proud father of Ann Tanenbaum, his daughter by the late Mary Mayer Tanenbaum, to whom he had been happily married for 59 years. Graduate of Exeter, Harvard College and Yale Law School, he was admitted to the New York Bar in 1937. He served in the army during World War II and the Korean War, primarily in Military Intelligence at the Pentagon. His active legal practice largely ended by 1947, when his father's death left him with primary responsibility for family real estate. He served for over fifty years in leadership roles in the Jewish Foundation for Education of Women and was active in the refugee field with the American Jewish Philanthropic Fund and the International Rescue Committee. Beginning as a book collector in 1963, what started as a hobby became a second career including service on Library Visiting Committees at Harvard and Stanford universities; mounting over thirty book exhibitions at libraries across the nation. Charles had a unique and imaginative approach to philanthropy. During his lifetime, he established several awards in a variety of institutions, and these were always named for people whose contribution to that particular institution was meaningful: The Hamilton Award at New York Hospital in White Plains; the Douglas Bryant Award at Harvard Library; the Miller Award at FEGS; the Fabrizio Michelassi Award for graduating Surgical Residents and Medical Students at Weill Cornell Medical School & New York Presbyterian Hospital; and the George Baer Award for medical students in the joint MD and MPH program at Mount Sinai School of Medicine. He was an honorary member of the Grolier Club after 40 years of distinguished membership. He also enjoyed the conviviality of the Century, Harmonie, Harvard and Lotos Clubs in New York and the Book Club of California. In lieu of flowers, you may wish to make a charitable donation to an organization of your choice in Charles' memory. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell-Funeral Chapel (1076 Madison Avenue), Tuesday, October 20 at 3:30pm. The family will be receiving at the Funeral Chapel on Monday evening from 6-9pm. In addition, there will be a gathering celebrating Charles' life at the Grolier Club at a date to be determined.

9 P.M. (IFC) MONTY PYTHON: ALMOST THE TRUTH (THE LAWYER'S CUT) The five living members of this British comedy troupe -- above, from left, Michael Palin, John Cleese, Terry Jones, Terry Gilliam and Eric Idle -- reunite in this new six-hour documentary series as part of ''Python-a-thon,'' a celebration of the 40th anniversary of the group's creation. (Archival material stands in for Graham Chapman, the sixth member, who died in 1989.) In interviews Jimmy Fallon, Lorne Michaels, Hugh Hefner, Eddie Izzard, Olivia Harrison, Stephen Merchant, Dan Aykroyd, Tim Roth and Seth Green offer their takes on the Python's particular brand of humor. ''This is the documentary I always hoped would be made,'' Mr. Jones says. ''Something so complete and so faithful to the truth that I don't need to watch it.'' But you'll probably want to. The series will be broadcast at 9 each night through Friday. Sunday night's installment is followed at 10 by ''Monty Python Live at the Hollywood Bowl'' (1982) and at 11:30 by an episode of ''Monty Python's Flying Circus.'' 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH JOHN KINGRahm Emanuel, White House chief of staff, and Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, discuss health care reform, Afghanistan and President Obama's agenda before joining Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, on ''Face the Nation'' at 10:30 on CBS.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Fair Ball Is Ruled Foul, Helping Yankees Escape,'' Oct. 10: The left-field umpire ruled foul a fair ball hit by Minnesota's Joe Mauer in the 11th inning of Game 2 of a division series game against the Yankees. Twins Manager Ron Gardenhire was asked how the game might have been different if the ball had been called fair and Mauer had ended up on second with a double. Gardenhire replied: ''Next guy got a single. You can figure that out, I think.''

THE WILD SIDE Predators are not an important problem for most of us today, but they surely were for our ancestors. Indeed, millions of years ago, fear of predators would have been one of the forces that caused our ancestors to evolve to live in groups. The seeds of our social lives were watered with blood and nurtured by the roar of the lion and the claw of the leopard. More recently, however, it's been the case that the mammal most likely to kill a human is: a human. Murder and war have long been more important causes of death for us than predatory wild animals. And in many parts of the world, the human most likely to cause your violent death is: you.

THE UNCERTAIN GANG MEMBER Joshua Febres, 17, a senior at the Bronx Lab School, missed most of his sophomore year after pleading guilty to robbery and assault charges. He said he had been selling drugs since age 13 and had joined the Crips, whose members were working nearby corners. ''It was rough chilling in the streets 24/7, my mom not knowing where I'm at, you know, getting high, hustling,'' he said of that time.

THIS is a city of people who are constantly on the move. But lately I have noticed many who are completely immobile. Their favorite places to stand are on the subway stairs, either at the top, bottom or halfway up; at times, they camp smack-dab in the middle of the sidewalk. Regardless of where these people choose to stop, they are all engaged in the same activity: talking on their cellphones. And while they chatter away, like statues newly bestowed with the gift of speech, the rest of us are obliged to perform something akin to interpretive dance to make our way around them. I had a close encounter with this new brand of boor this summer. Before even reaching the entry to the Woodhaven Boulevard subway station, I spotted her from a distance. As if glued to the top step and leaning against the steel railing, she was a textbook image of the cellphone user: oblivious to everything save the words she uttered and the ones coming from the stylish model she pressed firmly to her ear. As I neared the stairs, I felt my blood pressure inching up, yet I was determined to stay calm and noncombative.

SILVER--Fred I.,nationally renowned musician, composer/lyricist, author, and vocal coach, died October 9, 2009 at the age of 73. Fred graduated from the Juilliard School of Music in 1961, and was the first recipient of the Rodgers and Hammerstein Award to a gifted composer for the Musical Theatre. In the 1970s and 80s, Fred was a very influential part of New York's Musical Theatre scene as a composer, author, and vocal coach to major artists. A Master Steinway Piano Artist, he was half of the Duo-Piano team of DeMaio & Silver. Fred's body of work includes seven musicals including "In Gay Company," over 120 choral pieces, most notably, the song, "The Twelve Days After Christmas," (1968) performed by Carol Burnett; the book "Auditioning For The Musical Theatre," and "The Audition Doctor" column for Back Stage Magazine. He is survived by his sister, Francine Firestein; brother and sister-in-law, Robert and Denise Silverberg; nieces and nephews, Sharon Joy and Andrew Seth; Abbe Lynn, Marc Frank and wife Lauren; and partner, Thomas Caskey. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Humane Society, www.hsus.org. A memorial Service will be held on Monday, October 19 at 3:30pm at the Science of Mind Center, 2 SW 12th Ave., Boca Raton, FL. 561-368-8248.

WASSERSTEIN--Bruce. In memory of 30 years of valued friendship which inspired us all. Our condolences and love to the entire Wasserstein family. Marjorie, Jeffrey, Andrew, and Daniel

As Game 2 of the American League Championship Series stretched past midnight, past the ninth inning and into a steady rain in the Bronx early Sunday, Anthony Flynn, a Yankees video coordinator, sprinkled some October history on Jerry Hairston Jr. Flynn dropped a magical name on Hairston: Luis Sojo, the utility infielder on the Yankees' last title team, in 2000. Sojo's single scored the winning run for the Yankees in that World Series, and Flynn was saying Hairston could be like him.

YOHE--Robert L.,died at his home in Bonita Springs, Florida on October 13 after a courageous battle with cancer. Born May 11, 1936 in Flushing, New York to Berdene (Walker) and Robert C. Yohe, he attended Baldwin High School on Long Island. After graduating from Lafayette College, he served in the Navy on the USS Bristol, where he was known as "Grins" to his shipmates. He achieved the rank of Lieutenant and upon discharge, entered Harvard Business School, graduating in 1964 with an MBA. His highly successful business career included executive management positions at Hooker Chemical, Uniroyal, Inc., and Olin Corporation. Bob was elected executive vice president and member of the board of directors of Olin in 1990. In 1993, he was named vice chairman of Olin and served in that capacity until his retirement in 1994. His corporate board service included Air Gas Corporation, Calgon Carbon Corporation, Albchem Industries Ltd., The Middleby Corporation and Marsulex Corporation. He served as volunteer chairman of the board of directors of the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association of Connecticut and chairman of the Connecticut Commission on Educational Excellence. In 1992, he returned to Lafayette College to serve as a member of the board of trustees where he dedicated himself to giving back to the institution that played such an important role in his life. He was vice-chair of the board of trustees from 2004 to 2007 and vice-chair of the 2004 presidential search committee. He played significant roles on numerous college committees, including investments, finance, career planning and placement, and information technology. Bob was devoted to mentoring students and helping others whenever he could. He is survived by his wife, Judith, and his stepchildren, William H. Huckins (Linda), Elizabeth Huckins Erwin (Matthew) and their children. When he lost his only brother and best friend, Thomas G. Yohe to pancreatic cancer in 2000, Bob, (affectionately known as "UB") became surrogate father to his nieces and nephews, Thomas E. Yohe, James R. Yohe, Lauren Yohe von Krusenstiern, Suzanne Yohe Tessitore, Colin R. Seely, Darren C. Seely and their 13 children who survive him. An avid golfer, Bob enjoyed annual trips with HBS classmates. He belonged to the Bonita Bay Club and the Royal Poinciana Golf Club in Florida. He and Judy maintained a summer home in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, to be close to Lafayette College and belonged there to the Saucon Valley Country Club. Bob was both an inveterate bird hunter and dedicated conservationist. He enjoyed shooting quail over dogs in the South and driven birds in England. In the past few years he returned to an early passion hunting wild pheasants this time on the great plains of South Dakota. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, November 14 in Colton Chapel, Lafayette College, Easton, PA at 2:00pm. Memorial contributions may be made to the Robert L. Yohe '58 Scholarship Fund at Lafayette College or to Hope Hospice of Lee County, FL. We will all miss Bob very much.

JERRY STAFFORD Jerry Stafford, who imagined the looks for a group of iconic British personalities (''Batty Brits,'' Page 54), wears many hats. The one by Chanel (left), he says, is ''very Silvana Mangano in 'Death in Venice,' but makes me look more like Marcel Duchamp's female alter ego, Rrose Sélavy.'' (Mangano is at right.) Stafford, the creative director of the film production company Première Heure, was raised in Bromley, England -- ''the birthplace of punk rock,'' he says -- so he felt quite at home on the set. ''The common denominator in London is the hat, from mods to hairdos to crowns to poise.''

CHELSI--Lawrence, renowned baritone and teacher, died on October 6 at 89. He sang in opera, musicals, recordings, radio, TV and concerts with Bernstein, Munch, Shaw and Toscanini. Beloved friend and mentor, Emeritus Director of NYSTA and Board Member of Aviva Players. We will always miss him and his voice.

The hit NBC show ''The Biggest Loser'' has spawned books, DVDs and even a Wii game. Now the network has opened a real-life resort, the Biggest Loser Resort at Fitness Ridge, near St. George, Utah. Like the show, the resort focuses on weight loss, albeit without all that intense competition and TV exposure. Guests can choose from a one-week package ($1,995 for a private room; $1,595 a person for a double) or a four-week stay ($7,200 and $5,600) plus tax.

WERBEL--Morton. You were Harriet's soul mate, the guiding light to Traci and Jimmy, Shelly, Andrew and Lisa, and deeply devoted to Katie and Josh. Harvey and Glenda as well as Nettie, still value the years spent together growing up with Eddie, Betty and Walter, playing music together and, all the while, with Harvey, building the Brooklyn law firm of Werbel and Werbel. Your nieces and nephews admired you from far and near, as did your many friends. From the Brownsville Boys Club and Howard Beach, Manhasset, Boca and Westhampton Beach, from Scottsdale and New England to London, England, you were celebrated. Everyone loves Morty! With your beloved Harriet by your side, the entire Jewish community worldwide has been strengthened by your dedication and philanthropy. You lived your life influentially and courageously and enjoyed the best of everything. Until the end. You were in our hearts every day and were surrounded by all of us as we showed you just how much we loved you, needed you and who, now, profoundly miss you. Your Loving Family
WEISS--Doris T. 10/16/30-8/30/03 In my heart today and always. Your Daughter, Wendy

FREEMAN--Mary Louise Corley Sampsell, 89, born in Chicago and resident of Osterville, MA. and previously of Washington, DC, passed away peacefully in her sleep on October 10, 2009. Wife of the late William R Freeman, was known affectionately to family and friends as "Jimmy". She was a world traveler renowned for her wit and humor. She is survived by her daughters, Anne Anthony and Hope Freeman, and her son Dexter Freeman, five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Donations in her memory can be sent to Foundation of the Mass Eye & Ear Infirmary 243 Charles St., Boston, MA. 02114.

Tarrytown, which sits high on a hill and has majestic views of the Hudson River, claims as a native son none other than Washington Irving, the author of ''The Legend of Sleepy Hollow'' and other spooky tales. Its sister village, North Tarrytown, voted to rename itself Sleepy Hollow in 1996. So a visit to both villages is worthwhile, especially as Halloween looms and Irving's tales come to life -- at least in the imagination. Take the Hudson Line on Metro-North from Grand Central Terminal to Tarrytown. 10 A.M. Grab a cab at the train station and head to Philipsburg Manor, 381 North Broadway in Sleepy Hollow, (914) 631-3992, a national historic landmark. (Get a card from the driver; you'll need a ride back.) In the late 17th and early 18th centuries, the manor was a farming, milling and trading complex. A visit ($12; $6 for children 5 to 17) is a trip back in time, complete with staff members in period costume, like the miller dressed in breeches and stockings who makes stone-ground corn. (A bag costs $3.) The farm also has historical breeds of oxen, cows and sheep, and you can tour the 300-year-old manor house and learn, among other things, the lesser-known story of slavery in the North. This weekend and next, the manor will hold special Halloween events for children, like pumpkin carving and the telling of ghost stories.

Shepard Fairey, the artist whose ''Hope'' poster of Barack Obama became an emblem of the presidential campaign, has admitted that he lied about which photograph from The Associated Press he used as his source, and that he then covered up evidence to substantiate his lie. Mr. Fairey's admission, which he made public on Friday, threw his legal battle with the news agency into disarray.

She made a difference and will be missed by all. Graveside Services Sunday, 11:30am at Old Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield Gardens, NY.

It would have been nice to see the documentary “Schmatta: Rags to Riches to Rags” (HBO, 9 p.m.) during Fashion Week. This history of the actual manufacture of clothing in New York traces the genesis of the Garment District in the early 20th century, its apotheosis during the heyday of American designers in the ’70s and ’80s and its subsequent decline as the business fled to cheaper shores. (Neil Genzlinger has advice here on what to wear while watching it.)

SAN FRANCISCO — The new production of “Salome” at the San Francisco Opera, directed by Sean Curran and conducted by the opera’s new music director, Nicola Luisotti, has all the zesty blood lust of a good vampire movie. Richard Strauss’s famous work, based on Oscar Wilde’s version of the Biblical tale of the killing of John the Baptist, is legendarily salacious, of course, but you have to wonder whether Strauss could have imagined the bravely and marvelously macabre production that opened Sunday afternoon at War Memorial Opera House here and continues in five more performances through Nov. 1.

The British metal band Def Leppard has canceled the final leg of its North American tour, citing “personal matters.” The tour was to include 23 shows in the United States and Canada, starting Oct. 22 in Reno, Nev., and ending on Nov. 28 in Beaumont, Tex.

The British architect Richard Rogers has been awarded the Stirling Prize, one of Britain’s highest honors, for his design of Maggie’s Center in Hammersmith, a cancer support center, The Times of London reported. The prize comes with about $32,900.

Amanda M. Burden, chairwoman of the New York City Planning Commission, who was named the 2009 laureate of the Urban Land Institute’s J.C. Nichols Prize For Visionaries in Urban Development, announced Monday that she will donate the prize money she received to create an award that honors public open spaces.

It must be celebrity auction season: On Sunday, a swatch of Elvis Presley’s hair sold for $18,300 at a Chicago auction house, Reuters reported. The locks, believed to have been snipped from the singer when he joined the United States Army in 1958, were among some 200 items of memorabilia collected by Gary Pepper, who was the president of the Tankers Fan Club for Elvis devotees.

The Motion Picture Association of America confirmed on Monday what Hollywood has known privately for months: Dan Glickman, who has served as chairman of the trade organization since 2004, will leave when his contract ends in September.

Beyoncé has postponed a concert in Malaysia after accusations by Islamic conservatives that the show would be immoral, The Associated Press reported. But the Malaysian entertainment company that planned to present the show said the postponement was solely Beyoncé’s decision and had “nothing to do with other external reasons.” The company, Marctensia, tried last month to address concerns that Beyoncé might wear outfits considered inappropriate, saying “all parties have come to an amicable understanding” about stage costumes. A new date for the show, at a stadium in Kuala Lumpur, was not announced. Beyoncé canceled a 2007 concert in Malaysia after the Pan-Malaysian Islamic Party and other groups threatened protests over her provocative clothing and image.

PARIS | The roots of graffiti as an art form are on display in "Né Dans la Rue: Graffiti" ("Born in the streets: Graffiti") at the Fondation Cartier in Paris (261 Boulevard Raspail, 75014; Metro Raspail or Denfert-Rochereau; fondation.cartier.com). The exhibit, which runs through Nov. 29, traces the origins of graffiti on New York City streets in the early 1970s, and, through photography, short film, music videos, and interviews with major innovators, illustrates the medium's trajectory from the margins to the center of popular culture, design, and contemporary art.

The New York Times plans to eliminate 100 newsroom jobs -- about 8 percent of the total -- by year's end, offering buyouts to union and non-union employees, and resorting to layoffs if it cannot get enough people to leave voluntarily, the paper announced on Monday.The program mirrors one carried out in the spring of 2008, when the paper erased 100 positions in its newsroom, though other jobs were created, so the net reduction was smaller. That round of cuts included some layoffs of journalists -- about 15 to 20, though The Times would not disclose the actual figure -- which was the first time in memory that had happened.

A new book by former N.H.L.'er Bob Sirois argues that there is a strong bias against French Canadian players in the league. "Le Quebec mis en echec: la discrimination envers les Québécois dans le LNH" ( "Quebec Bodychecked: Discrimination against Québécois in the N.H.L.") uses statistical data to substantiate longstanding observations that the anglophone majority in the N.H.L. and the hockey media tend to stereotype French Canadian players as lazier, softer and more skills-obsessed than English-speaking Canadian players. One example: Studying 16-year-old players in Quebec over a 40-year time period, Sirois found that one in 334 anglophones were drafted by the N.H.L. compared with one in 618 francophones.

One of the relics of 1980s deal-making was the large management buyout -- such as the bid for RJR Nabisco -- which has since seen its demise. But a recent decision in the Delaware Court of Chancery in the case of In Re John Q. Hammons Hotels, has the potential for bringing about a revival of this deal form. For good measure, the decision may also affect the course of the purchase of Affiliated Computer Services by Xerox.

On Friday the 14th at 10 p.m., the Breslin smelled of fresh paint and pork product. It was opening night at Ken Friedman and April Bloomfield's new restaurant at the Ace Hotel and, said Friedman, "we were painting 20 minutes before we opened." Though the fresh paint was courtesy of Friedman, the smell of cracklings and roasted pig was courtesy of the chef Fergus Henderson, the fanatically lauded English chef at St. John in London and author of "The Whole Beast: Nose to Tail Eating," which is as graphic and appropriate a description of his culinary approach as one could wish. Henderson was in town for his annual FergusStock, a mini-circuit of New York kitchens.

The Energy Star program, run by the government, is supposed to bestow a seal of approval on consumer products that use less energy than competing models. But it has a number of flaws, as laid out in a new report released by the inspector general of the Energy Department, which administers the program with the Environmental Protection Agency.

Updated, 4:03 p.m. | A train derailment on Monday morning scrambled subway routes from Manhattan's West Side to Downtown Brooklyn. Straphangers should brace for an afternoon of delays and disruptions, but officials are hoping to restore normal service by the evening rush.

After a remarkable stretch of riveting games to start this year's postseason, it was about time for a clunker. Philadelphia's 11-0 rout of Los Angeles in Game 3 of the National League Championship Series was a snooze by any measure. The contest was for all intents and purposes over in the second inning, and the Dodgers never even mustered a threat off of Cliff Lee, who threw eight masterly shutout innings, allowing three hits and no walks while racking up 10 strikeouts. Los Angeles Manager Joe Torre summed up the disappointment in his postgame comments: "You never want to get your rear end kicked," he said, "but you don't toss and turn and wonder if you made the right move."

To the list of imported dishes that are easier to make than we Americans have been led to believe, you can add polenta. When the luxuriously creamy, pale yellow cornmeal mush first began to appear in cookbooks and in upscale Italian restaurants here about 35 years ago, we were (incorrectly) told that to prevent the cornmeal from forming lumps as it cooked, the cook had to stand by, stirring constantly for a half-hour or longer. Here's how to make polenta a regular, no-fuss part of your meal plan.

Martin Gardner turns 95 on Wednesday, and he's celebrating with the publication of a new book. In my Findings column on Tuesday, I'll be writing about Mr. Gardner and his phenomenal career-- the hundreds of "Mathematical Games" columns in Scientific American, the more than 70 books on mathematics and other topics. Today we'll start the celebration with several of the classic simple puzzles he has presented, like one above from his "Colossal Book of Short Puzzles and Problems." It involves toothpicks, although we could also think of them as birthday candles anticipating Mr. Gardner's 100th birthday.

Sportswriting has long played host to some of the most glorious, along with the most cliché-ridden, exercises in journalism. Now some kids at the Intelligent Information Laboratory at Northwestern University are suggesting that an average game day story can be bolted together without human intervention.

At the dawn of the progressive era early in the last century, muckrakers attacked the first billionaire, John D. Rockefeller, for creating capitalism's most ruthless monster. "The Octopus" was their nickname for Standard Oil, the trust that controlled nearly 90 percent of American oil. But even in that primordial phase of the industrial era, Mr. Rockefeller was mindful of his public image and eager to counter it, The New York Times's Frank Rich writes. "His great brainstorm," writes his biographer, Ron Chernow, "was undoubtedly his decision to dispense shiny souvenir dimes to adults and nickels to children as he moved about." Who could hate an octopus tossing glittering coins?

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week include Monday's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday. According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.06 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 0.15 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 0.04 percent.

9 P.M. (HBO) SCHMATTA: RAGS TO RICHES TO RAGS For the last 50 years garment production in the United States has been on a steep decline; 95 percent of American clothing was made here in 1965, but only 5 percent is today. And nowhere has that production been more vital to a city's success than in New York. This documentary from Marc Levin examines the effect of the increased globalization of clothing manufacturing on the city's once-thriving garment district. The economic and social forces that have transformed the industry and the nation over the last century are explored through interviews with those who have experienced as many ups and downs as hemlines, including Fern Mallis, the creator of Fashion Week; the designer Isaac Mizrahi; Joe Raico, above, a fabric cutter; Irving Rousso, a rags-to-riches garmento; and Lisa Nussbaum, a cousin of Sadie Nussbaum, one of 146 people who died in the Triangle Shirtwaist fire of 1911. 7 P.M. (Showtime) BUD GREENSPAN PRESENTS: BEIJING 2008 -- AMERICA'S OLYMPIC GLORY In this documentary about the Olympics, Mr. Greenspan goes behind the scenes in China and interviews American athletes and medalists including Jason Lezak, the swim team captain; the gymnast Nastia Liukin; Brenda Villa, the captain of the water polo team; and the fencers Keeth and Erinn Smart.

''A.M.A. Opens Bid to Kill Medicare.'' That was the blunt headline that appeared in The New York Times on Jan. 27, 1965, as Congress prepared to take up legislation to provide government health insurance to Americans 65 and over.

The White House signaled Sunday that President Obama would postpone any decision on sending more troops to Afghanistan until the disputed election there had been settled and resulted in a government that could work with the United States. As an audit of Afghanistan's Aug. 20 election ground toward a conclusion, American officials pressed President Hamid Karzai to accept a runoff vote or share power with his main rival, Abdullah Abdullah, a former foreign minister. Although Mr. Karzai's support appeared likely to fall below 50 percent in the final count, together he and Mr. Abdullah received 70 percent, in theory enough to forge a unity government with national credibility.

It is a problem that every football coach eventually has to consider. Your team is down by 7 points late in the game. If you score, do you kick the extra point for the tie, or go for the 2-point conversion and the win? That was what Notre Dame Coach Charlie Weis had to ponder late in a 34-27 loss to Southern California. The Irish fell short of scoring -- Jimmy Clausen's pass to Duval Kamara fell incomplete as time expired -- but in his postgame news conference, Weis was asked if he would have gone for 2 or played for the tie. After a long pause and a smile, Weis said: ''We didn't get in, so I was going to use my last timeout to make that decision. I was torn. I had been toiling with the answer to that question the whole drive. My gut is I probably would not have.''

TANENBAUM--Charles J.,died on October 17, 2009 at age 94, devoted husband of Szilvia Szmuk-Tanenbaum and proud father of Ann Tanenbaum, his daughter by the late Mary Mayer Tanenbaum, to whom he had been happily married for 59 years. Graduate of Exeter, Harvard College and Yale Law School, he was admitted to the New York Bar in 1937. He served in the army during World War II and the Korean War, primarily in Military Intelligence at the Pentagon. His active legal practice largely ended by 1947, when his father's death left him with primary responsibility for family real estate. He served for over fifty years in leadership roles in the Jewish Foundation for Education of Women and was active in the refugee field with the American Jewish Philanthropic Fund and the International Rescue Committee. Beginning as a book collector in 1963, what started as a hobby became a second career including service on Library Visiting Committees at Harvard and Stanford universities; mounting over thirty book exhibitions at libraries across the nation. Charles had a unique and imaginative approach to philanthropy. During his lifetime, he established several awards in a variety of institutions, and these were always named for people whose contribution to that particular institution was meaningful: The Hamilton Award at New York Hospital in White Plains; the Douglas Bryant Award at Harvard Library; the Miller Award at FEGS; the Fabrizio Michelassi Award for graduating Surgical Residents and Medical Students at Weill Cornell Medical School & New York Presbyterian Hospital; and the George Baer Award for medical students in the joint MD and MPH program at Mount Sinai School of Medicine. He was an honorary member of the Grolier Club after 40 years of distinguished membership. He also enjoyed the conviviality of the Century, Harmonie, Harvard and Lotos Clubs in New York and the Book Club of California. In lieu of flowers, you may wish to make a charitable donation to an organization of your choice in Charles' memory. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell-Funeral Chapel (1076 Madison Avenue), Tuesday, October 20 at 3:30pm. The family will be receiving at the Funeral Chapel on Monday evening from 6-9pm. In addition, there will be a gathering celebrating Charles' life at the Grolier Club at a date to be determined.

BUIKA Y CHUCHO ''El Último Trago'' (Casa Limon/Warner Music Latina) Super-chic even from a distance in its cross-generational, cross-national, cross-stylistic pan-Latinism, ''El Último Trago'' (''The Last Sip'') is a concept album that transcends its concept. The singer Concha Buika, who is in her late 30s, grew up in Majorca of Guinean ancestry; Chucho Valdés, in his late 60s, is Cuba's standard-bearing pianist. Here they're dealing with a half-century-old repertory: songs associated with Chavela Vargas, the Mexican ranchera singer.

KAHN--Robert L.,who lived life to the fullest, died on October 16 at the age of 77. Mr. Kahn co-founded the investment management firm of W P Stewart & Co. in 1974. He was a vital contributor to the company's uniquely successful investment philosophy. He continued to serve as a senior member of their investment management group until his recent illness. Robert Kahn was a renaissance man in many fields. He received top accolades as an athlete in tennis, running, and as a pianist. His generous spirit has inspired and empowered innumerable individuals and institutions. In lieu of flowers, consider supporting the non-profits established by his son, Stephen Kahn, M.D. (The Abundance Foundation www.abundance.net) and his daughter-in-law, Heather Williams Psy.D. (Veterans Resource www.veteransresource.org). He is survived by his wife, Helen, sons Stephen and Rocky, daughters-in-law Elizabeth Hodder Kahn and Heather Williams, and grandchildren, Zoe and Noah Kahn.

MICHAEL BUBLé ''Crazy Love'' (143/Reprise) Michael Bublé is a master at juggling musical attitudes, and his new CD, ''Crazy Love,'' whose title comes from the Van Morrison song, is his most confident balancing act yet. Mr. Bublé respects the Sinatra tradition but doesn't try to slavishly copy anyone. Appreciative of the past but not reverential, he juxtaposes pre-rock, rock and soul classics without favoring one style over another.

But after Texas Coach Mack Brown watched the freshman wide receiver Marquise Goodwin, a seven-time state track champion in Texas, in preseason practice, he had a message for his staff. ''Guys, we've got to get this guy on the field,'' Brown said. ''He's too fast and he can catch.''

Since the N.F.L. went to a 12-team playoff format in 1990, 11 teams have rebounded from being at least three games under .500 after Week 5 or later to qualify for the postseason. That includes five teams that began 1-4 and ended up winning their division. So keep the faith, St. Louis, Tampa Bay, Detroit, Cleveland and Tennessee. But especially you, Kansas City. Five things we learned in Week 6, other than that New Orleans is the best team in football: ANOTHER STRONG START FOR FAVRE Think the Jets' owner, Woody Johnson, is wondering where this Brett Favre was last year? Probably not. After all, this was the way Favre looked early last season for the Jets, before he broke down. But when Favre rifled a 58-yard pass to Sidney Rice after the Baltimore Ravens had taken a lead late in the fourth quarter Sunday, he looked like the Favre of Green Bay vintage. Favre is completely at ease running the Vikings' offense. He had only 259 yards passing in Minnesota's 33-31 victory, but the Vikings are 6-0. Things will become a lot scarier if Adrian Peterson's ankle injury and Percy Harvin's bad shoulder limit them.

Any conversation with Tim Berners-Lee, the creator of the Web's bedrock software standards, tends to be fast-paced and nonlinear. When he worked at the CERN physics laboratory in Geneva, colleagues tried to get him to speak French instead of English, in hopes of slowing him down. No surprise, then, that a half-hour dialogue with Mr. Berners-Lee, director of the World Wide Web Consortium and these days a professor at M.I.T., at a symposium last Thursday on the future of technology, fit that mold. I started, just for fun, with a historical question. If he were do it over again today, would he do anything differently? Any regrets?

BERNSTEIN--Morton J. The Directors and Staff of The Fan Fox and Leslie R. Samuels Foundation mourn the loss of their beloved colleague and friend Mort Bernstein on October 8, 2009. Mort served the Foundation as an officer and director for more than 50 years. As the first President after the death of the founders, Mort designed the Foundation's performing arts program, which today supports over 120 arts organizations in New York City each year. He also led the effort to expand the Foundation's grant-making into healthcare and the social services. At the time of his death, he held the title of Chairman Emeritus in recognition of his leadership and contribution to the Foundation's mission. We will miss Mort for the hallmarks of his service: sound judgment, common sense, and great consideration for others. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Muriel, his children, Eva and Adam, and his granddaughter, Sarah.

WHITE DENIM ''Fits'' (Downtown) White Denim, a mercurial three-piece band from Austin, Tex., makes rugged, fidgety, overdriven garage rock sweetened with a psychedelic swirl. ''Fits,'' the band's new album, has been available for four months in Europe, where the British music press greeted it with a glowing consensus. It's now out domestically through Downtown Records, in a package that also includes ''Exposion,'' a release from last year. You might listen to both albums and still feel uncomfortable trying to pin the band down.

In an article just posted on The Times’s Web site, my colleague Tamar Lewin reports that “the average annual cost of tuition and fees at four-year public colleges rose 6.5 percent from last year, to $7,020.” Those figures are among the most grim in a report issued this morning by the College Board.

“The problem of writing about comedy is that it’s like trying to hold a gas,” Conan O’Brien told John Ortved during an interview for “The Simpsons: An Uncensored, Unauthorized History” (Faber and Faber). “The tighter you squeeze, the more it dissipates.” Despite that warning — and the refusal of many key figures behind the series to cooperate with him — Mr. Ortved set out to write an inside look at the longest-running comedy series in American television history, which has just begun its 21st season. Mr. Ortved, 29, a self-described “comedy nerd,” who says he likes to laugh “more than the average person,” first pitched the idea of an oral history of the show when he was a 26-year-old editorial associate at Vanity Fair. ” ‘The Simpsons’ has been so influential that it is difficult to find a strain of television comedy that does not contain its bloodline,” Mr. Ortved said. Three years, 80 on-the-record interviews and one Vanity Fair article later, Mr. Ortved has produced a 300-page combination of juicy entertainment gossip, rich television history and notes from a disenchanted lover. Mr. Ortved recently spoke about the challenges of writing the book, the show’s legacy, Spider Pig and the possibility of a Simpsons Land theme park.

Times Square.” If those lyrics — or the sight of a cadaverous family snapping its fingers in unison — are still stuck in your head, it’s largely the fault of one man: the songwriter Vic Mizzy, who composed the theme songs to “Green Acres” and “The Addams Family,” and who died on Saturday at the age of 93.

A short film starring the rapper Kanye West and directed by Spike Jonze has been taken down from Mr. West’s official Web site almost as quickly and mysteriously as it appeared. The film, “We Were Once a Fairytale,” is a 14-minute short that depicts a fictional version of Mr. West acting drunkenly and misbehaving in a club, having sex with a woman, vomiting and stabbing himself in the stomach to unleash an inner demon. (The metaphor-laden movie was made by Mr. Jonze, the director of “Where the Wild Things Are,” in January, before Mr. West’s misadventures at the MTV Video Music Awards in September.) The video popped up on kanyeuniversecity.com over the weekend, but it has since been pulled; a message on the Web site said only, “SORRY I HAD TO TAKE IT DOWN :(“

It has been an up-and-down year in the film business for Bob and Harvey Weinstein, but that hasn’t halted their plans in other media. On Monday, the Weinstein Company said that it had entered into a partnership with the Perseus Books Group, an independent publisher, which will release new and backlist books for the Weinstein Books imprint. In a news release, the companies said the first new books to be released under the partnership would include “All Things at Once” by Mika Brzezinski, the MSNBC anchor and co-host of “Morning Joe,” and a memoir and beauty guide by Raquel Welch, both planned for January, as well as “The Overnight Socialite” by the novelist Bridie Clark (“Because She Can”), which is scheduled for December. The companies said that beginning on Dec. 1, Perseus will also handle earlier Weinstein Books titles like “My Remarkable Journey” by Larry King and “Quantum Wellness” by Kathy Freston. Judy Hottensen, the publisher of Weinstein Books, will remain in that position.

The pop star Rihanna is making headlines again, this time for the right reasons: on Tuesday, Island Def Jam Recordings said it would release her new studio album, “Rated R,” on Nov. 23. The album is her fourth full-length studio release and the first since an incident in February in which she was attacked by her companion, the R&B singer Chris Brown, during an argument. (Mr. Brown, who pleaded guilty to a felony count of assault, was given five years of probation.) In a news release, Island Def Jam said the album’s first single, “Russian Roulette,” written by the R&B singer Ne-Yo, would be available Tuesday on Rihanna’s official Web site. Other producers and writers on “Rated R” include Justin Timberlake, Stargate, Chase & Status, and The-Dream and Tricky Stewart.

The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra said on Tuesday it would appoint a Canadian conductor with a strong background in opera as its next music director. The new maestro, Jacques Lacombe, will take over in September with a contract for three seasons.

The Associated Press said on Tuesday that it had filed a motion to amend its counterclaim against the artist Shepard Fairey, and that Mr. Fairey’s explanation Friday about which photograph he had used to create a poster of Barack Obama was “simply not credible.” Mr. Fairey, who created the widely seen “Hope” poster of Mr. Obama from a photograph taken for The A.P., filed a pre-emptive lawsuit in February against that news organization, saying his use of the photograph was covered by fair-use rules. The A.P. filed a countersuit in March, saying that Mr. Fairey misappropriated its rights to that image. On Friday, Mr. Fairey admitted that he lied in court papers about using a different photograph of Mr. Obama than the one The A.P. has alleged and that he created false documents to cover the discrepancy. In a statement, The A.P. said that Mr. Fairey “concocted” this latest explanation to “spin those bad acts in the best light possible to the court and the public.” In its filing, the news organization said, “It is simply not credible that Fairey somehow forgot in January 2009 which source image he used to create the Infringing Works, which were completed only a year earlier in January 2008.”

Buoyed by the success of its weight-loss competition “The Biggest Loser,” NBC is adding a motivational partner to its lineup. The network said Tuesday that it had ordered eight episodes of “Losing It With Jillian,” a reality show that will star the “Biggest Loser” trainer Jillian Michaels. In the series, which will make its debut next year, Ms. Michaels will help families “make life-altering changes,” NBC said. She will be joined by the celebrity chef Curtis Stone, who will cut unhealthy foods from the family diet. The production company responsible for “Biggest Loser,” Reveille, will also produce “Losing It.” An extension of “Loser” is a no-brainer for NBC, as it is one of the low-rated network’s few bright spots. The two-hour show drew 9.1 million viewers last week.

The CMJ Music Marathon got straight to the point this year with the topic of its first panel discussion: “But How Do I Get Paid?” It turned into an arcane discussion of publishing royalties, but the bigger question remains: What are working musicians working toward?

I got a head start on CMJ on Monday night, when Fool’s Gold played the Knitting Factory in Brooklyn before its two CMJ shows: Tuesday at midnight at the Suffolk (107 Suffolk Street) and Wednesday at midnight at the Bowery Poetry Club (308 Bowery). It’s a Los Angeles band that loves African and Middle Eastern music, building identifiable but cross-cultural grooves with plenty of percussion (up to four members of the eight-man band) and pinpoint interlocking guitars.
More Photographs A slide show of photographs of the first day of CMJ.

Carnegie Hall paid $1.45 million during its 2007-8 season to an architectural firm run by the son-in-law of its board chairman, Sanford I. Weill, the former Citibank executive, according to the hall’s most recent publicly available tax return.
For bands traveling to CMJ from abroad, making it to the gig is often not a sure thing, thanks to last-minute visa problems and a variety of other travel issues.
Updated | 8:43 a.m. The Oscars are in the hands of a former studio mogul and a song-and-dance maven.

Getting your scare on at a haunted house in the New York area can be costly. Some of the more tech-heavy venues have entrance fees of up to $30. For that price you might as well stay in with a bag of candy corn and watch “Halloween.” (The original, of course.)
Sodbuster Farms in Salem, Ore., harvests its hops over the course of five weeks, setting aside a small amount for brewers who want to use them while they're fresh.
Three games in the N.H.L. Tuesday night, headed by the Penguins playing for sole possession of the league lead. Home teams listed first:
A week after Bloomberg announced it was buying BusinessWeek, the magazine's editor in chief, Stephen J. Adler, has resigned.

Matt Warshaw, a lifelong surfer and chronicler of the sport, was nowhere near the water in 2004 when he first saw the view that reminded him of what he was missing. Mr. Warshaw, 49, is a former editor of Surfer magazine and the author of "The Encyclopedia of Surfing" and the coming book "The History of Surfing." For years, he lived in San Francisco's Sunset District, where he had panoramic ocean views and 12 surfboards in the closet. A nondescript bench in a pocket park on the slopes of Twin Peaks changed his perspective. (His words have been edited and condensed. This article first appeared in print on Oct. 18.)

This week's restaurant review is of Marea, an elegant Italian seafood-and-more restaurant that the chef Michael White and the restaurateur Chris Cannon opened back in May on Central Park South. It's in the room that used to be San Domenico. As you'll see if you read the review, I liked the place a fair amount. Have you been? Would you like to? Either way, post a comment -- or a question -- below. As always, be civil. This is a family Web site.

Peter A. Collins chains together some musical names and then asks us to Name That Genre. Perhaps the odds for commercial singing success are enhanced by having two names, either of which could be first or last. It makes for a cute puzzle theme anyway.
The case for some sort of expanded instant replay was made in two fourth-inning plays, both involving the Yankees' Nick Swisher.

While Sam Cassell was finishing his N.B.A. career for the Boston Celtics last season, he spent more time wearing jeans than a jersey. But he was still able to pick up technical fouls from the far end of the bench.
This is the third installment of a seven-part series.
“Rembrandt’s J’Accuse” is a generally absorbing if sometimes fog-inducing investigation into the mysteries of the Rembrandt painting “The Night Watch.”

PHILADELPHIA - Every so often, Doug Mientkiewicz slips on his bulky, diamond-studded championship ring that commemorates the Red Sox' 2004 World Series championship, a memento of a glorious October gone by and everything it entailed.
For seven months, The Times's David Rohde was held captive by the Taliban. Much of what he learned during that time came from watching videos- day after day- with his captors.
Even before I reached the Imperial War Museum in London I was reminded of war.
The health insurance industry may have envisioned a low-key wonk session when it originally planned its "state issues" annual conference this year.

President Obama launched a week of political campaigning Tuesday with a critique of Wall Street right in its backyard, challenging financial industry executives at a Democratic fund-raiser in Manhattan to support his reform efforts.

President Obama will visit a Maryland business on Wednesday afternoon to announce initiatives to encourage lending to small businesses. According to an administration official, the proposal will increase the caps for existing Small Business Administration loans and give smaller banks better access to funds from the Troubled Assets Relief Program.
The Federal Reserve announced Tuesday that it had named Patrick M. Parkinson, an expert on financial markets, to be the director of its division of banking supervision and regulation.
The Senate Finance Committee has quietly recommended that millions elderly Americans who buy Medigap plans be charged new co-pays for doctor's visits starting in 2015.

Is Congress watering down the Obama administration's recommendations for regulating credit rating agencies? A draft bill on the issue obtained by Reuters indicates that some of the more significant changes proposed by the administration -- like a measure mandating a repeal of federal laws requiring the use of credit ratings and another that would make all credit rating agencies liable for each others' ratings -- have been removed.
In a bid to lure Anglican traditionalists, the Catholic Church will allow converts to preserve some liturgical traditions from the Church of England.

Oprah Winfrey, who had once said she would not become involved in presidential politics but then went on to lend her celebrity to Barack Obama, has now booked Sarah Palin for an appearance on the talk show in November.
New York Times writers Billy Witz, Jack Curry and Richard Sandomir provided updates of American League Championship Series Game 4 between the Yankees and the Angels.

My colleagues over at The Choice are soliciting comments on a new College Board report. The report found that the the average published (sticker price) annual cost of tuition and fees at four-year public colleges rose 6.5 percent from last year, to $7,020. Tuition rose across the board at other education institutions, too.

Traffic in Millburn's South Mountain neighborhood has been a concern for public officials for years, and speed tables - shorter versions of speed bumps - are in the works for a section of Parkview Drive, the street where an accident Sunday left a 19-year-old resident dead.
A proliferation of golf courses is displacing thousands of farmers and devouring the country's rice fields.

The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has announced that Bill Mechanic, the former head of 20th Century Fox film studios, and Adam Shankman, the director of "Hairspray" and a judge on "So You Think You Can Dance," will produce the upcoming Oscar telecast.

The Vatican announced on Tuesday that it would make it easier for Anglicans who are uncomfortable with the Church of England's acceptance of women priests and openly gay bishops to join the Catholic Church. The Vatican will set up a formal conversion structure to allow Anglicans to preserve some of their liturgical traditions, including allowing married Anglican priests to remain married after they convert to Catholicism.

I'd like to think that Rush Limbaugh was floating a thought experiment, and not seriously proposing something, when he told millions of listeners the following: "Mr. Revkin, why don't you just go kill yourself, and help the planet by dying." [UPDATE, 10/22: NPR has done a feature on this incident, including my request that Mr. Limbaugh apologize to my wife and sons.]

IMS Health acknowledged late Tuesday afternoon that it was "exploring a variety of strategic alternatives," indicating that the health care data company may be sold. The IMS statement came a day after reports surfaced saying that the company was in advanced talks with private equity firms to sell itself.
The arrival of the bill at a recent dinner set off a ballet of pocket patting as my companions searched for reading glasses to assess the damage. One guy even broke out a penlight.

The dangers of mixing driving and cellphone use have been well demonstrated. Studies have suggested that it increases the chance of an accident fourfold and may be responsible for thousands of fatalities a year. A growing number of states -- starting with New York in 2001 -- have banned driving while holding a cellphone.

O.K., can we all agree that Barack Obama has finally accomplished something in his presidency? Yesterday, his Justice Department issued a memorandum to federal prosecutors in the 14 states that have approved the use of medical marijuana, instructing them not to go after patients and doctors who are following the laws of their states.
People who want to send their friends virtual presents, whether it be a birthday cake or a bloody chainsaw, are about to have a lot more options.

For many students, Wikipedia ended the need to visit a university research library. Why bother trolling through the stacks, when you can find out at least a little something (that you hope is accurate) on just about everything through one Web site?

In August, news that the United States Postal Service was planning to close 14 of New York City's roughly 250 post offices elicited an outcry from residents and politicians alike, who clamored to protect their local branches.

Negotiators for the N.B.A. and its referees union agreed Tuesday to the parameters of a new contract, making it likely that the league's best officials will be on the court when the regular season begins next week.
Steven Spielberg will be in the theme park business with Universal for at least another eight years.

Condé Nast, which has been slow out of the digital gate, will be among the first publishers to repurpose an entire magazine issue for the iPhone, it announced Tuesday.GQ is creating an iPhone version of its December issue, repurposing the ads and the editorial pages for an application that will sell for $2.99.
A four-bedroom hillside home with Pacific Ocean view in Acapulco is on the market for $1.85 million.

Thanks, commenter Liane Steele, for telling us there will be a candlelight vigil Wednesday evening at 9:30 p.m. at the Taylor Park Pond for George Ganter, 19, who died after a car crash Sunday night.
