Meanwhile, we here at The Local send our condolences to the Ganter family. --Tina Kelley

The missions of the First Couple melded on Tuesday, with First Lady Michelle Obama praising employees at the Department of Veterans Affairs for helping the nation's military. Just a short while later, President Obama honored a regiment of soldiers for their heroism during the Vietnam War, saying their bravery inspired all Americans during this time of war.

Critics claim the health insurance industry was acting in bad faith when it released a controversial report last week from PricewaterhouseCoopers that suggested insurance premiums would rise sharply in the wake of proposed legislation to overhaul the market. As my colleague David M. Herszenzhorn has noted, the report was seen by many Democrats as an act of open aggression by the insurers.

Viewers inured to scenes of chaos can sometimes be moved by the disorienting sight of commonplace objects transformed by violence. In the case of Slide 1, it is a thick masonry school wall with a clean hole blown through it by suicide bombers. In the case of Slide 7, by Ricardo Moraes of Reuters, it is a shopping cart filled not with groceries but with a human body.

If you read my post last week about banking, you know I'm not a big defender of banks, especially big banks. Like a lot of people who commented on that post, I have a hard time understanding why so little of the bailout money the big banks got from our government seems to trickle down to small business owners. We are doing business in a new world. There are new rules.

Surrounded by cellophane-wrapped bike parts and small pieces of recently imported hardware, Sheng Chang sat in the window of a storefront on Broome Street in Manhattan and watched two men assemble his new electric bicycle. Mr. Chang, 50, a restaurant delivery man in Midtown, had been saving for months for the new bike, which he said would help him get through work days that can last 12 to 14 hours. "Now I'm old -- a regular bicycle makes me tired," he said.

We have written a few times about the idea of a tax credit for companies that expand their work forces, a policy that the federal government last tried in the 1970s. It may represent a good political compromise for Democrats and Republicans eager to help their jobless constituents with a business-friendly fix.

As regular readers know, I've been growing increasingly concerned about the buzz saying "the recession's over, let's raise interest rates". I think the ZIRP -- the zero interest rate policy -- needs to stay in place until unemployment has declined a long way, probably below 7 percent. And that will probably take years.
Bill George, a Harvard business professor and the author of "7 Lessons for Leading in Crisis," argues that we should not punish healthy banks for the sins of failed banks.

Seniority is typically the most valuable currency among United States senators. It's the key to leadership positions, prestigious committee assignments, and eventually chairmanships and plush hideaway offices in the Capitol. But once in a while, being a junior senator has its privileges -- in running for president, say, as Barack Obama found out. Or in the case of Senator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee, in not having been around to cast a vote for the 2003 Medicare prescription drug benefit.

Ezra Klein has an excellent update on the efforts of Ron Wyden, a Democratic senator from Oregon, to make sure health reform gives people greater ability to choose their own insurance plans. As we've written before, the current health bill -- both the Senate and House versions -- would do nothing for people who don't like the insurance choices their employer now offers. They would be stuck with them.

In 1980, Paul Ehrlich, a population activist and Stanford professor, famously bet Julian Simon, the late Cato Institute scholar, that, because of human pressures, the prices of five key metals would rise by 1990. In fact, the prices fell and Mr. Ehrlich paid a small sum to Mr. Simon.
President Obama is looking to scoop up big money for Democrats at a $30,400-a-couple fund-raiser in Manhattan on Tuesday night. But he will not forget the little people.

California's attorney general, Jerry Brown, said Tuesday that he was suing State Street, the large Boston-based bank, accusing it of committing "unconscionable fraud" against the state's two largest employee pension funds, Calpers and Calstrs. Mr. Brown said he was seeing to recover more than $200 million in overcharges and penalties.

Larry Coon has become a go-to guy for untangling the intricacies of the N.B.A.'s collective bargaining agreement and salary cap. He knows the cap's ins and outs better than some N.B.A. personnel and manages NBA Salary Cap FAQ. Coon has agreed to contribute occasionally to Off the Dribble, when salary cap issues arise. In the first of three articles on the subject, Coon will dissect options for Donnie Walsh, the president of the Knicks, to rid the organization of Eddy Curry's burdensome contract and create more room for the 2010 free-agent class. - Jonathan Abrams

BlackRock's chief executive, Laurence D. Fink, had a lot to celebrate on Tuesday as his big investment firm reported third-quarter earnings that exceeded analysts' estimates. The firm's hedge funds have nearly erased the losses posted during the financial crisis last year and are at or near their high-water marks. Meanwhile, BlackRock's other alternative investment strategies were able to attract billions of dollars in new capital for its higher-yielding and riskier asset classes.

Riding the Maplewood, Millburn or South Orange Jitney to and from the train station is a relatively small part of the workday. But because of the timing of the ride, it can color your whole day and/or evening. A good jitney ride won't make a hard day at work any better, but if we all observe just a few rules of Unofficial Jitney Etiquette, at least it won't start or end things on the wrong note. Many of these may seem obvious, but I've seen regular violations of these golden rules during my daily jitney journeys.

The movie "(Untitled)" is indeed an art-house flick, but it's also about the art world -- the art world of 2007, that is. The film, which opens this Friday at Angelika in New York, stars the charmingly neurotic Adam Goldberg as Adrian Jacobs, an experimental noise artist, and Marley Shelton as Madeleine Gray, a savvy Chelsea gallery opener, with the de rigueur Hitchcock blond coif and chunky glasses, who believes she can find him the proper audience. (Good luck. After one performance, a pair of critics call Adrian's "content pedestrian" and his "tempo anemic.")

The Atlanta Thrashers roll into Montreal and undergo the deepest news media scrutiny they have received since getting off to the best start in their 10-year history -- and it focuses inevitably on the club's effort to re-sign Ilya Kovalchuk before his contract expires at the end of the season. Kovalchuk, the 26-year-old Thrashers captain who is 7+1=8 in five games and surrounded by Russian-speaking players brought in by General Manager Don Waddell on his advice, takes reporters' questions about whether he'll re-sign. His answer, while offering some promise, is noncommital: "My agent is talking and we'll see. We'll figure out something."

As I wrote in Sunday's Week in Review section, California and Texas have both emerged as leaders in renewable energy - but in completely different ways. Texans despise regulations, an attitude that has helped wind farms to flourish; California, by contrast, requires hefty environmental assessments for large projects - which helps explain why rooftop solar panels and energy efficiency have done so well (they do not need painstaking reviews).
For all the concern that South Africa, the country, will not be prepared to host the 2010 World Cup, it was South Africa, the team, that took action.

The Tom Bradley International Terminal at LAX will undergo its first significant renovation since the city hosted the Olympics in 1984. The construction planned includes new security checkpoints, passenger lounges and a large central hall with restaurants and shops.

Regular Agenda readers have perhaps caught on that this column is, shall we say, skeptical about the employer mandate crafted by Max Baucus, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. We're not alone. Last week, commenting on one of The Agenda's analyses, a reader, Peter Lee, alerted us to another critique. The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal-leaning group focusing on income inequality, takes issue with the Baucus bill's mandate on other grounds.

New York State's English and math exams include several questions each year about livestock, crops and the other staples of the rural experience that some educators say flummox city children, whose knowledge of nature might begin and end at Central Park. On the state English test this year, for instance, third graders were asked questions relating to chickens and eggs. In math, they had to count sheep and horses.

In the summer of 2008, two months before Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy, Richard S. Fuld Jr., the firm's chairman, was continuing his desperate efforts to find a lifeline. They had begun in March, shortly after the demise of Bear Stearns, when Mr. Fuld called Warren E. Buffett seeking a capital infusion, to no avail. Lehman had raised money elsewhere, but that didn't help for long, and its condition again was worsening.

A swatch of Elvis Presley’s hair, above, sold for $18,300 at a Chicago auction on Sunday, Reuters reported. The locks, believed to have been snipped from Presley when he joined the Army in 1958, were among about 200 items of memorabilia collected by Gary Pepper, who was president of the Tankers Fan Club for Elvis devotees. The hair was not DNA-tested, but authenticated by “an expert in celebrity hair,” said the auction house, Leslie Hindman Auctioneers. The highest-grossing item was a cotton shirt with the monogram EP. Expected to sell for between $2,000 and $4,000, it went for $62,800.
NBC’s coverage of the Chicago Bears-Atlanta Falcons football game on Sunday night ranked No. 1 in the prime-time ratings race.

The Tate Modern’s publications arm, Tate Publishing, may have to destroy as many as 12,000 catalogs for one of its exhibitions because they contain a nude photograph of the actress Brooke Shields that has been removed from the show, The Telegraph of London reported. The museum was to show Richard Prince’s photograph “Spiritual America” as part of its exhibition “Pop Life: Art in a Material World,” which opened on Oct. 1, but withdrew it after Scotland Yard warned that the photograph, taken of Ms. Shields when she was 10, could violate obscenity laws. The hardcover and paperback editions of the catalog were expected to bring the Tate about $524,000.

The British architect Richard Rogers has won the RIBA Stirling Prize, one of Britain’s highest honors, for his design of Maggie’s Center, above, in the Hammersmith section of London, a clinic for cancer patients. He had received two of the six nominations for the RIBA Stirling Prize; the second nomination was for the Bodegas Protos winery near Valladolid, Spain. The prize, which comes with about $32,900, was awarded to Mr. Rogers even as he was recently removed from a housing development project in London after Prince Charles criticized the plans.

Amanda Burden, below, New York City’s planning commissioner, who recently was named the 2009 laureate of the Urban Land Institute’s J. C. Nichols Prize for Visionaries in Urban Development, said she would donate the $100,000 prize to create an award that honors public open spaces. The money will be returned to the Urban Land Institute, a nonprofit research and education organization, to create the Global Award for Public Open Space. Making open spaces in streets, parks and public plazas “is the essence of city life and the measure of its success,” Ms. Burden said in a telephone interview. “They’re important mixing chambers of all social classes.”.

The rock band Def Leppard has canceled the final leg of its North American tour, citing “personal matters.” The tour was to include 23 shows in the United States and Canada, starting on Thursday in Reno, Nev., and ending on Nov. 28 in Beaumont, Tex. The band said in a statement on its Web site (defleppard.com): “We know how truly blessed we are to have such committed fans. That’s why we’ve agonized over this decision. Even if just a single concert, we don’t take canceling shows lightly, but unfortunately life’s commitments need to be the priority.”.

An evening featuring John Cale of the Velvet Underground at the Museum of Modern Art was canceled because Mr. Cale suffered a sports-related injury, said his manager, Anita Scott. The event — scheduled for Monday as part of Modern Mondays, the museum’s weekly forum about film and media — was to include a discussion of his recent media installation, “Dyddiau Du” (“Dark Days”), on view in the Wales Pavilion at the Venice Biennale. Mr. Cale, who competes in stair-climb races in skyscrapers, was training on Friday in Los Angeles when he injured his knee. A doctor recommended that he not make the flight to New York. Mr. Cale plans to reschedule, Ms. Scott said.

The Motion Picture Association of America confirmed on Monday what Hollywood has known privately for months: Dan Glickman, chairman of the trade organization since 2004, will leave when his contract ends in September. Mr. Glickman, a former Democratic congressman from Kansas and a former agriculture secretary, has recently received public votes of confidence from some studios, but the industry has largely groused about a perceived lack of results during his tenure. He drew criticism last winter for failing to obtain tax cuts for filmed entertainment as part of the economic stimulus bill — though he did secure $400 million in domestic production incentives in a separate initiative — and studios are frustrated with the restriction on the distribution of foreign films inside China. Mr. Glickman has been aggravated that studios, citing the economic downturn, have cut the movie association’s annual budget by 20 percent.

Senate Democrats and White House officials met on Monday evening to discuss how to merge the two versions of the Senate's health care legislation, and Democratic aides said they were aiming to have a combined bill ''mostly baked'' by the end of this week. Once the bills are melded, the Congressional Budget Office will be asked to develop a revised cost analysis, which will take several days. At that point, provided everything is in order, the majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, will look to start the floor debate.

Judy, Mel and the Marder Family

OTELSBERG--Jonah. Born Warsaw, Poland 1932, survived Holocaust in Russia, returned to Poland 1946, moved to Israel 1950. Budget Director, City of Tel Aviv 1960-62; moved to U.S. 1962, worked as a researcher while earning a Ph.D. at City University of New York; Manager Statistical Design and Methods, McGraw-Hill Information Systems 1967-76; Project Director, Physician Reimbursement Study, Center For Social Research; 1976-79, taught at York College, CUNY 1979- 1996 as well as conducting research at The Graduate Center; Fulbright Scholar to the Soviet Union 1990-91. Died October 17, 2009 after a seven year struggle against cancer. She lived her life with resolution, optimism and integrity. Survived by her husband Peter Goodwin, brother Jerry Otelsberg, nephews Michael and Eliot and Niece Dina.

CLEARY--Martin J.,74, of Sea Girt, NJ and New York, died Sunday, October 18 at Jersey Shore University Hospital, Neptune, NJ. Mr. Cleary was a Senior Vice President and head of the Mortgage & Real Estate division at TIAA:CREF for 28 years. In 1981, he became President and COO of Jacobs, Visconsi and Jacobs, now the Jacobs Group, and was a part owner and Vice President of the Cleveland Indians. Mr. Cleary was a director of the Guardian Life Insurance Company. CBL & Associates, the former Lamson & Sessions, and had served as the President and a Trustee of the International Council of Shopping Centers. He is survived by his wife of 52 years Peggy, his children Patrick, Eileen McGraw, Michael, Kathleen, Michael and Maureen Carpenter, grandchildren Kate McGraw, Maggie and Richard Michael, and his sister, Ann Flood. Relative's and friends are invited to call today from 2-4 and 7-9pm at the O'Brien Funeral Home, 2028 Hwy 35 at New Bedford Rd., Wall, NJ, 07719 followed by a Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, October 21, 2009 at 12:30pm at St. Mark's RC Church, Sea Girt, NJ 08750. Committal will be private at the convenience of the family. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to either the Monmouth & Ocean Counties Food Bank, Rt. 66, Neptune, NJ 07753 or Fordham University, Bronx, NY. For further information or to send condolences to the family, please visit www.obrienfuneralhome.com.

Beyoncé, right, has postponed a concert in Malaysia after accusations by Islamic conservatives that the show would be immoral, The Associated Press reported. The Malaysian entertainment company that scheduled the show for Sunday said in a statement that the postponement was solely Beyoncé's decision and that it had ''nothing to do with other external reasons.'' Last month the company, Marctensia, tried to address concerns that Beyoncé might wear outfits considered inappropriate, saying, ''all parties have come to an amicable understanding'' about stage costumes. A new date for the show, at a stadium in Kuala Lumpur, was not announced. Beyoncé canceled her 2007 concert in that country after the Pan-Malaysian Islamic Party and other groups threatened protests over her provocative clothing and image.

For more than 30 years, Giants Stadium has been one of the top soccer destinations in the United States. When the American organizing committee for the 1994 World Cup submitted to FIFA its final list of stadiums across the country to be used for the tournament, a list that did not include Giants Stadium, the officials in Zurich said that a World Cup in the United States that bypassed the New York metropolitan area and Giants Stadium was unthinkable. A stop in East Rutherford, N.J., was quickly added.

He dropped out of the University of Texas at Austin in 1935 as a junior, because of what he called ''awful grades,'' to pursue a career in the news business, and what a career Walter Leland Cronkite Jr. had. But though he became a broadcasting legend, he never abandoned his Longhorn roots, as evident in his last will and testament now on file at Manhattan Surrogate's Court. The will bequeaths Mr. Cronkite's personal papers to the university, a process that started before his death on July 17 but will now end with the release of materials he had held onto at his office and homes in Manhattan and on Martha's Vineyard.

ADAMSHugh Trumbull. The Westover School community in Middlebury, CT, mourns the loss of Hugh Trumbull Adams. Inspired by the enthusiasm and commitment to Westover offered by his mother, Mary Trumbull Adams, Hugh continued her legacy of support for Westover, which was founded by his mother's great friend, Mary R. Hillard, 100 years ago in 1909. Generations of Westover girls have come of age surrounded by tangible examples of Hugh's wise guidance and thoughtful generosity in ways both large and small. In 1973 Hugh received a special award from Westover's Alumnae Association; Hugh's friendship with Westover is best captured in the Kahlil Gibran quotation that accompanied the award citation: "It is well to give when asked, it is better to give when unasked, through understanding." Louisa Jones Palmer '54, President of Westover's Board of Trustees; Ann S. Pollina, Westover's Head of School

TANENBAUM--Charles. The Council of the Grolier Club mourns the loss of its longtime member and former Councilor. A member since 1969, and an Honorary Member since 2002, Charles Tanenbaum was a Grolier Club Councilor from 1975 to 1984, and held the position of Secretary from 1978 to 1982. He served on the Library Committee, Committee on Members Exhibitions, and Committee on Public Exhibitions. During his tenure as Public Exhibitions chair (1978 to 1979), the Grolier Club mounted major exhibitions on printing in France, New York in literature, Noah Webster's dictionary, and Jean Grolier. A generous benefactor throughout his long association with the Grolier Club, among many other gifts, Charles Tanenbaum was responsible for establishing the Club's prestigious annual Robert L. Nikirk Lecture in Bibliography. We extend our deepest sympathy to Charles' widow, Szilvia Szmuk-Tanenbaum, and his daughter, Ann Tanenbaum. The world of books has lost a great collector and philanthropist. William H. Helfand, President, The Grolier Club

The Prescriptions column on Monday, by David M. Herszenhorn, analyzed the effort by some Congressional Democrats to adjust permanently a Medicare payment formula that for years has threatened to impose steep annual cuts in payments to doctors. The formula was originally devised to reduce Medicare's costs. The permanent adjustment is projected to cost Medicare $250 billion more over 10 years. But supporters of the solution say it should not count toward the cost of the broader effort to overhaul the health care system, which President Obama has promised would not add to the nation's deficits. Dozens of readers weighed in on the Prescriptions blog. Here are two of their comments:

ROSEN--Sandra, also known as Sally Fairchild of Manhattan, sadly passed away October 13th, 2009 in New York City. She was a distinguished painter and graduate of Brandeis University and Cooper Union. Her work has been exhibited since the 1970s at numerous art galleries; The Whitney Museum; The National Academy of Design; and in shows sponsored by The National Association of Women Artists. She has been listed in the Who's Who of American Women and has sold paintings since the 1960s to private collectors as well as institutions. Born to a French mother and raised in New Jersey, she was predeceased (1985) by her husband, Professor Edward Rosen, a prominent historian of science. She is survived by her loving only child, Carla Jeannette Rosen-Vacher. Donations in her memory may be sent to Defenders of Wildlife in Washington, D.C.

Things are becoming worse for the Washington Redskins, and it's only Week 7. On Monday, the team said that Sherman Lewis, a 22-year N.F.L. assistant who had been retired since 2004 before being hired as a consultant two weeks ago, would take over play-calling from Coach Jim Zorn. Two weeks ago, Lewis was calling bingo at a senior center -- literally. Now he is calling plays in the N.F.L. All this comes on the heels of the Redskins' latest debacle, a 14-6 loss to previously winless Kansas City.

314.5 Average passing yards per game for Ben Roethlisberger, above. On Sunday, his Pittsburgh Steelers (4-2) host the 6-0 Minnesota Vikings -- who rank 24th in the N.F.L. in pass defense (248.3 yards per game). Roethlisberger is the league leader in passing yardage with 1,887 and second in completion percentage (72.5). This will be his first game against Brett Favre, who is 17th in the league in average passing yards (224.5), 14th in the league in total yards (1,347) and third in completion percentage (69.7). The Vikings' defense is tied for first in the league in sacks (21) and the Steelers are third (17).

Some women love their shoes so much it hurts. That is the conclusion of a new study that looks at the link between shoes and foot pain. It was based on questioning of 3,378 men and women from Framingham, Mass., about their shoes. Their average age was 66.

One night during my training, long after all the other doctors had fled the hospital, I found a senior surgeon still on the wards working on a patient note. He was a surgeon with extraordinary skill, a doctor of few words whose folksy quips had become the stuff of department legend. ''I'm sorry you're still stuck here,'' I said, walking up to him. He looked up from the chart. ''I'm not working tomorrow, so I'm just fine.''

When MCC Theater needed an actor to cover two performances for a cast member in its production of “Still Life,” it did not have to look far to find one. Robert LuPone, who is a co-artistic director of MCC Theater, will substitute for Dominic Chianese in Saturday’s performances of that Alexander Dinelaris play, the theater company said in a news release. Mr. Chianese will be out of the show because of a previously scheduled engagement, the release said. Mr. LuPone, who shares the artistic direction of MCC Theater with Bernard Telsey, made his most recent Broadway appearances in the 2001 production of “A Thousand Clowns” and the 2000 revival of “True West”; he has also acted in television shows including “Law & Order: Criminal Intent” and “The Sopranos” (of which Mr. Chianese starred as Uncle Junior). The cast of “Still Life,” which is performed at the Lucille Lortel Theater, also features Sarah Paulson, Adriane Lenox and Frederick Weller.

Just as Rihanna announced the release of her first album since her former companion, Chris Brown, was sentenced to five years’ probation for assaulting her, Mr. Brown said that he, too, would soon be back in the public eye. Mr. Brown, the R&B singer, announced that he would commence a fan appreciation tour in November to thank his listeners for their support, Reuters reported. Mr. Brown, who has kept a low media profile since apologizing for attacking Rihanna during an argument in February, will begin the 19-city tour at the House of Blues in Houston on Nov. 14, and end it at the Nokia Theater in New York on Dec. 15. His label, Jive Records, said that a part of the proceeds from these concerts would be given to the Jenesse Center, a domestic violence shelter and counseling service in Los Angeles, and Best Buddies International, which helps people with developmental disabilities.

Last week, Michael Bublé got to rain on the painted faces of Kiss; this week, he can lord his supremacy over the pallid teenage vampires of the “Twilight” movies. In its second week on Billboard’s chart, Mr. Bublé’s album “Crazy Love” was No. 1 with more than 203,000 units sold, enough to outpace the debut of the soundtrack to the “Twilight” sequel “New Moon,” which was No. 2 with about 115,000 copies sold. (Chop Shop/Atlantic Records moved up the release of the “New Moon” soundtrack by four days citing “overwhelming and unprecedented demand”; it probably didn’t help that the album was also leaked to the Internet.)

It’s not easy to root out entertaining video clips in a week when most of the late-night shows are in reruns, but Tracy Morgan is doing his best to help us out. On Tuesday night, Mr. Morgan, the comedian and “30 Rock” star, was interviewed on CNN by Campbell Brown to promote his new book, “I Am the New Black.” The conversation finds Mr. Morgan in a mostly introspective mood, but of course he can’t go more than 30 seconds without letting slip the occasional was-that-or-wasn’t-that-a-joke: he notes that his book “may be around for 1,000 years” and declares that he’s still in his “zest-for-show-business” phase; and at the end of the conversation, he happily remarked, “I want to die like Vito Corleone, in the tomato patch, chasing my great-grandson around.”

Reszo Kasztner negotiated with the Nazis to save roughly 1,680 Jews during World War II. But those who killed him said that in doing so, he sold his soul to the devil.

In August 2008, Lehman Brothers issued a public apology for having plagiarized part of a 60-page report on semiconductor virtualization (whatever that is) from a series of similar reports by Toni Sacconaghi, the first-rate technology analyst at Sanford Bernstein. The Lehman report had been put together by a team of five Lehman analysts who covered the industry. At around the same time the apology was issued, one member of that team, Gordon Johnson, left the firm to go to work for a much smaller institution, Hapoalim Securities. When the Lehman letter came to my attention, I wrote a blog item about it, and, based on a source who was familiar with what had happened - but was not a part of the team that put together the Lehman Brothers report - I wrote that Mr. Johnson had been identified by the firm as the one who had committed the acts of plagiarism and had been fired.

High school counselors and admissions officers are always reaching for analogies to convey to students (and parents) the purpose of a college admissions essay. The Securities and Exchange Commission took its first steps on Wednesday to shed light on anonymous trading platforms known as "dark pools." The move, which Wall Street has vehemently opposed, threatens to erase much of the advantages that banks gain by operating and trading in dark pools as opposed to using the exchanges, where information on trades are available to the public.

On a recent trip to Los Angeles, I visited Robert Crowder & Company, a maker of wallpapers that was founded in the late 1940s by Robert Crowder, Bernard Gelbort and Lawrence Hooker on the popularity of the hand-painted, Asian-inspired murals and screens that Crowder, an artist, did for the city's film and social elite. (Gelbort, who has led a rather glamorous life, tells entertaining tales of the early days that feature style icons like the Duchess of Windsor and Barbara Hutton.) The company began producing silk-screened and hand-printed wallpapers and murals that it still makes today (although digital technology now speeds up part of the process) and also does a large custom business.

This Moonage Daydream Collar from the fledgling label Assad Mounser is fit for a futuristic (and fashionable) rock goddess. The line's designer, Amanda Assad Mounser, who previously worked for Moschino and Alejandro Ingelmo, based her spring collection on David Bowie's "Space Oddity." SPACs are in the news these days. These are special purpose acquisition companies formed solely to acquire other companies. SPACs constituted more than 20 percent of the initial public offering market in their heyday in 2007 when, according to SPAC Analytics, they raised more than $12 billion in 66 offerings. Remember, these almost all took place before August of that year, so it was quite a deluge.

Seeing that T is still in the grip of Anglomania (note the issue that came out this past Sunday), we were happy to learn that High Valley Books over in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has a new cache of vintage British Vogues. For fans of the current British Vogue, a savvy magazine that doesn't take itself too seriously, the earlier issues come as a shock. First, because typography and graphic design are light years from where they were 50 years ago. And second, because photography, despite the best efforts of Lord Snowdon and David Bailey, is now on another planet.

LONDON | A new station, Imperial Wharf, has opened in the west of London, improving access to the Chelsea Harbor area of the city, an affluent corner situated on the Thames, about three miles from the center. Until recently this peaceful area -- with its luxury flats, hotels and restaurants, a center devoted to interior design shops, and a yacht marina -- was ill-served for public transport. Although it is on a couple of bus routes, there was no train or underground station.

A truth of today's parenting is that saying "when I was your age" is often irrelevant. Kids do so many things at younger ages than their parents did (watch "inappropriate" movies, start worrying about college), except for the things they don't do until they are older (drink legally, stay home alone without parents hovering). Many of the choices we make as parents did not even exist when we were kids (computer okay in the bedroom? How many hours a day playing the Facebook game Farmville?)

This is the time of year that many students start thinking about whether or not, or where, to apply using Early Decision or Early Action. Early Decision is binding, meaning that if you get in, you are obligated to go to that school provided your financial need is met. Early Action is not binding, so there is no downside to applying Early Action as long as you do not feel rushed.

A couple of decades ago, it was common for American families to identify with the manufacturers of their cars. The automakers played up their rivalries on the racetrack, too, which helped secure loyalty. And a cottage industry of insulting rear-window stickers was born.

Today's idea: Forget Twitter and Facebook. That throwback television increasingly rules the world, an article says. "And let's hear it for the growing legions of couch potatoes: All those soap operas might be the ticket to a better future after all." World | Writing in Foreign Policy, Charles Kenny heralds "the rapid, planetwide proliferation of television sets and digital and satellite channels, to corners of the world where the Internet is yet unheard of." And, looking at the variety of social research done globally about TV's impact, he doesn't see its kudzu-like spread as necessarily a bad thing in many respects.

Stroll through the Impressionist galleries at almost any grand museum -- from the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York to the hallowed halls of Paris's Musée d'Orsay -- and discreetly placed among the Manets, Monets, and Renoirs you will find several lovely little flower still lifes by a painter you may never have heard of: Henri Fantin-Latour. Smaller in scale and typically more tautly composed and realistically painted than the neighboring Impressionist canvasses, Fantin-Latour's paintings provide a welcome oasis of calm and quiet composure amid all the bravura brushwork of his contemporaries.

With colder weather upon us, store windows are now adorned with boots, their studs and zippers forcing us to confront the harsh reality of winter. Tender hearts, have no fear. There is something romantic about Chloé's take on the aggressive over-the-knee boots for fall. The flat style in soft calf leather wraps up the leg, troubadour-style; if it's a heel you're after, the suede version has a cool 1970s feel. They're $1,095 and $1,346, respectively, at Chloé (850 Madison Avenue; 212 717-8220).

An article and a picture caption last Wednesday about “Encyclopedia of Pasta,” an Italian book just published in English, misidentified the cheese used in a pasta dish made by the book’s author, Oretta Zanini De Vita. As an accompanying recipe correctly noted, the dish, strozzapreti with roasted tomatoes, contains pecorino cheese, not Parmesan. The article also misstated a traditional Italian rule of thumb for serving pesto on pasta: it can be served on several types of pasta, not just short pasta.

An article last Wednesday about a blog and book called “Cake Wrecks,” which document embarrasing mistakes in cake decoration, misidentified the city where the book’s author, Jen Yates, held a reading. It was in Winter Park, Fla., not Orlando. The article also misidentified the hometown of Heidi Mattson, who attended the reading. She is from St. Cloud, Fla., not Winter Park.

Daniel Lieberman, PhD, a professor of human evolutionary biology at Harvard University, studies and periodically practices barefoot running. His academic work focuses in part on how early man survived by evolving the ability to lope for long distances after prey, well before the advent of Nike shoes. There "is good evidence that humans have been running long distances for millions of years," he says, "and most of that was probably done barefoot." For his own part, "I run a lot," he says, "and at least once a week, I run about three to five miles on the streets of Cambridge, completely barefoot. I can attest to the fact that it's a lot of fun."

Carnegie Hall paid $1.45 million during its 2007-8 season to an architectural firm run by the son-in-law of its board chairman, Sanford I. Weill, the former Citibank executive, according to the hall’s most recent publicly available tax return. The firm, Iu and Bibliowicz Architects, was hired to help carry out a major expansion of Carnegie’s space into two towers above the hall complex. When the firm’s role was disclosed in October 2007, Carnegie declined to reveal the firm’s fee. Carnegie’s spokeswoman, Synneve Carlino, said on Tuesday that the $1.45 million included payments to subcontractors. She did not immediately provide the total amount paid to the firm for the continuing project. Mr. Weill has said he played no role in the selection of the firm of his son-in-law, Natan Bibliowicz. Carnegie officials defended the choice, and said they knew from the start about the relationship. The tax return also confirmed the lucrative aspect of being a stagehand. Dennis O’Connell, listed as a stagehand on the return and properties manager on Carnegie’s Web site (carnegiehall.org), made $530,044 in salary and benefits, which was reported by Bloomberg News. That was second only to the executive and artistic director, Clive Gillinson, who earned $946,581. Four other stagehands earned more than $400,000.

Though it was promoted here, there and everywhere, a video game featuring the music and the likenesses of the Beatles posted only moderate sales in its first month of release. The Beatles: Rock Band, above, which was released by MTV Games and Electronic Arts, sold about 595,000 copies, according to a report from NPD Group, a market research company. The game was released for the Nintendo Wii, Microsoft Xbox 360 and Sony PlayStation3 consoles on Sept. 9, the same day that remastered versions of the Beatles albums were released on CD, and was frequently marketed with those albums. The Xbox 360 version (which sold 254,000 copies) was the No. 5 best-selling game for the month, and the Wii version (which sold 208,600 copies) was No. 10. But by comparison, the Xbox 360 shooter Halo 3: ODST, which was released on Sept. 22, has sold 1.52 million copies.

The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra said on Tuesday that it had appointed a Canadian conductor with a strong background in opera as its next music director. Jacques Lacombe, above, will take over in September with a contract to run for three seasons. Mr. Lacombe, 46, is not much known in the United States but has had a long association with the Montreal Symphony Orchestra, where he served as an assistant conductor under Charles Dutoit in the late 1990s and as principal guest conductor from 2002 to 2006. His other main post was a three-year stint as music director of the orchestra and opera at the Philharmonie de Lorraine in Metz, France. He was a last-minute substitute at the Metropolitan Opera in a production of Massenet’s “Werther” in 2004, a successful appearance that helped bring him to the attention of impresarios and orchestra managers.

It’s been an up-and-down year in the film business for Bob and Harvey Weinstein, but that hasn’t halted their plans in other media. On Monday the Weinstein Company said that it had entered into a partnership with Perseus Books Group, an independent publisher, which will release new and backlist books for the Weinstein Books imprint. In a news release, the companies said the first new books to be released included: “All Things at Once” by Mika Brzezinski, the MSNBC anchor and co-host of “Morning Joe,” and a memoir and beauty guide by Raquel Welch, both planned for January; and “The Overnight Socialite” by the novelist Bridie Clark (“Because She Can”), which is scheduled for December.

The Associated Press said on Tuesday that it had filed a motion to amend its counterclaim against the artist Shepard Fairey and that his explanation Friday about which photograph he had used to create a poster of Barack Obama was “simply not credible.” Mr. Fairey, who created the widely seen “Hope” poster of Mr. Obama from a photograph taken for The A.P., filed a pre-emptive lawsuit in February against that news organization, saying that his use of the photograph was covered by fair-use rules. The A.P. filed a countersuit in March, saying Mr. Fairey misappropriated its rights to that image. On Friday, Mr. Fairey admitted that he lied in court papers about using a different photograph of Mr. Obama than the one The A.P. has alleged, and that he created false documents to cover the discrepancy. In a statement, The A.P. said that Mr. Fairey “concocted” this latest explanation to “spin those bad acts in the best light possible to the court and the public.” In its filing the news organization said, “It is simply not credible that Fairey somehow forgot in January 2009 which source image he used to create the infringing works, which were completed only a year earlier in January 2008.”.

A Swiss court denied Roman Polanski’s appeal on Tuesday to be released from jail pending a ruling on his possible extradition to the United States, The Associated Press reported. The Swiss Federal Criminal Court said Mr. Polanski, 76, was a “high” flight risk and rejected his offers to be under house arrest or to post bail, even if his chalet in Gstaad were used as collateral. He has 10 days to appeal the decision. Mr. Polanski, who fled the United States in 1978 before he could be sentenced for having sex with a 13-year-old girl, was arrested on Sept. 26 as he arrived in Zurich for a film festival. More court proceedings are expected after the United States files a formal extradition request, which must be submitted by Nov. 25.

For bands traveling to CMJ Music Marathon from abroad, making it to the gig is often not a completely sure thing. On Tuesday representatives of the Very Best, an African-British hybrid whose showcase was one of the most highly anticipated, confirmed that the group would not play at CMJ because Esau Mwamwaya, the Malawian singer who performs in the Very Best with a British D.J. duo, “ran into unfortunate travel circumstances.” A statement from the band’s label, Green Owl, did not explain further, but said that Mr. Mwamwaya had a United States visa. Green Owl’s Wednesday showcase will continue as planned with the D.J. duo as well as Theophilus London and others, the statement said. The British rapper Speech Debelle, below, who won the Mercury Prize this year, also had visa problems. She canceled her American tour, which included a showcase at the Music Hall of Williamsburg and at least three other CMJ appearances. In a statement, her British representatives said that “visa laws have just recently changed and delayed a few of our artists from getting their visas this fall.” Other acts forced to cancel their CMJ appearances this year because of visas issues include the Swedish band First Aid Kit and the British singer VV Brown.

(49) GUSTAVO DUDAMEL AND THE LOS ANGELES PHILHARMONIC: THE INAUGURAL Mr. Dudamel, who exploded onto the scene in 1999 as the 18-year-old conductor of the Simon Bolívar Youth Orchestra of Venezuela, makes his official debut as the Philharmonic's 11th music director in Mahler's Symphony No. 1 and the premiere of John Adams's ''City Noir,'' above. ''Great Performances'' broadcasts the event, taped on Oct. 8 at the Walt Disney Concert Hall. ''For all of Mr. Dudamel's innate abilities to connect with audiences and inspire young people, he was hired to conduct a major American orchestra,'' Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times. ''The 10-minute ovation that erupted at the end of the Mahler made clear that supporters of the Los Angeles Philharmonic are thrilled with their new 28-year-old music director. But this was an exceptional and exciting concert by any standard.'' 10 A.M. (ABC) RACHAEL RAY A look at three body parts that make people look older; also, makeovers for carpooling mothers.

Seniority is valuable currency among United States senators. But once in a while, being a junior senator has its privileges. In the case of Senator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee, the perk is in not having been around to cast a vote for the 2003 Medicare prescription drug benefit. In a speech on the Senate floor on Tuesday morning, Mr. Corker sharply criticized Democrats and their plan to permanently adjust a Medicare doctor payment formula at a 10-year cost of nearly $250 billion that will simply be added to the federal deficit.

ERPELDINGLouise, 59, died October 15 after a brief illness. Beloved daughter of Marge Erpelding of Elmhurst, IL, sister of Linda Erpelding of Maineville, OH, and Gail Hartnett (deceased); caring aunt of John, Dan, and Katie; cherished by friends and colleagues and her dear Dakota. Louise shared a life devoted to the arts with her late husband, Harvey Gilman. As an esteemed Gestalt graphologist, she was known for her psychologically astute analyses, scholarship, and teaching. Her grace and generosity will be missed by all.

Assessing player popularity is a fraught exercise. Using jersey sales or All-Star votes or crowd ovations is flimsy and undemocratic. Not every fan can afford to attend a game or buy a pricey jersey, and not everyone looks good in a sleeveless Dwight Howard tank top. All-Star Games are, by definition, reserved for the best players, and thus exclude the pure crowd-pleasers like the Denver Nuggets' Chris Andersen or the Knicks' Nate Robinson.

Prosecutors asked a Paris court on Tuesday to convict former Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin of slander and give him a suspended 18-month sentence and a fine of about $67,000, in a deeply political trial in which President Nicolas Sarkozy is a complainant. Mr. de Villepin is accused of failing to stop a conspiracy in 2004 to defame Mr. Sarkozy and other politicians with falsified documents indicating that they were profiting from arms kickbacks. Mr. de Villepin says he is innocent.

The Senate Finance Committee has quietly recommended that the millions of elderly Americans who buy so-called Medigap insurance plans be charged new co-payments for doctors' visits starting in 2015. Consumer advocates predict that the changes, proposed in the committee's 1,500-page health care bill, will meet stiff opposition from lobbyists for the elderly as the final version of the legislation takes shape.

The Tennessee Titans' Vince Young threw two passes Sunday against New England. One was incomplete, the other was intercepted, leaving him with a 0.0 passer rating. Kerry Collins, the starter in the game, was 2 for 12 for minus-7 yards with one interception. His passer rating was 4.9. So minus-7 yards, according to the passer rating formula, is superior to zero yards because recording minus-7 yards requires the actual completion of a pass. After the Giants routed the Oakland Raiders on Oct. 11, Giants linebacker Antonio Pierce compared the game to a scrimmage. The Raiders used that as bulletin-board material for their upset victory against the Eagles. Maybe we'll see more players criticize opponents after games if it can have a negative effect on division rivals the next week. ANDY BENOIT

Astronomers have discovered a second planet outside Earth's solar system with some crucial chemical ingredients for life, according to NASA. Molecules of water, methane and carbon dioxide were detected on a hot gaseous planet that is about 150 light years from Earth, larger than Jupiter and inhospitable to life, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said. Mark Swain, a researcher with the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., and his colleagues made the discovery using data from the Hubble Space Telescope and the Spitzer Space Telescope. The planet, HD 209458b, orbits a sun-like star in the constellation Pegasus.

Tuesday was the N.F.L.'s annual trading deadline. Little was expected to occur, and little did. The blockbuster deals in baseball and the salary swaps of the N.B.A. have few counterparts at the N.F.L.'s deadline. Football teams are reluctant to shake up rosters once the season has begun; most teams still harbor postseason hopes after Week 6, when the deadline arrives each season. And the salary-cap ramifications of dealing or acquiring a player at that point make it hard for either side to consummate a trade.

Nancy Spero, an American artist and feminist whose tough, exquisite figurative art addressed the realities of political violence, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 83 and lived in Manhattan. The cause was respiratory complications of an infection, her son Philip said.

Kansas City kicker Ryan Succop, who was Mr. Irrelevant in the April draft as the last player chosen, was seemingly the only relevant player on the field Sunday in the Chiefs' 14-6 victory over Washington. Three rookies who played at Southern California -- all linebackers -- have fared better than Mark Sanchez recently. Green Bay's Clay Matthews had two sacks Sunday. All four were chosen among the first 38 picks of the draft. TONI MONKOVIC

The new multimillion-dollar Broadway “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark” is now expected to start previews and open this spring later than scheduled, because of weeks of production delays and ongoing difficulties recruiting additional investors for the show, according to executive involved in the production.

At the start of the year, Spike Jonze recalled in a telephone interview Thursday evening, he and the rapper Kanye West had a conversation about collaborating on a music video that would challenge them creatively and let them take a break from larger projects on their plates. By the end of that conversation they had planned something more ambitious: a short low-budget film that could be sold and distributed on the Web.

How often does one get to say that Eric Bogosian is making a theatrical debut? Though Mr. Bogosian, the hyperverbal actor and prolific playwright, has appeared on stage and had his work produced on Broadway (his play “Talk Radio” ran at the Longacre Theater in 2007), he has not performed on Broadway himself — yet. But now Mr. Bogosian has been added to the cast of Manhattan Theater Club‘s production of “Time Stands Still,” the Donald Margulies play, which is heading to the Samuel J. Friedman Theater next year. In a news release, publicists for the production said that Mr. Bogosian, who currently appears on television’s “Law & Order: Criminal Intent,” will appear in the play as the editor of a photojournalist played by Laura Linney. The previously announced cast also includes Brian d’Arcy James, and Alicia Silverstone. “Time Stands Still” is to begin previews on Jan. 5 and open on Jan. 28.

The Grammy-winning rap artist Lil Wayne pleaded guilty on Thursday to second-degree attempted weapon possession, a felony, and is to be sentenced to a year in prison under a plea agreement with prosecutors, the Manhattan district attorney’s office announced.

Update | 1:50 p.m. Opera purists may be pleased to learn that the renovation of New York City Opera’s home at Lincoln Center, the David H. Koch Theater, has eliminated the amplification system for live voices installed in 1999. New York City Ballet shares the house — formerly known as the New York State Theater — with the opera, and the stage had originally been designed to muffle footfalls. The acoustical system was revamped twice before amplification was added. City Opera opens its season Nov. 5 in the renovated theater, where the changes include new acoustic side walls installed near the stage and new seats that have been tested for sound absorption.

Updated | 2:58 p.m. Artists don’t always want to brag about things they did at the Chelsea Hotel, but Leonard Cohen will soon receive a distinction there that’s worth boasting about. On Friday, the hotel will unveil a plaque in recognition of Mr. Cohen, the singer-songwriter and poet, who resided there and wrote his song “Chelsea Hotel No. 2″ in memory of it (and a liaison with Janis Joplin). The honor puts Mr. Cohen in the company of other notable former hotel denizens, including Thomas Wolfe, Arthur Miller and Dylan Thomas, who have also received plaques in its entranceway. Mr. Cohen’s plaque, which is dated Sept. 21, 2009, to honor his 75th birthday, is scheduled to be unveiled at 2:30 p.m.
As the world waits for someone to write “Obama: The Musical,” the Public Theater will tide audiences over with a return of a rock musical about the nation’s seventh president, Andrew Jackson.

Seeing a dozen bands a day can make you appreciate one of the basics: dynamics, those subtle or not-so-subtle gradations of volume that let music breathe. Some bands have them, and some — in the era of drum machines, computer-in-the-bedroom recording and easy studio tweaking — just don’t, making songs sound mechanical or unfinished. But my Wednesday CMJ peregrinations were full of bands getting all worked up, dropping back down and revving up again.

The announcement was made Thursday by the producer Darren Bagert in a news release.

If you watched any five minutes of CBS programming over the last week, you probably saw the promo for Thursday’s “Survivor: Samoa” (8 p.m.): Russell Swan collapsing, hitting his head on some sort of tropical rat’s maze and requiring medical attention. (He’s the other Russell, not the weird, megalomaniacal Russell H.) If Jeff Probst says it’s his scariest moment in 19 seasons of “Survivor,” then you know it’s serious. Or at least it’s really good television.

Pearl Jam, R.E.M. and Trent Reznor are among the musicians who have joined a campaign to close the prison at the American naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, as they seek to learn whether their music was used during the questioning of detainees there, The Associated Press reported. The National Security Archive in Washington said it was filing a Freedom of Information Act request on behalf of a coalition called the National Campaign to Close Guantánamo, including an effort to gain more details about how loud music was used as an interrogation device. Based on public documents and interviews with former detainees, the archive said, Guantánamo prisoners were played loud music, including songs by AC/DC, Britney Spears and Marilyn Manson, as well as advertising jingles and “Sesame Street” tunes, in their cells and in preparation for interrogations. Thomas Blanton, the executive director of the archive, told The A.P., “At Guantánamo, the U.S. government turned a jukebox into an instrument of torture.” A spokeswoman for Joint Task Force Guantánamo, which handles the care and custody of detainees, said loud music had not been used with prisoners since the fall of 2003.

Days before Roman Polanski was arrested in Switzerland, American prosecutors were monitoring him in Austria and considered having him apprehended there. In an e-mail exchange that appears in documents obtained by The Associated Press, prosecutors in Los Angeles discussed the possibility of seeking the arrest of Mr. Polanski, 76, in Vienna in mid-September when he traveled there for the opening of a musical based on his film “Dance of the Vampires.”

More than 70 years after her disappearance, Amelia Earhart has once again eluded her pursuers, as a museum item believed to be a lock of her hair has turned out to be a piece of thread. This year, Agence France-Presse reported, the International Women’s Air and Space Museum in Cleveland put the sample on display, describing it as a strand of Earhart’s hair that had been recovered by a White House maid after the aviatrix, who was a friend of Eleanor Roosevelt’s, stayed there before her final flight. But DNA analysis revealed that it did not match other possessions of Earhart’s that were found on the Pacific island of Nikumororo. Earhart went missing over the Pacific Ocean in 1937 during an attempted solo flight around the world. The thread still remains on display at the museum as part of an Earhart exhibition that runs through Nov. 15. “We’ve changed the sign and explained everything,” Heather Alexander, the museum’s manager, told Agence France-Presse, adding that visitors “show more interest and are very grateful that we are telling the truth and the whole story.”

Sunnyside and Woodside are the twins of Queens. Each has wide avenues, leafy streets and a mix of private homes, small apartment buildings and the occasional towering co-op. They are sunny and woody and ethnically rich - just check out the Romanian, Thai, Irish, Filipino and Mexican bars and restaurants. Where the neighborhoods meet, near 50th Street on the No. 7 line, is a good place to get the feel. Exit the train at the 46th Street/Bliss Street station, named for a street that goes by two names - one utilitarian, the other charming - and head into one of the prettiest spots in Queens.

Bob Herbert: David, the president is deciding what we should be doing with regard to troop deployments in Afghanistan. It seems to me that however one feels about this war and the war in Iraq, the environment here on the home front is bizarre. This is as weird a wartime atmosphere as I can imagine. For most Americans, there is nothing in the way of shared wartime sacrifices. There is no draft. We have not raised taxes to pay for the wars. Except for the families of those in the military, most Americans are paying very little attention to these conflicts. I've brought this matter up a few times on college campuses and the response has been, in essence, a collective shrug.

Democrats have made a tacit agreement to pay off the doctors' lobby, a politically crucial ally in the fight for a health care overhaul, by undoing projected cuts to their Medicare payments. But the cost is $250 billion over ten years and now lawmakers in both parties are balking. They say Congress is already straining against the burden of soaring deficits to find more federal money to help the homebuyers and the unemployed. To talk Afghan President Hamid Karzai into a runoff to election, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton deputized a former rival with his own experience losing elections. A nice note arrived by e-carrier pigeon this morning concerning the space in which Marea, the restaurant I reviewed this week, now swims. Before the room was Marea, of course, it housed San Domenico, Tony May's epic Italian restaurant, which went into the building in 1988. (Here's Bryan Miller's review from that year.) This morning's correspondent reminds us, however, that in New York there is often history before the history, that what we think of as the past generally has a past all its own.

Alternate side of the street parking, which was introduced by the city in 1952 to facilitate street cleaning, is one of the more burdensome rituals of New York City life. And the city's diversity -- and its accompanying smorgasbord of religious and cultural holidays -- has made it more complicated, as politicians cater to various constituencies. At last count, there were more than 40 holidays each year on which the rules are suspended, plus any number of snow days that are declared so the Sanitation Department can clear the streets.

If you ask me, the best part of a fashion show is its ending. That moment after the models have exited, when the designer emerges and you think, "Wait a second, that guy looks like he just rolled out of bed!" With a few dandy exceptions (John Galliano, Karl Lagerfeld), this past season male fashion designers were remarkably consistent in their schlubbiness. Maybe for them it's about looking like an artist, or not competing with their collections. Or maybe chic dressing is just too easy? Regardless, I sort of love it. It gives every Dockers dude out there high-fashion cred he never knew he had. And just think, this Halloween I can wear an old undershirt beneath a billowy Oxford, throw on some baggy jeans and - poof - I'm Alexander McQueen!

The European Union's competition commission is busy reviewing Oracle's acquisition of Sun Microsystems and has said it may not rule until Jan. 19, 2010. Sun is not doing well in the meantime, and this week it announced it would lay off up to 3,000 workers. Sun's stock price is also rapidly imploding in light of the failure of progress in the Oracle acquisition and from Sun's own difficulties.
Early snow fall, colder temperatures and perhaps a sprinkle of P.R. have led ski resorts in North America, Europe and elsewhere to open early.

Cantonese, a dialect from southern China that has dominated the Chinatowns of North America for decades, is being rapidly swept aside by Mandarin, the national language of China and the lingua franca of most of the latest Chinese immigrants.
For the 25 highest paid executives at the seven companies that received particularly generous bailout sums, this morning is proof that bigger isn't always better.
Thinking of putting a wind turbine in your backyard? Mariah Power is introducing a program that will let you measure the wind speed around your house by pointing your iPhone toward the sky.

The Korea National Oil Corporation, the state-owned oil and gas company of South Korea, said it would buy Harvest Energy Trust in a deal worth 4.1 billion Canadian dollars, ($3.9 billion). The transaction represents a coup for South Korea as it seeks a steady supply of oil from overseas.
PlainsCapital has priced the 15 million shares of common stock it plans to offer in an initial public offering, The Associated Press reported.

Anglo American, the mining group that appointed a new chairman in August amid a takeover approach, announced a revamping that would shed a quarter of overhead staff, divest it of some businesses and save $120 million a year, Reuters reported.

The landmark 19th-century church that once housed the Limelight club -- a troubled Chelsea night spot that garnered a drug-suffused reputation before it was shut down and its owner was ordered deported for tax fraud -- is being turned into a retail complex where credit-card systems, high-speed Internet access and unlimited phone service will be made available to small-business owners.

PAI Partners, the private equity firm, has offered to allow investors to slash their commitments to its 5.4 billion-euro ($8.1 billion) buyout fund by as much as 50 percent, Bloomberg News reported, citing people familiar with the matter. British developer Bill Davies has purchased Chicago's old post office for $20.8 million, The Chicago Tribune reported. The amount is about half what Mr. Davies agreed to pay at an auction in late August.

HONG KONG | Hong Kong is mad about wine. According to the city's trade board, Hong Kongers drink more vino per capita than anyone in Asia -- 3.3 liters (111 oz.) per year per person. Earlier this month, a Sotheby's auction of rare vintages here fetched a whopping $7.9 million, just weeks after the American wine merchants Acker Merrall & Condit sold $6.4 million worth of vino in the city. But what about oenophiles (and gourmands) without such deep pockets? Hong Kong has something for us too: the three-day Hong Kong Wine & Dine Festival, which begins on Oct. 30 on the West Kowloon Waterfront Promenade.

A hedge fund manager and arbitrageur, John Meriwether, is setting up his third fund, The Financial Times reported. The man behind Long-Term Capital Management is making the move just three months after he chose to close his second fund manager, JWM Partners.

National Express, the British bus and rail operator, said it was mulling a merger proposal from its rival, Stagecoach, and planning an equity fund-raising by year-end, but reported a slower third quarter.

Job prospects for executives at multinationals in Greater China and Singapore have improved sharply in the past three months amid growing optimism that Asia's recovery from the global recession will be sustainable, a quarterly survey showed on Thursday.

Macerich, the real estate investment trust, has said it will sell as many as 13.8 million new shares, The Wall Street Journal reported. The owner of 72 U.S. malls, Macerich said it would use the cash to pay down part of its $1.5 billion credit line.

An article last Thursday about the renovation of a former water-pumping station in Berlin and its conversion into a home and art studio misidentified the location of Neukölln, the building’s neighborhood. Neukölln is on the west side of the former border of West and East Berlin, not the east side.
Equinix has agreed to acquire Switch & Data Facilities in a $689 million deal that will bring together two of the world's largest operators of data centers.

Hedge fund assets increased by about $34 billion in September, Bloomberg News reported, citing findings by Eurekahedge.com. The fifth straight monthly uptick was aided by improved investor confidence and global stock market gains.

Twitter gets 55 million monthly visitors, it has raised $155 million in venture capital, and it has generated intense interest from Hollywood to Iran. But it hasn't earned much revenue and certainly no profit, Miguel Helft and Claire Cain Miller write in The New York Times.
Arcadia, the fashion group owned by billionaire Philip Green, on Thursday posted a 13 percent increase in full-year profit along with solid current trading and said it had significantly cut its debt.
For the 14th consecutive season, Joe Torre led a team to the playoffs. But for the ninth straight year, he failed to win the World Series.

The Marlboro Man may not look so tough anymore, but investors shouldn't write him off. Altria, which makes Marlboros, announced on Wednesday that it had shipped sharply fewer cigarettes in the third quarter than a year earlier. The looming health care reform, meanwhile, could further restrain smokers and manufacturers, Breakingviews.com writes.

Whoa: Cintra Wilson likes Ann Taylor, of all places. The refurbished Ann Taylor— with a designer, Lisa Axelson, hired from Club Monaco — earns comparisons to Prada, Lanvin and Balenciaga. “It’s the kind of visual shoplifting I approve of: most of the items remind you of a similar luxury model, but you’re not sure which one,” Ms. Wilson writes of moderately priced jackets, pencil skirts and strapless dresses. “This is a positive change that doesn’t undercut the intelligence, style or wallet of the consumer. It feels generous and respectful. They’ve found smarter ways to produce better products for less.” Eat your heart out, JC Penny.

A music review on Wednesday about the Brooklyn Big Band Bonanza, at the Bell House, misidentified the group of musicians who “sprang an ambush, manically braying and honking their way through the crowd” after an encore by the Secret Society. It was Stefan Zeniuk’s Baritone Army, not some of the players from the Industrial Jazz Group.

WASHINGTON -- Remember when drug makers, hospitals, doctors and medical device manufacturers stood by President Obama and pledged to cut $2 trillion in health costs over the next decade? A nonpartisan coalition of business, labor and religious groups has a message for Congress: write that promise into law.

Joseph Rodriguez, 58, is what you might call an old-school cat, a straight talker who is a bit rough around the edges. As a photojournalist, his past is his starting point and his palette.

An article in some editions on Wednesday about a rash of umpiring errors in baseball’s playoffs itself contained an error. Tuesday night’s game in the American League Championship Series, when umpires missed three calls, was Game 4 of that series, not Game 3.
Two Dallas men serving life sentences in prison in a 1997 murder case are expected to be released after another man confessed to the crime, the Dallas County District Attorney’s Office said.

An article on Wednesday about the formation of a State Senate investigative committee to determine whether Senator Hiram Monserrate, who was convicted of a misdemeanor for assaulting his companion, should lose his seat misidentified, in some copies, the senator who called Mr. Monserrate’s detractors racially biased. He is Rúben Díaz Sr. of the Bronx, not Rúben Díaz Jr. (The younger Mr. Díaz is Bronx borough president.).

Robert Groves, director of the Census Bureau, told a House panel that poor planning had resulted in added costs and overruns in preparations for the 2010 canvassing operation.

An article on Wednesday about a warning from federal health officials that doctors should promptly prescribe antiviral drugs for patients with suspected flu, without waiting for the results of flu tests, misspelled the surname of the director of immunization and respiratory diseases at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. She is Dr. Anne Schuchat, not Shuchat. (Her surname was also misspelled in an article on May 28 about public fears over swine flu.).

Last week Michael Bublé, below, rained on the painted faces of Kiss; this week he can lord his supremacy over the pallid teenage vampires of the “Twilight” movies. In its second week on Billboard’s chart, Mr. Bublé’s album “Crazy Love” was No. 1 with more than 203,000 units sold, enough to outpace the debut of the soundtrack to the “Twilight” sequel “New Moon,” which was No. 2, with about 115,000 copies sold. (Chop Shop/Atlantic Records moved up the release of the “New Moon” soundtrack by four days, citing “overwhelming and unprecedented demand”; it probably didn’t help that the album was also leaked to the Internet.) Down the chart, Jay-Z’s “Blueprint 3” was No. 3, with almost 55,000 sales, followed by Barbra Streisand’s “Love Is the Answer,” with about 49,000 sales. “Embryonic,” a new album by the Flaming Lips, made its debut at No. 8, with about 31,700 sales, followed closely behind by the new Mario album “D.N.A.,” which sold about 31,500 copies. In the October showdown of holiday-theme albums, Bob Dylan’s “Christmas in the Heart” was No. 23, with about 20,350 sales, defeating David Archuleta’s similarly titled “Christmas From the Heart,” which was No. 30, with about 16,700 sales.

Just as Rihanna announced the release of her first album since her former companion, Chris Brown, was sentenced to five years’ probation for assaulting her, Mr. Brown, the R&B singer, said he, too, would soon be back in the public eye. Mr. Brown, right, announced that he would start a fan appreciation tour in November to thank his listeners for their support, Reuters reported. Mr. Brown, who has kept a low profile since apologizing for attacking Rihanna during an argument in February, will begin the 19-city tour at the House of Blues in Houston on Nov. 14 and end it at the Nokia Theater in New York on Dec. 15. His label, Jive Records, said part of the proceeds would go to Jenesse Center, a domestic-violence shelter and counseling service in Los Angeles, and Best Buddies International, which helps people with developmental disabilities.

The Oscars are in the hands of a former studio mogul and a song-and-dance maven. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Tuesday that its 82nd Academy Awards telecast would be produced by Bill Mechanic, the former chairman of 20th Century Fox, and Adam Shankman, the director of “Hairspray” and a judge on the program “So You Think You Can Dance.” A host will be selected in the coming months. Mr. Mechanic, who now runs Pandemonium Films (“Coraline”), was at Fox during the robust years of “Titanic,” “Die Hard With a Vengeance” and “Independence Day.” He also worked in top positions at Disney and Paramount. Aside from “Hairspray,” Mr. Shankman’s directorial credits include “The Wedding Planner”; he was a producer of the recent Zac Efron comedy “17 Again.” The Oscars will be presented on March 7 on ABC.

Run-DMC helped bring hip-hop to the mainstream, revitalized the career of Aerosmith, and now it could be headed to Broadway. Paula Wagner, the veteran Hollywood producer, said her Chestnut Ridge Productions company was working with the rappers Joseph Simmons (known as Run), above left, Darryl McDaniels (DMC), above center, and the estate of Jason Mizell (Jam Master Jay), above right, to produce a stage musical about Run-DMC, the seminal hip-hop group founded in Hollis, Queens, in the early 1980s. “Their work speaks to everybody,” Ms. Wagner said in a telephone interview, “and the story of their rise to fame is innately theatrical.” Run-DMC became one of the first rap acts to reach a mass audience, selling millions of albums as well as a ubiquitous 1986 remake of the Aerosmith song “Walk This Way.” The band was on the verge of a reunion in 2002 when Mr. Mizell was shot and killed in his recording studio in Jamaica, Queens. Ms. Wagner, whose films include the “Mission: Impossible” movies and “War of the Worlds,” said that in addition to the original Run-DMC music that would be featured in the show, songs might be provided by Mr. Simmons and Mr. McDaniels or by an outside composer.

YOUTH HOCKEY'S 'FAST TRACK' Mark Messier spoke about the ''philosophical challenges'' facing parents and children in youth hockey as he accepted the Lester Patrick Award alongside his former Rangers teammate Mike Richter and Red Wings senior vice president Jim Devellano at a Manhattan ceremony. ''I think we may be professionalizing our players too early,'' Messier said of his experience coaching children at youth tournaments and the high costs of playing the sport. ''There's too much money, too many private lessons, too many games and too much travel to weekend tournaments. Sport should be about the physical, mental and spiritual well being of kids.''

President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono on Wednesday began to unveil his new cabinet, a mix of well-respected professionals and political allies who analysts said would do little to increase the pace of change here. After Mr. Yudhoyono, a liberal former general, won re-election in a landslide victory in July, there was an expectation that he would fill his cabinet with technocrats who could tackle Indonesia's persistent problems, including graft, crumbling infrastructure and an unreliable judicial system. Instead, the president appears to have reserved only the economic posts for technocrats, while doling out others to members of the political parties that supported his re-election bid. For example, although Mr. Yudhoyono has emphasized the need for changes in the country's fractured justice system, he picked Patrialis Akbar, a career politician without reformist credentials, to run the important Ministry of Law and Human Rights.

SEGAL--Sheldon, Ph.D. The trustees, scientists, and staff of the Marine Biological Laboratory (MBL) in Woods Hole, MA, mourn the loss of Sheldon Segal, chairman of the MBL Board of Trustees from 1991-2002, trustee since 1982, and a longtime MBL scientist and supporter. Dr. Segal conducted groundbreaking research on gamete fertilization in his MBL lab and mentored countless young scientists from around the globe. As board chairman, he helped the MBL transform its governance structure and successfully conduct its first capital campaign. We join many in remembering Dr. Segal's scientific acumen, warm friendship, and wise leadership. On behalf of the MBL community, we extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. John W. Rowe, M.D., Chairman, Board of Trustees Gary G. Borisy, Ph.D., Director and CEO

Derek Jeter clutched a bottle of NyQuil as he left Angel Stadium on Tuesday. His voice was raspy and hoarse. He looked and sounded as if he needed a rest, and the Yankees are getting one Wednesday, when their American League Championship Series with the Los Angeles Angels takes a one-day break. Jeter's spirits were sound, at least, because of the way his team has played. The Yankees lead the series, three games to one, and a victory in Game 5 on Thursday will clinch their 40th pennant and the seventh of Jeter's career. The World Series is tantalizingly close.

RUNNING is a delightfully simple sport compared with other gear-laden activities. Still, it's a treat when something comes along to add a little fun and function to a runner's wardrobe: Enter arm warmers. Also called arm sleeves, these accessories are exactly what they sound like -- stretchy sleeves that keep an athlete's arms warm. They are migrating from the cycling world and have grown in popularity as they are seen on the arms of professional runners, who typically wear them along with sleeveless shirts. Arm warmers can be worn at a chilly starting line, then tucked away when a runner warms up.

Americans are evenly divided on President Obama's plan to overhaul the health care system, according to the latest CNN/Opinion Research Corporation poll. But the latest USA Today/Gallup poll suggests that many people are reserving final judgment on the legislation in Congress until all the details have been ironed out. In the CNN poll, 49 percent favor Mr. Obama's plan to overhaul health care and 49 percent oppose it. But when asked whom they trust more to handle the changes, half of those surveyed named Mr. Obama, while a third said the Republicans in Congress.

8 P.M. (TCM) TCM SPOTLIGHT: LIFE DURING THE DEPRESSION Turner Classic Movies continues its Thursdays-in-October series of films pegged to financial ruin -- both those to which audiences once flocked to escape harsh realities and more current Hollywood interpretations of the way things were. Tonight's installment begins with the ''42nd Street'' follow-up, ''Gold Diggers of 1933,'' above. Joan Blondell, Aline MacMahon and Ruby Keeler star as chorus girls -- displayed to advantage in numbers choreographed by Busby Berkeley -- who fight to keep their show going and find rich husbands in the process. In Woody Allen's ''Purple Rose of Cairo'' (1985), at 10, Mia Farrow plays an abused waitress in 1930s New Jersey who forgets her troubles at the local cinema, with Jeff Daniels as the movie character who steps off the screen and into her life. In ''Annie'' (1982), at 11:30, Aileen Quinn sings and struts as the 1930s orphan who attracts the attention of a Wall Street tycoon (Albert Finney) and escapes a conniving orphanage boss (Carol Burnett). The evening ends with ''Gabriel Over the White House'' (1933), at 2 a.m., starring Walter Huston as a crooked president who is mysteriously reformed after a car accident. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAYPresident Obama is a guest. Also, financial tips for women, and family Halloween costumes.

Q.Can I play Internet radio through Windows Media Player instead of through the Web browser? A. Recent versions of Windows Media Player let you listen to live streaming radio in a few different ways. You can add a stream you find yourself on a radio station's Web site or select one from the collection offered in the Media Guide menu in Windows Media Player. Some sites that collect radio streams from around the world also give you an option to listen to the audio feed through media software like Windows Media Player, iTunes and WinAMP.

Depending on whom you speak to, Kate Murray is either a hard-headed obstructionist willing to drive the Islanders from Long Island, a principled public servant protecting taxpayers or a Republican veteran holding out for a political ransom. Murray has been tagged with these and other less flattering labels because as supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, she and the Town Board have the power to block, delay or approve the zoning for the Lighthouse Project, a $3.8 billion plan to refurbish Nassau Coliseum, the Islanders' shabby home, and build thousands of homes, offices and stores nearby.
