Roman Polanski may change his mind and return to the United States after 31 years as a fugitive to face sentencing on charges of having sex with a 13-year-old girl after a Swiss court rejected his latest appeal to be released from jail, according to one of his French lawyers. For the first time the lawyer, Georges Kiejman, suggested the idea of a possible return in interviews with European news outlets on Wednesday, during which he also said Mr. Polanski, 76, was suffering from health problems. ''If this process drags on, it is not completely impossible that Roman Polanski could choose to go finally to explain himself in the United States, where arguments in his favor exist,'' he said in a morning interview with the French radio station Europe 1.

An article last Thursday about the renovation of a former water-pumping station in Berlin and its conversion into a home and art studio misidentified the location of Neukölln, the building's neighborhood. Neukölln is on the west side of the former border of West and East Berlin, not the east side.

Not all of Michael Jackson‘s fans are eagerly awaiting the release of the documentary “This Is It”: a contingent of the King of Pop’s admirers have started a group that plans to protest the film’s release, saying it sugarcoats the circumstances that led to Mr. Jackson’s death, Reuters reported. The documentary, which Sony Pictures is releasing on Wednesday, was compiled from footage shot during the rehearsals for the “This Is It” concerts that Mr. Jackson never got to perform in London. He died on June 25 from an overdose of several drugs, including propofol, an anesthetic he had been taking as a sleeping aid.

Ryan Trecartin, a 28-year-old painter, sculptor and video filmmaker from Philadelphia, was named the first winner of the Wolgin International Competition in the Fine Arts on Thursday night, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported. The distinction, which is endowed by the real-estate investor Jack Wolgin and awarded by the Tyler School of Art at Temple University, comes with a prize of $150,000. Mr. Trecartin’s work has been shown at the 2006 Whitney Biennial and the Guggenheim Museum, as well as the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles and the Saatchi Gallery in London. The Inquirer reported that the competition did not accept unsolicited applicants; instead, an advisory board chose about a dozen nominators from the international art world who recommended about 20 candidates. The other finalists were Sanford Biggers, an artist from New York, and Michael Rakowitz, from Chicago and New York.

The doctor is (back) in: Paul Weston, the psychoanalyst so tormented by his patients that they have driven him to therapy, will return for a third season of the HBO series “In Treatment,” as will Gabriel Byrne, the actor who portrays him, the cable channel said on Friday. Adapted from an Israeli television series, “In Treatment” usually airs five nights a week, with each episode focusing on Dr. Weston’s sessions with a different patient or patients; Friday episodes depict his own therapy with an analyst played by Dianne Wiest. HBO did not immediately announce which other cast members might return to the show, but it said production on the third season would begin early next year.

On the ground, the 29th annual CMJ Music Marathon might seem to be all shoestring budgets and gas-money revenue. But even in these dark days of the record business, it is still about potential: the possibility of starting a viral buzz, making critical industry connections and striking deals for bookings, foreign distribution rights or commercial sync rights, in addition to record contracts. Undoubtedly one of the bands you will see on a magazine cover in a year or so will have come through CMJ this week as a little-known, as so many others have done, from R.E.M. to MGMT.

Two sets, two musical guises, same slouch cap: That was Alec Ounsworth’s Thursday at CMJ. A songwriter with a yammery high voice who led Clap Your Hands Say Yeah to blog renown and indie-rock sales success without a record label, Ounsworth has re-emerged with two new albums simultaneously: “Mo Beauty” (Anti-), which he recorded in New Orleans with local musicians, and, under the name Flashy Python, a self-released album called “Skin and Bones.” The afternoon set at Pianos was barely promotional, although it did include “Obscene Queen Bee,” a song that’s on both albums. Ounsworth played alone with an acoustic guitar, picking quietly reverbed arpeggios and singing a handful of his own songs along with the Blue Nile’s “Let’s Go Out Tonight,” the traditional “Moonshiner” and Chris Knox’s nicely barbed “A Song to Welcome the Onset of Maturity.” The songs were meditative, and they ran together; a series of reflections on being a perpetual stranger.

For now at least, Steven A. Cohen, the hedge-fund billionaire and collector, seems to be content with buying art at auctions without buying the auction house, too. Earlier this year, Mr. Cohen’s fund, SAC Capital Advisors, disclosed in a filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had recently accumulated a roughly 6 percent stake in Sotheby’s. Around the same time, Mr. Cohen and his wife, Alexandra, loaned 20 artworks from their collection, which is estimated to be worth $750 million, for an exhibition at Sotheby’s. The two developments led some financial journalists and bloggers to speculate about whether Mr. Cohen might enjoy the perks of owning an auction house, and might be interested in taking Sotheby’s private. Christie’s, its main competitor, is a private company owned by another major collector, the French billionaire François Pinault.

Multi-instrumentalism is nearly de rigueur in indie rock now, but the Suckers, from Brooklyn, take it a step farther: their members play multiple instruments at the same time.
